Authors: X., Guo, Xuexia; Z., Yao, Zhangnan; X., Long, Xianhu; L., Zeng, Lu; C., Wang, Chenghua; Z., Fang, Zhong; T., Zhong, Tao; S., Tian, Shuanghong; D., Shu, Dong; C., He, Chun
Title: Recent advances in tailored nanostructured ozonation catalysts for enhanced VOCs removal: synergistic optimization of scale configuration and electronic microenvironment
Affiliations: Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Ltd., Shenzhen, China; South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Guo, Xuexia, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Yao, Zhangnan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Long, Xianhu, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Zeng, Lu, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Wang, Chenghua, Ltd., Shenzhen, China; Fang, Zhong, Ltd., Shenzhen, China; Zhong, Tao, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Tian, Shuanghong, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Shu, Dong, School of Chemistry, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; He, Chun, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), as a significant component of atmospheric pollution, present critical environmental risks and public health hazards. Catalytic ozonation has been widely concerned due to its high efficiency and environmental compatibility compared with traditional approaches. While previous reviews have been summarized the catalytic ozonation technology based on the types of VOCs, there is a lack of systematic synthesis of advancements in catalyst design, especially the tailoring strategy of nanostructures, aiming at the scientific problems of active center competition, slow electron transfer rate, low ozone utilization and low mass transfer efficiency. This work systematically investigates the research progress on various metal-based catalysts (noble metals and transition metal oxides) and catalyst configurations (mixed-metals and single-atom catalysts) at the nanoscale. The purpose of this review is to propose precise enhancement strategies tailored to different scenarios, leveraging synergistic optimization of nanoscale configuration and electronic microenvironment based on catalytic ozonation mechanisms involving oxidation pathways and active sites. In addition, the problem of catalyst deactivation of various types of VOCs are examined. This review comprehensively summarizes the current research progress, proposes practical enhancement strategies to address technical bottlenecks, which provides new insights and directions for the future development of catalytic ozonation technology. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Catalytic Ozonation; Electronic Microenvironment; Metal-based Catalyst; Nanoscale Configuration; Vocs

Authors: C., Zhang, Chenxiao; F., Gao, Fengyu; N., Luo, Ning; J., Shi, Jingtong; H., Yi, Honghong; X., Tang, Xiaolong
Author full names: Zhang, Chenxiao (59323131000); Gao, Fengyu (55820303400); Luo, Ning (57832847300); Shi, Jingtong (59959915300); Yi, Honghong (59664186700); Tang, Xiaolong (15078647800)
Title: Recent advances of chlorobenzene catalytic oxidation: influencing factors, roles of active sites and optimization
Affiliations: University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Chenxiao, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China; Gao, Fengyu, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China; Luo, Ning, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China; Shi, Jingtong, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China; Yi, Honghong, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China; Tang, Xiaolong, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China
Abstract: Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) such as chlorobenzene (CB) pose a threat to the environment and human health due to their low reactivity, high toxicity and mobility, as well as the potential to develop into secondary and high-risk pollutants. Catalytic oxidation, as a promising gas-phase chlorobenzene degradation method, is still limited by the poor low-temperature activity, low stability, and low selectivity of catalysts, as well as the generation of harmful by-products. In this paper, the performance of various catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene, such as noble metals, molecular sieves, transition metal oxides, etc., is compared and summarized, and the roles of various active sites (such as Brønsted acid, Lewis acid and oxygen vacancies) are analyzed in the thermocatalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene, and the difficulties and challenges of the catalysts are also pointed out, which mainly include the chlorine poisoning of catalysts, generation of chlorine-containing by-products, and complex water effects. Finally, a variety of catalyst optimization methods including morphology modification, facet engineering, doping, loading and after-treatment modification are summarized to provide directions and references for future catalyst design and optimizations. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Recent advances in catalytic removal volatile organic compounds: Structure activity correlation, mechanism and application insights
Affiliations: Qingdao Agricultural University, Qingdao, China; Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, China; Chinese Research Academy of Environmental Sciences, Beijing, China

Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), pervasive environmental pollutants from diverse sources, present substantial threats to human health and ecological balance. Amidst escalating air pollution incidents, the efficient treatment of VOCs has increasingly gained prominence. This review focuses on elucidating the removal mechanisms of VOCs via thermal catalytic oxidation, exploring the diverse types and distinctive characteristics of catalytic materials, and optimizing synthesis strategies for these catalysts. Additionally, the modification measures for other factors in the exhaust gas are discussed. Finally, it highlights challenges in designing catalysts for multiple VOCs treatment and anticipates future trends and obstacles in the field of VOCs catalytic oxidation technology. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Ma, Mudi; S., Xu, Shuai; R.J., Wong, Roong Jien; C., Chen, Changwei; Y., Chen, Yutao; Q., Liu, Qiyuan; C., He, Chi
Title: Boosted activity and water resistance towards catalytic ethyl acetate degradation over hierarchical MnOx/meso-KZSM-5: K-incursion enriched active oxygen and Mn4 + species
Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Flow in Power Engineering, Xi'an, China; Chang'an University, Xi'an, China; Institute of Sustainability for Chemicals, Energy and Environment, Singapore City, Singapore; Xi'an University of Science and Technology, Xi'an, China; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Ma, Mudi, School of Energy and Power Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Flow in Power Engineering, Xi'an, China; Xu, Shuai, School of Water and Environment, Chang'an University, Xi'an, China; Wong, Roong Jien, Institute of Sustainability for Chemicals, Energy and Environment, Singapore City, Singapore; Chen, Changwei, Department of Environmental Engineering, Xi'an University of Science and Technology, Xi'an, China; Chen, Yutao, School of Energy and Power Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Flow in Power Engineering, Xi'an, China; Liu, Qiyuan, School of Energy and Power Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Flow in Power Engineering, Xi'an, China; He, Chi, School of Energy and Power Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Flow in Power Engineering, Xi'an, China, National Engineering Laboratory for VOCs Pollution Control Material & Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Abstract: Developing efficient and economical catalysts with superior mineralization rate and water resistance for industrial volatile organic compounds (VOCs) low-temperature deep degradation is of great significance. Herein, hierarchical MnO<inf>x</inf>/meso-KZSM-5 catalyst was engineered via a wetness impregnation approach, achieving 100 % CO<inf>2</inf> yield at 260 °C in ethyl acetate (EA) oxidation, over 100 °C lower than that of Mn/HZSM-5. Adsorbed oxygen species (O<inf>ads</inf>) and Mn4+ respectively play vital roles in EA conversion to intermediates with long chain and deep degradation of intermediate with short chain. The presence of K reduces sites for H<inf>2</inf>O adsorption and maintains the Mn4+ sites, thereby enhancing the water resistance and CO<inf>2</inf> yield simultaneously. Besides, the K species serves as an additional site for O<inf>2</inf> adsorption to compensate for the reduction in O<inf>ads</inf> species due to the decrease in oxygen vacancies. Remarkably, the outstanding performance of monolithic Mn/meso-KZSM-5/cordierite in EA oxidation further extends the practical feasibility of above strategy. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., Ye, Dong; J., Feng, Jingyi; S., Gao, Shujie; X., Wang, Xiaoxiang; K., Zhu, Kai; K., Wu, Ke; R., Guo, Ruitang
Title: Insights into the catalytic oxidation of toluene over CoOx-based catalysts: A review
Source title: Journal of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry
Affiliations: China Jiliang University, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Shanghai University of Electric Power, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Ye, Dong, College of Energy Environment and Safety Engineering, China Jiliang University, Hangzhou, China; Feng, Jingyi, College of Energy Environment and Safety Engineering, China Jiliang University, Hangzhou, China; Gao, Shujie, College of Energy Environment and Safety Engineering, China Jiliang University, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Xiaoxiang, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Zhu, Kai, College of Energy Environment and Safety Engineering, China Jiliang University, Hangzhou, China; Wu, Ke, Key Laboratory of Offshore Geotechnics and Material of Zhejiang Province, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Guo, Ruitang, School of Energy and Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai University of Electric Power, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are significant contributors to air pollution, presenting substantial risks to both environmental health and human well-being. Toluene, a prevalent VOC, is commonly employed as a model compound in laboratory studies due to its widespread occurrence across various industrial sectors. Catalytic oxidation has emerged as a highly effective method for removing toluene from exhaust gases. Among various catalytic materials, cobalt oxides (CoO<inf>x</inf>) have garnered increasing attention for their potential as active species and additives in toluene degradation, owing to their ease of synthesis and cost-effectiveness. This review summarizes recent developments in the catalytic oxidation of toluene using CoO<inf>x</inf>-based catalysts. Key properties, such as catalytic activity, CO<inf>2</inf> selectivity, and the adaptability to flue gas components, are identified as crucial factors for assessing catalyst performance in practical applications. Approaches to enhance these properties are discussed, alongside a comprehensive analysis of the reaction mechanisms, providing valuable insights from a microscopic perspective. In conclusion, the review underscores the importance of developing novel catalysts that can stably and efficiently eliminate toluene from exhaust gases. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Hu, Chao; Z., Hu, Zihao; Y., Zhang, Yinggui; P., Wang, Pengyu; E., Gao, Erhao; J., Li, Jing; W., Wang, Wei; J., Zhu, Jiali; S., Yao, Shuiliang; Z., Wu, Zuliang
Title: Elucidating the water-promoted plasma-catalytic oxidation of medium-chain alkane VOCs (n-pentane) on a palladium catalyst using operando DRIFTS
Affiliations: Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Key Laboratory of Advanced Plasma Catalysis Engineering for China Petrochemical Industry, Changzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Hu, Chao, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Hu, Zihao, School of Environmental and Safety Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Zhang, Yinggui, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Wang, Pengyu, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Gao, Erhao, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China, Key Laboratory of Advanced Plasma Catalysis Engineering for China Petrochemical Industry, Changzhou, China; Li, Jing, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China, Key Laboratory of Advanced Plasma Catalysis Engineering for China Petrochemical Industry, Changzhou, China; Wang, Wei, School of Environmental and Safety Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China, Key Laboratory of Advanced Plasma Catalysis Engineering for China Petrochemical Industry, Changzhou, China; Zhu, Jiali, School of Environmental and Safety Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China, Key Laboratory of Advanced Plasma Catalysis Engineering for China Petrochemical Industry, Changzhou, China; Yao, Shuiliang, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China, School of Environmental and Safety Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China, Key Laboratory of Advanced Plasma Catalysis Engineering for China Petrochemical Industry, Changzhou, China; Wu, Zuliang, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China, Key Laboratory of Advanced Plasma Catalysis Engineering for China Petrochemical Industry, Changzhou, China
Abstract: The catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as n-pentane (C5) remains a critical challenge due to their environmental and health hazards. This study investigates the water-promoted plasma-catalytic oxidation of C5 using noble metal-loaded 1.5Mn-CeO<inf>2</inf> catalysts. This approach combines non-thermal plasma with advanced catalyst design to achieve efficient oxidation at near-room temperature (30 °C). Among the tested noble metals (Au, Ag, Pt, and Pd), 0.4 wt% Pd/1.5Mn-CeO<inf>2</inf> exhibited exceptional performance, with C5 conversion increasing by 15 % and CO<inf>x</inf> selectivity improving significantly with the addition of 1 % H<inf>2</inf>O. In contrast, 0.7 wt% Au/1.5Mn-CeO<inf>2</inf> showed superior activity under dry conditions but suffered performance loss with H<inf>2</inf>O addition. Operando DRIFTS and kinetic analyses revealed that water vapor enhanced Pd-catalyzed oxidation by generating hydroxyl radicals (•OH), promoting the complete oxidation of C5, while inhibiting Au-based catalyst via bidentate carbonate formation. The synergistic plasma-catalytic effect enabled near-complete C5 oxidation at 30 °C with high CO<inf>x</inf> selectivity (>90 %), significantly lowering the energy barrier compared to thermal catalysis alone. Structural characterization (XRD, XPS, and EPR) confirmed that Mn doping and Pd loading optimized oxygen vacancy concentration and redox properties, with Pd/1.5Mn-CeO<inf>2</inf> demonstrating robust water tolerance due to its high proportion of chemically adsorbed water. This work provides mechanistic insights into humidity-dependent plasma catalysis and offers a sustainable strategy for low-temperature VOC abatement in industrial applications. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Yang, Hanbiao; L.L., Sun, Lu Lu; X., Tan, Xiuqin; Y., Zeng, Yuan; Y., Huang, Yuqi; Z., Huang, Zhenshan; S., Chen, Shejun; Z., Wei, Zaishan
Title: Synergistic microaerobic bio-decontamination of dimethyl sulfide and elemental mercury in the low-O2 content flue gas by a sulfur-oxidizing membrane biofilm reactor
Affiliations: South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; State Key Joint Laboratory of Environmental Simulation and Pollution Control, Beijing, China; Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Yang, Hanbiao, School of Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; Sun, Lu Lu, School of Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; Tan, Xiuqin, State Key Joint Laboratory of Environmental Simulation and Pollution Control, Beijing, China; Zeng, Yuan, School of Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; Huang, Yuqi, School of Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; Huang, Zhenshan, School of Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; Chen, Shejun, School of Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; Wei, Zaishan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: Synergistic decontamination of multi-pollutants in combustion flue gas is of importance. This study achieved and elucidated simultaneous bioremoval of dimethyl sulfide (DMS) and elemental mercury (Hg0) in simulated low-O<inf>2</inf> content flue gas by a sulfur-oxidizing membrane biofilm reactor. Optimal removal efficiencies of DMS and Hg0 attained 92 % and 94 %, respectively, at 2 % O<inf>2</inf> content in a 140-day operation. A variety of facultative anaerobes: Thiobacillus, Pseudomonas, Bacillus, Alcaligenes, and Hyphomicrobium synergized DMS reductive degradation, partial sulfur oxidation, and Hg0 bio-oxidation. Overall, DMS and Hg0 acted as the initial donors and their oxidation products further co-stabilized, O<inf>2</inf> acted as the terminal acceptor, and thereby to collaboratively establish a bio-redox. Specifically, at 2–4 % O<inf>2</inf>, DMS can be oxygenated to H<inf>2</inf>S and then partially oxidized to S0; sulfur reducing bacteria can also anaerobically oxidize DMS to H<inf>2</inf>S and prevent its further oxidation. At 11 % O<inf>2</inf>, DMS was excessively oxidized to SO<inf>4</inf>2−. Hg0 was effectively bio-oxidized to Hg2+ at 2, 4, and 11 % O<inf>2</inf>. However, Hg0 was primarily bio-stabilized into HgS with biogenic S2− and S0 at 2–4 % O<inf>2</inf> via Hg2+-S2− precipitation, Hg0-S0 chemosorption, and catalase-mediated in situ Hg0-S0 bio-redox. HCHO derived from DMS oxygenation can be metabolized into CO<inf>2</inf> via O<inf>2</inf> respiration. Microaerobic synergistic bioconversion of DMS and Hg0 into S0 and HgS can provide a greener and integrated strategy for flue gas desulfurization and demercuration. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Mahmood, Asad
Author full names: Mahmood, Asad (56382010300)
Title: Photocatalyst deactivation in gaseous VOCs photooxidation: Mechanisms, stability enhancement, and regeneration strategies
Affiliations: Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Mahmood, Asad, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Air pollution from volatile organic compounds (VOCs) has raised interest in photocatalytic oxidation for air cleaning. However, photocatalysts often lose activity under real conditions. Unlike laboratory settings, real air contains many organic compounds. These can cause competitive adsorption, form reactive byproducts, and poison the surface. As a result, photocatalytic performance drops over time. This review explains the main reasons for deactivation in gas-phase systems. These include the buildup of carbon residues, formation of byproducts with nitrogen or sulfur, coke deposits, and damage to the material's structure. We also discuss how surface defects, crystal structure, and particle shape affect both activity and durability. Different methods to restore activity are reviewed. These include heating, chemical cleaning, and light-based recovery. We also highlight recent advances in material design. Examples include single-site catalysts and porous structures such as metal organic frameworks. These materials can improve selectivity and resist deactivation. Machine learning is also gaining attention. It can help predict stability and guide the design of better photocatalysts. Although deactivation is widely studied, few reports focus on gas-phase systems with a clear mechanistic view. This review fills that gap. It combines experiments with analysis to support the design of stable and reusable photocatalysts for clean air. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J., Hao, Jiayan; X., Nie, Xiangqi; Z., Fan, Zhiying; Z., Zeng, Zheng; C., Yang, Cuixia; H., Li, Haibo
Title: Performance of Formaldehyde Removal Catalyzed by Al Honeycomb Loaded MnOx/CeO2 Coupled with Plasma
Affiliations: College of Resources and Civil Engineering, Shenyang, China; Ltd., Foshan, China
Authors with affiliations: Hao, Jiayan, College of Resources and Civil Engineering, Shenyang, China; Nie, Xiangqi, College of Resources and Civil Engineering, Shenyang, China; Fan, Zhiying, Ltd., Foshan, China; Zeng, Zheng, Ltd., Foshan, China; Yang, Cuixia, Ltd., Foshan, China; Li, Haibo, College of Resources and Civil Engineering, Shenyang, China
Abstract: Formaldehyde, a major indoor pollutant, poses severe health risks. This study developed an aluminum honeycomb-structured 10-MnO<inf>x</inf>/CeO<inf>2</inf> catalyst integrated with nonthermal plasma (NTP) technology to overcome limitations of powdered catalysts. Experimental results demonstrate that the monolithic catalyst reduces formaldehyde concentration from 1.30 mg/m3 to <0.08 mg/m3 within 40 min at room temperature, achieving 93.8% removal efficiency. After eight drops and continuous 14 days of testing, it maintains >90% efficiency with robust adhesion, stability, and reusability. This work provides an efficient and eco-friendly solution for indoor air purification, offering significant engineering and scientific value for developing robust air-cleaning catalysts. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Aluminum Honeycomb; Formaldehyde; Mnox/ceo2; Nonthermal Plasma

Authors: A., Fatima, Areej; F., Zazimal, František; T., Homola, Tomáš
Author full names: Fatima, Areej (60006561500); Zazimal, František (57223666857); Homola, Tomáš (25825099600)
Title: A review of plasma modification strategies of nanomaterials for wastewater treatment
Affiliations: Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic; Slovak University of Technology in Bratislava, Bratislava, Slovakia
Authors with affiliations: Fatima, Areej, Department of Plasma Physics and Technology, Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic; Zazimal, František, Department of Plasma Physics and Technology, Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic; Homola, Tomáš, Department of Plasma Physics and Technology, Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic, Department of Environmental Engineering, Slovak University of Technology in Bratislava, Bratislava, Slovakia
Abstract: The discharge of wastewater into aquatic environments has emerged as a major environmental concern in recent decades. The capture and degradation of pollutants in wastewater using nanomaterials (NMs) has emerged as a cost-effective and highly efficient strategy through adsorption, membrane filtration, and advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), including heterogeneous photocatalysis. This review examines NMs features that influence their optoelectronic properties and resulting performance in the AOPs that can be employed in wastewater treatment. This work particularly highlights the modification of NMs by low-temperature and atmospheric pressure plasmas e.g., dielectric barrier discharge, plasma jet, corona and gliding arc discharge. These plasma modification strategies are favored over conventional chemical methods due to their minimal waste generation, production of non-toxic byproducts, preservation of bulk material properties, solvent-free (dry) operation, rapid, energy-efficient processing, and scalability to large areas. Emphasis is placed on defect engineering, the generation of oxygen vacancies, and surface functionalization of NMs by plasma. These key factors can shift the band gap of NMs, improve charge carrier separation, boost reactive oxygen species formation, provide additional pathways for charge transfer, enhance visible light response, and increase surface area. Collectively, these effects alter the performance of NMs in pollutant degradation. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cold Plasma; Nanomaterials (nms); Photocatalysis; Plasma Modifications; Wastewater Treatment

Authors: C., Hu, Changjuan; Y., Tian, Yongying; S., Zhou, Shihao; S., Chen, Shan; Y., Guo, Youmin; H., Yin, Huajie
Title: Advances in Room-Temperature Catalytic Ozone Decomposition: Mechanisms, Catalysts, and Future Challenges
Affiliations: Anhui University, Hefei, China; Institute of Solid State Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei, China; University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China
Authors with affiliations: Hu, Changjuan, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Anhui University, Hefei, China, Key Laboratory of Materials Physics, Institute of Solid State Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei, China; Tian, Yongying, Key Laboratory of Materials Physics, Institute of Solid State Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei, China, Science Island Branch of Graduate School, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Zhou, Shihao, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Anhui University, Hefei, China, Key Laboratory of Materials Physics, Institute of Solid State Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei, China; Chen, Shan, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Anhui University, Hefei, China; Guo, Youmin, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Anhui University, Hefei, China; Yin, Huajie, Key Laboratory of Materials Physics, Institute of Solid State Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei, China, Science Island Branch of Graduate School, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China
Abstract: Ozone (O<inf>3</inf>) is a powerful oxidant and a significant atmospheric pollutant that poses serious risks to human health and the environment. Various technologies such as activated carbon filtration, solution adsorption, and catalytic decomposition have been employed to mitigate ozone pollution. Among these, room-temperature catalytic ozone decomposition has gained attention due to its high efficiency, low energy requirements, and the absence of harmful by-products. This review comprehensively summarizes the recent progress in ozone decomposition catalysts, categorizing and evaluating their properties and mechanisms of action. The discussion also includes the catalytic degradation and deactivation mechanisms, with proposed synergistic processes for the simultaneous removal of ozone and volatile organic compounds, and the mechanism for catalytic ozonation for wastewater treatment. Additionally, primary pathways for catalyst deactivation are identified along with protocols for catalyst reactivation. Finally, this review addresses the challenges of catalytic ozone decomposition and offers recommendations for future catalyst designs to improve performance and durability. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Qin, Caihong; X., Zhang, Xiaoge; P., Zhang, Peng; R., Liu, Rongrong; T., Wang, Tong
Title: Efficient degradation of dichloromethane by nonthermal plasma combined with UV-activated wet scrubber
Affiliations: Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi'an, China; Shaanxi Environmental Investigation and Assessment Center, Xi'an, China
Authors with affiliations: Qin, Caihong, School of Environment and Municipal Engineering, Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi'an, China; Zhang, Xiaoge, School of Environment and Municipal Engineering, Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi'an, China; Zhang, Peng, School of Environment and Municipal Engineering, Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi'an, China; Liu, Rongrong, School of Environment and Municipal Engineering, Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology, Xi'an, China; Wang, Tong, Shaanxi Environmental Investigation and Assessment Center, Xi'an, China
Abstract: Non-thermal plasma (NTP) technology has emerged as a promising approach for the control of chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) due to its high degradation efficiency and operational simplicity. However, practical application is constrained by secondary ozone (O₃) emissions and incomplete degradation of CVOCs to CO<inf>2</inf> and HCl. To address these limitations, a liquid-phase UV system was integrated downstream of the NTP reactor to convert O₃ into reactive oxygen species (ROS), thereby enhancing DCM mineralization. The results showed that the degradation efficiency (DE) and mineralization rate (MR) of DCM in the NTP+UV(L) system reached 83.5 % and 73.9 %, respectively, which were markedly elevated compared to those of the NTP system (DE: 17.3 %, MR: 20.9 %) and the UV(L) system (DE: 28.7 %, MR: 36.1 %). The synergistic effect in this combined system was attributed to the activation of O<inf>3</inf> into hydroxyl radicals (·OH) and superoxide ions (·O<inf>2</inf>-) by UV light in the solution for the deep oxidation of DCM. The chlorine in DCM was converted into chloride ions (Cl-) and trapped in the solution. Finally, the reaction pathways of DCM within the NTP+UV(L) system were inferred by detecting organic intermediates in both the gas and liquid phases. This novel combined NTP+UV(L) system represents a potential method for DCM degradation. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Challenges in the production of livestock manure-derived biochar (LMB) for sustainable carbon neutrality: Evaluation of hazardous volatile organic compound (VOC) emission characteristics
Affiliations: Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea; Rural Development Administration, Jeonju, South Korea; Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea; Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Choi, Ye Bin, Department of Environment and Energy, Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea, Department of Animal Environment, Rural Development Administration, Jeonju, South Korea, Department of Environmental Engineering, Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea; Kim, Yong Hyun, Department of Environment and Energy, Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea, Department of Environmental Engineering, Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea, Department of Environmental Engineering and Soil Environment Research Center, Jeonbuk National University, Jeonju, South Korea
Abstract: Livestock manure-derived biochar presents an environmentally sustainable approach for managing livestock waste and achieving carbon neutrality through carbon sequestration. However, incomplete pyrolysis during biochar production may result in the retention of hazardous organic compounds, which can be emitted into the atmosphere during field application. In this study, biochar was produced at both lab- and pilot-scales under varying conditions, including manure type (cow and chicken), pyrolysis temperature (400°C and 700°C), and residence time (5–12 min). Emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOC) were evaluated across a temperature range of 35–280°C. Lab-scale results revealed that pyrolysis temperature had a more significant influence on VOC emissions than residence time. For example, total VOC concentrations measured at 50°C were 73.4 μg g–1 for biochar produced at 400°C, compared to 4.96 μg g–1 at 700°C. In a modeled field scenario, where 1 metric ton of pilot-scale biochar is mixed into soil (density 1.5 g cm–3; application rate 5 wt%), predicted ambient total VOC concentrations at 2 m height ranged from 8740 to 52,513 μg m–3. These levels far exceed the WHO's indoor air quality target of 250 μg m–3, indicating substantial risk. Therefore, pyrolysis at or above 700°C and strict thermal management are essential for safe biochar production. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J., Wilson, Jamie; X., Ke, Xinyuan; D., Maskell, Dan; R.J., Ball, Richard J.
Author full names: Wilson, Jamie (59911723900); Ke, Xinyuan (56019213200); Maskell, Dan (55218360800); Ball, Richard J. (58025330200)
Title: Evaluation of photocatalytic ZnO-geopolymer composites: degradation of methylene blue and α-pinene
Affiliations: University of Bath, Department of Architecture & Civil Engineering, Bath, United Kingdom; University of Bath, Faculty of Engineering & Design, Bath, United Kingdom; University of Bath, Faculty of Engineering & Design, Bath, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, Jamie, University of Bath, Department of Architecture & Civil Engineering, Bath, United Kingdom, Centre for Integrated Materials, University of Bath, Faculty of Engineering & Design, Bath, United Kingdom; Ke, Xinyuan, University of Bath, Department of Architecture & Civil Engineering, Bath, United Kingdom, University of Bath, Faculty of Engineering & Design, Bath, United Kingdom; Maskell, Dan, University of Bath, Department of Architecture & Civil Engineering, Bath, United Kingdom, University of Bath, Faculty of Engineering & Design, Bath, United Kingdom; Ball, Richard J., University of Bath, Department of Architecture & Civil Engineering, Bath, United Kingdom, Centre for Integrated Materials, University of Bath, Faculty of Engineering & Design, Bath, United Kingdom
Abstract: Alkali-activated ZnO–geopolymer composites were synthesised using metakaolin to investigate their photocatalytic degradation efficiency toward methylene blue and α-pinene under 253.7 nm irradiation. Composites prepared with bulk Si/Al molar ratios (1 and 2), ZnO/Al loadings (0.10, 0.15, and 0.20), were characterised using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), N<inf>2</inf>-sorption, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and UV–vis spectroscopy. A custom-built flow cell was used for gas-phase α-pinene degradation, while aqueous methylene blue degradation was evaluated under batch conditions. A key finding of the study was that increasing ZnO content led to matrix densification, reduced surface area, and blue shifting of the adsorption band. Structural studies revealed that ZnO was integrated into the geopolymer framework through bonding with aluminium within the composite. The highest 160 mg/L methylene blue removal (91.05 %) was achieved by a geopolymer with Si/Al ratio of 2 and attributed to naturally occurring TiO<inf>2</inf> phases in the metakaolin coupled with a high surface area. These samples exhibited superior continuous α-pinene degradation, with a maximum removal of 26.93 %, which was attributed to reduced Al–OH surface groups and lower hydrophilicity, favouring VOC adsorption. Significantly, this research identifies the critical parameters of incorporating ZnO into a geopolymer framework, suggesting that both the concentration of ZnO added, and the microstructural modification induced by ZnO play important roles in determining photocatalytic activity. This study revealed how ZnO influences the physicochemical characteristics of geopolymers, and the remediation mechanism of pollutants from aqueous and gaseous environments. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: X., Zeng, Xinran; C., Li, Chunhui; Z., Li, Zhenhai; Z., Tao, Zhizheng; M., Li, Mingtong
Title: Review of research advances in microbial sterilization technologies and applications in the built environment
Affiliations: Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Southwest Jiaotong University, Chengdu, China; Jilin Institute of Chemical Technology, Jilin, China
Authors with affiliations: Zeng, Xinran, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Li, Chunhui, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Li, Zhenhai, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Tao, Zhizheng, Southwest Jiaotong University, Chengdu, China; Li, Mingtong, College of Biology and Food Engineering, Jilin Institute of Chemical Technology, Jilin, China
Abstract: As globalization accelerates, microbial contamination in the built environment poses a major public health challenge. Especially since Corona Virus Disease 2019 (COVID-19), microbial sterilization technology has become a crucial research area for indoor air pollution control in order to create a hygienic and safe built environment. Based on this, the study reviews sterilization technologies in the built environment, focusing on the principles, efficiency and applicability, revealing advantages and limitations, and summarizing current research advances. Despite the efficacy of single sterilization technologies in specific environments, the corresponding side effects still exist. Thus, this review highlights the efficiency of hybrid sterilization technologies, providing an in-depth understanding of the practical application in the built environment. Also, it presents an outlook on the future direction of sterilization technology, including the development of new methods that are more efficient, energy-saving, and targeted to better address microbial contamination in the complex and changing built environment. Overall, this study provides a clear guide for selecting technologies to handle microbial contamination in different building environments in the future, as well as a scientific basis for developing more effective air quality control strategies. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Sun, Yulin; Y., Zhang, Yiwei; Y., He, Yong; W., Weng, Wubin; Y., Zhu, Yanqun; Z., Wang, Zhihua
Title: Enhanced Catalytic Ozonation of Formaldehyde over MOFs- Derived MnOx Catalysts with Diverse Morphologies: The Role of Oxygen Vacancies
Affiliations: National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Yulin, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; Zhang, Yiwei, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; He, Yong, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Weng, Wubin, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Zhu, Yanqun, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Zhihua, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have become a hot topic in various research fields nowadays. And MOF-derived metal oxides prepared by the sacrificial template method have been widely applied as catalysts for pollutant removal. Accordingly, we prepared a series of MOF-derived MnO<inf>x</inf> catalysts with diverse morphologies (rod-like, flower-like, slab-like) via the pyrolysis of MOF precursors, and the as-prepared MnO<inf>x</inf> catalysts demonstrated superior performance compared to the one prepared using the co-precipitation method. MnO<inf>x</inf>-II, with a flower-like structure, exhibited excellent activity for formaldehyde (HCHO) catalytic ozonation at room temperature, reaching complete HCHO conversion at O<inf>3</inf>/HCHO of 1.5 and more than 90% CO<inf>2</inf> selectivity at an O<inf>3</inf>/HCHO ratio of 2.5. On the basis of various characterization methods, it was clarified that the enhanced catalytic performance of MnO<inf>x</inf>-II benefited from its larger BET surface area, abundant oxygen vacancies, better redox ability at lower temperature, and more Lewis acid sites. The H<inf>2</inf>O resistance and stability tests were also conducted. Furthermore, DFT calculations substantiated the enhanced adsorption of HCHO and O<inf>3</inf> on oxygen vacancies, while in–situ DRIFTS measurements elucidated the degradation pathway of HCHO during catalytic ozonation through detected intermediates. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Yu, Lian; Y., Duan, Yajing; D., Wang, Dabin; Z., Liang, Zhen; C., Liang, Cunzhen; Y., Wang, Yafei
Title: Recent advances in TiO2 modification for improvement in photocatalytic purification of indoor VOCs
Affiliations: Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Beijing, China; Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Beijing, China; Southwest University, Chongqing, China
Authors with affiliations: Yu, Lian, Department of Environmental Engineering, Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Beijing, China; Duan, Yajing, Department of Environmental Engineering, Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Beijing, China; Wang, Dabin, State Agriculture Ministry Laboratory of Quality & Safety Risk Assessment for Tobacco, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Beijing, China; Liang, Zhen, College of Fisheries, Southwest University, Chongqing, China; Liang, Cunzhen, Department of Environmental Engineering, Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Beijing, China; Wang, Yafei, Department of Environmental Engineering, Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Beijing, China
Abstract: TiO<inf>2</inf>-based photocatalytic oxidation technology has been widely used for the purification of indoor VOCs. However, the fast recombination rates of photoexcited charge carriers and wide energy band gaps have limited the practical application of TiO<inf>2</inf>-based photocatalysts. Therefore, developing highly efficient catalysts is crucial for efficiently separating charge carriers and hindering their recombination, fully utilizing visible light. There are four main methods to improve TiO<inf>2</inf> photocatalytic activity: increasing e−-h+ separation rates and decreasing e−-h+ recombination rates, increasing visible light photocatalytic activity, increasing surface-active sites, and increasing physicochemical stability. Metal and non-metal doping, coupling of different semiconductors, surface and interface design, and TiO<inf>2</inf> immobilization are usually used to enhance the photocatalytic activity of TiO<inf>2</inf>. This review aims to improve photocatalytic purification efficiency for indoor VOCs, and may provide new insights and guidance for the design of novel photocatalysts based on the intrinsic characteristics of VOCs, such as high volatility, low molecular weight, low polarity, high hydrophobicity, strong chemical activity and high toxicity. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: X., Zhang, Xiao; D., Chen, Da; C., Liang, Cai; B., Shen, Boxiong
Title: Water poisoning and resistance in catalytic oxidation of VOCs from industrial flue gas
Affiliations: Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Xiao, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Chen, Da, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Liang, Cai, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Shen, Boxiong, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted from industrial flue gas, as precursors to particulate matter and photochemical smog, pose direct hazards to atmospheric environment and adversely affect the health of communities. Catalytic oxidation is a cost-effective and feasible method for VOCs purification from industry flue gas, however, encounter catalyst poisoning caused by water vapor under realistic working environments. Understanding the influence of water vapor on VOCs catalytic oxidation activity and the water-involved mechanisms on metal oxide catalyst surfaces is crucial in solving water poisoning in catalytic reactions. This review concludes that various working conditions of industrial flue gas significantly influence the impact of water vapor on VOCs oxidation, in terms of efficiency, stability, and selectivity. Water-involved VOCs catalytic oxidation mechanisms, including: competitive adsorption, generation of hydroxyl, alter reaction path and cleaning effect, alongside the specific methods employed to study these processes are analyzed. This review also covers the developments in water-resistant catalysts, focusing on strategies such as optimizing catalyst supports, active components, morphologies, and preparation methods. This review aims to advance industrial flue gas purification by providing better understanding of mechanisms of VOCs oxidation in wet flue gas. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Ismail, Ahmed; M., Zahid, Muhammad; B., Ahmad, Bilal; F., Raziq, Fazal; S.U.H., Bakhtiar, Syed Ul Hasnain; S., Ali, Sher; A., Khan, Adnan; N., Ali, Nauman; X., Wu, Xiaoqiang; S., Ali, Sharafat
Author full names: Ismail, Ahmed (57204471878); Zahid, Muhammad (57220487537); Ahmad, Bilal (59025713400); Raziq, Fazal (56623205400); Bakhtiar, Syed Ul Hasnain (57193795777); Ali, Sher (59811491700); Khan, Adnan (55831775300); Ali, Nauman (24385328000); Wu, Xiaoqiang (59411525400); Ali, Sharafat (59440388900)
Title: Catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds: A review of recent advances in supported and non-supported catalysts
Affiliations: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China; Heilongjiang University, Harbin, China; Chengdu University, Chengdu, China; Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; University of Peshawar, Peshawar, Pakistan; Chengdu University, Chengdu, China; Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China; The University of Newcastle, Australia, Callaghan, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Ismail, Ahmed, School of Physics, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China; Zahid, Muhammad, School of Physics, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China; Ahmad, Bilal, Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, China; Raziq, Fazal, Institute for Advanced Study, Chengdu University, Chengdu, China; Bakhtiar, Syed Ul Hasnain, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China; Ali, Sher, School of Physics, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China; Khan, Adnan, Institute of Chemical Sciences, University of Peshawar, Peshawar, Pakistan; Ali, Nauman, Institute of Chemical Sciences, University of Peshawar, Peshawar, Pakistan; Wu, Xiaoqiang, School of Mechanical Engineering, Chengdu University, Chengdu, China; Ali, Sharafat, Institute for Advanced Study, Chengdu University, Chengdu, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are air pollutants that have garnered considerable consideration because of their detrimental effects on both public health and the environment. Catalytic oxidation is extensively recognized as an emerging technology for VOC elimination, as it produces no secondary pollutants and requires low energy input. This review systematically examines recent advancements in supported noble metal catalysts (SNM), supported transition metal catalysts (STM) and non-supported transition metal oxides (NSTM) for VOC oxidation. First, various types of VOCs and their emission sources are discussed. Next, recent progress in the catalytic oxidation of different VOCs using SNM, STM and NSTM is reviewed. The oxidation mechanisms of VOCs are then comprehensively summarized. Additionally, the effects of reaction conditions, including the presence of H<inf>2</inf>O, CO<inf>2</inf>, SO<inf>2</inf>, Cl species as well as reactant composition, concentration, and space velocity, on catalyst performance, deactivation, and regeneration approaches are explored. Finally, the key scientific obstacles and future perspectives in this field are addressed. This review provides as a solid experimental and theoretical basis for the development and design of stable SNM, STM and NSTM catalysts for VOC oxidation in the years to come. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Catalytic Oxidation; Non-supported Catalysts; Oxidation Mechanism; Supported Catalysts; Transition Metals; Volatile Organic Compounds

Authors: J.R., Silva, João R.; R.M., Quinta Ferreira, Rosa M.; L.M., Castro, Luís M.
Author full names: Silva, João R. (57221107203); Quinta Ferreira, Rosa M. (6701717235); Castro, Luís M. (7202228757)
Title: Biological Treatments for VOC-Contaminated Off-Gas: Advances, Challenges, and Energetic Valorization Opportunities
Affiliations: Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal; Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal; Universidade de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal; Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Silva, João R., Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal, Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universidade de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal, SiSus—Laboratory of Sustainable Industrial Systems, Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal; Quinta Ferreira, Rosa M., Department of Chemical Engineering, Universidade de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal; Castro, Luís M., Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal, Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universidade de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal, SiSus—Laboratory of Sustainable Industrial Systems, Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOC) are major contributors to the burgeoning air pollution issue, predominantly from industrial areas, with well-documented environmental and health risks, which demand efficient and sustainable control policies. This review analyzes the current technological challenges and investigates recent developments in biological treatment technologies for VOC-contaminated off-gases, including biofilters, biotrickling filters, and bioscrubber, as well as emerging technologies, such as bioaugmentation and microbial fuel cells (MFCs). Operational performance, economic feasibility, and adaptability to various industrial applications are assessed, alongside opportunities for integration with other technologies, including energy recovery technologies. Biological systems offer considerable advantages regarding cost savings and lower environmental impacts and enhanced operational flexibility, particularly when combined with innovative materials and microbial optimization techniques. Nevertheless, challenges persist, such as choosing the best treatment settings suited to different VOC streams and addressing biofilm control concerns and scalability. Overall, biological VOC treatments are encouraging sustainable solutions, though continued research into reactor design, microbial dynamics, and MFC-based energetic valorization is essential for broader industrial application. These insights cover advancements and highlight the continuous need for innovative prowess to forge sustainable VOC pollution control. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B., Divya, Baskaran; V., Saravanan, Viswanathan; H., Byun, Hun-soo
Author full names: Divya, Baskaran (57192545870); Saravanan, Viswanathan (59540542000); Byun, Hun-soo (7103324876)
Title: Casuarina seed-packed biofilter for the treatment of gaseous mixture: Performance, optimization, synergistic effects, neural model analysis, and kinetics
Affiliations: Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; Annamalai University, Chidambaram, India; Saveetha Dental College And Hospitals, Chennai, India
Authors with affiliations: Divya, Baskaran, Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea, Department of Biomaterials, Saveetha Dental College And Hospitals, Chennai, India; Saravanan, Viswanathan, Department of Chemical Engineering, Annamalai University, Chidambaram, India; Byun, Hun-soo, Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea
Abstract: Assessing the interactions and biodegradation of multicomponent gas streams is crucial for understanding industrial operations. Thus, the lab-scale casuarina seed-packed biofilter was performed with industrial settings i.e. different inlet concentrations of benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) in a mixture for their synchronized removal. Comparative computational models were studied using response surface methodology (RSM) and artificial neural network (ANN) to predict the individual pollutant performance in terms of removal efficiency (RE) and elimination capacity (EC). The synergistic effects of the individual pollutants load on the RE and EC were studied effectively. The response surface plots indicated that the developed biofilter could potentially eliminate multicomponent in the order of benzene>xylene>toluene with the decreasing order of toluene>xylene>benzene inlet concentrations. The RSM model prediction was cross verified by investigating the causal index (CI) analysis, applied to govern the effect of one variable on another beyond mere connection. The CI analysis confirmed that the toluene and xylene had a negative effect on their own RE and had positive effects on other pollutant performance; however, toluene vigorously supported the benzene and xylene biodegradation. The computational models show significant fluctuation in predicting responses due to substrate competitive inhibition, accumulation of toxic intermediates, and increasing multipollutant loads. Finally, the mathematical model was employed to predict the theoretical EC and average biofilm thickness at different regimes of biofiltration. The identified significant interaction information is more beneficial in designing and operating the multicomponent biofilter rationally. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: W., Wang, Wenqiang; Z., Chen, Ziran; X., Min, Xin; D., Hu, Dandan; J., Xu, Jingxin; S., Wang, Sheng; S., Zhao, Songjian; Z., Ye, Zhaolian
Title: Efficient plasma-catalytic decomposition of mixed toluene and NO over Mn-based spinel catalysts
Affiliations: Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Ltd., Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Wenqiang, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Chen, Ziran, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Min, Xin, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Hu, Dandan, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Xu, Jingxin, Ltd., Nanjing, China; Wang, Sheng, Ltd., Nanjing, China; Zhao, Songjian, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Ye, Zhaolian, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China
Abstract: To solve the complex problem pollution resulting from volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and nitrogen oxides (NOx), plasma-assisted catalytic technology was introduced and a series of AMn2O4 (A = Co, Cu, Ni, Zn) spinel catalysts with high coordination with plasma were developed, and the influence of A-site cations on the oxidation of toluene and NO mixture was investigated. The characteristics of the catalysts were characterized and analyzed by various physical and chemical characterization methods, confirming the successful synthesis of spinel materials. The specific surface area of four bimetallic spinel catalysts prepared via sol-gel method (130-150 m2/g) is significantly higher than that of conventional spinels (45-49 m2/g). CoMn2O4 displayed superior plasma-assisted catalytic performance compared to other three catalysts. When the specific energy density was 766.35JL-1, the degradation efficiency of toluene was 93.0%, the energy efficiency was 4.56 g·kWh-1, the total COx selectivity was 93.6% and the conversion efficiency of NO reached 100%. Lattice oxygen in the catalyst plays a crucial role in the oxidation of toluene and NO. Oxygen vacancies and electron migration between Mn4+/ Mn3+ in the spinel phase enhance the production and migration of reactive oxygen species, as well as the replenishment of lattice oxygen. The coexistence of toluene and NO has a synergistic effect, with NO accelerating the release of intermediate products during toluene degradation and freeing up active sites. Additionally, these intermediates can react with NO. These findings provide valuable theoretical insights for plasma-assisted catalytic removal of VOCs and NOx. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.J.C., Bunkan, Arne Joakim Coldevin; D., Hatscher, Deike
Author full names: Bunkan, Arne Joakim Coldevin (54794926600); Hatscher, Deike (55531572500)
Title: Direct Non-Thermal Corona Plasma Treatment in Air Pollution Control
Affiliations: Norwegian Defence Research Establishment, Skedsmokorset, Norway; SEID AS, Sandnes, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Bunkan, Arne Joakim Coldevin, Norwegian Defence Research Establishment, Skedsmokorset, Norway; Hatscher, Deike, SEID AS, Sandnes, Norway
Abstract: Air pollution constitutes a major threat to public health. To meet increasingly strict air quality regulations, efficient air purification solutions are necessary. Non-thermal plasma (NTP) offers an economic alternative to traditional methods such as incineration and filter adsorption as it can treat large emissions with minimal pressure drop and without the need to heat the emission. NTP is suitable for particle, VOC, and odour abatement in a variety of industries. The exact processes in an NTP discharge are only partially understood, and effective air purification requires tailoring the solution to the emission in question. This paper gives an introduction to the industrial implementation of NTP as either a standalone solution or as the basis for a multi-step cleaning solution. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Tang, Su; T., Zhong, Tao; Z., Yao, Zhangnan; W., Qu, Wei; T., Li, Ting; H., Zhao, Huinan; S., Tian, Shuanghong; C., He, Chun
Title: Construction of Spatially Adjacent Ni and Co-Based Spinel Frustrated Lewis Pair Sites for Efficient Catalytic Ozonation
Affiliations: Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Tang, Su, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Zhong, Tao, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Yao, Zhangnan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Qu, Wei, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Li, Ting, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Zhao, Huinan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Tian, Shuanghong, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; He, Chun, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: Frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) present new opportunities for the development of highly active spinel materials for the activation of stable molecules. Herein, a Ni and Co-based spinel with abundant FLPs sites (NiCo<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf>-F) is synthesized through morphologic defect engineering and used for efficient catalytic ozonation CH<inf>3</inf>SH elimination. Characterization results reveal that the NiCo<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf>-F with nanoflower structure exposes more surface oxygen vacancies (Ov), inducing local charge redistribution and forming active regions. Ov acts as Lewis basic sites, while the unsaturated coordinated Ni atoms (Ni<inf>uc</inf>) act as Lewis acidic sites, and spatially ≈4.08 Å. The Ov···Ni<inf>uc</inf> FLPs function as “electron shuttles” in the reaction, facilitating specific adsorption of reactants via the dual acidic–basic reaction sites, thereby activating O<inf>3</inf> to generate ·O<inf>2</inf>− and 1O<inf>2</inf> species to achieve deep oxidation of CH<inf>3</inf>SH. The resulting NiCo<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf>-F catalyst exhibits an outstanding CH<inf>3</inf>SH removal efficiency of 94.4%, achieving a high mass activity (5.6 ppm mg−1), which is 70 times greater than that of commercial MnO<inf>2</inf> (0.08 ppm mg−1). This work presents a promising approach to developing sophisticated ozone catalysts by controllable construction of acid–base sites on spinel surface, enhancing the understanding of the role of FLPs structure in molecular activation. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Xu, Tong; C., Wang, Chenlong; Y., Lv, Yanfei; B., Zhu, Bin; X., Zhang, Xiaomin
Title: Catalytic Oxidative Removal of Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) by Perovskite Catalysts: A Review
Affiliations: Dalian Maritime University, Dalian, China; Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, China
Authors with affiliations: Xu, Tong, Laboratory of Plasma Catalysis, Dalian Maritime University, Dalian, China; Wang, Chenlong, Laboratory of Plasma Catalysis, Dalian Maritime University, Dalian, China; Lv, Yanfei, Laboratory of Plasma Catalysis, Dalian Maritime University, Dalian, China; Zhu, Bin, Laboratory of Plasma Catalysis, Dalian Maritime University, Dalian, China; Zhang, Xiaomin, State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions have become a critical environmental concern due to their contributions to photochemical smog formation, secondary organic aerosol generation, and adverse human health impacts in the context of accelerated industrialization and urbanization. Catalytic oxidation over perovskite-type catalysts is an attractive technological approach for efficient VOC abatement. This review systematically evaluates the advancements in perovskite-based catalysts for VOC oxidation, focusing on their crystal structure–activity relationships, electronic properties, synthetic methodologies, and nanostructure engineering. Emphasis is placed on metal ion doping strategies and supported catalyst configurations, which have been demonstrated to optimize catalytic performance through synergistic effects. The applications of perovskite catalysts in diverse oxidation systems, including photocatalysis, thermal catalysis, electrocatalysis, and plasma-assisted catalysis, are comprehensively discussed with critical analysis of their respective advantages and limitations. It summarizes the existing challenges, such as catalyst deactivation caused by carbon deposition, sulfur/chlorine poisoning, and thermal sintering, as well as issues like low energy utilization efficiency and the generation of secondary pollutants. By consolidating current knowledge and highlighting future research directions, this review provides a solid foundation for the rational design of next-generation perovskite catalysts for sustainable VOC management. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: I., Anil, Ismail; Ö., Ağa, Ömer
Title: Dispersion Modeling and Assessment of Volatile Organic Compound Emissions From a Municipal Wastewater Treatment Plant
Affiliations: Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Dammam, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Anil, Ismail, Environmental Engineering Department, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Dammam, Saudi Arabia; Ağa, Ömer, Environmental Engineering Department, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Dammam, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: This study presents the dispersion modeling and assessment of total volatile organic compounds (TVOC) emissions from a municipal wastewater treatment plant in Saudi Arabia. The study uses the AERMOD dispersion model to predict the ground-level atmospheric TVOC emissions over 1-h, 8-h, 24-h, and annual periods under average and peak flow-rate scenarios. The effects of winter and summer seasons on TVOC dispersion were also analyzed by generating seasonal dispersion maps. The significant findings indicate that maximum TVOC concentrations are confined within the Dhahran North Sewage Treatment Plant (NSTP) area, attributed to low release heights from aeration and settling tanks. TVOC concentrations during the summer were approximately 6.8% higher than the annual average due to lower wind speeds, while winter winds enhanced dispersion, resulting in an 8.7% decrease in TVOC concentrations. The study shows that TVOC levels decrease with distance from the source, following linear and logarithmic patterns. Comparison with wastewater treatment plants in other regions demonstrates that Dhahran NSTP has lower TVOC concentrations, highlighting the influence of influent characteristics on emission levels. The strong correlation between influent flowrate and TVOC concentrations reinforces the consistency of the findings with similar facilities. The study findings indicate that the predicted atmospheric dispersion of TVOC from Dhahran NSTP may not pose a health risk to treatment plant employees and the public residing within the selected receptor domain. This supports the efficacy of the implemented air quality management practices. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: X., Wu, Xin; C., Yang, Chunping; Y., Lin, Yan; X., Li, Xiang; S., Wu, Shaohua; P., Rybarczyk, Piotr; J., Gȩbicki, Jacek
Title: Performances, mechanisms, and strategies for methane removal via gas biofiltration
Source title: Frontiers of Environmental Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology, Maoming, China; Hunan University of Technology, Zhuzhou, China; Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Hainan University, Haikou, China; Hunan Normal University, Changsha, China; Gdańsk University of Technology, Gdansk, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Xin, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology, Maoming, China, College of Urban and Environment Sciences, Hunan University of Technology, Zhuzhou, China, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Yang, Chunping, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology, Maoming, China, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Hainan University, Haikou, China; Lin, Yan, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan Normal University, Changsha, China; Li, Xiang, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology, Maoming, China; Wu, Shaohua, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology, Maoming, China; Rybarczyk, Piotr, Department of Process Engineering and Chemical Technology, Gdańsk University of Technology, Gdansk, Poland; Gȩbicki, Jacek, Department of Process Engineering and Chemical Technology, Gdańsk University of Technology, Gdansk, Poland
Abstract: Control of methane emissions has attracted widespread attention in the context of worldwide efforts to alleviate the greenhouse effect. Biofiltration, a green and cost-effective treatment process, has been widely used for the purification of methane. Currently, there is still a lack of comprehensive information on methane biofiltration. Herein, the state-of-the-art development trends of methane removal via biofiltration were comprehensively reviewed and commented on. First of all, this article reviewed the mechanisms of methane removal and the possible degradation pathways in biofilters. Secondly, the removal characteristics of single methane, methane mixed with volatile organic compounds or gaseous inorganic compounds by biofiltration, were summarized and discussed. Thirdly, the practical applications of methane biofiltration were summed up and some inspirations were proposed. Finally, the effective measures to improve the performance of methane biofiltration were put forward, and corresponding insights and future research directions for methane biofiltration were provided. This article can provide references for the practical applications of methane biofiltration and the mitigation of greenhouse effects. (Figure presented.) © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: W., Kong, Wenjing; X., Zhong, Xueyun; Y., Yan, Ying; Y., Xing, Yun; L., Liu, Lei; C., Yu, Chuan; L., Yang, Leneng; X., Song, Xiaofei; M., Fu, Mingli
Title: Enhancement of the catalytic performance of Co3O4 towards butyl acetate oxidation by weakening the Co-O bond and promoting oxygen activation
Affiliations: Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China; Guangdong Chengyi Environmental Protection Technology Corp, Shaoguan, China
Authors with affiliations: Kong, Wenjing, School of Environment and Energy, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China; Zhong, Xueyun, School of Environment and Energy, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China; Yan, Ying, School of Environment and Energy, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China; Xing, Yun, School of Environment and Energy, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China; Liu, Lei, School of Environment and Energy, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China; Yu, Chuan, School of Environment and Energy, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China; Yang, Leneng, Guangdong Chengyi Environmental Protection Technology Corp, Shaoguan, China; Song, Xiaofei, School of Environment and Energy, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China; Fu, Mingli, School of Environment and Energy, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: With the widespread use of waterborne coatings, the treatment of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), which can easily produce odor pollution, has become a major concern for air pollution control in the coating industry. Since the deep oxidation of the butyl acetate (BA) molecule requires the involvement of a large amount of reactive oxygen species, the catalytic oxidation of BA was promoted by weakening the Co-O bond strength on the cobalt oxide surface. In this study, we adopted a simple sacrificial template approach to fabricate a series of specifically shaped and uniform Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of BA. The flaky CM71-C catalyst showed the best catalytic properties for BA oxidation (T<inf>50</inf> = 197 °C, T<inf>90</inf> = 215 °C). According to the characterization results, flaky CM71-C has the largest specific surface area and the weakest Co-O bond, which is more conducive to redox and oxygen activation capabilities of the catalyst. The results of in situ DRIFTS studies showed that the surface reactive oxygen species were continuously recharged during the reaction due to the higher oxygen activation capacity, which accelerated the rapid decomposition of carboxylate, a key reactive intermediate species in the deep oxidation of BA. This study provides a practical and effective way to gain insight into the role of oxygen vacancies in the preparation of efficient catalysts with a specific morphology for the oxidation of VOCs. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J., Zhang, Jinjian; K., Vikrant, Kumar; C., Yeon, Changho; C., Lee, Chan-woo; Y.H., Kim, Yong Hyun
Author full names: Zhang, Jinjian (57449642800); Vikrant, Kumar (57195930655); Yeon, Changho (57765269600); Lee, Chan-woo (57230005400); Kim, Yong Hyun (57196174153)
Title: The practical feasibility of bismuth oxyhalide semiconductors with controlled surface defects in photocatalytic degradation of toluene in air
Source title: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Hanyang University, Seoul, South Korea; Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea; Korea University, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Jinjian, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, South Korea; Vikrant, Kumar, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, South Korea; Yeon, Changho, Energy AI & Computational Science Laboratory, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Lee, Chan-woo, Energy AI & Computational Science Laboratory, Korea Institute of Energy Research, Daejeon, South Korea; Kim, Yong Hyun, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of toluene (as model aromatic volatile organic compound (VOC)) is studied using two-dimensional semiconductors (bismuth oxyhalides (BiOX (X = Cl and Br)) synthesized with surface defects (BiOX-R (R = reduction)) through a solvothermal-induced reduction process. The PCD efficiency of BiOCl-R against 5 ppm toluene (20 % relative humidity (RH)) is 98.6 % under ultraviolet light irradiation with the quantum yield and clean air delivery rate of 1.04E-03 molecules photon-1 and 3 L/h, respectively. A combined evaluation of catalyst properties, experimental data, and density functional theory simulations consistently indicates that the formation of surface defects should promote the adsorption and activation of toluene, molecular oxygen (O<inf>2</inf>), and water (H<inf>2</inf>O) molecules. Meanwhile, the geometric and electronic structure of defective BiOX favorably generates superoxide anion ([rad]O<inf>2</inf>–) and hydroxyl ([rad]OH) radicals through electron (e-)-assisted O<inf>2</inf> activation and hole (h+)-mediated H<inf>2</inf>O oxidation, respectively. Notably, the BiOCl-R surface becomes more advantageous to reduce the reaction energy barrier in the ring-opening processes of intermediate forms like benzaldehyde and benzoic acid. Overall, the results of this study offer practical guidelines for the design of advanced photocatalysts with controlled surface defects for the efficient PCD of aromatic VOCs in air. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.W., Uz Zaman, Md Wahad; A.D., Phule, Ajit Dattatray; T.G., Senthamaraikannan, Thillai Govindaraja; S., Kim, Seul-yi; S., Elkaee, Sahar; J., Yang, Jae-hwan; D.H., Lim, Dong Hee
Author full names: Uz Zaman, Md Wahad (58632865500); Phule, Ajit Dattatray (35730226200); Senthamaraikannan, Thillai Govindaraja (57220873283); Kim, Seul-yi (58632865400); Elkaee, Sahar (57218204035); Yang, Jae-hwan (55240130900); Lim, Dong Hee (12804228200)
Title: Design of bifunctional nitrogen-doped biochar with adsorption and catalytic oxidation capabilities for enhanced toluene emission control
Affiliations: Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Chungbuk National University, Cheongju, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Uz Zaman, Md Wahad, Department of Environmental & IT Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Phule, Ajit Dattatray, Department of Environmental & IT Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Senthamaraikannan, Thillai Govindaraja, Department of Environmental Engineering, Chungbuk National University, Cheongju, South Korea; Kim, Seul-yi, Department of Environmental & IT Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Elkaee, Sahar, Department of Environmental & IT Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Yang, Jae-hwan, Department of Environmental & IT Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, South Korea; Lim, Dong Hee, Department of Environmental Engineering, Chungbuk National University, Cheongju, South Korea
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), such as toluene, are hazardous air pollutants that pose significant health and environmental risks. This study addresses remediation of toluene by developing a bifunctional nitrogen-doped biochar (NDB) activated with sodium hydroxide (NaOH), aimed at reducing toluene emissions through both adsorption and catalytic oxidation. A series of NDB samples were prepared via NaOH activation and pyrolysis at varying temperatures to optimize their adsorption capacity and catalytic performance. The results demonstrated that NaOH-activated NDB exhibits substantial mesopore volumes and excellent surface area, with adsorption performance highly dependent on surface area and catalytic performance strongly influenced by nitrogen species. The dynamic adsorption tests revealed that BUN-900 achieved an outstanding toluene adsorption capacity of 422.25 mg/g, attributed to its high specific surface area of 1321.72 m2/g. In contrast, BU-800 showed complete toluene conversion at 450 °C via catalytic oxidation, attributed to the presence of pyridinic-N species. Interestingly, while the sample with the best adsorption performance had the lowest catalytic oxidation performance, the sample with the best catalytic performance exhibited the lowest adsorption capacity. This study demonstrates that NaOH activation and nitrogen doping can significantly enhance the bifunctional properties of biochar, positioning it as a promising, sustainable material for VOC control through combined adsorption and catalytic oxidation. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
