Authors: Y., You, Yuewen; Z., Zhang, Zhihong; Z., Sun, Zhekai; B., Pan, Biao
Title: Catalytic oxidation of low concentration ethyl acetate and butyl acetate on cerium-manganese composite metal oxides
Affiliations: Changzhou University, Changzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: You, Yuewen, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Zhang, Zhihong, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Sun, Zhekai, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Pan, Biao, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China
Abstract: Herein, Ce-Mn oxide catalysts were obtained by a coprecipitation process and applied to the oxidation of ethyl acetate and butyl acetate. Among a series of catalysts, Ce<inf>1</inf>Mn<inf>2</inf> displayed exceptional catalytic performance for ethyl acetate (3933 mg m−3, T<inf>90</inf> = 157 °C) and butyl acetate (5186 mg m−3, T<inf>90</inf> = 171 °C) when the GHSV was 15 000 h−1. The properties of these Ce-Mn oxide catalysts were characterized using XRD, BET, SEM, and XPS. It was observed that the solid solution structure formed between Ce and Mn oxides and the specific surface area increased. Ce3+ and Mn3+ were considered to be key species in the reaction process, with lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen playing their parts. A water content of approximately 1.5 wt% promoted the catalytic process. In addition, FT-IR and GC-MS were employed to detect the by-products generated by the reaction, and it was found that aldehydes and alcohols were the main by-products. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Zhu, Yimeng; X., Min, Xin; X., Wu, Xueqian; S., Huang, Siyan; J., Cai, Jia; Z., Li, Zhen; S., Zhao, Songjian
Title: Structure-Activity Relationships and Catalytic Applications of Manganese-Based Oxides with Different Nanostructures in Multi-Pollutant Gas Treatment
Affiliations: Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; The Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Electronic Waste and New Energy Solid Waste Resource Utilization, Changzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, Yimeng, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Min, Xin, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China, The Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Electronic Waste and New Energy Solid Waste Resource Utilization, Changzhou, China; Wu, Xueqian, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Huang, Siyan, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Cai, Jia, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Li, Zhen, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China; Zhao, Songjian, School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, China
Abstract: Manganese-based oxides have shown potential in the catalytic treatment of gaseous pollutants, including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), carbon monoxide (CO), and ozone (O<inf>3</inf>). However, most studies have focused on specific manganese oxides and their performance in treating single pollutants, with limited understanding of behavior across multiple pollutants and under complex conditions relevant to practical applications. This research systematically evaluated the catalytic performance of four manganese-based oxides (MnO<inf>2</inf>, Mn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, Mn<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>, and LaMnO<inf>3</inf>) under diverse reaction conditions. Results revealed that MnO<inf>2</inf> exhibits superior catalytic activity in toluene oxidation (T<inf>90</inf> = 207 °C) and CO oxidation due to its well-defined crystal structure and abundant oxygen vacancies. Mn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> shows excellent performance in chlorobenzene oxidation (T<inf>90</inf> = 328 °C) and ozone decomposition, attributed to the high specific surface area and moderate redox properties. Stability tests highlighted that all catalysts are resistant to H<inf>2</inf>O and NO poisoning, while Mn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> demonstrates enhanced SO<inf>2</inf> tolerance by suppressing SO<inf>2</inf>-to-SO<inf>3</inf> conversion and preventing MnSO<inf>4</inf> from blocking active sites. Mechanistic analyses indicated that VOCs oxidation is strongly influenced by oxygen vacancies and oxidation states of manganese, while lattice oxygen and redox cycling drive the CO and the O<inf>3</inf> reactions. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Gong, Haili; Y., Liu, Yonglin; T., Yang, Tingzheng; L., Liu, Lin; X., Li, Xuechen; C., Gu, Chuantao; Z., Jin, Zhenyu; D., Li, Debao; W., Wang, Weiliang
Title: Advancements in Hybrid and Combined Biological Technologies for Treating Polluted Gases: A Comprehensive Review
Affiliations: Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Shandong Institute for Food and Drug Control, Jinan, China
Authors with affiliations: Gong, Haili, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Liu, Yonglin, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Yang, Tingzheng, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Liu, Lin, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Li, Xuechen, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Gu, Chuantao, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Jin, Zhenyu, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China; Li, Debao, Shandong Institute for Food and Drug Control, Jinan, China; Wang, Weiliang, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Qingdao University of Technology, Qingdao, China
Abstract: Air pollution is widespread and poses significant health risks, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, cancer, and even lead to death. Among the strategies to mitigate exhaust gases, biological treatment technology has gained significant attention due to its high treatment efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and environmental friendliness. This technology has become a key area of research. This paper discusses the principles, scope, advantages, and cons of various biological treatment methods, including biofiltration, biotrickling filtration, bioscrubbing, and membrane bioreactors. Noteworthy advantages of current biological treatment for exhaust gases include cost savings, reduced energy consumption, and lower secondary pollution risks. However, limitations exist, such as the treatment of treating low concentration and high flow rate of exhaust gases, and the dependence on specific microbial species and fillers. Combining biological treatments with other technologies could significantly improve effectiveness. The review also explores challenges and future directions, aiming to enhance the application of biological treatments in exhaust gas management towards sustainable development. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Wang, Longfei; C., Huang, Chun; Z., Gao, Ziting; B., Cui, Bing; M., Zhao, Mingqin; M., Xiao, Menglan; X., Yu, Xiaolin
Title: Recent Research on the Anti-Poisoning Catalysts in the Catalytic Oxidation of VOCs: A Review
Affiliations: Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Ltd., Xi'an, China; University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Longfei, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Huang, Chun, Ltd., Xi'an, China; Gao, Ziting, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Cui, Bing, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Zhao, Mingqin, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Xiao, Menglan, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Yu, Xiaolin, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from petrochemical, pharmaceutical, and other industries have serious damage to human health and the environment. Catalytic oxidation is a promising method to eliminate air pollution due to its high efficiency, wide application range, and environmental friendliness. However, in the actual industrial environment, the composition of industrial exhaust gases is complex, including VOCs, water vapour, chloride, sulfide and so on. The impurities would have competitive adsorption with reactants or react with the active sites, leading to the decline of catalytic activity, even the deactivation of catalysts. Therefore, this review summarises the recent research on the anti-poisoning ability of catalysts in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs, primarily focusing on the effect of water vapour, chloride, and sulfide. The catalytic oxidation mechanism manifested that the adsorption and activation of reactants are significant in VOCs degradation. On this basis, the mechanism of catalyst poisoning was analysed, and the inhibitory effect of impurities on the oxidation reaction was elucidated. According to the research status, three anti-poisoning strategies are proposed, including building a bimetallic system, modifying supports, and establishing the protected coating. This work provides a theoretical foundation and reference point for the rational construction of anti-poisoning catalysts in VOCs elimination. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G.L.L., Fraga, Gabriel Luiz Lopes; M., Konarova, Muxina; L., Massin, Laurence; A.D.K., Deshan, Athukoralalage Don K.; D.W., Rackemann, Darryn W.; B.G., Laycock, Bronwyn G.; S., Pratt, Steven; N.R., Batalha, Nuno R.
Author full names: Fraga, Gabriel Luiz Lopes (58743117000); Konarova, Muxina (23489144700); Massin, Laurence (23009607800); Deshan, Athukoralalage Don K. (57218545968); Rackemann, Darryn W. (23502394600); Laycock, Bronwyn G. (23067654200); Pratt, Steven (7103017574); Batalha, Nuno R. (55220668900)
Title: Reduction of RuO2 nanoparticles supported on silica by organic molecules: a strategy for nanoparticle redispersion
Affiliations: Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia; Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia; The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia; Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse et l'Environnement de Lyon, Villeurbanne, France
Authors with affiliations: Fraga, Gabriel Luiz Lopes, Centre for Agriculture and the Bioeconomy, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia, Medical and Process Engineering, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia, Architecture and Information Technology, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia; Konarova, Muxina, Architecture and Information Technology, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia; Massin, Laurence, Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse et l'Environnement de Lyon, Villeurbanne, France; Deshan, Athukoralalage Don K., Centre for Agriculture and the Bioeconomy, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia, Medical and Process Engineering, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia; Rackemann, Darryn W., Centre for Agriculture and the Bioeconomy, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia, Medical and Process Engineering, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia; Laycock, Bronwyn G., Architecture and Information Technology, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia; Pratt, Steven, Architecture and Information Technology, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia; Batalha, Nuno R., Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse et l'Environnement de Lyon, Villeurbanne, France
Abstract: High metal surface area is a critical parameter in metal-based supported heterogeneous catalysts. However, supported metal nanoparticle coalescence or sintering is inevitable and a cause for catalyst deactivation. While reversing the sintering process is challenging, it is an essential topic as this would further extend catalyst use and reduce the consumption of critical raw materials often used in catalysts, e.g., noble metals. The cyclic oxidation-reduction of supported metal nanoparticles is commonly reported as a method for redispersing supported metal nanoparticles. While multiple molecules can be used to reduce supported metal oxide nanoparticles, H<inf>2</inf> is the primary reducing agent used when performing redispersion via oxidation/reduction. Yet, replacing the H<inf>2</inf> with other organic molecules could significantly impact the redispersion phenomena as it is well-known that metal nanoparticles' configuration is affected by molecular adsorption. Herein, we explored organic molecules as reducing agents to reduce silica-supported ruthenium oxide nanoparticles (RuO<inf>2</inf>/SiO<inf>2</inf>). Six compounds were evaluated: methanol, ethanol, isopropanol, acetone, heptane, and cyclohexane, and the results were compared to the conventional reduction with H<inf>2</inf>. The products and the energy released showed two pathways: (i) conversion of RuO<inf>2</inf> to metallic Ru due to oxidative dehydrogenation and oxidation of the reducing agents, and (ii) dehydrogenation of the organic molecules when enough metallic Ru is available. The energy released during reduction was substantially lower with organic molecules (27-85 kJ mol<inf>RuO<inf>2</inf></inf>−1), as opposed to H<inf>2</inf> (156 kJ mol<inf>RuO<inf>2</inf></inf>−1). In addition, smaller Ru nanoparticles resulted from the reduction of organic molecules (4.5-7.0 nm) instead of H<inf>2</inf> (11.9 nm). This observation was attributed to a redispersion phenomenon, which was not observed when using H<inf>2</inf>, supported by the existence of clusters of small nanoparticles, which were, in turn, impacted by the kinetics of the reduction reaction. The Ru/SiO<inf>2</inf> catalyst was employed in the furfural hydrogenation reaction as a model reaction, where all catalysts reduced with organic compounds displayed a two-fold increase in activity compared to those reduced with H<inf>2</inf>. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Ochiai, Tsuyoshi; K., Hamada, Kengo; M., Okui, Michifumi
Author full names: Ochiai, Tsuyoshi (35387067400); Hamada, Kengo (57200560261); Okui, Michifumi (59660479500)
Title: Synergistic Effects of Photocatalysis, Ozone Treatment, and Metal Catalysts on the Decomposition of Acetaldehyde
Affiliations: Kanagawa Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Ebina, Japan; Ltd., Sagamihara, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ochiai, Tsuyoshi, Kanagawa Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Ebina, Japan; Hamada, Kengo, Kanagawa Institute of Industrial Science and Technology, Ebina, Japan; Okui, Michifumi, Manufacturing Innovation Division R&D Department, Ltd., Sagamihara, Japan
Abstract: This study explores the synergistic interactions between photocatalysis, ozone treatment, and metal catalysts in the decomposition of acetaldehyde, a representative volatile organic compound (VOC). The study addresses the growing need for efficient air purification technologies by integrating advanced oxidation processes. Metal catalysts, particularly manganese oxide-based materials, were combined with photocatalysis and ozonation to investigate their impact on acetaldehyde removal efficiency. Experimental results revealed that the treatment integrating these methods significantly outperformed conventional single-process treatments. Metal catalysts facilitated the initial oxidation of acetaldehyde, while photocatalysis accelerated subsequent stages, including the mineralisation of intermediates. Ozone contributed additional reactive oxidative species, further enhancing decomposition rates. These findings provide valuable insights into the design of efficient VOC removal systems, demonstrating that integrating metal catalysts with photocatalytic and ozonation processes offers a promising strategy for improving air purification technologies. This approach has potential applications in environmental remediation and indoor air quality management. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Acetaldehyde Decomposition; Air Purification; Metal Catalysts; Ozone; Photocatalysis

Authors: M., Govindan, Muthuraman; Y., Choi, Youngyu; E., Erusappan, Elangovan; D., Kim, Daekeun
Author full names: Govindan, Muthuraman (54991046900); Choi, Youngyu (57831702300); Erusappan, Elangovan (57195219856); Kim, Daekeun (55742883300)
Title: Advances in electrochemical treatment for state-of-the-art abatement of gaseous air pollutants: A review
Affiliations: Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Govindan, Muthuraman, Department of Environmental Engineering, Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Choi, Youngyu, Department of Environmental Engineering, Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Erusappan, Elangovan, Department of Environmental Engineering, Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Daekeun, Department of Environmental Engineering, Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Effective abatement of air pollutants in their gaseous state is essential for achieving a cleaner environment. A promising and environment-friendly technology for this purpose involves the use of electrons as clean energy or solvents. The field of electrochemical abatement of air pollutants using electrons has made significant progress in recent years, particularly in terms of solid-gas electrochemical reactions within suitable cell assemblies. Herein, we provide a comprehensive overview of the absorption of gaseous volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into liquids involved in electrochemical abatement at the solid-liquid or liquid-gas interfaces. Techniques such as electroscrubbing, which use electrically charged ions for the treatment of flue gases, odor gases, and VOCs with wet scrubbers, are explored. Advances in the abatement of gaseous pollutants include the development of tri-phase interfaces using gas diffusion electrodes (GDE) in electrochemical cell assemblies, which have subsequently progressed to membrane electrode assemblies (MEA) in all-solid-cell configurations. A recent innovation involves a half-cell approach that eliminates the need for liquid electrolytes and minimizes humidity supply to the gaseous pollutant stream. This review highlights the importance of mediators or catalysts at the liquid-gas and solid-gas interfaces in improving the effectiveness of air pollutant abatement. Furthermore, a potential application of a gel membrane design for a liquid-electrolyte-free one-half-cell configuration is suggested, which could facilitate the abatement of gaseous pollutants at solid-gas electrochemical interfaces. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: X., Wu, Xiangci; C., Dai, Chenglong; L., Zhang, Lisheng; G., Gao, Ge; J., Shi, Jiahui; D., Zhao, Dan; B., Fu, Bingfeng; S., Liu, Shejiang; J., Fu, Jianfeng; H., Ding, Hui
Title: Catalytic degradation of ethyl acetate at room temperature over Ni/NAC monolithic catalyst
Affiliations: Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Ltd., Shenzhen, China
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Xiangci, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Dai, Chenglong, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Zhang, Lisheng, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Gao, Ge, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Shi, Jiahui, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Zhao, Dan, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Fu, Bingfeng, Ltd., Shenzhen, China; Liu, Shejiang, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Fu, Jianfeng, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Ding, Hui, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China
Abstract: Ethyl acetate, a typical oxygen-containing volatile organic compounds (OVOCs) pollutant with a pungent odor and low toxicity, is still a great challenge to catalyze degradation at room temperature. Here, nitrogen-doped activated carbon loading Ni monolithic catalysts prepared by the one-pot impregnation method at an annealing temperature of 900°C (Ni/NAC-900) achieves the 95 % removal of ethyl acetate and 67.15 % CO<inf>2</inf> selectivity within 58.5 h at 25°C. The result of XRD proves the monolithic catalysts contains Ni single atoms and Ni NPs, of which the Ni single atoms accounts for 92 % of the total Ni elements. The XAFs characterization results shows that the active site structure of Ni single atoms is NiN<inf>4</inf>C<inf>2</inf> coordination structure. Hydroxyl radicals (·OH) converted by O<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O in the air on the atomically dispersed NiN<inf>4</inf>C<inf>2</inf> catalytic centers results in the breakage of the C-O bond and C-C bond, which eventually causes the oxidation of ethyl acetate to CO<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O. The findings provide fresh insights into the degradation of ethyl acetate with high efficiency, low consumption and in a safe manner. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.K., Haider, Syed Kamran; A., Dildar, Aqsa; M.N., Shah, Muhammad Naqi; S.I., Haider, Syed Imran; T.A., Sheikh, Tahir Ali; A., Islam, Amjad; Z., Haider, Zeeshan; S.A., Ali, Syed Ashar; A., Siddique, Amna; M.A., Abbasi, Muhammad Athar
Author full names: Haider, Syed Kamran (59371951200); Dildar, Aqsa (59131760700); Shah, Muhammad Naqi (59547202900); Haider, Syed Imran (59547013800); Sheikh, Tahir Ali (34771926400); Islam, Amjad (57203666762); Haider, Zeeshan (57213846662); Ali, Syed Ashar (57205731888); Siddique, Amna (59020816500); Abbasi, Muhammad Athar (7004042601)
Title: REVIEW ON CATALYTIC TREATMENT OF VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS BY ZEOLITE-BASED HETEROGENEOUS CATALYSTS IN LIQUID AND GASEOUS MEDIUM
Source title: Special Topics and Reviews in Porous Media
Affiliations: Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; The Islamia University of Bahawalpur, Bahawalpur, Pakistan; Government College University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan; University of Sargodha, Sargodha, Pakistan; Shantou University, Shantou, China; Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Western Digital Inc., Seoul, South Korea; Government College University Lahore, Lahore, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Haider, Syed Kamran, Department of Chemistry, Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; Dildar, Aqsa, Institute of Chemistry, The Islamia University of Bahawalpur, Bahawalpur, Pakistan; Shah, Muhammad Naqi, Department of Biochemistry, Government College University Faisalabad, Faisalabad, Pakistan; Haider, Syed Imran, Institute of Chemistry, University of Sargodha, Sargodha, Pakistan; Sheikh, Tahir Ali, Institute of Chemistry, The Islamia University of Bahawalpur, Bahawalpur, Pakistan; Islam, Amjad, Shantou University, Shantou, China; Haider, Zeeshan, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Ali, Syed Ashar, Western Digital Inc., Seoul, South Korea; Siddique, Amna, Institute of Chemistry, The Islamia University of Bahawalpur, Bahawalpur, Pakistan; Abbasi, Muhammad Athar, Department of Chemistry, Government College University Lahore, Lahore, Pakistan
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) constitute a significant component of air pollutants, posing substantial risks to both human health and the environment due to their toxicity, volatility, and diffusivity. Oxidative catalysis has emerged as a highly effective strategy for treating VOCs, and zeolite-based materials have proven to be efficient catalysts for such reactions. To date, zeolite-based materials are acknowledged as promising candidates for VOC oxidation, leveraging their meritorious properties, including unique structures, large surface areas, high adsorption capacity, uniform/intricate channels, high thermal stability, wettability, and well-defined micropores with excellent shape selectivity. This review comprehensively outlines the potential utility of zeolite-based catalysts, encompassing their types, adsorption, and catalysis mechanisms. Various research methods, such as adsorption–desorption, selective catalytic reduction, oxidation, isomerization, cracking, hydrogenation/dehydrogenation, peroxidation, and photocatalysis, employed in zeolite-assisted catalysis of VOCs, are also discussed. Furthermore, the review delves into the effects of feed gas composition, feed gas flow rate, reaction temperature, and zeolite type on the catalytic process. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.M., Möller, Detlev M.
Author full names: Möller, Detlev M. (7102816537)
Title: Chemistry of the Climate System, 4th Revised Edition
Affiliations: Brandenburgische Technische Universität Cottbus, Cottbus, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Möller, Detlev M., Brandenburgische Technische Universität Cottbus, Cottbus, Germany
Abstract: Climate change is a major challenge facing the modern world. The chemistry of air and it's influence on the climate system forms the main focus of this monograph. The book presents a problem-based approach to presenting global atmospheric processes, evaluating the effects of changing air composition as well as possibilities for interference within these processes and indicates ways for solving the problem of climate change through chemistry. The new edition includes innovations and latest research results. A chemical approach to global climate change: including 2 new chapters on chemical climatology and an extended discussion of atmospheric trace species. For environmental scientists in atmospheric chemistry, meteorology, geology, and ecology. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Marchildon, Keith; D., Mody, David
Author full names: Marchildon, Keith (36721594800); Mody, David (59521452200)
Title: Practical Process Design for Chemical Engineers
Authors with affiliations: Marchildon, Keith, ; Mody, David,
Abstract: In-depth and practical textbook resource on chemical engineering processes, ranging from fundamentals to advanced aspects Practical Process Design for Chemical Engineers presents an extensive overview of the fundamental and advanced aspects of chemical engineering processes. Spanning 20 chapters, the book delves into various processes, equipment, and methodologies essential for modern chemical engineering, from basic principles to specific applications such as reactors, separations, and process integration. Each chapter systematically covers both theoretical concepts and practical applications, emphasizing process design, operational efficiency, environmental considerations, and safety. The book aims to equip chemical engineers with a robust toolkit for tackling diverse challenges in the industry, emphasizing innovation, sustainability, and the integration of new technologies. Unlike conventional texts that often focus primarily on established methods and theoretical fundamentals, this book actively explores innovative technologies and strategies to enhance efficiency and minimize environmental impact. Additionally, the book places significant emphasis on practical experience and real-world applications, imbuing readers not only with theoretical knowledge but also with practical skills and an understanding of industry trends. The book covers: • Creativity, choice, and decision-making in chemical engineering, emphasizing the artistic and imaginative aspects of process design • Solids processes such as size reduction, granulation, particle measurement and classification, and the conveyance of solids • Principles and methods employed to mix diverse materials such as miscible and immiscible liquids, gases with liquids, and solids with liquids or gases • Critical aspects of heat exchange in chemical processes, focusing on the heating, cooling, and phase changes of various substances • Estimation of process engineering hours With detailed discussions on process intensification and the latest developments in solvent and reactor technologies, and a focus on modern, sustainable practices alongside traditional engineering concepts, this book serves as a vital resource for students and professionals seeking to polish and hone their knowledge and practice in chemical engineering design. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: E.A., Elimian, Ehiaghe Agbovhimen; C., Kiki, Claude; N.A., Amenaghawon, Nosakhare Andrew; R., Djellabi, Ridha
Author full names: Elimian, Ehiaghe Agbovhimen (57221752005); Kiki, Claude (57214362376); Amenaghawon, Nosakhare Andrew (57219660259); Djellabi, Ridha (55965104200)
Title: Biofiltration as a sustainable approach for the treatment of hydrophobic volatile organic compounds: Improvement strategies and integrated systems
Affiliations: University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada; University of Benin, Benin, Nigeria; Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; University of Benin, Benin, Nigeria; Alfaisal University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Elimian, Ehiaghe Agbovhimen, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada, Department of Plant Biology and Biotechnology, University of Benin, Benin, Nigeria; Kiki, Claude, Institute of Urban Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Amenaghawon, Nosakhare Andrew, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Benin, Benin, Nigeria; Djellabi, Ridha, Department of Chemistry, Alfaisal University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) pose significant risks to human health and the environment, making their removal a critical concern. Biological treatment is emerging as a promising strategy for VOCs removal due to its low energy consumption and minimal potential for secondary pollution. Biofiltration systems offer an efficient technology, characterized by their straightforward operation and low energy requirements. The effectiveness of biofiltration systems is influenced by the nature, composition, and community structure of the microorganisms within the biofilm that develops on the medium. However, hydrophobic VOCs present a particular challenge for degradation due to their complex structures and strong affinity for organic materials. This hydrophobicity limits their bioavailability, making it difficult for microorganisms to access and metabolize these compounds effectively. Furthermore, hydrophobic VOCs tend to adsorb onto surfaces rather than dissolving in aqueous environments, complicating their degradation in biological treatment systems. This paper reviews recent advancements in VOCs treatment technologies, with a particular focus on hydrophobic VOCs and innovations in biofiltration that integrate photolysis, photocatalysis, non-thermal plasma (NTP), and electrochemical treatment. Additionally, it addresses current challenges and future prospects for optimizing biofiltration performance. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.D., Nyuyki, Dzeyewir Divine; H.N., Museba, Hugues Nkomba; Y.K., Balue, Yannick Kumona; B., Lee, Bongju
Author full names: Nyuyki, Dzeyewir Divine (59408720300); Museba, Hugues Nkomba (58310928400); Balue, Yannick Kumona (59408384200); Lee, Bongju (24471760800)
Title: Abatement of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and fluorine gases by a microwave plasma torch (MPT)
Affiliations: Handong Global University, Pohang, South Korea; Handong Global University, Pohang, South Korea; Green Science Corporation, Taebaek-si, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Nyuyki, Dzeyewir Divine, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Handong Global University, Pohang, South Korea; Museba, Hugues Nkomba, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Handong Global University, Pohang, South Korea; Balue, Yannick Kumona, Department of Advanced Green Energy and Environment, Handong Global University, Pohang, South Korea; Lee, Bongju, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Handong Global University, Pohang, South Korea, Department of Advanced Green Energy and Environment, Handong Global University, Pohang, South Korea, Green Science Corporation, Taebaek-si, South Korea
Abstract: The use of microwave plasma torch (MPT) in the abatement of potent greenhouse and fluorinated (F-gases) gases is crucial due to their high global warming potential. The purpose of this study was the abatement of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and carbon tetrafluoride (CF4) using specifically designed reverse vortex flow reactor (RVR) and pillar of fire reactor (POF). The RVR has properties that are crucial for their synergistic effects with the MPT, and the POF configurations showed high-efficiency combustion due to plasma radicals and a large contact area with the MPT. The study used Aspen Plus and COMSOL software to analyse the mass balance involved in the thermal decomposition of isopropyl alcohol (C₃H₈O) and CF<inf>4</inf> and to design the RVR and POF reactors. Using MPT without hydrocarbon fuel, low-concentration C₃H₈O and CF<inf>4</inf> were successfully destroyed in high-flow streams. The experiment on C₃H₈O showed that using a plasma power of 2 kW and 1 cubic meter per minute (CMM) of bulk gas, a destruction removal efficiency (DRE) of 95 % was achieved for a polluted C₃H₈O of 410 ppm. In a second experiment, a DRE of 94 % was achieved for a polluted C₃H₈O of 370 ppm. The first CF<inf>4</inf> experiment achieved a DRE of 93.3 % with a 7 kW plasma power and 1 CMM bulk gas polluted at 285 ppm. In the second experiment, the presence of highly reactive hydroxyl radicals (OH*) in steam plasma improved the DRE to 99.8 % at 7 kW plasma power and 100 LPM bulk polluted at 180 ppm. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Q., Jiang, Qi; H., Zhao, He; Z., Xu, Zhongjun; S., Zhang, Song; S., Chen, Shaobo; G., Zhu, Guangxiao
Title: Modulation of Oxygen Vacancies and Surface Acidity in MnxCeyO Catalysts via Microemulsion Enhances the Catalytic Ozonation of p-xylene
Affiliations: Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Jiang, Qi, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China; Zhao, He, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China; Xu, Zhongjun, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China; Zhang, Song, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China; Chen, Shaobo, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China; Zhu, Guangxiao, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China
Abstract: P-xylene (PX), a compound with high photochemical activity, is widely used in the production of polyester fibers, resins, paints, dyes, and pesticides. Catalytic ozonation technology effectively degrades PX at low temperatures. The oxygen vacancy density and surface acidity of Mn<inf>x</inf>Ce<inf>y</inf>O catalysts were modulated using a microemulsion method. The results revealed that the structural defects formed in the Mn/Ce composite oxides enhanced the oxygen vacancies on the catalysts. By adjusting the Mn/Ce molar ratio and the W/O (water/oil) mass ratio in the microemulsion, Mn<inf>x</inf>Ce<inf>y</inf>O catalysts enriched with oxygen vacancies and surface acidic sites were obtained. The optimal microemulsion conditions were identified as a Mn/Ce molar ratio of 1 and a W/O mass ratio of 0.2. The catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance, achieving p-xylene (PX) conversion and mineralization rates of approximately 100% and 72%, respectively. The proposed mechanism of catalytic ozonation suggests that the benzene ring of PX was broken by O<inf>3</inf> activated on the catalyst, and the produced intermediate gradually demethylated to form a series of chain alkanes, which were oxidized to ketones and aldehydes compounds and finally decomposed to CO<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F., Qi, Fei; J., Shen, Jun; W., Wang, Weidong; Y., Chen, Yu; D., Zheng, Dezong; L., Li, Lin
Title: Effect of morphological control of La/MnO2 on catalytic oxidation of low-concentration toluene; 形貌调控对 La / MnO2 低质量浓度甲苯催化氧化性能的影响
Affiliations: Northeast Forestry University, Harbin, China; Neimenggu Agricultural University, Hohhot, China
Authors with affiliations: Qi, Fei, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin, China; Shen, Jun, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin, China; Wang, Weidong, College of Material Science and Art Design, Neimenggu Agricultural University, Hohhot, China; Chen, Yu, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin, China; Zheng, Dezong, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin, China; Li, Lin, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin, China
Abstract: Furniture and wooden materials are known to emit volatile organic compounds (VOCs), such as toluene, which pose significant health risks. This study investigated a highly efficient approach to the catalytic oxidation of low- concentration toluene, offering a practical and impactful solution for improving indoor air quality. Despite the increasing attention to toluene emissions, research on the catalytic oxidation of low-concentration toluene remains limited. To address this gap, the catalytic performance of La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> catalysts synthesized via hydrothermal methods was evaluated. La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> catalysts with various morphologies (particles, flowers, rods, and sheets) were successfully synthesized. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis revealed that both the precursor materials and hydrothermal synthesis temperature significantly influenced catalyst crystallinity. Among the four morphologies, La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> nanosheets (NS) exhibited the lowest crystallinity, which likely resulted in more surface defects, thus enhancing catalytic activity. La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> nanosheets exhibited a highly porous surface with a combination of high specific surface area, mesopores, and a small fraction of micropores, facilitating the effective adsorption of low-concentration toluene. Additionally, the NS catalyst showed a significantly higher Mn3+ / Mn4+ ratio compared to the other morphologies, which facilitates the formation of oxygen vacancies. The ratio of lattice oxygen to adsorbed oxygen was nearly identical for the NS, and the lower desorption temperature of lattice oxygen further promoted the conversion of toluene to benzoate. The catalytic activity for low-concentration toluene oxidation followed this order: La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> nanosheets > La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> nanoparticles > La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> nanowires > La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> nanoflowers. Notably, the La-doped NS catalyst exhibited a higher proportion of Mn3+ and better catalytic performance than the undoped catalysts. At 40 ℃, the NS catalyst achieved a 40% toluene removal rate, demonstrating excellent durability and reusability. The NS catalyst maintained strong catalytic performance during both the initial and long-term stages, providing a reliable foundation for practical applications. Further testing revealed that, at 200 ℃, the La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> nanosheets achieved up to 90% toluene removal and maintained stable catalytic activity for up to 11 h. The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis showed that the combination of La doping and the sheet-like structure promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies and low-valence manganese, which played a crucial role in enhancing the oxidation process and facilitating the transformation of oxygen species. In conclusion, the La/ MnO<inf>2</inf> nanosheets, especially with La doping, exhibited excellent catalytic performance, stability, and reusability, highlighting their strong potential for removing indoor VOCs such as toluene. With their promising catalytic activity and durability, further research into their scalability for large-scale air purification applications is highly encouraged. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Catalyst Morphology; Catalytic Oxidation; La/ Mno2; Toluene

Authors: S., Zhang, Shaoyu; L., Yao, Lu; B., Xu, Bo; L., Yang, Lin; Z., Dai, Zhongde; W., Jiang, Wenju
Title: Recent advances in zeolite-based materials for volatile organic compounds adsorption
Affiliations: Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; National Engineering Research Centre for Flue Gas Desulfurization, Chengdu, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Shaoyu, College of Architecture and Environment, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Yao, Lu, College of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China, National Engineering Research Centre for Flue Gas Desulfurization, Chengdu, China; Xu, Bo, College of Architecture and Environment, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Yang, Lin, College of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China, National Engineering Research Centre for Flue Gas Desulfurization, Chengdu, China; Dai, Zhongde, College of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China, National Engineering Research Centre for Flue Gas Desulfurization, Chengdu, China; Jiang, Wenju, College of Carbon Neutrality Future Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China, National Engineering Research Centre for Flue Gas Desulfurization, Chengdu, China
Abstract: Massive exhaust emissions containing low-concentration volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are widespread in the pharmaceutical, petroleum, and chemical industries, posing a significant hazard to the environment and human health. Among various VOCs removal technologies, adsorption technology has been widely applied due to its high purification efficiency and low operating cost. Zeolites with good thermal stability and adjustable pore structure advantages, have been driven as a promising adsorbent to achieve efficient adsorption and purification of VOCs. This review briefed on the fundamentals of VOCs adsorption technology, and provides a comprehensive analysis of the adsorbent reactions on zeolites from the perspective of thermodynamics and kinetics. Besides, rational design strategies for VOCs adsorbents applied to water-containing conditions are comprehensively discussed in terms of adsorption performance modification and water resistance modulation. The current status of the study and potential areas for further innovation are presented. Hopefully, this review can bridge the gap between developed zeolites and VOCs contained exhaust purification to realize engineering. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Qu, Miaomiao; Z., Sun, Zhirong; Z., Cheng, Zhuowei; J., Zhao, Jingkai; J., Yu, Jianming; R., Zhou, Renlei; J., You, Juping; W., Wang, Wenjun; J., Chen, Jianmeng
Author full names: Qu, Miaomiao (57220635863); Sun, Zhirong (57226125752); Cheng, Zhuowei (23995091100); Zhao, Jingkai (56285958400); Yu, Jianming (55682065200); Zhou, Renlei (59308368500); You, Juping (57196458524); Wang, Wenjun (57203758312); Chen, Jianmeng (55656094900)
Title: Dielectric barrier discharge plasma for chlorobenzene removal: Performance optimization, process modeling, and toxicity evaluation
Affiliations: Zhejiang University of Science and Technology, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Qu, Miaomiao, School of Environment and Natural Resources, Zhejiang University of Science and Technology, Hangzhou, China, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Sun, Zhirong, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Cheng, Zhuowei, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Zhao, Jingkai, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Yu, Jianming, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Zhou, Renlei, School of Environment and Natural Resources, Zhejiang University of Science and Technology, Hangzhou, China; You, Juping, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Wenjun, School of Environment and Natural Resources, Zhejiang University of Science and Technology, Hangzhou, China; Chen, Jianmeng, School of Environment and Natural Resources, Zhejiang University of Science and Technology, Hangzhou, China, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: Bio-purification has been recognized as an effective method of removal of volatile organic pollutants (VOCs), yet exist a technical bottleneck of low removal efficiency in the treatment of high toxicity and low water-soluble VOCs, especially chlorobenzene (CB). Herein, dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) technology was used as a pre-treatment technology, and the effect of process parameters (specific input of energy (SIE), inlet concentration of CB, humidity, and discharge length) of DBD on the removal performance of CB was analyzed, in order to investigate the feasibility of DBD as a pre-treatment approach for bio-purification. Taking energy yield, by-product analysis and exhaust evaluation as considerations, an SIE of 1,131.57 J·L-1, an inlet CB concentration of 300 ppm, a humidity of 50 %, and a discharge length of 10 cm were selected as the most suitable experimental conditions for the air DBD reactor. The temperature of gas flow was analyzed. Results suggested that DBD have no adverse thermal effect on the subsequent biotechnology (decreased by about 8 K during the discharge process). The temperature change caused by the degradation of CB (e.g., phenyl ring-opening and other processes) accounts for about 90 % of the total temperature change, where remaining part of temperature decreased caused by the large number of active substances produced by electron excitation, collision and cracking during discharge. The regulation of short-life active substances (e.g., ·NO, ·NO<inf>2</inf>,·OH, and O<inf>2</inf>–·) further reduced the toxicity of the outlet gas generated by DBD through affect the contents the long-life active substances (e.g., H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf>, and O<inf>3</inf>). This study provides a better understanding of the feasibility of DBD as a treatment for bio-purification and a new coupling technology for the effective removal of CB. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Ten Scientific & Technological Challenges and Strategies for Soil Pollution Prevention and Remediation of Contaminated Industrial Sites in China; 我国工业场地土壤污染防治十大科技问题与对策
Affiliations: Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Anhui Normal University, Wuhu, China
Authors with affiliations: Yan, Jingchun, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Song, Jing, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Sun, Yuyuan, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, China; Tang, Wei, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Liu, Rui, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Yan, Zichen, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Liu, Yuxin, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China, School of Ecology and Environment, Anhui Normal University, Wuhu, China; Yao, Yijun, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Luo, Yongming, Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Abstract: Since the launch of the ‘10th Five-Year Plan’, China has spent nearly 20 years developing a comprehensive system for managing and cleaning up contaminated industrial sites. As the country enters a phase of high-quality development, with a focus on green and low-carbon initiatives, the prevention and control of soil contamination at these sites faces both challenges and new opportunities. This paper reviews progress in technologies for the prevention and remediation of contaminated industrial sites in China, evaluates current needs, and identifies ten major scientific and technical challenges across five key areas: soil environmental standards, pollution mechanisms, monitoring and regulatory technologies, remediation techniques, and decision-support systems. It highlights specific gaps, including limited scientific support for soil standards, unclear pollution mechanisms for certain contaminants, incomplete sampling and monitoring systems, insufficient green remediation technologies, and a lack of comprehensive decision-making tools. Based on China′s national conditions and global trends, the paper proposes several strategies: strengthening research on soil standards, deepening the study of pollution mechanisms, improving monitoring systems, advancing green remediation technologies, and building an information and intelligence-based decision-support system. These efforts aim to drive scientific and technological innovation, promoting coordinated development across disciplines, technologies as well as the soil remediation industry. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Sun, Yulin; Y., Zhang, Yiwei; B., Hou, Baoqing; Y., He, Yong; W.B., Weng, Wubin Bin; Y., Zhu, Yanqun; Z., Wang, Zhihua
Title: Catalytic Ozonation of Formaldehyde with an Oxygen-Vacancy-Rich MnOx/γ-Al2O3 Catalyst at Room Temperature
Affiliations: National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; Shanghai Maritime University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Yulin, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; Zhang, Yiwei, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; Hou, Baoqing, College of Ocean Science and Engineering, Shanghai Maritime University, Shanghai, China; He, Yong, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; Weng, Wubin Bin, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; Zhu, Yanqun, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Zhihua, National Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Energy Utilization, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: Formaldehyde (HCHO) is known as one of the important indoor organic pollutants. How to remove and decompose the low concentration of formaldehyde at room temperature is important for indoor environments. Catalytic ozonation is an efficient method to thoroughly remove HCHO at room temperature, with high efficiency and few byproducts. A series of MnO<inf>x</inf>/γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalysts were prepared in this work via the impregnation method and treated with different reagents (acid, alkali, and H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf>) to evaluate their catalytic activity for HCHO removal. The results showed that MnAl-II (acid treatment) performed well in activity tests, reaching a nearly 100% HCHO conversion at an O<inf>3</inf>/HCHO of 2.0 and attaining a CO<inf>2</inf> selectivity of above 95% at an O<inf>3</inf>/HCHO of 3.0 at 30 °C, with almost no ozone residual existing. The larger specific surface area, abundant oxygen vacancies, and higher number of acid sites contributed to the excellent performance of MnAl-II. Stability and H<inf>2</inf>O resistance tests of MnAl-II were also conducted. To reveal the intermediate product formation and further investigate the reaction mechanism of HCHO ozonation, in-situ DRIFTS measurement was carried out combined with DFT calculations. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Catalytic Ozonation; Formaldehyde; Low Temperature; Mnox/γ-al2o3; Reaction Mechanism

Authors: Y., Cheng, Yizhen; Z., Chen, Zhonglin; J., Bi, Jinhong; S., Wang, Shaobin; X., Duan, Xiaoguang
Author full names: Cheng, Yizhen (57369414600); Chen, Zhonglin (57202832804); Bi, Jinhong (16835830200); Wang, Shaobin (7410345755); Duan, Xiaoguang (57218125905)
Title: Surface coordination species in heterogeneous catalytic ozonation for water purification
Affiliations: Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, China; The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, Yizhen, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, China, School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Chen, Zhonglin, School of Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China; Bi, Jinhong, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, China; Wang, Shaobin, School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Duan, Xiaoguang, School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia
Abstract: Heterogeneous catalytic ozonation (HCO) becomes a promising advanced oxidation process for water purification due to its strong portability and applicability. Although many efforts have been made to explore the radical-based catalytic mechanism in traditional HCO processes, they are susceptible to co-existing impurities in natural water. Hence, achieving non-radical and selective oxidation in the catalyst surface region is an important strategy to overcome this bottleneck and attain high chemical utilization efficiency. Despite a handful of studies having been conducted for the non-radical ozonation system, the associated mechanism has not been fully elucidated yet. In this perspective, the surface coordination species in different HCO catalysts are deliberately discussed, including (1) surface-adsorbed H<inf>2</inf>O or surface-OH, (2) surface-adsorbed oxygen species, and (3) surface-organic-O<inf>3</inf> complex. The limitations and prospects of these surface coordination species in HCO were highlighted to arouse attention in future applications. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Heterogeneous Catalytic Ozonation; Surface Coordination Species; Surface Oxidation; Water Purification

Authors: G., Gan, Guangmei; Z., Yang, Zhixiong; Y., Li, Yuan; G., Zhang, Gaoke
Author full names: Gan, Guangmei (59177990900); Yang, Zhixiong (57203316219); Li, Yuan (57191852916); Zhang, Gaoke (8337278200)
Title: Efficient photothermal mineralization of toluene over MnCo2O4 with different exposed facets: Revealing the role of oxygen vacancy and photo-/thermo- synergistic mechanism
Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Silicate Materials for Architectures, Wuhan, China
Authors with affiliations: Gan, Guangmei, Key Laboratory of Green Utilization of Critical Non-metallic Mineral Resources, State Key Laboratory of Silicate Materials for Architectures, Wuhan, China; Yang, Zhixiong, Key Laboratory of Green Utilization of Critical Non-metallic Mineral Resources, State Key Laboratory of Silicate Materials for Architectures, Wuhan, China; Li, Yuan, Key Laboratory of Green Utilization of Critical Non-metallic Mineral Resources, State Key Laboratory of Silicate Materials for Architectures, Wuhan, China; Zhang, Gaoke, Key Laboratory of Green Utilization of Critical Non-metallic Mineral Resources, State Key Laboratory of Silicate Materials for Architectures, Wuhan, China
Abstract: Modulating oxygen vacancies through facet engineering is a potential strategy to enhance activity of photo-/thermo- synergistic catalysis for toluene mineralization. Hence, we synthesized MnCo<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> catalysts with exposed {01−1} facets (MCO-R), {1−1−2} facets MCO-S), and {1−10} facets (MCO-C), in which the MCO-R with the highest oxygen vacancy concentration exhibited the highest toluene conversion (95.8 %) and CO<inf>2</inf> yield (85.5 %) under the full-spectrum light irradiation. The results of various characterizations and DFT calculations confirmed that the oxygen vacancy could accelerate the activation of lattice oxygen and molecule oxygen, thereby enhancing the photothermal catalytic toluene activity of MnCo<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf>. Meanwhile, the results of performance evaluations identified that the efficient photothermal mineralization activity of toluene was induced by the photo-/thermo- synergistic catalysis. Besides, the reaction pathway studies by In-situ DRIFTS tests revealed the key role of oxygen vacancy and photo-/thermo- synergistic effects in the reaction progress of photothermal mineralization of toluene over MnCo<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf>. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J., Lu, Jichang; W., Mu, Weihong; C., Qin, Chuanyun; T., Liu, Ting; Z., Xu, Zhizhi; W., Zhu, Wenjie; J., Fang, Jian; T., Ai, Tianhao; R., Tian, Rui; L., Zhang, Lei
Title: Synchronous catalytic elimination of malodorous mercaptans based VOCs: Controlling byproducts and revealing sites-pathway relationship
Affiliations: Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Yancheng Institute of Technology, Yancheng, China
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Jichang, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Mu, Weihong, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Qin, Chuanyun, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Liu, Ting, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Xu, Zhizhi, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Zhu, Wenjie, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Fang, Jian, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Ai, Tianhao, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Tian, Rui, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; Zhang, Lei, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Yancheng Institute of Technology, Yancheng, China
Abstract: Controlling byproducts and unveiling “sites-pathway” relationship during synchronous catalytic degradation of sulfur-containing VOCs mixtures remains a huge challenge due to their variability, multi-components and multiple-sites characteristics. This work proposes the competitive adsorption combined with bifunctional catalysts as a strategy to avoid malodorous sulfur-containing byproducts. Experimental and theoretical researches demonstrated that ceria incorporated ZSM-5 was a bifunctional material with the coupled, but geometrically separated oxygen site and acid site, while praseodymium-incorporated one was a dual acid site catalyst. A “sites-pathway” relationship for decomposing a mixture of methyl mercaptan (CH<inf>3</inf>SH) and ethyl mercaptan (C<inf>2</inf>H<inf>5</inf>SH) was revealed, i.e., C<inf>2</inf>H<inf>5</inf>SH occupies preferentially on acid site, whereas CH<inf>3</inf>SH is converted into intermediate of CH<inf>3</inf>SCH<inf>3</inf> over acid site, and then CH<inf>3</inf>SCH<inf>3</inf> is forced to occupy on oxygen site, which accelerates the oxidation of CH<inf>3</inf>SCH<inf>3</inf> to CO<inf>2</inf>. This work provides mechanistic understanding of “sites-pathway” relationship to control toxic byproducts for simultaneous catalytic degradation of sulfur-containing VOCs mixtures. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Application of artificial intelligence tools in wastewater and waste gas treatment systems: Recent advances and prospects
Affiliations: Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore, India; Alagappa College of Technology, Chennai, India; Karunya Institute of Technology and Sciences, Coimbatore, India; Indian Statistical Institute Bangalore, Bengaluru, India; University of Technology and Applied Sciences Sur, Sur, Oman; Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; Saveetha Dental College And Hospitals, Chennai, India; Annamalai University, Chidambaram, India; Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore, India; Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati, India; IHE Delft Institute for Water Education, Delft, Netherlands

K., Systems Science and Informatics Unit, Indian Statistical Institute Bangalore, Bengaluru, India; Zafar, Mohd, Department of Applied Biotechnology, University of Technology and Applied Sciences Sur, Sur, Oman; Divya, Baskaran, Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea, Department of Biomaterials, Saveetha Dental College And Hospitals, Chennai, India; Ravi, Rajamanickam, Department of Chemical Engineering, Annamalai University, Chidambaram, India; Raja, Das K., Department of Mathematics, Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore, India; Pakshirajan, Kannan, Department of Biosciences and Bioengineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati, India; Bilyaminu, Abubakar M., Department of Water Supply, IHE Delft Institute for Water Education, Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: The non-linear complex relationships among the process variables in wastewater and waste gas treatment systems possess a significant challenge for real-time systems modelling. Data driven artificial intelligence (AI) tools are increasingly being adopted to predict the process performance, cost-effective process monitoring, and the control of different waste treatment systems, including those involving resource recovery. This review presents an in-depth analysis of the applications of emerging AI tools in physico-chemical and biological processes for the treatment of air pollutants, water and wastewater, and resource recovery processes. Additionally, the successful implementation of AI-controlled wastewater and waste gas treatment systems, along with real-time monitoring at the industrial scale are discussed. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: X., Wang, Xiaowen; T., Ma, Teng; J., Ma, Jiangong; P., Cheng, Peng
Title: Integration of devices based on metal–organic frameworks: A promising platform for chemical sensing
Affiliations: Nankai University, Tianjin, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Xiaowen, Department of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin, China; Ma, Teng, Department of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin, China; Ma, Jiangong, Department of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin, China; Cheng, Peng, Department of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin, China
Abstract: Chemical sensor devices are rapidly developing due to the demand for healthcare, environmental monitoring, manufacturing industry and smart home. Unlike traditional materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) exhibit excellent prospects in chemical sensing devices due to the designability of metals and ligands, tunable pore size and abundant functional sites. By integrating MOFs with devices, the excellent sensing performance of MOFs and the portability of devices have been combined, making them stand out in areas such as gas detection and disease diagnosis. Here, we summarize the basic methods for combining MOFs with devices, the sensing mechanisms and chemical sensor devices based on MOFs in recent years, including electrochemical, electronic, electromechanical and optoelectronic sensor and devices. Finally, inspired by previous studies, the drawbacks and future prospects of chemical sensing devices based on MOFs are presented. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Zhu, Yuxue; W., Liang, Wenjun; C., Zhang, Chenhang; F., Bin, Feng; Q., Tao, Qianyu
Title: Defect-Rich Regulatory Activity Strategy: Disordered Structure for Enhanced Catalytic Interfacial Reaction of Chlorobenzene
Affiliations: Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Institute of Mechanics Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, Yuxue, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Liang, Wenjun, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Zhang, Chenhang, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China, State Key Laboratory of High Temperature Gas Dynamics, Institute of Mechanics Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Bin, Feng, State Key Laboratory of High Temperature Gas Dynamics, Institute of Mechanics Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Tao, Qianyu, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China
Abstract: In contrast to previous defect engineering methods, the preparation of amorphous materials can obtain abundant defect sites through a simple way, which is expected to effectively degrade Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) under milder conditions. However, in-depth and systematic studies in this area are still lacking. Novel types of amorphous CeMn<inf>x</inf> catalysts with abundant defects were prepared through simple hydrothermal synthesis and used for Cl-VOCs catalysis for the first time. Experimental characterizations and DFT calculations proved that Ce doping induced MnO<inf>2</inf> lattice distortion, which led to the transformation of CeMn<inf>x</inf> into an amorphous structure and the formation of abundant defect sites. It was observed that CeMn<inf>0.16</inf> was able to eliminate chlorobenzene (CB) at 200 °C, and the CO<inf>2</inf> yields and the selectivity of inorganic chlorine was significantly higher than that of MnO<inf>2</inf>. The 18O isotope kinetic experiments revealed that the interfacial reaction process followed the MVK mechanism. The large number of oxygen vacancies accelerated the migration of lattice oxygen from the interior to the exterior, enhancing the ability to trap gas-phase oxygen. Mn4+ acted as the main active center to participate in CB catalysis, and the resulting reactive oxygen species (ROS) and Mn3+-[O2-]-Ce4+ further accelerated the entire oxidation cycle. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Huang, Haibao; X., Xie, Xiaowen; F., Xiao, Fei; B., Liu, Biyuan; T., Zhang, Tao; F., Feng, Fada; B., Lan, Bang; C., Zhang, Chao
Title: A Critical Review of Deep Oxidation of Gaseous Volatile Organic Compounds via Aqueous Advanced Oxidation Processes
Affiliations: Xinjiang University, Urumqi, China; Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Jiaying University, Meizhou, China; South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; Nan'an SCNU Institute of Green and Low-carbon Research, Quanzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Haibao, College of Ecology and Environment, Xinjiang University, Urumqi, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Xie, Xiaowen, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China, School of Chemistry and Environment, Jiaying University, Meizhou, China, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China, Nan'an SCNU Institute of Green and Low-carbon Research, Quanzhou, China; Xiao, Fei, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Liu, Biyuan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Zhang, Tao, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Feng, Fada, School of Chemistry and Environment, Jiaying University, Meizhou, China; Lan, Bang, School of Chemistry and Environment, Jiaying University, Meizhou, China; Zhang, Chao, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China, Nan'an SCNU Institute of Green and Low-carbon Research, Quanzhou, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are considered to be the most recalcitrant gaseous pollutants due to their high toxicity, diversity, complexity, and stability. Gas-solid catalytic oxidation methods have been intensively studied for VOC treatment while being greatly hampered by energy consumption, catalyst deactivation, and byproduct formation. Recently, aqueous advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) have attracted increasing interest for the deep oxidation of VOCs at room temperature, owing to the generation of abundant reactive oxygen species (ROS). However, current reviews mainly focus on VOC degradation performance and have not clarified the specific reaction process, degradation products, and paths of VOCs in different AOPs. This study systematically reviews recent advances in the application of aqueous AOPs for gaseous VOC removal. First, the VOC gas-liquid mass transfer and chemical oxidation processes are presented. Second, the latest research progress of VOC removal by various ROS is reviewed to study their degradation performances, pathways, and mechanisms. Finally, the current challenges and future strategies are discussed from the perspectives of synergistic oxidation of VOC mixtures, accurate oxidation, and resource utilization of target VOCs via aqueous AOPs. This perspective provides the latest information and research inspiration for the future industrial application of aqueous AOPs for VOC waste gas treatment. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Zhong, Tao; X., Long, Xianhu; M., Luo, Manhui; S., Tang, Su; W., Huang, Wenbin; H., Zhao, Huinan; L., Hu, Lingling; S., Tian, Shuanghong; D., Shu, Dong; C., He, Chun
Title: Local microenvironment modulation of Pt0/Pt2+ nano-clusters inducing synchronous mass transfer effect to boost catalytic ozonation
Affiliations: Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhong, Tao, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Long, Xianhu, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Luo, Manhui, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Tang, Su, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Huang, Wenbin, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Zhao, Huinan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Hu, Lingling, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Tian, Shuanghong, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Shu, Dong, School of Chemistry, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; He, Chun, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: Rational catalyst structure design is expected to solve the low O<inf>3</inf> utilization and poor molecular mass transfer efficiency in heterogeneous catalytic ozonation (HCO). Herein, Pt/CMK-3 catalyst with confined space to enhance mass transfer was synthesized and employed for CH<inf>3</inf>SH removal. Unlike fully free diffusion in 0–2.0 wt% Pt/CMK-3 and bulk phase diffusion in 10.0 wt% Pt/CMK-3, removal efficiency of 5.0 wt% Pt/CMK-3 was significantly improved to 97.0%, which was attributed to the effective interfacial diffusion of O<inf>3</inf> and CH<inf>3</inf>SH through local microenvironment modulation of Pt0/Pt2+ nanoclusters (NCs) inducing synchronous mass transfer. Experimental and DFT calculations confirmed the strong electronic interactions between O<inf>3</inf> and Pt0 facilitated charge redistribution and preferential O<inf>3</inf> activation. AIMD simulation demonstrated that the synchronous difference in mean-square displacements (MSD) and diffusion coefficient (Dc) of CH<inf>3</inf>SH (Dc=0.022) and O<inf>3</inf> (Dc=0.0046) in the confined Pt/CMK-3 system could facilitate CH<inf>3</inf>SH migrate to Pt2+ through interfacial diffusion. Especially, the d-orbital electrons of Pt NCs interact sequentially with p-orbital electrons of CH<inf>3</inf>SH and O<inf>3</inf> to maintain redox of Pt0/Pt2+. This study provides novel insights on effective mass transfer and kinetic properties of gaseous reaction between oxidant and pollutant by constructing unique interfacial diffusion behaviors. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Song, Shengnan; M., Wen, Meicheng; W., Zhao, Weina; J., Kong, Jiejing; G., Li, Guiying; T., An, Taicheng
Author full names: Song, Shengnan (57219030468); Wen, Meicheng (54386303000); Zhao, Weina (57208514988); Kong, Jiejing (56608612600); Li, Guiying (7407051300); An, Taicheng (7004832388)
Title: Modulation mechanism of Mn-O strength in α-MnO2 catalyst for high-efficiency catalytic combustion of propane
Affiliations: Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Song, Shengnan, Institute of Environmental Health and Pollution Control, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Wen, Meicheng, Institute of Environmental Health and Pollution Control, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Zhao, Weina, Institute of Environmental Health and Pollution Control, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Kong, Jiejing, Institute of Environmental Health and Pollution Control, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Li, Guiying, Institute of Environmental Health and Pollution Control, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; An, Taicheng, Institute of Environmental Health and Pollution Control, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: The cleavage of C-H with high energy impedes the catalytic combustion of propane. Herein, α-MnO<inf>2</inf> with modulation of Mn-O strength by changing the calcination temperature was applied in propane catalytic combustion. α-MnO<inf>2</inf> calcinated at 350 °C (α-MnO<inf>2</inf>-350) exhibited superior performance (T<inf>20</inf>=150 °C, T<inf>90</inf>= 220 °C) in propane oxidation due to the synergistic effect of oxygen vacancies (OVs) and Lewis acidity. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the lowest o-vacancy formation energy on α-MnO<inf>2</inf>-350 (E<inf>vo</inf>=0.74 eV) with its lowest Mn-O strength prompted the existence of abundant OVs and propane oxidation. Moreover, the highest Lewis acidity in α-MnO<inf>2</inf>-350 displayed the strongest propane adsorption, promoting the activation of C-H. The mineralization of propane on α-MnO<inf>2</inf>-350 dropped steeply after 68 h while could recover to 90 % in long-term water vapor stability test owing to the H<inf>2</inf>O adsorbed at OVs and the carbonaceous intermediates adsorbed at the Lewis acid sites. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., Kulkarni, Deepali; D.K., Jaspal, Dipika Kaur; N.P., Itankar, Nilisha P.; P., Petrounias, Petros; A., Rogkala, Aikaterini; P.G., Lampropoulou, Paraskevi G.
Author full names: Kulkarni, Deepali (58731931100); Jaspal, Dipika Kaur (55324154600); Itankar, Nilisha P. (56178034300); Petrounias, Petros (57195981598); Rogkala, Aikaterini (57195979298); Lampropoulou, Paraskevi G. (7801591575)
Title: Bleaching Agents: A Review of Their Utilization and Management
Affiliations: Symbiosis Institute of Technology, Pune, India; University of Patras, Rio, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Kulkarni, Deepali, Department of Applied Sciences, Symbiosis Institute of Technology, Pune, India; Jaspal, Dipika Kaur, Department of Applied Sciences, Symbiosis Institute of Technology, Pune, India; Itankar, Nilisha P., Department of Applied Sciences, Symbiosis Institute of Technology, Pune, India; Petrounias, Petros, Department of Geology, University of Patras, Rio, Greece; Rogkala, Aikaterini, Department of Geology, University of Patras, Rio, Greece; Lampropoulou, Paraskevi G., Department of Geology, University of Patras, Rio, Greece
Abstract: Exposure to disinfectants, cleansers, and bleaching chemicals irritates the eyes, respiratory systems, and skin, triggering asthma and allergic rhinitis symptoms. Bleach, as the major constituent of cleansers, when used improperly or mixed with other indoor cleaning agents, produces harmful halogenated volatile organic compounds. This manuscript assesses the influence of excessive exposure to disinfectants, including bleaching agents, when used against infectious conditions related to SARS-COVID-19 and its management. The use and impact of different bleaching agents in cleansing and their associated problems have been analyzed and presented in this review. This analysis focuses on the conventional and post-pandemic approach towards bleaches. Usage of bleaching agents increased by a staggering 20.4% and 16.4% from January to March 2020 compared to the same period in 2018 and 2019. Mounting use of bleaching agents during the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in negative health effects like asthma, eye irritation, and skin allergies. An approximately 42% rise in poisoning cases, including a few deaths, has been associated with exposure to harmful chemicals involving bleaches during the recent pandemic. Bleaching agents are the primary sources of hazardous indoor pollutants; therefore, despite their importance in disinfection, their utility must be substantiated based on legal guidelines, disposal, and remedial measures. Thus, conducting future occupational exposure assessment studies for bleach hazard management is crucial. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
