Authors: K., Altof, Kristen; M., Krichevskaya, Marina; S.V., Preis, Sergei V.; J., Bolobajev, Juri
Author full names: Altof, Kristen (58813160000); Krichevskaya, Marina (23983079300); Preis, Sergei V. (7003331897); Bolobajev, Juri (56181845400)
Title: Oxidation of Airborne m-Xylene in Pulsed Corona Discharge: Impact of Water Sprinkling
Affiliations: Tallinna Tehnikaülikool, Tallinn, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Altof, Kristen, Department of Materials and Environmental Technology, Tallinna Tehnikaülikool, Tallinn, Estonia; Krichevskaya, Marina, Department of Materials and Environmental Technology, Tallinna Tehnikaülikool, Tallinn, Estonia; Preis, Sergei V., Department of Materials and Environmental Technology, Tallinna Tehnikaülikool, Tallinn, Estonia; Bolobajev, Juri, Department of Materials and Environmental Technology, Tallinna Tehnikaülikool, Tallinn, Estonia
Abstract: Plasma from electric discharges can be used in the abatement of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The application of gas-phase pulsed corona discharge (PCD) in air–water mixtures provides favorable conditions for the oxidation of VOCs at unsurpassed energy efficiency. This research investigates the impact of water sprinkling on PCD performance in the oxidation of m-xylene as a model compound. Experimental research into the plasma treatment of continuous air flow was undertaken using the PCD reactor in dry and water-sprinkled modes. Water sprinkling more than doubled the m-xylene oxidation rate, which can be attributed to abundant OH-radicals produced at the plasma–water interface. Water sprinkling substantially reduced the formation of nitrous oxide, which is considered to be a secondary pollutant in the outlet air. Ozone is considered a by-product helping the subsequent photocatalytic oxidation of potential residues and photocatalyst maintenance. The use of water-sprinkled PCD is a promising approach to energy-efficient abatement of VOCs. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Air Purification; Aop; Nitrous Oxide; Non-thermal Plasma; Ozone; Plug Flow Plasma Reactor; Ros; Vocs; Water Sprinkled Plasma

Authors: Y., Xia, Yunbin; Z., Lan, Ziyue; Y., Yang, Yuanyuan; M., Li, Mingli; G., Wu, Ganxue; D., Fang, Dexin; Z., Zeng, Zhenxin; H., Xiao, Hong; S., Deng, Shihuai; Y., Chu, Yinghao
Title: Defect engineering on Ce2Co1Cu1Ox catalyst surface via NaOH modification: Boosting the catalytic oxidation toluene performance by reducing intermediates and increasing ring-open ability of benzoate
Affiliations: Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Sichuan University, Chengdu, China
Authors with affiliations: Xia, Yunbin, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Lan, Ziyue, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Yang, Yuanyuan, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Li, Mingli, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Wu, Ganxue, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Fang, Dexin, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Zeng, Zhenxin, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Xiao, Hong, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Deng, Shihuai, College of Environmental Sciences, Sichuan Agricultural University, Ya'an, China; Chu, Yinghao, College of Architecture and Environment, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China
Abstract: Catalytic oxidation is still an effective approach to eliminate volatile organic compound (VOCs). In order to explore the promotion mechanism for the improvement of toluene oxidation capacity over NaOH-modified Ce<inf>2</inf>Co<inf>1</inf>Cu<inf>1</inf> catalyst (Ce<inf>2</inf>Co<inf>1</inf>Cu<inf>1</inf>-AT), NaOH-modified catalysts with similar physical-structure and chemical properties were prepared by modified co-precipitation, impregnation and etching methods, respectively. Characterization results revealed that NaOH modification could generate a large number of defects, oxygen vacancies as well as abundant active sites on the surface of Ce<inf>2</inf>Co<inf>1</inf>Cu<inf>1</inf>, the concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen species and the mobility of surface lattice oxygen species were both increased. Hence, the catalyst's redox capacity was enhanced, the accumulation rates of benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde were much lower (reduced about 69 % and 83 %, respectively), and the negative effect of the accumulation of intermediate species covering the reactive site was weakened. Benefiting from these, the toluene oxidation performance of the NaOH-modified catalysts was significantly improved, with T<inf>90</inf> (191 ℃) of Ce<inf>2</inf>Co<inf>1</inf>Cu<inf>1</inf>-AT was nearly 20 ℃ lower than that of the un-modified catalyst, which is among the best reported activity values. Additionally, it also exhibited excellent thermal stability and water resistance. This work may provide a new strategy to design and synthesize the high-efficiency VOCs catalyst. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: R., Niessner, Reinhard; A., Schaeffer, Andreas
Author full names: Niessner, Reinhard (7101793845); Schaeffer, Andreas (7102901137)
Title: Organic trace analysis: 2nd, revised edition
Affiliations: Technische Universität München, Munich, Germany; Rheinisch-Westfälische Technische Hochschule Aachen, Aachen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Niessner, Reinhard, Institute of Hydrochemistry, Technische Universität München, Munich, Germany, ; Schaeffer, Andreas, Institute for Environmental Research, Rheinisch-Westfälische Technische Hochschule Aachen, Aachen, Germany
Abstract: Organic contaminants even in very low concentrations can have toxic and ecotoxic effects on exposed organisms. Detection and quantification of such trace amounts in diverging matrices (e.g., water, air, soil, food, tissue, organisms) is challenging and great carefulness and strategic thinking is needed to get reliable results along the way from taking samples up to the final analysis. In the 2nd edition, besides revisions of existing chapters, new analytical technologies and recent application examples are presented: non-target mass spectrometric analysis, trace analysis of per- and polyfluoroalkylated "forever chemicals", organophosphorus esters (nerve agents), and micro- and nanoplastic particles in the environment. Students will learn about peculiarities and state of the art organic trace analysis and acquire basic and advanced principles of statistical evaluation of analytical results quality control strategies and good laboratory practices sampling techniques from various matrices sample treatment, enrichment and clean-up techniques chromatographic analyses including hyphenated techniques, and spectroscopy as well mass spectrometry and bioanalytical tools. An extended chapter on selected applications will transfer the theoretical understanding into applied scientific problems. Students will profit from a comprehensive and state of the art overview of organic trace analyses and from an extensive collection of relevant literature. Helpful resource for teaching. Relevant to all scientists working in trace organic analysis. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Analytical Chemistry; Chromatography; Mass Spectrometry; Organic Chemistry; Trace Analysis

Authors: C.E., Stere, Cristina Elena; M., Delarmelina, Maicon; M.W., Dlamini, Mbongiseni W.; S., Chansai, Sarayute; P.R., Davies, Philip Rosser; G.J., Hutchings, Graham John; C.R.A., Catlow, C. Richard A.; C., Hardacre, Christopher
Author full names: Stere, Cristina Elena (6603556541); Delarmelina, Maicon (56529568400); Dlamini, Mbongiseni W. (56811279900); Chansai, Sarayute (36909377500); Davies, Philip Rosser (35606910500); Hutchings, Graham John (35502091400); Catlow, C. Richard A. (58852835800); Hardacre, Christopher (56243169300)
Title: Removal and Oxidation of Low Concentration tert-Butanol from Potable Water using Nonthermal Plasma Coupled with Metal Oxide Adsorption
Affiliations: The University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom; Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom; University College London, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stere, Cristina Elena, Department of Chemical Engineering, The University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; Delarmelina, Maicon, Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom; Dlamini, Mbongiseni W., Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom; Chansai, Sarayute, Department of Chemical Engineering, The University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; Davies, Philip Rosser, Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom; Hutchings, Graham John, Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom; Catlow, C. Richard A., Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom, Department of Chemistry, University College London, London, United Kingdom; Hardacre, Christopher, Department of Chemical Engineering, The University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom
Abstract: Taste and odor are crucial factors in evaluating the quality of drinking water for consumers. Geosmin is an example of a pollutant commonly found in potable water responsible for earthy and musty taste, and odor even at low concentrations. We have investigated the use of a hybrid two-step adsorption-mineralization process for low-level volatile organic compounds removal from potable water using dielectric barrier discharge over common metal oxides (MO). The system proposed is a proof of principle with tert-butanol (TBA) used as a model compound for geosmin removal/degradation during wastewater treatment when combined with an appropriate metal oxide adsorbent. Initial assessments of the adsorption properties of titania by density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental tests indicated that the adsorption of geosmin and TBA with water present results in only weak interactions between the sorbate and the metal oxide. In contrast, the DFT results show that alumina could be a suitable adsorbent for these tertiary alcohols and were reinforced by experimental studies. We find that while there is a competitive effect between the water and TBA adsorption from gaseous/liquid feed, the VOC can be removed, and the alumina will be regenerated by the reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD). The use of alumina in conjunction with NTP leads to efficient degradation of the adsorbate and the formation of oxygenated intermediates (formates, carbonates, and carboxylate-type species), which could then be mineralized for the regeneration of the adsorbent. A reaction mechanism has been proposed based on the in-situ infrared measurements and DFT calculations, while the removal of TBA with conventional heating is indicative of a gradual desorption process as a function of temperature rather than the destruction of the adsorbate. Furthermore, steady performance was observed after several adsorption-regeneration cycles, indicating no alteration of the adsorption properties of alumina during the NTP treatment and demonstrating the potential of the approach to be applied in the treatment of high throughput of water, without the challenges faced by the biocatalysts or formation of toxic byproducts. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Adsorption; Al2o3; Plasma Dbd; Tert-butanol; Water Treatment

Authors: G., Qu, Guangfei; Y., Yang, Yixin; Y., Xu, Youxiao; C., Zhao, Chenyang; P., Ning, Ping
Title: In situ pyrolysis of Mn-doped MOF-74 metal-organic framework derived MCNOx catalysts for enhanced low-temperature catalytic performance of toluene
Affiliations: Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China; National Regional Engineering Research Center-NCW, Yunnan, China
Authors with affiliations: Qu, Guangfei, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, National Regional Engineering Research Center-NCW, Yunnan, China; Yang, Yixin, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, National Regional Engineering Research Center-NCW, Yunnan, China; Xu, Youxiao, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, National Regional Engineering Research Center-NCW, Yunnan, China; Zhao, Chenyang, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, National Regional Engineering Research Center-NCW, Yunnan, China; Ning, Ping, Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China, National Regional Engineering Research Center-NCW, Yunnan, China
Abstract: This paper focuses on the use of catalysts generated from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for the degradation of toluene in a linked non-thermal plasma/photocatalytic process. The porous tri-metal oxide catalyst (MCNOx) was derived from the metal organic framework (MOF-74) via an in situ pyrolysis strategy utilizing Mn-doped CoNi-MOF-74 as the precursor. The resulting MCNOx material exhibits a unique series of surface defects, which significantly enhances its catalytic activity. We found that MCNOx materials, due to their high specific surface area, regular porous structure, and excellent reducibility, can synergize well with NTP in the complete decomposition of toluene, which makes the NTP coupled catalytic system have better catalytic activity and CO<inf>2</inf> selectivity. The toluene conversion temperature of T90 in the NTP synergistic thermocatalytic system was 250 °C for the 5MCNOx catalyst, which was also much higher than that of 1MCNOx (256 °C), 10MCNOx (258 °C), CNOx (270 °C), and 5MCNOx catalyst in the monocatalytic system (270 °C). In addition, the catalytic stability of MOF-derived MCNOx oxides and the influence of water vapor on catalytic activity were investigated, confirming their excellent catalytic performance. Finally, the importance of Mn doping in improving toluene oxidation activity on MOF-74 derived CNOx has been demonstrated, providing a viable strategy for developing a toluene oxidation catalyst. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Ma, Mudi; R., Albilali, Reem; C., He, Chi
Title: Recent advancements and challenges in the catalytic purification of volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Imam Abdulrahman bin Faisal University, College of Science, Dammam, Saudi Arabia; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Ma, Mudi, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Albilali, Reem, Department of Chemistry, Imam Abdulrahman bin Faisal University, College of Science, Dammam, Saudi Arabia; He, Chi, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China, National Engineering Laboratory for VOCs Pollution Control Material & Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Abstract: With the development of industrialization, the emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are steadily increasing, posing a significant risk to atmospheric quality and public health. Catalytic oxidation can be a promising technology for VOC purification owing to its high efficiency and energy-saving advantages. Over the past few decades, the development of catalysts with excellent activity and lower degradation temperature for VOCs has been the main purpose of research. The research goal is gradually refined and changed as research deepens. In consideration of different types of pollutants and their actual sources, the challenges in catalyst design become more specific and practical, such as the improvement of catalyst stability, the inhibition of the generation of harmful by-products and the enhancement of resistance to impurity poisoning. Meanwhile, it is necessary to develop catalysts for simultaneous control of multiple pollutants. Concurrently, some new technologies have become research hotspots, including hydrolysis oxidation technology for CVOCs and ozone oxidation technology for VOCs. In this review, the latest advancements in the catalytic degradation of various VOCs are discussed and insights into future research directions for novel materials and technologies in VOC catalytic oxidation are further provided. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Synergistic catalytic elimination of NOx and VOCs: State of the art and open challenges
Affiliations: Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Hebei University of Science and Technology, Shijiazhuang, China
Authors with affiliations: Chu, Peiqi, Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Zhang, Long, Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Wang, Zhiwei, Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Wei, Lu, Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Liu, Yuxi, Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Dai, Hongxing, Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Duan, Erhong, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Hebei University of Science and Technology, Shijiazhuang, China; Deng, Jiguang, Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China
Abstract: Nitrogen oxide (NO<inf>x</inf>) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) pose a severe threat to human health and eco-environment. Synergistic catalytic degradation has sparked significant interest in multipollutant control, especially for industries with limited space for technological upgrades to satisfy more stringent emission regulations. However, it is still in the early stages of development and faces many issues and challenges, such as highly efficient catalyst design, uncertain reaction mechanism for multipollutant removal, impact of other components in complex flue gas on the synergistic catalytic degradation, and environmental risk assessment of synergistic catalytic degradation in terms of byproduct. This review summarizes the advantage and disadvantage of common reported catalysts for synergistic catalytic degradation, discusses the factors affecting the performance and the optimization technique from the standpoint of acidity and redox characteristics, refines the synergistic catalytic degradation mechanism and deactivation process due to the presence of toxic component, and highlights the category and formation mechanism of the potential byproduct during the synergistic catalytic degradation. It will provide a reference for ongoing in-depth research and real-world industrial application in the area of synergistic catalytic degradation of NO<inf>x</inf> and VOCs. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Catalysts; Nox; Reaction Mechanism; Synergistic Catalytic Degradation; Vocs

Authors: Y., Li, Yue; N., Jiang, Nan; Z., Liu, Zhengyan; L., Qin, Liang; B., Peng, Bangfa; R., Wang, Ronggang; Y., Sun, Yurong; J., Li, Jie
Title: Efficient activation of the Co/SBA-15 catalyst by high-frequency AC-DBD plasma thermal effects for toluene removal
Affiliations: Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China; Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China; Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Ltd., Suzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Yue, School of Environment, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China; Jiang, Nan, School of Electrical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China; Liu, Zhengyan, School of Environment, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China; Qin, Liang, School of Electrical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China; Peng, Bangfa, College of Electrical and Power Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Wang, Ronggang, Ltd., Suzhou, China; Sun, Yurong, Ltd., Suzhou, China; Li, Jie, School of Electrical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China
Abstract: Dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) plasma excited by a high-frequency alternating-current (AC) power supply is widely employed for the degradation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). However, the thermal effect generated during the discharge process leads to energy waste and low energy utilization efficiency. In this work, an innovative DBD thermally-conducted catalysis (DBD-TCC) system, integrating high-frequency AC-DBD plasma and its generated thermal effects to activate the Co/SBA-15 catalyst, was employed for toluene removal. Specifically, Co/SBA-15 catalysts are closely positioned to the ground electrode of the plasma zone and can be heated and activated by the thermal effect when the voltage exceeds 10 kV. At 12.4 kV, the temperature in the catalyst zone reached 261 °C in the DBD-TCC system, resulting in an increase in toluene degradation efficiency of 17%, CO<inf>2</inf> selectivity of 21.2%, and energy efficiency of 27%, respectively, compared to the DBD system alone. In contrast, the DBD thermally-unconducted catalysis (DBD-TUC) system fails to enhance toluene degradation due to insufficient heat absorption and catalytic activation, highlighting the crucial role of AC-DBD generated heat in the activation of the catalyst. Furthermore, the degradation pathway and mechanism of toluene in the DBD-TCC system were hypothesized. This work is expected to provide an energy-efficient approach for high-frequency AC-DBD plasma removal of VOCs. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: E.F.O., Merouani, El Farouk Omar; M., Ferdowsi, Milad; G., Buelna, Gerardo; J.P., Jones, Joseph Peter; E.H., Benyoussef, El Hadi; L., Malhautier, Luc; M.W., Heitz, Michèle W.
Author full names: Merouani, El Farouk Omar (57367116500); Ferdowsi, Milad (52563448300); Buelna, Gerardo (57196350648); Jones, Joseph Peter (55892781400); Benyoussef, El Hadi (11142267400); Malhautier, Luc (6602630988); Heitz, Michèle W. (7006738900)
Title: Exploring the potential of biofiltration for mitigating harmful gaseous emissions from small or old landfills: a review
Affiliations: Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Ecole Nationale Polytechnique, Algiers, Algeria; IMT Mines Alès, Ales, France
Authors with affiliations: Merouani, El Farouk Omar, Department of Chemical and Biotechnological Engineering, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Ferdowsi, Milad, Department of Chemical and Biotechnological Engineering, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Buelna, Gerardo, Department of Chemical and Biotechnological Engineering, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Jones, Joseph Peter, Department of Chemical and Biotechnological Engineering, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Benyoussef, El Hadi, Laboratoire de Valorisation des Énergies Fossiles, Ecole Nationale Polytechnique, Algiers, Algeria; Malhautier, Luc, Laboratoire des Sciences des Risques, IMT Mines Alès, Ales, France; Heitz, Michèle W., Department of Chemical and Biotechnological Engineering, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada
Abstract: Landfills are widely employed as the primary means of solid waste disposal. However, this practice generates landfill gas (LFG) which contains methane (CH<inf>4</inf>), a potent greenhouse gas, as well as various volatile organic compounds and volatile inorganic compounds. These emissions from landfills contribute to approximately 25% of the total atmospheric CH<inf>4</inf>, indicating the imperative need to valorize or treat LFG prior to its release into the atmosphere. This review first aims to outline landfills, waste disposal and valorization, conventional gas treatment techniques commonly employed for LFG treatment, such as flares and thermal oxidation. Furthermore, it explores biotechnological approaches as more technically and economically feasible alternatives for mitigating LFG emissions, especially in the case of small and aged landfills where CH<inf>4</inf> concentrations are often below 3% v/v. Finally, this review highlights biofilters as the most suitable biotechnological solution for LFG treatment and discusses several advantages and challenges associated with their implementation in the landfill environment. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Wu, Mengting; W., Liu, Wei; Z., Ma, Zhifei; T., Qin, Tian; Z., Chen, Zhiqin; Y., Zhang, Yalan; N., Cao, Ning; X., Xie, Xianchuan; S., Chi, Sunlin; J., Xu, Jinying
Title: Global Trends in the Research and Development of Petrochemical Waste Gas from 1981 to 2022
Affiliations: Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Nanjing University, Nanjing, China; Nanjing University, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Mengting, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Liu, Wei, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Ma, Zhifei, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Qin, Tian, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Chen, Zhiqin, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Zhang, Yalan, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Cao, Ning, Department of Applied Foreign Language Studies, Nanjing University, Nanjing, China; Xie, Xianchuan, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Chi, Sunlin, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China; Xu, Jinying, School of Resources and Environment, Nanchang University, Nanchang, China
Abstract: As a highly energy-intensive and carbon-emitting industry with significant emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), the petroleum and chemical industry is a major contributor to the global greenhouse effect and ozone layer destruction. Improper treatment of petrochemical waste gas (PWG) seriously harms human health and the natural environment. This study uses CiteSpace and VOSviewer to conduct a scientometric analysis of 1384 scholarly works on PWG and carbon sequestration published between 1981 and 2022, revealing the basic characteristics, knowledge base, research topic evolution, and research hotspots of the field. The results show the following: (1) In the early stages of the petrochemical industry, it was processed tail gas, plant leakage waste gas, and combustion flue gas that were investigated in PWG research. (2) Later, green environmental protection technology was widely studied in the field of PWG treatment, such as biotechnology, catalytic oxidation technology, membrane separation technology, etc., in order to achieve efficient, low energy consumption and low emissions of waste gas treatment, and the number of publications related to this topic has increased rapidly. In addition, researchers studied the internet of things and technology integration, such as the introduction of artificial intelligence, big data analysis, and other technologies, to improve the accuracy and efficiency of exhaust gas monitoring, control, and management. (3) The department has focused on how to reduce emissions by optimizing petrochemical process lines or improving energy efficiency. Emission reduction and low-carbon transition in the petrochemical industry will become the main trend in the future. Switching from renewable carbon to feedstock carbon derived from captured carbon dioxide, biomass, or recycled chemicals has become an attractive strategy to help curb emissions from the chemical industry. The results of our analysis can provide funding agencies and research groups with information to better understand the global trends and directions that have emerged in this field from 1981 to 2022 and serve as a reference for future research. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: W., Qu, Wei; S., Tang, Su; Z., Tang, Zhuoyun; T., Zhong, Tao; H., Zhao, Huinan; S., Tian, Shuanghong; D., Shu, Dong; C., He, Chun
Title: Refining Asymmetric Low-Coordinated Fe-N3 Motif to Boost Catalytic Ozonation Activity
Affiliations: Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Qu, Wei, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Tang, Su, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Tang, Zhuoyun, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Zhong, Tao, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Zhao, Huinan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Tian, Shuanghong, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China; Shu, Dong, School of Chemistry, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China; He, Chun, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: In the quest to boost the intrinsic activity of single-atom catalysts (SACs), optimizing the electronic properties of metal centers and maximizing active sites play a pivotal role. Here, a facile surface molten salt-assisted approach for fabricating porous iron-nitrogen-carbon catalysts enriched with catalytically accessible single-atom motifs is reported. Multiple characterization analyses prove that abundant intrinsic defects are generated at the edge sites, resulting in the formation of thermally stable unstitched Fe-N<inf>3</inf> motif. Theoretical investigations unveil that the transition from Fe-N<inf>4</inf> to Fe-N<inf>3</inf> induces structural alteration, resulting in the convergence of Fe-3d orbital energy to Fermi energy. The low-coordinated Fe-N<inf>3</inf> motif exhibits higher activation ability, reinforcing its interaction with O<inf>3</inf> and weakening the O-O bond. This leads to a reduction in the reactivity of surface atomic oxygen barriers (O<inf>3</inf>-to-*O/*OO), ultimately achieving efficient catalytic oxidation of methyl mercaptan and its intermediates, achieving performance 20-fold higher than intact Fe-N<inf>4</inf> catalysts and 625-fold higher than commercial MnO<inf>2</inf>. These findings present a comprehensive approach for synthesizing SACs with fully accessible active sites and boosted electronic configurations to advance catalytic ozonation activity. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Xiao, Menglan; T., Zhao, Tingyi; Y., Li, Yuanjun; B., Zhu, Bing; T., Yu, Taige; W., Liu, Wenting; M., Zhao, Mingqin; B., Cui, Bing
Title: Co3O4-Based Catalysts for the Low-Temperature Catalytic Oxidation of VOCs
Affiliations: Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Xiao, Menglan, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Zhao, Tingyi, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Li, Yuanjun, School of Ecology and Environment, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, China; Zhu, Bing, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Yu, Taige, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Liu, Wenting, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Zhao, Mingqin, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China; Cui, Bing, College of Tobacco Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are a significant source of environmental pollution, posing threats to human safety. With growing concerns about environmental degradation, catalytic oxidation technology emerges as a paramount and widely adopted approach for VOC elimination, renowned for its operational simplicity, energy efficiency, and environmental friendliness. As a representative transition metal catalyst, cobalt-based catalysts have garnered widespread use in VOC catalytic oxidation due to their cost-effectiveness, versatility, and distinctive physicochemical properties. This paper provides a detailed exposition of the construction strategies and structure-activity relationship of Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>-based catalysts in VOCs oxidation reaction, encompassing both monometallic Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> and multimetallic cobalt-based catalysts. Furthermore, it offers a comprehensive summary and discussion of the latest research progress concerning Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>-based catalysts in practical applications. Concluding with a meticulous analysis, the paper addresses the technical challenges inherent in developing Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>-based catalysts for VOCs degradation. Additionally, it proposes research directions aimed at overcoming these challenges, contributing to the ongoing discourse on environmental sustainability. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B., Divya, Baskaran; D., Dhamodharan, Duraisami; U.S., Behera, Uma Sankar; H., Byun, Hun-soo
Author full names: Divya, Baskaran (57192545870); Dhamodharan, Duraisami (57207863101); Behera, Uma Sankar (57216436368); Byun, Hun-soo (7103324876)
Title: A comprehensive review and perspective research in technology integration for the treatment of gaseous volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia; Saveetha Dental College And Hospitals, Chennai, India
Authors with affiliations: Divya, Baskaran, Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea, Department of Biomaterials, Saveetha Dental College And Hospitals, Chennai, India; Dhamodharan, Duraisami, Interdisciplinary Research Center for Refining and Advanced Chemicals, King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia; Behera, Uma Sankar, Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; Byun, Hun-soo, Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are harmful pollutants emitted from industrial processes. They pose a risk to human health and ecosystems, even at low concentrations. Controlling VOCs is crucial for good air quality. This review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the various methods used for controlling VOC abatement. The advancement of mono-functional treatment techniques, including recovery such as absorption, adsorption, condensation, and membrane separation, and destruction-based methods such as natural degradation methods, advanced oxidation processes, and reduction methods were discussed. Among these methods, advanced oxidation processes are considered the most effective for removing toxic VOCs, despite some drawbacks such as costly chemicals, rigorous reaction conditions, and the formation of secondary chemicals. Standalone technologies are generally not sufficient and do not perform satisfactorily for the removal of hazardous air pollutants due to the generation of innocuous end products. However, every integration technique complements superiority and overcomes the challenges of standalone technologies. For instance, by using catalytic oxidation, catalytic ozonation, non-thermal plasma, and photocatalysis pretreatments, the amount of bioaerosols released from the bioreactor can be significantly reduced, leading to effective conversion rates for non-polar compounds, and opening new perspectives towards promising techniques with countless benefits. Interestingly, the three-stage processes have shown efficient decomposition performance for polar VOCs, excellent recoverability for nonpolar VOCs, and promising potential applications in atmospheric purification. Furthermore, the review also reports on the evolution of mathematical and artificial neural network modeling for VOC removal performance. The article critically analyzes the synergistic effects and advantages of integration. The authors hope that this article will be helpful in deciding on the appropriate strategy for controlling interested VOCs. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Funding Texts: Funding text 1: Inorganic filler and organic polymer combined and synthesised to MMM which has good separation and permeability performance (Drobek et al., 2015). Many separation studies have been conducted by authors Sedláková et al. (2014), Banihashemi et al. (2018) and Fang et al. (2015) using MMM with carbon nano tubes/activated carbon fiber/metal organic frameworks for the removal of hexane, ethanol, toluene, propane, p-xylene and o-xylene. n-Hexane and toluene has higher permeability than ethanol while p-xylene has higher permeability than o-xylene. Unlike MMM, CM generally prepared by covering a porous support (PVDF, polysulfone, polypropylene and polyetherimide) with the help of dense of organic polymer (PDMS and PEBA) (Liao et al., 2018). Anyhow, interface improvement between the porous and polymer layer is still challenging. Membrane separation processes are currently being used for the recovery of VOCs. However, their industrial application remains challenging due to issues such as membrane fouling, regeneration, permeability, selectivity trade-offs, physical aging, and plasticization. It should be noted that these recovery methods only transfer the VOCs from one phase to another without degrading them into eco-friendly substances. As a result, secondary treatment is still required. Therefore, destruction methods have become more popular in the last few decades.Comparatively, biodegradation (BIO) process has been recommended for VOCs removal because of efficient conversion of pollutants into innocuous end-products, relatively cheap, eco-friendly, and reliable process (Baskaran et al., 2019; Rajamanickam et al., 2020). Bioreactors found to be promising technology for various type of VOCs (less than 3 g m−3) and VOCs mixture using biofilter (BT), biotrickling filter (BTF), bioscrubber (BS), hollow fiber membrane bioreactor (MB), rotating biological contractor (RBC), air diffusion bioreactor (ALR), and two-phase partitioning bioreactor (TPPB). Bioreactors can be designed to handle a VOC concentration: <10 g m-3, inlet loading rate (ILR): >5000 m3 h−1, empty bed residence time (EBRT): >20 s and pressure drop: 0.4–4 cm H2O and achieved elimination capacity (EC): 21 g m−3 h−1 when inlet loading rate of 35 g m−3 h−1 and removal efficiency: 85–95% (Yoshikawa et al., 2017; Cheng et al., 2016; Wu et al., 2023). The advantages, limitations and remarkable actions for the bioreactors are presented in Table S2. The main difference between the bioreactors is based on the amount of flow of water inside (stagnant for BT, continuously moving for BTF and BS), phase state of the biomass (immobilized or suspended) and supported media on test bed. We have reviewed and detailed the comparison of biodegradation techniques including BT, BTF and BS for the removal of available VOCs earlier (Malakar et al., 2017). Microorganisms can grow on the surface of porous support material as a biofilm where it can uptake the VOCs and produced CO2, H2O, organic biomass, and sometimes intermediate by-products. The selected microorganisms (aerobic, an-aerobic, and facultative bacteria, algae, fungi, protozoa, etc.) used under local dryness condition and maintained a good level of activity and some of the reported microorganisms are showed in Table S2.The performance of the biofilter and biotrickling filter is highly dependent on the type of packing materials used such as organic, natural inorganic and synthetic materials. Many green packing materials and their compositions were tested in the biofilter for VOC treatment, such as scoria-bagasse, peat, coconut fiber and shell, bamboo, sugar beet pulp, poplar tree skin, wood bark, rice, maize, cane residues, pine leaves, cow dung compost, cattle bone porcelite, composite ceramic, horticultural perlite, pelletized diatomaceous earth biological support media, peat mixed with heather, sludge-based compost, and compost over a clay pellet. Overall, the use of green carriers in different BF and BTF showed the highest performance in terms of pollutants elimination capacity and economic viability. There are various typical operating conditions affecting the biodegradation efficiency in bioreactor including VOC concentration, empty bed residence time, gas flow rate, velocity of air, bed depth, bed porosity, moisture content, pressure drop, oxygen content, bed surface area, liquid holdup, type of packing material, temperature, pH and acclimation time of microbes (Baskaran et al., 2019).The authors declare the following financial interests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing interests: Hun-Soo Byun reports financial support was provided by National Research Foundation of Korea. Authors: X., Meng, Xiang; B., Dong, Boxu; L., Zhao, Liang; W., Zhou, Wenhui; X., Li, Xinhao; J., Zai, Jiantao; X., Qian, Xuefeng
Title: Synergistic regulation of charge state and electron-donating ability via heterojunctions design for fixation of electronegative greenhouse F-gases
Affiliations: Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Meng, Xiang, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and Shaoxing Research Institute of Renewable Energy and Molecular Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Dong, Boxu, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and Shaoxing Research Institute of Renewable Energy and Molecular Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Zhao, Liang, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and Shaoxing Research Institute of Renewable Energy and Molecular Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Zhou, Wenhui, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and Shaoxing Research Institute of Renewable Energy and Molecular Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Li, Xinhao, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and Shaoxing Research Institute of Renewable Energy and Molecular Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Zai, Jiantao, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and Shaoxing Research Institute of Renewable Energy and Molecular Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Qian, Xuefeng, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and Shaoxing Research Institute of Renewable Energy and Molecular Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: The net-zero greenhouse gas emission has now become a global strategy. In this context, electronegative fluorinated-gases such as sulfur hexafluoride (SF<inf>6</inf>) and hydrofluorocarbon, have become important emission reduction objects due to their strong global warming potential. In this work, the MnOx@Mn/SiC heterojunction was rationally designed and prepared. Because of the high electron coupling, the positively charged active-site MnOx@Mn (δ+) not only promotes the adsorption of SF<inf>6</inf> but also acts as a donor to transport electrons to SF<inf>6</inf>, so that the adsorption and activation of SF<inf>6</inf> are unified in one active site. Therefore, MnOx@Mn/SiC can effectively degrade SF<inf>6</inf> above 450°C, and the degradation amount for 12 vol% SF<inf>6</inf> can reach 523.8 mL g−1 at 600°C. Furthermore, it also has good degradation performance on hydrofluorocarbons (R-22 and R-410A) even at 100°C. Given the cheap and easy scale-up synthesis, MnOx@Mn/SiC has the potential to reduce the emission of multiple fluorinated-gases in practical applications. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Electron Donor; Electronegative F-gases; Greenhouse Gas Fixation; Heterojunction; Sulfur Hexafluoride (sf6)

Authors: L., Wang, Liangliang; C., Zhang, Chenhang; T., Xu, Tongzhou; L., Lv, Lirong; Z., Zhang, Zhongguo; C., He, Can
Author full names: Wang, Liangliang (57941335700); Zhang, Chenhang (57578322300); Xu, Tongzhou (56231265300); Lv, Lirong (57192834347); Zhang, Zhongguo (12142540700); He, Can (57212034628)
Title: Treatment of VOCs with a wet scrubbing – catalytic ozonation process: Efficiency, mechanism and pilot-scale application
Affiliations: Beijing Academy of Science and Technology, Beijing, China; The National Engineering Laboratory of Circular Economy (Industrial Wastewater Utilization and Industrial Water Conservation), Beijing, China; Beijing Automotive Group Co.,ltd., Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Liangliang, Institute of Resources and Environment, Beijing Academy of Science and Technology, Beijing, China, The National Engineering Laboratory of Circular Economy (Industrial Wastewater Utilization and Industrial Water Conservation), Beijing, China; Zhang, Chenhang, Beijing Automotive Group Co.,ltd., Beijing, China; Xu, Tongzhou, Institute of Resources and Environment, Beijing Academy of Science and Technology, Beijing, China, The National Engineering Laboratory of Circular Economy (Industrial Wastewater Utilization and Industrial Water Conservation), Beijing, China; Lv, Lirong, Institute of Resources and Environment, Beijing Academy of Science and Technology, Beijing, China, The National Engineering Laboratory of Circular Economy (Industrial Wastewater Utilization and Industrial Water Conservation), Beijing, China; Zhang, Zhongguo, Institute of Resources and Environment, Beijing Academy of Science and Technology, Beijing, China, The National Engineering Laboratory of Circular Economy (Industrial Wastewater Utilization and Industrial Water Conservation), Beijing, China; He, Can, Institute of Resources and Environment, Beijing Academy of Science and Technology, Beijing, China, The National Engineering Laboratory of Circular Economy (Industrial Wastewater Utilization and Industrial Water Conservation), Beijing, China
Abstract: A wet scrubbing – catalytic ozonation (WCO) process with activated carbon (AC) loaded MnOx (MnOx/AC) as the catalyst was developed, based on volatile organic compounds (VOCs) can be efficiently removed. The mineralization efficiency, degradation pathway and mechanism, and effects of the process operating parameters were investigated in detail using toluene as the target pollutant. The results show that the average removal efficiency of toluene reached 71.82 % within 90 min under optimal conditions (C<inf>Toluene</inf> = 100 mg/m3; C<inf>O3</inf> = 1 mg/L; catalyst loading = 5 g/L; pH = 7; gas flow = 500 mL/min), which outperformed that of the gaseous system. Quenching experiments and electron spin resonance spectroscopy indicate that [rad]OH and [rad]O<inf>2</inf>− are the two main reactive oxygen species (ROSs) in the system, which facilitate the opening of the benzene ring and significantly reduce by-products. The intermediates of toluene degradation were identified by proton-transfer reaction time-of-flight mass spectroscopy (PTR-TOF-MS). The results indicate that most of the intermediates generated in the system are captured in water rather than being emitted into the atmosphere. In the pilot-scale experiments, the WCO process exhibited a stable VOC removal efficiency (≥61.05 %) for 10 d in the treatment of actual low-concentration VOCs. Therefore, in this study, an effective process for the removal of low-concentration VOCs is proposed, which can be used for multiple VOC treatments. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: W., Feng, Wenji; F., He, Feiyang; X., Chen, Xinru; B., Jiang, Boqiong; H., Wang, Haiqiang; Z., Wu, Zhongbiao
Author full names: Feng, Wenji (57222990326); He, Feiyang (58968760200); Chen, Xinru (58968542700); Jiang, Boqiong (16506755300); Wang, Haiqiang (57219102674); Wu, Zhongbiao (7501414011)
Title: Optimizing the CeO2-MnO2 interface via H2O2 etching for surface lattice oxygen activation in the plasma catalytic degradation of trimethylamine
Affiliations: College of Environmental and Resource Sciences Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang Gongshang University, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Feng, Wenji, Key Laboratory of Environment Remediation and Ecological Health, College of Environmental and Resource Sciences Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler, Hangzhou, China; He, Feiyang, Key Laboratory of Environment Remediation and Ecological Health, College of Environmental and Resource Sciences Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler, Hangzhou, China; Chen, Xinru, Key Laboratory of Environment Remediation and Ecological Health, College of Environmental and Resource Sciences Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler, Hangzhou, China; Jiang, Boqiong, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Zhejiang Gongshang University, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Haiqiang, Key Laboratory of Environment Remediation and Ecological Health, College of Environmental and Resource Sciences Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler, Hangzhou, China; Wu, Zhongbiao, Key Laboratory of Environment Remediation and Ecological Health, College of Environmental and Resource Sciences Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: Trimethylamine (TMA) is a nitrogen-containing malodorous gas that is toxic and hazardous to humans. Plasma catalysis is a promising technique for removing low-concentration malodorous gases. CeO<inf>2</inf>/MnO<inf>2</inf> nanowires with different Ce–Mn contact interfaces prepared by impregnation, physical mixing, and H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf> etching were investigated for TMA degradation in a plasma catalytic system. The CMO-H sample prepared by H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf> etching achieved a removal efficiency of 100% at 98 J/L, demonstrating the highest activity. Characterization revealed that H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf> etching led to the uniform formation of CeO<inf>2</inf> nanoparticles on MnO<inf>2</inf>, promoting the transfer of electrons between Ce and Mn species. Surface lattice oxygen and high-valent manganese were confirmed to be the main active species, consistent with the Mars van Krevelen mechanism. Density functional theory calculations confirmed that the CMO-H sample exhibited the lowest oxygen vacancy formation energy. In situ plasma diffuse reflection infrared transform spectroscopy analysis and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry results showed the possible degradation pathway of TMA. In summary, the H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf> etching process optimized CeO<inf>2</inf>-MnO<inf>2</inf> interactions and improved the utilization of lattice oxygen active sites, enhancing the catalytic degradation of TMA and providing new insights into the design of an efficient plasma catalytic system for environmental remediation. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G., Iervolino, Giuseppina; T., Russo, Tina; V., Vaiano, Vincenzo
Author full names: Iervolino, Giuseppina (56195819300); Russo, Tina (58862284200); Vaiano, Vincenzo (8432129900)
Title: Catalytic non-thermal plasma reactor operating at low applied voltage for the removal of toluene in air
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Salerno, Salerno, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Iervolino, Giuseppina, Department of Industrial Engineering, Università degli Studi di Salerno, Salerno, Italy; Russo, Tina, Department of Industrial Engineering, Università degli Studi di Salerno, Salerno, Italy; Vaiano, Vincenzo, Department of Industrial Engineering, Università degli Studi di Salerno, Salerno, Italy
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOC) represent a large group of pollutants characterized by high volatility. They can cause problems both for humans and the environment. This work aimed to examine the non-thermal plasma (NTP) technology combined with a heterogeneous catalyst (“in plasma catalysis”, IPC) for the removal of toluene from the air at an applied voltage lower than that commonly reported in the literature. The NTP system was studied in the absence and presence of two commercial catalysts (γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> spheres and TiO<inf>2</inf> pellets) investigating the influence of the operating conditions (inlet flow rate, inlet pollutant concentration, water vapor presence and applied voltage). The results demonstrated that NTP without catalyst can remove toluene at voltages not less than 13.20 kV. On the other hand, the use γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> in IPC configuration allowed to achieve better performance than TiO<inf>2</inf> with the lowest applied voltage (10.67 kV) for plasma generation. Specifically, with an air flow rate of 15 NL/h at 8.7% of relative humidity and containing 500 ppm of toluene, a pollutant conversion of about 89% and a CO<inf>2</inf>/CO molar ratio equal to 4.72 was achieved. Moreover, contrary to what was observed in the NTP system without catalyst, the presence of both γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> and TiO<inf>2</inf> in the IPC configuration allowed to avoid the presence of O<inf>3</inf> and NO<inf>x</inf> at the reactor outlet. Finally, the calculated energy efficiency was in the order NTP+ γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> > NTP+TiO<inf>2</inf> > NTP alone. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Chang, Koping; T.D., Zaikos, Thomas Dimitrios; N., Kilner-Pontone, Nicholas; C., Ho, Chengying
Author full names: Chang, Koping (57201269993); Zaikos, Thomas Dimitrios (58920374300); Kilner-Pontone, Nicholas (58910515200); Ho, Chengying (57188738172)
Title: Mechanisms of COVID-19-associated olfactory dysfunction
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, United States; National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, Koping, Department of Pathology, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, United States, Graduate Institute of Pathology, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan; Zaikos, Thomas Dimitrios, Department of Pathology, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, United States; Kilner-Pontone, Nicholas, Department of Pathology, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, United States; Ho, Chengying, Department of Pathology, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, United States
Abstract: Olfactory dysfunction is one of the most common symptoms of COVID-19. In the first 2 years of the pandemic, it was frequently reported, although its incidence has significantly decreased with the emergence of the Omicron variant, which has since become the dominant viral strain. Nevertheless, many patients continue to suffer from persistent dysosmia and dysgeusia, making COVID-19-associated olfactory dysfunction an ongoing health concern. The proposed pathogenic mechanisms of COVID-19-associated olfactory dysfunction are complex and likely multifactorial. While evidence suggests that infection of sustentacular cells and associated mucosal inflammation may be the culprit of acute, transient smell loss, alterations in other components of the olfactory system (e.g., olfactory receptor neuron dysfunction, olfactory bulb injury and alterations in the olfactory cortex) may lead to persistent, long-term olfactory dysfunction. This review aims to provide a comprehensive summary of the epidemiology, clinical manifestations and current understanding of the pathogenic mechanisms of COVID-19-associated olfactory dysfunction. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Dubuisson, Candice; H.M., Wortham, Henri M.; T., Garinie, Tessie; M.M., Hossaert-McKey, Martine M.; B., Lapeyre, Benoit; B., Buatois, Bruno; B., Temime-Roussel, Brice; E., Ormeño, Elena; M., Staudt, Michael; M., Proffit, Magali
Author full names: Dubuisson, Candice (57562495500); Wortham, Henri M. (7004204248); Garinie, Tessie (58199237100); Hossaert-McKey, Martine M. (7003442585); Lapeyre, Benoit (57215526402); Buatois, Bruno (14007394900); Temime-Roussel, Brice (6506496327); Ormeño, Elena (10839558200); Staudt, Michael (7005372761); Proffit, Magali (15846655200)
Title: Ozone alters the chemical signal required for plant – insect pollination: The case of the Mediterranean fig tree and its specific pollinator
Affiliations: Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France; Aix Marseille Université, Marseille, France; Institut Méditerranéen de Biodiversité et d'Ecologie Marine et Continentale, Marseille, France
Authors with affiliations: Dubuisson, Candice, Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France; Wortham, Henri M., Aix Marseille Université, Marseille, France; Garinie, Tessie, Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France; Hossaert-McKey, Martine M., Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France; Lapeyre, Benoit, Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France; Buatois, Bruno, Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France; Temime-Roussel, Brice, Aix Marseille Université, Marseille, France; Ormeño, Elena, Institut Méditerranéen de Biodiversité et d'Ecologie Marine et Continentale, Marseille, France; Staudt, Michael, Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France; Proffit, Magali, Université de Montpellier, Montpellier, France
Abstract: Tropospheric ozone (O<inf>3</inf>) is likely to affect the chemical signal emitted by flowers to attract their pollinators through its effects on the emission of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and its high reactivity with these compounds in the atmosphere. We investigated these possible effects using a plant-pollinator interaction where the VOCs responsible for pollinator attraction are known and which is commonly exposed to high O<inf>3</inf> concentration episodes: the Mediterranean fig tree (Ficus carica) and its unique pollinator, the fig wasp (Blastophaga psenes). In controlled conditions, we exposed fig trees bearing receptive figs to a high-O<inf>3</inf> episode (5 h) of 200 ppb and analyzed VOC emission. In addition, we investigated the chemical reactions occurring in the atmosphere between O<inf>3</inf> and pollinator-attractive VOCs using real-time monitoring. Finally, we tested the response of fig wasps to the chemical signal when exposed to increasing O<inf>3</inf> mixing ratios (0, 40, 80, 120 and 200 ppb). The exposure of the fig tree to high O<inf>3</inf> levels induced a significant decrease in leaf stomatal conductance, a limited change in the emission by receptive figs of VOCs not involved in pollinator attraction, but a major change in the relative abundances of the compounds among pollinator-attractive VOCs in O<inf>3</inf>-enriched atmosphere. Fig VOCs reacted with O<inf>3</inf> in the atmosphere even at the lowest level tested (40 ppb) and the resulting changes in VOC composition significantly disrupted the attraction of the specific pollinator. These results strongly suggest that current O<inf>3</inf> episodes are probably already affecting the interaction between the fig tree and its specific pollinator. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Q., Yan, Qianqian; J., Ji, Jiafan; Y., Chen, Yi; G., Zhao, Gaosheng; B., Jia, Bin; L., Xu, Li; P., Cheng, Ping
Title: By-product reduction for the non-thermal plasma removal of toluene using an α-MnO2/Cordierite honeycomb monolithic catalyst in a honeycomb structure
Affiliations: Shanghai University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Yan, Qianqian, School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China; Ji, Jiafan, School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China; Chen, Yi, School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China; Zhao, Gaosheng, School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China; Jia, Bin, School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China; Xu, Li, School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China; Cheng, Ping, School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: The practical implementation of non-thermal plasma (NTP) combined with catalysts still faces challenges due to the by-products, such as O<inf>3</inf> and nanoparticles. In this study, α-MnO<inf>2</inf>/Cordierite honeycomb monolithic (CHM) catalyst was used to reduce the by-products for NTP degradation of toluene. The by-products analysis shows that using the α-MnO<inf>2</inf>/CHM catalyst not only improves the degradation efficiency up to 98% and CO<inf>X</inf> selectivity to 50%, but also simultaneously and greatly reduces the release of three types of hazardous by-products, organic components, ozone, and particles. The mechanisms of toluene degradation and by-product formation were investigated through online monitoring which can be summarized in two ways: direct degradation by energetic electrons and reactive radicals in the discharge region, and deep oxidation by active oxygen species on the catalyst surface. This investigation can improve our understanding of VOC degradation by combining monolithic catalysts with plasma, and accelerate the implementation of plasma-catalyzed technology in real-world. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Cheng, Lujun; Y., Li, Yingshuang; J., Fan, Jiahai; M., Xie, Man; X., Liu, Xueyan; P., Sun, Pengfei; X., Dong, Xiaoping
Title: High efficiency photothermal synergistic degradation of toluene achieved through the utilization of a nickel foam loaded Pt-CeO2 monolithic catalyst
Affiliations: Zhejiang Sci-Tech University, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang Tianlan Environmental Protection Technology Co., Ltd., Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, Lujun, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang Sci-Tech University, Hangzhou, China; Li, Yingshuang, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang Sci-Tech University, Hangzhou, China; Fan, Jiahai, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang Sci-Tech University, Hangzhou, China; Xie, Man, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang Sci-Tech University, Hangzhou, China; Liu, Xueyan, Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler, Hangzhou, China, Zhejiang Tianlan Environmental Protection Technology Co., Ltd., Hangzhou, China; Sun, Pengfei, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang Sci-Tech University, Hangzhou, China; Dong, Xiaoping, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang Sci-Tech University, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: Recent research highlights the pressing need for innovative and practical oxidation degradation technologies for volatile organic compounds (VOCs). In this study, a monolithic catalyst was successfully developed by loading Pt-CeO<inf>2</inf> onto nickel foam (NF) matrix through hydrothermal and reduction methods. The photothermal catalytic performance was investigated at room temperature for varying Pt content, toluene concentration, light source type, and water content. Remarkably, the toluene removal efficiency and CO<inf>2</inf> selectivity stabilized at 98.8 % and 74.6 %, respectively, within less than 10 min of light activation. The d-d transition thermal effect of CeO<inf>2</inf> and plasma effect of Pt enhanced light-to-heat conversion and active free radical generation (•O<inf>2</inf>– and •OH) through light absorption, respectively. The NF matrix's excellent thermal conductivity ensured a rapid increase in catalyst temperature upon visible light irradiation, reaching 173 °C. The study demonstrated that both the Mars-van Krevelen (Mvk) oxidation process, driven by temperature increase from near-infrared (NIR) absorption, and the free radical oxidation process, induced by higher energy illumination, synergistically contributed to toluene decomposition and mineralization. The catalyst's morphology, physical and chemical properties, surface synergistic oxidation process involving gaseous oxygen and free radicals, and toluene degradation pathway were thoroughly analyzed. We believe that this coexistence of thermocatalytic and photocatalytic mechanisms in a monolithic catalyst driven by renewable solar energy holds significant potential for practical applications and warrants further exploration. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Cheng, Yizhen; Z., Chen, Zhonglin; P., Yan, Pengwei; J., Shen, Jimin; J., Kang, Jing; S., Wang, Shaobin; X., Duan, Xiaoguang
Author full names: Cheng, Yizhen (57369414600); Chen, Zhonglin (57202832804); Yan, Pengwei (57200519481); Shen, Jimin (57204012138); Kang, Jing (55277143800); Wang, Shaobin (7410345755); Duan, Xiaoguang (57218125905)
Title: Synergistic Catalytic Ozonation Mediated by Dual Active Sites of Oxygen Vacancies and Defects in Biomass-Derived Composites for Long-Lasting Water Decontamination
Affiliations: Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China; The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, Yizhen, School of Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China, School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Chen, Zhonglin, School of Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China; Yan, Pengwei, School of Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China; Shen, Jimin, School of Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China; Kang, Jing, School of Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China; Wang, Shaobin, School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Duan, Xiaoguang, School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia
Abstract: Environmental decontamination relies on low-cost, sustainable materials to drive diverse catalytic redox reactions. In this work, we used low-cost biomass to develop nanocomposites of N-doped carbon-supported zinc oxide (ZNC400) at a low temperature (400 °C), which exhibited ultrahigh activity in heterogeneous catalytic ozonation (HCO) for organic water decontamination. Our experimental and computational studies revealed the collaborative functions of dual active centers of defective carbons and oxygen vacancies (OVs)-containing zinc oxide (ZnO) at the composite interface for successive ozone (O<inf>3</inf>) adsorption and catalytic decomposition, respectively. Inspiringly, OVs on ZnO will spontaneously dissociate water molecules (H<inf>2</inf>O) to form surface hydroxyl groups (-OH) as key intermediates to accelerate O<inf>3</inf> decomposition. This synergistic interplay results in the continuous generation of hydroxyl radicals (•OH) and maintains over 90.2% atrazine (ATZ) removal over five successive cycles, endowing ZNC400 with substantial reusability. Furthermore, four ATZ degradation pathways were proposed, and the corresponding toxicity was evaluated by the embryonic development of zebrafish in the treated water. Overall, the engineered dual-function catalyst effectively addresses the long-standing issue of poor stability of carbon materials in HCO and offers high-performance, cheap, and green catalysts for advanced water purification. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
