Authors: B., Solsona, B.; E., Aylón, Elvira; R., Murillo, Ramón; A.M., Mastral, Ana María; A., Monzonís, Alejandro; S., Agouram, Saïd; T.E., Davies, Thomas Edward; S.H., Taylor, Stuart H.; T., García, Tomás
Author full names: Solsona, B. (6603807161); Aylón, Elvira (8524020000); Murillo, Ramón (7004714377); Mastral, Ana María (24374026100); Monzonís, Alejandro (36990527400); Agouram, Saïd (16308729000); Davies, Thomas Edward (7401742860); Taylor, Stuart H. (7404757166); García, Tomás (57205514864)
Title: Deep oxidation of pollutants using gold deposited on a high surface area cobalt oxide prepared by a nanocasting route
Affiliations: Universitat de València, Valencia, Spain; CSIC - Instituto de Carboquimica (ICB), Zaragoza, Spain; Universitat de València, Valencia, Spain; Universitat de València, Valencia, Spain; Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Solsona, B., Departament d'Enginyeria Química, Universitat de València, Valencia, Spain; Aylón, Elvira, CSIC - Instituto de Carboquimica (ICB), Zaragoza, Spain; Murillo, Ramón, CSIC - Instituto de Carboquimica (ICB), Zaragoza, Spain; Mastral, Ana María, CSIC - Instituto de Carboquimica (ICB), Zaragoza, Spain; Monzonís, Alejandro, Departament d'Enginyeria Química, Universitat de València, Valencia, Spain; Agouram, Saïd, Department of Applied Physics and Electromagnetism, Universitat de València, Valencia, Spain, Universitat de València, Valencia, Spain; Davies, Thomas Edward, School of Chemistry, Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom; Taylor, Stuart H., School of Chemistry, Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom; García, Tomás, CSIC - Instituto de Carboquimica (ICB), Zaragoza, Spain
Abstract: Gold deposited on a cobalt oxide with high surface area (138m2g-1), obtained through a nanocasting route using a siliceous KIT-6 mesoporous material as a hard template, has demonstrated high activity for the total oxidation of propane and toluene, and ambient temperature CO oxidation. The addition of gold promotes the activity when compared to a gold-free Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> catalyst prepared using the same nanocasting technique. The enhanced catalytic activity when gold is present has been explained for the deep oxidation of propane and toluene in terms of the improved reducibility of cobalt oxide when gold is added, rather than to the intrinsic activity of metallic gold particles. The improved behaviour for CO oxidation has been linked to the simultaneous presence of Auδ+ and Au°. © 2011 Elsevier B.V. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: T., Vinodkumar, Thallada; B.M., Reddy, Benjaram M.
Author full names: Vinodkumar, Thallada (55996044600); Reddy, Benjaram M. (57203798193)
Title: Catalytic combustion over cheaper metal oxides
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Vinodkumar, Thallada, Inorganic and Physical Chemistry Division, Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, India; Reddy, Benjaram M., Inorganic and Physical Chemistry Division, Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: Currently, mankind has been facing the consequences arising from extensive fossil-fuel exploitation and their continuous use is expected to produce more harmful effects. It is an acknowledged fact that world's major energy needs are met from thermal power generation which depends mainly on the combustion of fossil fuels. On the other hand, these combustion systems have elevated much of the environmental problems. One of the emission gases of most serious concern is nitrogen oxide (NO<inf>x</inf>), which causes acid rain, global warming and ozone depletion. To settle the global environmental and energy issues, the combustion systems need to be much more improved for high efficiency and low pollutant emissions. Catalytic combustion has been developed as a method of promoting efficient combustion over a wide range of air-to-fuel ratios with a minimum pollutant formation at low temperatures as compared to conventional flame combustion. The application of catalysts facilitates efficient combustion of hydrocarbons at relatively lower temperatures without promoting oxidation of nitrogen and also stringent control over the emission of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Generally, effective emission control is often achieved by the use of noble metal catalysts; they are very active at low temperatures but due to the economical reasons, as well as limited availability of noble metals, motivated the investigation into the alternative materials for catalytic combustion. Metal oxides are the promising option, because they are relatively cheap, show variable valency and exhibit greater redox characteristics. Mixed metal oxides in the form of perovskites, hexa-aluminates and doped metal oxides are promising because of their thermal stability at high temperatures, low cost, and flexible composition. Among doped metal oxides, ceria-based materials are attractive in catalytic combustion apart from three-way-catalytic applications, VOC abatement, and fuel cell technologies due to their ease of redox and high thermal stability. Metal oxide catalysts exhibit good catalytic activity in narrow temperature range. However, the catalytic combustion range is up to 1773 K for that, it is necessary to add supports to increase the thermal stability. Recently, it has been reported that ceria supported on lanthanum hexa-aluminate shows an impressive activity and stability up to 1273 K. In this chapter we have concentrated on the catalytic application of pure metal oxides, and mixed metal oxides such as perovskites, hexa-aluminates and ceria doped materials for catalytic combustion. We also discussed the significance of supports to metal oxides to improve the catalytic efficiency at high temperatures. Finally, we have provided new directions for future work on this subject. © 2011 Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All Rights Reserved. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Z., Abbasi, Zahra; M., Haghighi, Mohammad; E., Fatehifar, Esmaeil; S., Saedy, Saeed
Author full names: Abbasi, Zahra (57196249117); Haghighi, Mohammad (35237013100); Fatehifar, Esmaeil (15831558400); Saedy, Saeed (36246528300)
Title: Synthesis and physicochemical characterizations of nanostructured Pt/Al2O3-CeO2 catalysts for total oxidation of VOCs
Affiliations: Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran; Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran; Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Abbasi, Zahra, Department of Chemical Engineering, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran, Reactor and Catalysis Research Center (RCRC), Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran; Haghighi, Mohammad, Department of Chemical Engineering, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran, Reactor and Catalysis Research Center (RCRC), Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran, Environmental Engineering Research Center, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran; Fatehifar, Esmaeil, Department of Chemical Engineering, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran, Reactor and Catalysis Research Center (RCRC), Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran, Environmental Engineering Research Center, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran; Saedy, Saeed, Department of Chemical Engineering, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran, Reactor and Catalysis Research Center (RCRC), Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran
Abstract: Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-CeO<inf>2</inf> nanocatalysts with Pt loading of 1% and ceria loading of 10, 20 and 30% were successfully prepared via wet impregnation method to be utilized in catalytic oxidation of BTX. The nanocatalysts were characterized using XRD, FESEM, TEM, N<inf>2</inf> adsorption, FTIR and TPR-H<inf>2</inf> techniques. The XRD patterns confirmed the formation of cerium oxide as the crystalline phase on alumina with the average crystallite size of 8.1-8.7nm, derived by Scherrer equation. FESEM images confirmed that these nanocatalysts had ceria particles in nano-ranges. TEM analysis showed that platinum particles were fairly well dispersed on Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-CeO<inf>2</inf> with an average size of 5-20nm. BET surface area presented large surface area for nanocatalysts. TPR patterns showed that by adding 1% platinum to support, the reducibility is highly increased. These patterns also revealed the promoting effect of ceria on reducibility of Pt and Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>. The results of toluene oxidation indicated that the synthesized nanocatalysts were highly active and able to remove nearly 100% of toluene and xylene and about 85% of benzene as representative VOCs. The presence of nanoparticles along with good characteristics of the synthesized nanocatalysts presented them as highly efficient materials for catalytic oxidation of VOCs. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: J.L., Perry, Jay L.; K.R., Frederick, Kenneth R.; J.P., Scott, Joseph P.; D.N., Reinemann, Dana N.
Author full names: Perry, Jay L. (55574195261); Frederick, Kenneth R. (7003747143); Scott, Joseph P. (55805640400); Reinemann, Dana N. (57195637438)
Title: A comparison of photocatalytic oxidation reactor performance for spacecraft cabin trace contaminant control applications
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Washington, D.C., United States; University of Mississippi, University, United States; NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, United States; NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, United States; NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, United States; School of Engineering, University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Perry, Jay L., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Washington, D.C., United States, Environmental Control Systems, NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, United States; Frederick, Kenneth R., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Washington, D.C., United States, NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, United States; Scott, Joseph P., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Washington, D.C., United States, NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, United States; Reinemann, Dana N., University of Mississippi, University, United States, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, School of Engineering, University, United States
Abstract: Photocatalytic oxidation (PCO) is a maturing process technology that shows potential for spacecraft life support system application. Incorporating PCO into a spacecraft cabin atmosphere revitalization system requires an understanding of basic performance, particularly with regard to partial oxidation product production. Four PCO reactor design concepts have been evaluated for their effectiveness for mineralizing key trace volatile organic compounds (VOC) typically observed in crewed spacecraft cabin atmospheres. Mineralization efficiency and selectivity for partial oxidation products are compared for the reactor design concepts. The role of PCO in a spacecraft's life support system architecture is discussed. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: E., Epstein, Eliot
Author full names: Epstein, Eliot (7202747724)
Title: Industrial composting: Environmental engineering and facilities management
Affiliations: University of Maine, Orono, United States
Authors with affiliations: Epstein, Eliot, University of Maine, Orono, United States
Abstract: The ultimate in recycling, composting has been in use in some form since ancient times. A well-managed composting facility should exist as a good neighbor contributing to ecology. However, since local populations often perceive risks if a composting facility is built nearby, composting facilities must be designed and operated with minimal odor, dust, and noise emissions. Industrial Composting examines the key operational aspects and problems associated with composting, with strong emphasis on odor mitigation, pathogens, and aerosols. Designed for composting professionals and supported by extensive quality references, this book covers: • Facilities Planning and Design • Odor Management • Design, Material, Energy, and Water Balances • Economics of Product Marketing and Sales • Public Relations, Participation, and Communication Regulations • Pathogen Concentrations as Related to Feedstocks • Bioaerosols Associated with Composting and Their Potential Diseases While many books cover composting, most of those currently available are either out of date or contain only a few chapters on the subject. With interest growing in the use of composting for biosolids, food wastes, and other specialty areas, the need for an up-to-date, focused resource is also increasing. To assist composting practitioners, community decision makers, and advocates, Industrial Composting brings recent advances and best practices in composting together in an accessible, professional volume. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F.J., Peñas, F. Javier; J.R., Isasi, José R.
Author full names: Peñas, F. Javier (6603224419); Isasi, José R. (7003278590)
Title: Cyclodextrin-based polymers as support for the biofiltration of air polluted with toluene
Affiliations: Universidad de Navarra, Pamplona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Peñas, F. Javier, Department of Chemistry and Soil Science, Universidad de Navarra, Pamplona, Spain; Isasi, José R., Department of Chemistry and Soil Science, Universidad de Navarra, Pamplona, Spain
Abstract: A novel environmental application of hydrogels has been explored. Materials based on the polymerisation of β-cyclodextrin onto inert solids have been developed and used as biomass supports for the biofiltration of air contaminated with toluene. Several supports were prepared by the crosslinking of β-cyclodextrin with epichlorohydrin onto commercial polymers and evaluated in pilot-scale biofilters for different testing periods. Batches of high density polyethylene rings and two types of reticulated polyurethane foam cubes were used as structural frameworks of the cyclodextrin polymer. Each support material was inoculated with an acclimated microbial culture and packed separately in different modules. The influent gas stream was prepared by vaporizing liquid toluene in air. In a first phase, a module with polyurethane cubes and another one with high density polyethylene rings were studied in the same biofilter for 23 and 12 months, respectively. The second phase, which lasted 20 months, worked with new polyurethane foam cubes in twin biofilters, one with the support particles coated with the cyclodextrin polymer and the other without this coating. In the third phase, the biofilters were operated under extreme conditions of high organic loads and total nutrient limitation during 9 months. Because of an irregular nutrient watering, the biofilters were operated under non-optimal conditions during practically the whole experimentation period. Organic loading rates up to 117 g/m3h and gas residence times between 0.45 and 7.0 min were applied. In general, the efficiency of the hydrogel-coated particles was somewhat higher than the non-coated corresponding support. The performance of cyclodextrin polymer supported onto the polyurethane cubes was more satisfactory than that over the polyethylene rings, with a maximum toluene elimination capacity of 103 g/m3h. © 2009 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.A., Hosseini, Seyed Ali; M.T., Sadeghi-Sorkhani, Mohammad Taghi; L., Kafi-Ahmadi, Leila; A.A., Alemi, Abdol Ali; A., Niaei, Aligholi; D., Salari, Dariush
Author full names: Hosseini, Seyed Ali (25936409000); Sadeghi-Sorkhani, Mohammad Taghi (35732044300); Kafi-Ahmadi, Leila (35731643100); Alemi, Abdol Ali (6602359891); Niaei, Aligholi (55942693600); Salari, Dariush (8978153600)
Title: Synthesis, characterization, and catalytic activity of nanocrystalline La1-xEuxFeO3 during the combustion of toluene
Affiliations: University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Hosseini, Seyed Ali, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Sadeghi-Sorkhani, Mohammad Taghi, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Kafi-Ahmadi, Leila, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Alemi, Abdol Ali, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Niaei, Aligholi, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Salari, Dariush, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran
Abstract: Nanostructured LaFeO<inf>3</inf> and substituted La<inf>1-x</inf>Eu<inf>x</inf>FeO<inf>3</inf> (x = 0.1, 0.15, and 0.2) perovskites were synthesized by sol-gel auto-combustion and their activities during the combustion of toluene were evaluated. The structure and physico-chemical properties of the perovskites were characterized by X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and BET surface area analyses. The compounds were crystallized as a perovskite phase with an orthorhombic structure. The mean particle size of the perovskites increased with an increase in europium loading while the specific surface area decreased. Characterization data confirmed that a total insertion of Eu into LaFeO<inf>3</inf> occurred at x ≤ 0.15. However, Eu<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> segregation occurred to some extent especially at x > 0.15. The catalytic activity of the catalysts increased substantially with an increase in Eu substitution in the evaluated range. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F., Seitz, Frank; K., Pollmann, Katrin; K., Mackenzie, Katrin; S., Opiolka, Siegfried
Author full names: Seitz, Frank (58822255100); Pollmann, Katrin (6602833712); Mackenzie, Katrin (7202720589); Opiolka, Siegfried (6602496000)
Title: Photooxidation in combination with nanotechnologies - Principles, developments and R & D approaches of an advanced technology for water and air treatment - Uviblox®
Affiliations: IBL Umwelt- und Biotechnik GmbH, Heidelberg, Germany; HZDR - Helmholtz-Zentrum Dresden-Rossendorf, Dresden, Germany; Helmholtz Zentrum für Umweltforschung, Leipzig, Germany; Institute of Energy and Environmental Technology (IUTA), Duisburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Seitz, Frank, Department of Process Engineering, IBL Umwelt- und Biotechnik GmbH, Heidelberg, Germany; Pollmann, Katrin, Department of Biophysics, HZDR - Helmholtz-Zentrum Dresden-Rossendorf, Dresden, Germany; Mackenzie, Katrin, Department of Enviromental Engineering, Helmholtz Zentrum für Umweltforschung, Leipzig, Germany; Opiolka, Siegfried, Institute of Energy and Environmental Technology (IUTA), Duisburg, Germany
Abstract: Many organic and oxidizable inorganic substances are main targets for oxidation and destruction during treatment, purification and disinfection of contaminated ground water, waste water, air, soil and waste gas and odor. Uviblox® technology uses the effects of photooxidation and photocatalytical processes by middle and low pressure UV lamps for technical systems. There are many possibilities for combination and optimisation of photooxidation with other technologies like nanotechnologies. Degradation processes can be enforced by nano structures of photocatalysts significantly. Different approaches are strongly pursued in research & development projects like NanoAqua, Fe-NANOSIT and nanoblox. These projects search for different ways of applying and handling the photocatalytical nano particles like TiO<inf>2</inf> and ZnO. Biological surface layers, magnetite, transparent and reflecting materials are tested for suspending nano particle solids as well as for coating fixtures. Research results are very promising and economic application of nano photocatalysts in water and gas phase for purification seems likely. Any presumed ecotoxicity was not found for the examined nanoparticles so far. © 2011 Science & Technology Network, Inc. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Z., Abbasi, Zahra; M., Haghighi, Mohammad; E., Fatehifar, Esmaeil; S., Saedy, Saeed
Author full names: Abbasi, Zahra (57196249117); Haghighi, Mohammad (35237013100); Fatehifar, Esmaeil (15831558400); Saedy, Saeed (36246528300)
Title: Synthesis and physicochemical characterization of nanostructured Pt/CeO2 catalyst used for total oxidation of toluene
Source title: International Journal of Chemical Reactor Engineering
Affiliations: Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Abbasi, Zahra, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran; Haghighi, Mohammad, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran; Fatehifar, Esmaeil, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran; Saedy, Saeed, Sahand University of Technology, Tabriz, Iran
Abstract: Nanostructured Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf> with different loadings of platinum was successfully synthesized via redox reaction along with wet impregnation method. The catalytic performance of the synthesized nanocatalysts was evaluated for abatement of toluene from waste gas stream. The synthesized nanocatalysts were characterized using XRD, FESEM, TEM, N<inf>2</inf> adsorption, FTIR and TPR-H2 techniques. Crystallographic analysis confirmed the formation of CeO<inf>2</inf> as crystalline phase with average crystallite size of 10.5 nm. Morphological analysis showed that majority of the synthesized CeO<inf>2</inf> particles were less than 100 nm with average particle size of 50.62 nm. TEM analysis illustrated that platinum particles were fairly well dispersed with an average size of 5-15 nm. Specific surface analysis revealed that the synthesized nanocatalysts had large enough surface area for catalytic oxidation of toluene. Temperature programmed reduction profiles indicated that Pt/CeO<inf>2</inf> had more reducibility compared to pure ceria. The results of catalytic experiments showed that the synthesized catalysts had the ability to remove 99% of toluene via total oxidation. According to these results, the best loading of Pt on ceria was 0.5 wt% with higher activity compared to pure ceria. Copyright © 2011 The Berkeley Electronic Press. Authors: F.N., Agüero, Fabiola Nerina; B.P., Barbero, Bibiana P.; L.C., Almeida, Luciano Costa; M., Montes, Mario; L.E., Cadús, Luis E.
Author full names: Agüero, Fabiola Nerina (23099500000); Barbero, Bibiana P. (6603006154); Almeida, Luciano Costa (22633342000); Montes, Mario (7102925861); Cadús, Luis E. (7004615497)
Title: MnOx supported on metallic monoliths for the combustion of volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: Universidad Nacional de San Luis, San Luis, Argentina; Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Agüero, Fabiola Nerina, Universidad Nacional de San Luis, San Luis, Argentina; Barbero, Bibiana P., Universidad Nacional de San Luis, San Luis, Argentina; Almeida, Luciano Costa, Grupo de Ingeniería Química, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Montes, Mario, Grupo de Ingeniería Química, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Cadús, Luis E., Universidad Nacional de San Luis, San Luis, Argentina
Abstract: The most convenient way to prepare structured manganese oxide catalyst for the combustion of volatile organic compounds was studied. The preparation conditions (solid concentration in the slurry, the addition of a suspension stabilizer, and the immersion numbers) were studied. The catalytic properties of these catalysts were evaluated in ethanol, ethyl acetate and toluene combustion. The surface area and the catalytic activity of monoliths in VOCs combustion increased with the amount of catalyst retained. A higher catalyst loading and a more homogeneous and well adhered layer was obtained using a 30wt% solid content suspension and performing two immersions. The addition of Nyacol® is not necessary to improve the stability of suspensions because these are stable by themselves. The washcoating of monoliths with a θ-δ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> suspended in manganese acetate solution not only reduces the number of stages during the preparation procedure but also produces more active catalysts. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Aly Hassan, Ashraf; G.A., Sorial, George A.
Author full names: Aly Hassan, Ashraf (57213162034); Sorial, George A. (7004846905)
Title: Treatment of dynamic mixture of hexane and benzene vapors in a Trickle Bed Air Biofilter integrated with cyclic adsorption/desorption beds
Affiliations: United States Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, D.C., United States; University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aly Hassan, Ashraf, United States Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, D.C., United States; Sorial, George A., Biological and Medical Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, United States
Abstract: One of the main challenges that face successful biofiltration is the erratic loading pattern and long starvation periods. However, such patterns are common in practical applications. In order to provide long-term stable operation of a biofilter under these conditions, a cyclic adsorption/desorption beds system with flow switching was installed prior to a biofilter. Different square waves of a mixture containing n-hexane and benzene at a 2:1 ratio were applied to the cyclic adsorption/desorption beds and then fed to a biofilter. The performance of this integrated system was compared to a biofilter unit receiving the same feed of both VOCs. The cyclic adsorption/desorption beds unit successfully achieved its goal of stabilizing erratic loading even with very sharp peaks at the influent concentration equalizing influent concentrations ranging from 10-470. ppmv for n-hexane to 30-1410. ppmv for benzene. The study included different peak concentrations with durations ranging from 6 to 20. min. The cyclic beds buffered the fluctuating influent load and the followed biofilter had all the time a continuous stable flow. Another advantage achieved by the cyclic adsorption/desorption beds was the uninterrupted feed to the biofilter even during the starvation where there was no influent in the feed. The results of the integrated system with regard to removal efficiency and kinetics are comparable to published results with continuous feed studies at the same loading rates. The removal efficiency for benzene had a minimum of 85% while for n-hexane ranged from 50% to 77% according to the loading rate. The control unit showed very erratic performance highlighting the benefit of the utilization of the cyclic adsorption/desorption beds. The biofilter was more adaptable to concentration changes in benzene than n-hexane. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.M., Möller, Detlev M.
Author full names: Möller, Detlev M. (7102816537)
Title: Chemistry of the Climate System
Affiliations: Brandenburgische Technische Universität Cottbus, Cottbus, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Möller, Detlev M., Lehrstuhl für Luftchemie und Luftreinhaltung, Brandenburgische Technische Universität Cottbus, Cottbus, Germany
Abstract: Climate change is one of the biggest challenges facing the modern world. The chemistry of the air within the framework of the climate system forms the main focus of this monograph. This problem-based approach to presenting global atmospheric processes begins with the chemical evolution of the climate system in order to evaluate the effects of changing air composition as well as possibilities for interference within these processes. Chemical interactions of the atmosphere with the biosphere and hydrosphere are treated in the sense of a multi-phase chemistry. From the perspective of a "chemical climatology" the book offers an approach to solving the problem of climate change through chemistry. © 2010 Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co. KG, Berlin/New York. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J., Yang, Jiantao; H., Pan, Hua; J., Chen, Jie; Q., Su, Qingfa; D., Wang, Dahui; Y., Shi, Yao
Title: Two-stage system of non-thermal plasma and adsorption for decomposition of hydrogen sulfide
Source title: Zhejiang Daxue Xuebao (Gongxue Ban)/Journal of Zhejiang University (Engineering Science)
Affiliations: Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Yang, Jiantao, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Pan, Hua, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Chen, Jie, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Su, Qingfa, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Dahui, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Shi, Yao, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: In order to overcome the high energy consumption and discharge of byproducts for decomposition of hydrogen sulfide with non-thermal plasma (NTP) alone, a two-stage system of NTP and activated carbon fibers (ACF) was presented for decomposition of H<inf>2</inf>S. The effects of two-stage system and single NTP system on H<inf>2</inf>S removal efficiency and byproducts were investigated at different input voltage. The synergistic mechanisms of NTP and ACF for H<inf>2</inf>S decomposition were also analyzed. The two-stage system could remarkably improve the H<inf>2</inf>S removal efficiency, decrease the energy consumption and remove byproducts, while prolong the breakthrough time of ACF and increase the decomposition and adsorption capacity for H<inf>2</inf>S. The results showed that the two-stage system improved 15% of the H<inf>2</inf>S removal efficiency and reduced 26.5% of the energy consumption at 6 kV with a gas-flow rate of 11.8 m3/h. The energy consumption of the two-stage system at 6 kV reduced 26.5%. ACF could remove the SO<inf>2</inf> and O<inf>3</inf>, no SO<inf>2</inf> and O<inf>3</inf> were detected before the breakthrough time of ACF for H<inf>2</inf>S. The breakthrough time of ACF for H<inf>2</inf>S was prolonged from 2 to 16 times by NTP at the input voltage range from 3 to 7 kV. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Dearinger, Michael; S., Wiley, Sam; M., Steele, Michael; C., Osse, Christian; J., Elarde, Jonathan
Author full names: Dearinger, Michael (36717441100); Wiley, Sam (36139087100); Steele, Michael (36718078300); Osse, Christian (36718020500); Elarde, Jonathan (36717727300)
Title: A new generation of field flares
Source title: Proceedings, Annual Convention - Gas Processors Association
Affiliations: MRW Technologies, Inc., Tulsa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dearinger, Michael, MRW Technologies, Inc., Tulsa, United States; Wiley, Sam, MRW Technologies, Inc., Tulsa, United States; Steele, Michael, MRW Technologies, Inc., Tulsa, United States; Osse, Christian, MRW Technologies, Inc., Tulsa, United States; Elarde, Jonathan, MRW Technologies, Inc., Tulsa, United States
Abstract: Applications for combustion technology as a means to controlling emissions in the natural gas industry are numerous and are common from the wellhead to the pipeline. A new generation of field flares has been developed to accommodate the need for higher destruction efficiencies, odor reduction, enclosed flames, improved operating efficiencies, and smokeless operation. A discussion covers the driving force for new technologies; selection criteria; selecting the proper emissions control device; new environmental regulations and equipment to meet such regulations; and new flare technologies developed to control H<inf>2</inf>S, BTEX, and VOC in the natural gas industry. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 89th Annual Convention of the Gas Processors Association (Austin, TX 3/24-24/2010). © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Scire, Salvatore; P.M., Riccobene, Paolo Maria; C., Crisafulli, Carmelo
Author full names: Scire, Salvatore (7003883560); Riccobene, Paolo Maria (34877703900); Crisafulli, Carmelo (8729312300)
Title: Ceria supported group IB metal catalysts for the combustion of volatile organic compounds and the preferential oxidation of CO
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Catania, Catania, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Scire, Salvatore, Dipartimento di Scienze Chimiche, Università degli Studi di Catania, Catania, Italy; Riccobene, Paolo Maria, Dipartimento di Scienze Chimiche, Università degli Studi di Catania, Catania, Italy; Crisafulli, Carmelo, Dipartimento di Scienze Chimiche, Università degli Studi di Catania, Catania, Italy
Abstract: Catalytic combustion of volatile organic compounds (VOC) and preferential oxidation of CO (PROX) were investigated over IB metal/ceria catalysts prepared by deposition-precipitation (DP) or coprecipitation (CP). The activity towards the deep oxidation of VOC was in the order: Au/CeO<inf>2</inf>≥Ag/CeO<inf>2</inf>>Cu/CeO<inf>2</inf>»CeO<inf>2</inf>. The same trend was also found in the PROX reaction in terms of total conversion of O<inf>2</inf>, which includes O<inf>2</inf> consumed both for CO and H<inf>2</inf> oxidation. A different behaviour was observed in the CO conversion to CO<inf>2</inf>, that is the desired PROX reaction. For this reaction, in fact, Au and Cu catalysts gave high CO conversions, Au/CeO<inf>2</inf> at low temperature (maximum of 84.3% for AuDP at 70°C) and Cu/CeO<inf>2</inf> at higher temperature (maximum of 96.8% for CuCP at 150°C), whereas Ag catalysts always exhibited very low CO conversions (maximum of 16.7% for AgCP at 80°C). Both for PROX and VOC combustion the Au sample prepared by DP was more active than the CP one, whereas a reverse behaviour was found on Ag and Cu catalysts. On the basis of characterization data (XRD, H<inf>2</inf>-TPR, surface area measurements, H<inf>2</inf>-D<inf>2</inf> isotopic exchange, N<inf>2</inf>O and H<inf>2</inf>-O<inf>2</inf> chemisorption) it was proposed that a higher atomic radius of the IB metal and the presence of smaller crystallites of both IB metal and ceria result in a larger enhancement of mobility/reactivity of surface ceria oxygens, involved in both investigated reactions through a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. The very low PROX activity of Ag/CeO<inf>2</inf> samples was related to the low capacity of silver to activate the CO molecule. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: W., Li, Weibin; J., Wang, Jianxin; H., Gong, Hao
Title: Catalytic combustion of VOCs on non-noble metal catalysts
Affiliations: Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Weibin, Graduate School at Shenzhen, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Wang, Jianxin, Graduate School at Shenzhen, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Gong, Hao, Graduate School at Shenzhen, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are toxic and contribute significantly to the formation of the photochemical smog, which has remarkable impact to the air quality; therefore, the research on the removal of VOCs has attracted increasing interests during the last decade. This review covers the recent developments in catalytic combustion of VOCs over non-noble metal catalysts including mixed metal oxide catalysts, perovskite catalysts and Au-containing catalysts. The effect of water vapor, coke formation and the effect of supports on the catalytic combustion process will be discussed. The concept of an adsorption/catalytic combustion dual functional system is introduced and several examples of such systems are evaluated. To develop efficient and cost effective VOC removal technologies, further research in catalytic combustion needs to develop novel non-noble metal catalysts and adsorbents, and improve the understanding of catalytic mechanisms involved. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Son, Youn-suk; K., Kim, Ki-joon; J., Kim, Jo-chun
Title: A Review on VOCs Control Technology Using Electron Beam
Affiliations: Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea; National Institute of Environmental Research, Icheon, South Korea; Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Son, Youn-suk, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Ki-joon, Emission Sources Research Division, National Institute of Environmental Research, Icheon, South Korea; Kim, Jo-chun, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea, Department of Environmental Engineering, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The removal characteristics for aromatic and aliphatic VOCs by electron beam (EB) were discussed in terms of several removal variables such as initial VOC concentration, absorbed dose, background gas, moisture content, reactor material and inlet temperature. It was reviewed that only reactor material was an independent variable among the potential control factors concerned. It was also suggested that main mechanism by EB should be radical reaction for the VOC removal rather than that by primary electrons. It was discussed that the removal efficiency of benzene was lower than that of hexane due to a closed benzene ring. In the case of aromatic VOCs, it was observed that the decomposition of the VOCs with more functional groups attached on the benzene ring was much easier than those with less ones. As for aliphatic VOCs, it was also implied that the longer carbon chain was, the higher the removal efficiency became. An EB-catalyst hybrid system was discussed as an alternative way to remove VOCs more effectively than EB-only system due to much less by-products. This hybrid included supporting materials such as cordierite, Y-zeolite, and γ-alumina. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Aromatic Voc; By-product; Catalytic Oxidation; Electron Beam; Toluene

Authors: R., Beauchet, Romain; J., Mijoin, Jérôme; I., Batonneau-Gener, Isabelle; P., Magnoux, Patrick
Author full names: Beauchet, Romain (16479921800); Mijoin, Jérôme (8159975400); Batonneau-Gener, Isabelle (23670029900); Magnoux, Patrick (7007007287)
Title: Catalytic oxidation of VOCs on NaX zeolite: Mixture effect with isopropanol and o-xylene
Affiliations: Université de Poitiers, Poitiers, France
Authors with affiliations: Beauchet, Romain, Université de Poitiers, Poitiers, France; Mijoin, Jérôme, Université de Poitiers, Poitiers, France; Batonneau-Gener, Isabelle, Université de Poitiers, Poitiers, France; Magnoux, Patrick, Université de Poitiers, Poitiers, France
Abstract: Catalytic oxidation of isopropanol and o-xylene alone as well as in mixture was investigated over basic NaX zeolite. Experiments were carried out in wet air (11,000ppm of water) and at a high gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 18,000h-1. Results show an inhibiting effect of the o-xylene on the isopropanol destruction whereas the isopropanol has no effect on the o-xylene destruction. Adsorption experiments as well as molecular modelling seem to demonstrate that this inhibiting effect of o-xylene is due to the adsorption of this aromatic VOCs near the apertures of the NaX supercages limiting the access of isopropanol to the basic active sites of this zeolite. Furthermore, the concentration of o-xylene influences the formation of secondary products (propene, coke) resulting from the isopropanol transformation. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Hybrid TiO2-SiMgOx composite for combined chemisorption and photocatalytic elimination of gaseous H2S
Affiliations: CSIC - Instituto de Catálisis y Petroleoquímica (ICP), Madrid, Spain; Centro de Investigaciones Energéticas, Medioambientales y Tecnológicas, Madrid, Spain; Instituto IMDEA Energía, Mostoles, Spain; Universidad Nacional de Educacion a Distancia, Madrid, Spain

L., Dpto. Química Inorgánica y Técnica, Universidad Nacional de Educacion a Distancia, Madrid, Spain; Ávila, Pedro, CSIC - Instituto de Catálisis y Petroleoquímica (ICP), Madrid, Spain; Sanchez, B., Centro de Investigaciones Energéticas, Medioambientales y Tecnológicas, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: Cheap natural sepiolite clay and TiO<inf>2</inf> in the anatase form can easily be converted into an efficient hybrid adsorbent/photocatalytic material, usable for H<inf>2</inf>S and SO<inf>2</inf> capture and odor elimination. This can be achieved by extrusion of powder mixtures combined with coating of photocatalytically active titania. By means of the sorption capacity of the sepiolite, it is possible to fixate gaseous sulfur species and by subsequent or simultaneous use of sunlight or artificial light sources, photocatalytic oxidation into oxidized sulfur compounds can be achieved without SO<inf>2</inf> release. The formation of such compounds as final products makes it possible to regenerate the composite material after saturation by washing with normal water. This technology constitutes an economically promising, sustainable, nontoxic, future method for H<inf>2</inf>S elimination from the gas phase in sewage and wastewater treatment plants. © 2010 American Chemical Society. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.P., Santos, Vera P.; S.A., Carabineiro, Sónia A.C.; P.B., Tavares, P. B.; M.F.R., Pereira, Manuel Fernando R.; J.J., De Melo Órfão, José J.; J.L., Figueiredo, José Luís
Author full names: Santos, Vera P. (24391388700); Carabineiro, Sónia A.C. (6602118574); Tavares, P. B. (23107878500); Pereira, Manuel Fernando R. (8615785800); De Melo Órfão, José J. (6701707160); Figueiredo, José Luís (7102525310)
Title: Oxidation of CO, ethanol and toluene over TiO2 supported noble metal catalysts
Affiliations: Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Centro de Química-Vila Real, Vila Real, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Santos, Vera P., Laboratório de Catálise e Materiais (LCM), Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Carabineiro, Sónia A.C., Laboratório de Catálise e Materiais (LCM), Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Tavares, P. B., Department of Chemistry, Centro de Química-Vila Real, Vila Real, Portugal; Pereira, Manuel Fernando R., Laboratório de Catálise e Materiais (LCM), Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; De Melo Órfão, José J., Laboratório de Catálise e Materiais (LCM), Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Figueiredo, José Luís, Laboratório de Catálise e Materiais (LCM), Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal
Abstract: The oxidation of CO, ethanol and toluene was investigated on noble metal catalysts (Pt, Pd, Ir, Rh and Au) supported on TiO<inf>2</inf>. The catalysts were prepared by liquid phase reduction deposition (LPRD) and by incipient wetness impregnation (IMP). It was observed that the preparation method can have a significant effect on the dispersion of the metallic phase, and subsequently on the performance of the catalysts towards total oxidation of CO or VOC.For CO oxidation, Au IMP was the worst catalyst, while Au LPRD was the most active. This can be explained in terms of different Au particle sizes, well known to be related with catalytic activity. For all the other metals, LPRD also produces better results, although the differences are not so marked as with gold. Iridium seems to be the only exception since results were very similar.In VOC oxidation, the following performance trend was observed: Pt/TiO<inf>2</inf>>Pd/TiO<inf>2</inf>{right double angle bracket}Rh/TiO<inf>2</inf>≈Ir/TiO<inf>2</inf>{right double angle bracket}Au/TiO<inf>2</inf>, for both preparation methods. Ethanol and toluene oxidation over Pt and Pd catalysts were found to be structure sensitive reactions.Some experiments with ethanol/toluene mixtures were performed using the best catalyst (Pt/TiO<inf>2</inf>). It was observed that toluene inhibits the combustion of ethanol, namely by slowing down the partial oxidation of ethanol towards acetaldehyde. Ethanol also has a slight inhibition effect on the total oxidation of toluene. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Last decade of research on activated carbons as catalytic support in chemical processes
Affiliations: CSIC - Instituto de Catálisis y Petroleoquímica (ICP), Madrid, Spain; Universidad Nacional de Educacion a Distancia, Madrid, Spain; Universidad de Extremadura, Badajoz, Spain

Química Inorgánica y Técnica, Universidad Nacional de Educacion a Distancia, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: This review is devoted to the application and knowledge developed in the past 10 years in the area of chemical processes catalyzed by activated carbon supported catalysts. Activated carbons are well known for their catalytic properties and for being used as support in heterogeneous catalysis. The supported catalysts have been successfully used in the chemical industries for long time. In the last decade, carbon supported catalysts have opened the door for new chemical catalytic processes based on their intrinsic features. However, fundamental understanding of molecular structure-reactivity relationship of these carbon materials remains unexplored. Futures advances in all areas may be possible through combined experimental and theoretical approaches. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Arai, Hidetaka; A., Ogata, Atsushi; A., Yamäsaki, Akihiro; H., Kim, Hyun-Ha; Y., Yanagisawa, Yukio
Author full names: Arai, Hidetaka (16199777100); Ogata, Atsushi (56448190500); Yamäsaki, Akihiro (7103172600); Kim, Hyun-Ha (35737438500); Yanagisawa, Yukio (7101683840)
Title: Toluene decomposition by ferroelectrics packed-bed plasma methods: For enhancement of toluene decomposition efficiency and suppression of NOx formation
Affiliations: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Seikei University, Musashino, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Arai, Hidetaka, Environmental Management Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Ogata, Atsushi, Environmental Management Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Yamäsaki, Akihiro, Department of Materials and Life Science, Seikei University, Musashino, Japan; Kim, Hyun-Ha, Environmental Management Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Yanagisawa, Yukio, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Toluene decomposition was carried out using nonthermal plasma reactors, which were packed with spherical ferroelectric pellets [SrTiO<inf>3</inf> (ε=330) or BaTiO<inf>3</inf> (ε=15,000)]. The former showed higher efficiencies for toluene decomposition and suppression of NOx formation than the latter. To clarify the difference in effectiveness between SrTiO<inf>3</inf> and BaTiO<inf>3</inf>, the waveforms of applied voltage and discharge current were investigated in detail using an oscilloscope. Many discharge current pulses were observed in both reactors when plasma discharge was generated. However, plasma conditions, such as maximum value and numbers of pulsed discharge current peaks in one cycle, differed greatly between the two reactors even at the same input power. The results suggested that plasma conditions could be changed by changing the ferroelectric pellets in the packed-bed plasma reactor. We proposed different models of discharge mode in the two plasma reactors, based on the effect of the ferroelectrics on plasma reaction. © 2010 The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.J., Himanen, Sari J.; J.D., Blande, James D.; T., Klemola, Tero; J.T., Pulkkinen, Juha T.; J., Heijari, Juha; J.K., Holopainen, Jarmo K.
Author full names: Himanen, Sari J. (23466601000); Blande, James D. (16063149700); Klemola, Tero (7003671875); Pulkkinen, Juha T. (7004325046); Heijari, Juha (9043533500); Holopainen, Jarmo K. (57155049100)
Title: Birch (Betula spp.) leaves adsorb and re-release volatiles specific to neighbouring plants - a mechanism for associational herbivore resistance?
Affiliations: Itä-Suomen yliopisto, Kuopio, Finland; Natural Resources Institute Finland (Luke), Helsinki, Finland; Turun yliopisto, Turku, Finland; Itä-Suomen yliopisto, Kuopio, Finland; Kotka Maritime Research Centre, Kotka, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Himanen, Sari J., Department of Environmental Sciences, Itä-Suomen yliopisto, Kuopio, Finland, MTT Agrifood Research Finland, Natural Resources Institute Finland (Luke), Helsinki, Finland; Blande, James D., Department of Environmental Sciences, Itä-Suomen yliopisto, Kuopio, Finland; Klemola, Tero, Department of Biology, Turun yliopisto, Turku, Finland; Pulkkinen, Juha T., Department of Biosciences, Itä-Suomen yliopisto, Kuopio, Finland; Heijari, Juha, Department of Environmental Sciences, Itä-Suomen yliopisto, Kuopio, Finland, Kotka Maritime Research Centre, Kotka, Finland; Holopainen, Jarmo K., Department of Environmental Sciences, Itä-Suomen yliopisto, Kuopio, Finland
Abstract: Summary: •Plant-emitted semi-volatile compounds have low vaporization rates at 20-25°C and may therefore persist on surfaces such as plant foliage. The passive adsorption of arthropod-repellent semi-volatiles to neighbouring foliage could convey associational resistance, whereby a plant's neighbours reduce damage caused by herbivores.•We found that birch (Betula spp.) leaves adsorb and re-release the specific arthropod-repelling C<inf>15</inf> semi-volatiles ledene, ledol and palustrol produced by Rhododendron tomentosum when grown in mixed association in a field setup. In a natural habitat, a higher concentration of ledene was released from birches neighbouring R. tomentosum than from birches situated > 5 m from R. tomentosum. Emission of α-humulene, a sesquiterpene synthesized by both Betula pendula and R. tomentosum, was also increased in R. tomentosum-neighbouring B. pendula.•In assessments for associational resistance, we found that the polyphagous green leaf weevils (Polydrusus flavipes) and autumnal moth (Epirrita autumnata) larvae both preferred B. pendula to R. tomentosum. P. flavipes also preferred birch leaves not exposed to R. tomentosum to leaves from mixed associations. In the field, a reduction in Euceraphis betulae aphid density occurred in mixed associations.•Our results suggest that plant/tree species may be protected by semi-volatile compounds emitted by a more herbivore-resistant heterospecific neighbour. © The Authors (2010). Journal compilation © New Phytologist Trust (2010). © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: K., Kang, Kyoung-hee; J., Dong, Jongin
Author full names: Kang, Kyoung-hee (35791866800); Dong, Jongin (7403365121)
Title: Hazardous air pollutant (HAP) emission characterization of sewage treatment facilities in Korea
Affiliations: National Institute of Environmental Research, Icheon, South Korea; University of Seoul, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kang, Kyoung-hee, Air Quality Research Division, National Institute of Environmental Research, Icheon, South Korea; Dong, Jongin, Faculty of Environmental Engineering, University of Seoul, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Until recently, nearly all sewage treatment-related regulations and researches have focused on the removal of the conventional and toxic pollutants from liquid effluents. The discharge of toxic compounds to the atmosphere has been implicitly regarded as a way of removal or destruction. During sewage treatment, the fate mechanism of volatilization/stripping, sorption and biotransformation primarily determines the fate of volatile HAPs. The objectives of this study are to investigate the emission characteristics of HAPs, which are generated from the liquid surface of sewage treatment facilities, by using an emission isolation flux chamber. HAP emissions increased at the inlet of the aerobic chamber during summer due to the relatively high atmospheric temperature. The percent ratio of flux for toluene reached its peak in winter, accounting for 33.6-34.2% of the total, but decreased to 25.1-28.6% in summer. In autumn, trichloroethene (TCE) was the highest, recording 17.6-18.1%, with chloroform and toluene showing similar levels. It seems that the ratio of chlorinated hydrocarbons increases in both summer and autumn because the chamber temperature during that time is higher than winter. This study is the initial study to investigate the emission characteristics of volatile HAPs emitted from domestic sewage treatment facilities to the air in Korea. Therefore, the isolation flux chamber will be used as an emission estimations tool to measure HAPs from sewage treatment facilities and may be applied to develop the emission factor and national source inventory of HAPs. © 2010 The Royal Society of Chemistry. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: C., Domeño, Celia; Á., Rodríguez-Lafuente, Ángel; J.M., Martos, J. M.; R., Bilbao, Rafael; C., Nerin, C.
Author full names: Domeño, Celia (6603172565); Rodríguez-Lafuente, Ángel (35776928700); Martos, J. M. (35776639700); Bilbao, Rafael (56781173300); Nerin, C. (57017459400)
Title: VOC removal and deodorization of effluent gases from an industrial plant by photo-oxidation, chemical oxidation, and ozonization
Affiliations: Escuela de Ingeniería y Arquitectura, Universidad de Zaragoza, Zaragoza, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Domeño, Celia, ; Rodríguez-Lafuente, Ángel, ; Martos, J. M., Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Escuela de Ingeniería y Arquitectura, Universidad de Zaragoza, Zaragoza, Spain; Bilbao, Rafael, Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Escuela de Ingeniería y Arquitectura, Universidad de Zaragoza, Zaragoza, Spain; Nerin, C.,
Abstract: The efficiency of photo-oxidation, chemical oxidation by sodium hypochlorite, and ozonization for the industrial-scale removal of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and odors from gaseous emissions was studied by applying these treatments (in an experimental system) to substances passing through an emission stack of a factory producing maize derivatives. Absorption and ozonization were the most efficient treatment, removing 75% and 98% of VOCs, respectively, while photo-oxidation only removed about 59%. The emitted chemical compounds and odors were identified and quantified by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (in full-scan mode). In addition to presenting the results, their implications for selecting optimal processes for treating volatile emissions are discussed © 2010 American Chemical Society. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: N., Invernizzi, Noela; G., Foladori, Guillermo
Author full names: Invernizzi, Noela (24778682700); Foladori, Guillermo (11241338000)
Title: Nanotechnology implications for labor
Affiliations: Universidade Federal do Parana, Curitiba, Brazil; Universidad Autónoma de Zacatecas, Zacatecas, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Invernizzi, Noela, Education Faculty, Universidade Federal do Parana, Curitiba, Brazil; Foladori, Guillermo, Development Studies, Universidad Autónoma de Zacatecas, Zacatecas, Mexico
Abstract: Research on the social implications of nanotechnology has hardly addressed the topic of labor, despite the social importance of the subject. Based on an analysis of the characteristics of nanotechnology products that are already on the market, this article shows that nanotechnology will have a significant impact on employment distribution among sectors, the international division of labor and skill requirements for labor, causing destabilizing effects on employment at the national and global levels. The authors describe how nanotechnology will lead to employment creation and destruction, changes in sectoral distribution of the workforce, changes in the global spatial distribution of the workforce, and changes in qualifications for jobs. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F.N., Agüero, Fabiola Nerina; B.P., Barbero, Bibiana P.; O., Sanz, Oihane; F.J.E., Lozano, Francisco J.Echave; M., Montes, Mario; L.E., Cadús, Luis E.
Author full names: Agüero, Fabiola Nerina (23099500000); Barbero, Bibiana P. (6603006154); Sanz, Oihane (23036585400); Lozano, Francisco J.Echave (57214481114); Montes, Mario (7102925861); Cadús, Luis E. (7004615497)
Title: Influence of the support on MnOx metallic monoliths for the combustion of volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: Universidad Nacional de San Luis, San Luis, Argentina; Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Agüero, Fabiola Nerina, Universidad Nacional de San Luis, San Luis, Argentina; Barbero, Bibiana P., Universidad Nacional de San Luis, San Luis, Argentina; Sanz, Oihane, Departamento de Química Aplicada, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Lozano, Francisco J.Echave, Departamento de Química Aplicada, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Montes, Mario, Departamento de Química Aplicada, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Cadús, Luis E., Universidad Nacional de San Luis, San Luis, Argentina
Abstract: The influence of the alumina layer nature which acts as the support on the preparation of structured catalysts and on the catalytic performance in VOC combustion was studied. Anodized aluminum and a ferritic alloy covered with colloidal alumina (Nyacol) and θ-δ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> were the materials used to prepare the monolith catalysts. The impregnation was performed in one and two stages using two different concentrations of manganese acetate solutions. The catalytic properties of these catalysts were evaluated in ethanol, ethyl acetate, and toluene combustion. The most active catalysts in the combustion of the three molecules were those prepared using a θ-δ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> as a support. The low activity of aluminum monoliths anodized with H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf> is due to the presence of SO<inf>4</inf>2- ions which act as catalyst poison. The anodization with H<inf>2</inf>C<inf>2</inf>O<inf>4</inf> is a preferable method to prepare MnOx monolithic catalysts. © 2010 American Chemical Society. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: The leading resource on ozone technology, this book contains everything from chemical basics to technical and economic concerns. The text has been updated to include the latest developments in water treatment and industrial processes. Following an introduction, the first part looks at toxicology, reaction mechanisms and full-scale applications, while Part B covers experimental design, equipment and analytical methods, mass transfer, reaction kinetics and the application of ozone in combined processes. © 2010 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. Authors: W.R., Niessen, Walter R.
Author full names: Niessen, Walter R. (7006660809)
Title: Combustion and Incineration Processes: Applications in Environmental Engineering, Fourth Edition
Affiliations: Niessen Consultants, Andover, United States
Authors with affiliations: Niessen, Walter R., Niessen Consultants, Andover, United States
Abstract: "In our 'throwaway' society, with landfills filled to capacity, interest in incineration- and conversion-based waste management technologies continues to grow. Increasing net waste generation rates within U.S. metropolitan centers, skyrocketing transportation costs for waste hauling, and the enticement of increased electrical revenues from 'green' power sources all amplify the need for better technologies. Written by an internationally renowned expert with fifty years of experience, Combustion and Incineration Processes: Applications in Environmental Engineering, Fourth Edition has been updated to reflect the latest advances in the field, keeping pace with the evolution of complex and interdisciplinary technology that can better the environment. Detailing the changes that have occurred since the previous editions appeared, this volume's expanded scope includes additional details, data, and graphics regarding the design and operational characteristics of municipal and industrial waste incineration and conversion systems and numerous refinements in associated pollution control. The book offers a thorough overview of: Design, operation, and evaluation of incineration and conversion (gasification) systems for hazardous and non-hazardous gaseous, liquid, biosolid, and solid wastes; the waste management facility, from contaminant receipt, materials handling, and storage to stack discharge and dispersion; breakthroughs in air pollution control; waste and residue characteristics; and advances in materials handling, waste processing, refractory and materials engineering, combustion technology, and energy recovery to reduce and control toxins and pollutants in the environment. Achievement of true Zero Waste, or the eradication of landfills, will likely require thermal processing to economically extract the ultimate useful value from waste residue after minimization, reuse, and recycling. The latest technical advances continue to evolve and attract increased attention, and this book provides the requisite technical education and guidance to those responsible for selection and procurement of these new systems". © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.S., Matlack, Albert S.
Author full names: Matlack, Albert S. (6507117597)
Title: Introduction to green chemistry
Authors with affiliations: Matlack, Albert S.,
Abstract: In the nearly 10 years since the publication of the bestselling first edition of Introduction to Green Chemistry, interest in green chemistry and clean processes has grown so much that topics, such as fluorous biphasic catalysis, metal organic frameworks, and process intensification, barely mentioned in the first edition, have become major areas of research. In addition, government funding has ramped up the development of fuel cells and biofuels. It reflects the evolving focus from pollution remediation to pollution prevention. Copiously illustrated with over 800 figures, this second edition provides an update from the frontiers of the field. New and expanded research topics: • Metal-organic frameworks • Solid acids for alkylation of isobutene by butanes • Carbon molecular sieves • Mixed micro- and mesoporous solids • Organocatalysis • Process intensification and gas phase enzymatic reactions • Hydrogen storage for fuel cells • Reactive distillation • Catalysts in action on an atomic scale Updated and expanded current events topics: • Industry resistance to inherently safer chemistry • Nuclear power • Removal of mercury from vaccines • Removal of mercury and lead from primary explosives • Biofuels • Uses for surplus glycerol • New hard materials to reduce wear • Electronic waste • Smart growth The book covers traditional green chemistry topics, including catalysis, benign solvents, and alternative feedstocks. It also discusses relevant but less frequently covered topics with chapters such as Chemistry of Longer Wear and Population and the Environment. This coverage highlights the importance of chemistry to everyday life and demonstrates the benefits the expanded exploitation of green chemistry can have for society. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Son, Youn-suk; K., Kim, Ki-joon; J., Kim, Jo-chun
Title: A review on VOCs control technology using electron beam
Affiliations: Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea; National Institute of Environmental Research, Icheon, South Korea; Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Son, Youn-suk, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Ki-joon, Emission Sources Research Division, National Institute of Environmental Research, Icheon, South Korea; Kim, Jo-chun, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea, Department of Environmental Engineering, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The removal characteristics for aromatic and aliphatic VOCs by electron beam (EB) were discussed in terms of several removal variables such as initial VOC concentration, absorbed dose, background gas, moisture content, reactor material and inlet temperature. It was reviewed that only reactor material was an independent variable among the potential control factors concerned. It was also suggested that main mechanism by EB should be radical reaction for the VOC removal rather than that by primary electrons. It was discussed that the removal efficiency of benzene was lower than that of hexane due to a closed benzene ring. In the case of aromatic VOCs, it was observed that the decomposition of the VOCs with more functional groups attached on the benzene ring was much easier than those with less ones. As for aliphatic VOCs, it was also implied that the longer carbon chain was, the higher the removal efficiency became. An EB-catalyst hybrid system was discussed as an alternative way to remove VOCs more effectively than EB-only system due to much less by-products. This hybrid included supporting materials such as cordierite, Y-zeolite, and γ-alumina. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Rojo, Naiara; G., Gallastegui, Gorka; A., Barona, Astrid; L., Gurtubay, Luis; G., Ibarra-Berastegui, Gabriel; A., Elías, Ana
Author full names: Rojo, Naiara (36667245500); Gallastegui, Gorka (36716192800); Barona, Astrid (6701889016); Gurtubay, Luis (23070797300); Ibarra-Berastegui, Gabriel (6508274262); Elías, Ana (7203051097)
Title: Biotechnology as an alternative for carbon disulfide treatment in air pollution control
Affiliations: Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Rojo, Naiara, Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Gallastegui, Gorka, Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Barona, Astrid, Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Gurtubay, Luis, Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Ibarra-Berastegui, Gabriel, Nuclear Engineering and Fluid Mechanics Department, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Elías, Ana, Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain
Abstract: Biotechnology has emerged as an affordable, effective, and eco-friendly alternative to treat carbon disulfide (CS<inf>2</inf>) containing waste gases. Carbon disulfide is a chemical of widespread use both in the past and in the present. Its industry demand has dramatically changed over the last two decades and is expected to grow in future in step with those industries involving fibre, mining, rubber products, and the agro-chemical sector. This compound, classified as a hazardous air pollutant about 20 years ago, has been re-appraised, as increasingly restrictive pollution standards are expected to be introduced. An array of physical-chemical technologies for treating CS <inf>2</inf> containing air are already in use, but they have a series of drawbacks, such as high energy consumption (incineration, thermal oxidation), the immobilization of the contaminant solely from one phase to another (adsorption), and the generation of secondary by-products that require additional treatment (hydrolysis). Thus, technological research on affordable processing alternatives is of considerable interest for related industries using or producing CS<inf>2</inf>. The biological technologies whose efficiency is based on the activity of microorganisms to biodegrade air pollutants overcome many of the disadvantages of conventional techniques and are especially useful for the removal of relatively low concentrations of pollutants. In this paper, the main properties, sources, and uses of CS<inf>2</inf> are summarized, and alternative biotreatments for CS<inf>2</inf> are reviewed. Several applications of the technical and economical feasibility of biofilters and biotrickling filters are shown, although their widespread industrial application still requires further research. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.A., Hosseini, Seyed Ali; M.T., Sadeghi, Mohammad Taghi; A.A., Alemi, Abdol Ali; A., Niaei, Aligholi; D., Salari, Dariush; L., Kafi-Ahmadi, Leila
Author full names: Hosseini, Seyed Ali (25936409000); Sadeghi, Mohammad Taghi (57203721754); Alemi, Abdol Ali (6602359891); Niaei, Aligholi (55942693600); Salari, Dariush (8978153600); Kafi-Ahmadi, Leila (35731643100)
Title: Synthesis, characterization, and performance of LaZnxFe1-xO3 perovskite nanocatalysts for toluene combustion
Affiliations: University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Hosseini, Seyed Ali, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Sadeghi, Mohammad Taghi, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Alemi, Abdol Ali, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Niaei, Aligholi, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Salari, Dariush, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran; Kafi-Ahmadi, Leila, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran
Abstract: Nanostructured LaFeO<inf>3</inf> and substituted LaZn<inf>x</inf>Fe<inf>1-x</inf>O<inf>3</inf> (x = 0.01, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.3) perovskites were synthesized by the sol-gel auto-combustion method and used in the catalytic combustion of toluene. Their structures and surface properties were investigated by X-ray diffraction, Fourier transmission infrared spectroscopy, BET surface area, and scanning electron microscopy. Characterization data revealed that the total insertion of zinc into LaFeO<inf>3</inf> takes place when x ≤ 0.1. However, ZnO segregation occurs to some extent, especially at x > 0.1. The performance of these perovskites was evaluated by toluene combustion. The catalytic activity of the catalysts increased substantially with an increase in zinc substitution. These results can be attributed to the cooperative effect between LaZn<inf>x</inf>Fe<inf>1-x</inf>O<inf>3</inf> and the zinc oxide phases. The relative concentration of these phases determines their oxygen activation ability and reactivity. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: W., Li, Weibin; H., Gong, Hao
Title: Recent progress in the removal of volatile organic compounds by catalytic combustion
Source title: Wuli Huaxue Xuebao/ Acta Physico - Chimica Sinica
Affiliations: Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Weibin, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Gong, Hao, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Abstract: Catalytic combustion is one of the most effective techniques for the removal of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). In this review, the recent developments in catalytic combustion of VOCs with regard to active species such as noble metal catalysts, mixed metal oxides, perovskite and spinel metal oxide phases were examined. The effects of particle sizes of active species, catalyst supports, the water vapor effect and the coking effect on catalytic combustion were evaluated. It is found that the research on noble metal catalysts mainly focuses on developing new supports and bi-elemental noble metal catalysts; while the research on non-noble metal catalysts focuses on developing new mixed metal oxides, perovskites and spinel catalysts, as well as investigating the effects of particle sizes and various supports on the combustion activity. Additionally, as far as practical application is concerned, the effect of water vapor and coking deactivation on the catalytic combustion process are discussed. This review will be helpful in choosing an appropriate technique for the removal of VOCs by catalytic combustion with high activity and high stability. © Editorial office of Acta Physico-Chimica Sinica. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Catalytic Combustion; Coking Deactivation; Noble Metal; Non-noble Metal; Volatile Organic Compounds

Abstract: The leading resource on ozone technology, this book contains everything from chemical basics to technical and economic concerns.The text has been updated to include the latest developments in water treatment and industrial processes.Following an introduction, the first part looks at toxicology, reaction mechanisms and full-scale applications, while Part B covers experimental design, equipment and analytical methods, mass transfer, reaction kinetics and the application of ozone in combined processes. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Langmuir-hinshelwood model of photocatalytic oxidation kinetics of volatile organic pollutants
Affiliations: Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Hangzhou Environmental Monitoring Centre, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Jingshuang Jinglan, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Wang, Zimeng, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Shen, Jiandong, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai, China, Hangzhou Environmental Monitoring Centre, Hangzhou, China; Zhang, Shicheng, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Chen, Jianmin, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: The photocatalytic oxidation (PCO) kinetics of volatile organic pollutants generally fit the L-H model. In this paper, we reviewed the recent research in proposed kinetic models based on L-H models. However, besides the flow rate and the initial concentration, light intensity, relative humidity, the photoreactor-related coefficients, the convective mass transfer coefficients, electron-hole pair recombination rate and intermediate by-production also play an important role in the photocatalytic oxidation reactions. Methods to identify the rate-determining step using those kinetic models were then discussed. The applicability of L-H model under various experimental conditions, such as photoreactor parameters, light sources and the properties of VOCs and photocatalysts, was also investigated. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Kinetic Models; Photocatalytic Oxidation; Volatile Organic Pollutants

Authors: M.C., Alvarez-Galvan, M. C.; V.A., de la Peña O'Shea, V. A.; G., Arzamendi, Gurutze; B.G., Pawelec, B. G.; L.M., Gandía, Luis M.; J.L., Fierro, J. L.G.
Author full names: Alvarez-Galvan, M. C. (6507500014); de la Peña O'Shea, V. A. (6603184783); Arzamendi, Gurutze (6701457770); Pawelec, B. G. (56270389100); Gandía, Luis M. (7005125966); Fierro, J. L.G. (7202608150)
Title: Methyl ethyl ketone combustion over La-transition metal (Cr, Co, Ni, Mn) perovskites
Affiliations: CSIC - Instituto de Catálisis y Petroleoquímica (ICP), Madrid, Spain; Instituto IMDEA Energía, Mostoles, Spain; Universidad Pública de Navarra, Pamplona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Alvarez-Galvan, M. C., CSIC - Instituto de Catálisis y Petroleoquímica (ICP), Madrid, Spain; de la Peña O'Shea, V. A., Instituto IMDEA Energía, Mostoles, Spain; Arzamendi, Gurutze, Department of Applied Chemistry, Universidad Pública de Navarra, Pamplona, Spain; Pawelec, B. G., CSIC - Instituto de Catálisis y Petroleoquímica (ICP), Madrid, Spain; Gandía, Luis M., Department of Applied Chemistry, Universidad Pública de Navarra, Pamplona, Spain; Fierro, J. L.G., CSIC - Instituto de Catálisis y Petroleoquímica (ICP), Madrid, Spain
Abstract: A series of LaBO<inf>3</inf> (B = Cr, Co, Ni, Mn) and La<inf>0.9</inf>K<inf>0.1</inf>MnO<inf>3+δ</inf> perovskites have been prepared and tested as catalysts in the combustion of methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) at two concentration levels in air. Complete MEK conversion can be achieved for the most concentrated stream (1250 ppmv, WHSV = 425 h-1) at temperatures between 270 °C (manganite) and 345 °C (chromite). Activity is governed by the nature of the cation in position B and related to reducibility, being comparable for manganite activity with that of the much more expensive Pt-supported catalysts. Doping with K of lanthanum manganite produces an increase in surface area, as well as the formation of non-stoichiometric oxygen and a greater proportion of Mn4+ on the surface. All these factors may have a role in increasing its activity for catalytic combustion. Catalytic results suggest a marked influence of MEK concentration on the combustion rate. MEK oxidation to CO<inf>2</inf> goes through acetaldehyde as intermediate product; methyl vinyl ketone and diacetyl (2,3-butanedione) were also formed, albeit in very low amounts. Nevertheless, acetaldehyde yield is zero at complete conversion, so the combustion of MEK can be carried out over these perovskite systems with 100% selectivity for CO<inf>2</inf>. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Z., Tian, Zhen-Yu; N., Bahlawane, Naoufal; F., Qi, Fei; K., Kohse-Höinghaus, Katharina
Author full names: Tian, Zhen-Yu (15835938200); Bahlawane, Naoufal (6602680443); Qi, Fei (7101777280); Kohse-Höinghaus, Katharina (35596830400)
Title: Catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbons over Co3O4 catalyst prepared by CVD
Affiliations: University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Universität Bielefeld, Bielefeld, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tian, Zhen-Yu, National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Bahlawane, Naoufal, Physikalische Chemie I, Universität Bielefeld, Bielefeld, Germany; Qi, Fei, National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Kohse-Höinghaus, Katharina, Physikalische Chemie I, Universität Bielefeld, Bielefeld, Germany
Abstract: The total oxidation of C<inf>2</inf>H<inf>2</inf>, C<inf>3</inf>H<inf>6</inf>, C<inf>3</inf>H<inf>8</inf>, n-C<inf>4</inf>H<inf>8</inf>, n-C<inf>4</inf>H<inf>10</inf> and i-C<inf>4</inf>H<inf>10</inf> was studied in a monolithic flow reactor under temperature-programmed mode and highly diluted conditions. The non-catalytic combustion of the investigated hydrocarbons leads to a substantial formation of CO and traces of methane at intermediate temperatures. This drawback was suppressed upon the deposition of a thin layer of Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> on the monolith and all investigated hydrocarbons tend to light off at 250-290 °C. The apparent activation energy was found to exhibit a linear correlation with the C-H bond dissociation energy, indicating that the C-H activation is still the rate-limiting step. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
