Authors: C., Kennes, Christian; E.R., Rene, Eldon Raj; M.C., Veiga, Maria Carmen
Author full names: Kennes, Christian (8627862800); Rene, Eldon Raj (14523428600); Veiga, Maria Carmen (35550232800)
Title: Bioprocesses for air pollution control
Source title: Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology
Affiliations: Universidade da Coruña, A Coruna, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Kennes, Christian, Chemical Engineering Laboratory, Universidade da Coruña, A Coruna, Spain; Rene, Eldon Raj, Chemical Engineering Laboratory, Universidade da Coruña, A Coruna, Spain; Veiga, Maria Carmen, Chemical Engineering Laboratory, Universidade da Coruña, A Coruna, Spain
Abstract: Bioprocesses have been developed as relatively recent alternatives to conventional, non-biological technologies, forwaste gas treatment and air pollution control in general. This paper reviewsmajor biodegradation processes relevant in this field as well as both accepted andmajor innovative bioreactor configurations studied or used nowadays for the treatment of polluted air, i.e. biofilters, one- and two-liquid phase biotrickling filters, bioscrubbers, membrane bioreactors, rotating biodiscs and biodrums, one- and two-liquid phase suspended growth bioreactors, as well as hybrid reactor configurations. Some of these bioreactors are being used at full-scale for solving air pollution problems, while others are still at the research and development stage at laboratory- or pilot-scale. © 2009 Society of Chemical Industry. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Kim, Hyun-Ha; J., Kim, Jongho; A., Ogata, Atsushi
Author full names: Kim, Hyun-Ha (35737438500); Kim, Jongho (57203325151); Ogata, Atsushi (56448190500)
Title: Microscopic observation of discharge plasma on the surface of zeolites supported metal nanoparticles
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Hanseo University, Seosan, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Hyun-Ha, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Kim, Jongho, Department of Environmental Engineering, Hanseo University, Seosan, South Korea; Ogata, Atsushi, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The physical role of nanometre-sized metal particles (Ag, Zr, Cu) in the generation of discharge plasma over the surface of zeolites is presented.The optical observation system, consisting of a microscope-ICCD camera, was applied to observe the generation of discharge plasma on zeolites supported metal nanoparticle. The zeolite supported metal nanoparticles assisted the discharge plasma to expand over a wide surface area. Among the tested active metals in this study, silver exhibited the most prominent influence in the discharge plasmas on the surface of zeolites. On the other hand, plasma eneration was limited to the edges of the zeolites when the bare zeolites were used. The difference in the shape and the area of the discharge plasma was also found to be correlated with the performance of plasma-catalyst reactor for the decomposition of volatile organic compounds. The microscopic observation method can also be used for the rough-but-rapid evaluation of catalyst for a plasma-driven catalyst process. © 2009 IOP Publishing Ltd. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Processes for removal of odorous compds. From air by absorption, adsorption, biofiltration, biowashing, condensation, combustion and catalytic oxidn. were reviewed. In particular, the metal and metal oxide catalysts for oxidn. of N and S-contg. Compds. (thiophene, MeSH, amines, NH<inf>3</inf>) were characterized. Photocatalytic processes were also mentioned. © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.M., Harling, Alice M.; D.J., Glover, David J.; J.C., Whitehead, J. Christopher; K., Zhang, Kui
Author full names: Harling, Alice M. (57974385500); Glover, David J. (24375989400); Whitehead, J. Christopher (55664107500); Zhang, Kui (56599444600)
Title: The role of ozone in the plasma-catalytic destruction of environmental pollutants
Affiliations: The University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; Plasma Clean Ltd., Stockport, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Harling, Alice M., School of Chemistry, The University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; Glover, David J., Plasma Clean Ltd., Stockport, United Kingdom; Whitehead, J. Christopher, School of Chemistry, The University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; Zhang, Kui, Plasma Clean Ltd., Stockport, United Kingdom
Abstract: The destruction of low concentrations of toluene and cyclohexane in air streams using the combination of a novel multistage, non-thermal plasma reactor with either a MnO<inf>2</inf> or a MnO<inf>2</inf>-CuO catalyst has been investigated. It is found possible to get complete destruction of the organic pollutant when the plasma and catalyst were combined. The different catalysts produced different outcomes in terms of the residual ozone in the outlet stream and the extent of oxidation to CO<inf>2</inf>. Neither of these compounds react to any measurable extent with ozone in the gas-phase nor are they decomposed by the catalyst at the temperature of the experiment. It is deduced that adsorption of ozone onto the catalyst surface and its subsequent dissociation into reactive atomic oxygen species is the key step in the heterogeneous destruction of toluene and cyclohexane. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F.F., Tassi, Franco F.; G., Montegrossi, Giordano; O., Vaselli, Orlando; C., Liccioli, Caterina; S., Moretti, Sandro; B., Nisi, B.
Author full names: Tassi, Franco F. (6602532097); Montegrossi, Giordano (55957368000); Vaselli, Orlando (7003931314); Liccioli, Caterina (26633993700); Moretti, Sandro (7103215933); Nisi, B. (24725188100)
Title: Degradation of C2-C15 volatile organic compounds in a landfill cover soil
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse, Sezione di Firenze, Florence, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Tassi, Franco F., Department of Earth Sciences, Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy, Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse, Sezione di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Montegrossi, Giordano, Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse, Sezione di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Vaselli, Orlando, Department of Earth Sciences, Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy, Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse, Sezione di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Liccioli, Caterina, Department of Earth Sciences, Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Moretti, Sandro, Department of Earth Sciences, Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Nisi, B., Department of Earth Sciences, Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy
Abstract: The composition of non-methane volatile organic compounds (hereafter VOCs) in i) the cover soil, at depths of 30, 50 and 70 cm, and ii) gas recovery wells from Case Passerini landfill site, (Florence, Italy) was determined by GC-MS. The study, based on the analysis of interstitial gases sampled along vertical profiles within the cover soil, was aimed to investigate the VOC behaviour as biogas transits from a reducing to a relatively more oxidizing environment. A total of 48 and 63 different VOCs were identified in the soil and well gases, respectively. Aromatics represent the dominant group (71.5% of total VOC) in soil gases, followed by alkanes (6.8%), ketones (5.7%), organic acids (5.2%), aldehydes (3.0%), esters (2.6%), halogenated compounds (2.1%) and terpenes (1.3%). Cyclics, heterocyclics, S-bearing compounds and phenols are ≤ 1%. In the wells the VOC composition is characterized by higher concentrations of cyclic (7.6%) and S-bearing compounds (2%) and lower concentrations of O-bearing compounds. The vertical distribution of VOCs in the cover soil shows significant variations: alkanes, aromatics and cyclics decrease at decreasing depth, whereas an inverse trend is displayed by the O-bearing species. Total VOC and CH<inf>4</inf> concentrations at a depth of 30 cm in the soil are comparable, inferring that microbial activity is likely affecting VOCs at a very minor extent with respect to CH<inf>4</inf>. According to these considerations, to assess the biogas emission impact, usually carried out on the sole basis of CO<inf>2</inf> and CH<inf>4</inf> emission rates, the physical-chemical behaviour of VOCs in the cover soil, regulating the discharge of these highly contaminant compounds in ambient air, has to be taken into account. The soil vertical distribution of these species can be used to better evaluate the efficiency of oxidative capability of intermediate and final covers. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Bai, Yanhong; J., Chen, Jierong; X.Y.X.Y., Li, Xiao'ang Y.Xiao Yong; C., Zhang, Chunhong
Author full names: Bai, Yanhong (59606638300); Chen, Jierong (56206576400); Li, Xiao'ang Y.Xiao Yong (55831302900); Zhang, Chunhong (56529832700)
Title: Non-thermal plasmas chemistry as a tool for environmental pollutants abatement
Source title: Reviews of Environmental Contamination and Toxicology
Affiliations: Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China
Authors with affiliations: Bai, Yanhong, School of Life Science and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China, Department of Chemistry, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Chen, Jierong, Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Li, Xiao'ang Y.Xiao Yong, School of Life Science and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Zhang, Chunhong, School of Life Science and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China
Abstract: Increasing concern for protecting the environment against the effects of growing industrialization, intensive agriculture, and further exploitation of natural resources poses enormous challenges to contemporary science and to the sustainable development of mankind. Most environmental pollutants pose some harm to human health and the environment irrespective of whether exposures occur through air, water, soil, or the food chain. Therefore, innovative alternative technologies and equipment are needed to abate, convert, decompose, or otherwise manage environmental pollutants. Non-thermal plasma (NTPs) chemistry is an innovative tool for potentially abating environmental pollutants; this technology promises to meet a host of abatement demands, including those mentioned above, and also offers crucial advantages such as improved energy efficiency, higher levels of treatment in smaller spaces, and near zero-emissions. © 2009 Springer-Verlag US. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: Z., Li, Zhanguo; Z., Hu, Zhen; Z., Liu, Zhinong; P., Cao, Peng
Title: Non-equilibrium plasma decomposition reaction kinetics model of gaseous pollutant
Affiliations: Research Institute for Chemical Defense of China, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Zhanguo, Research Institute for Chemical Defense of China, Beijing, China; Hu, Zhen, Research Institute for Chemical Defense of China, Beijing, China; Liu, Zhinong, Research Institute for Chemical Defense of China, Beijing, China; Cao, Peng, Research Institute for Chemical Defense of China, Beijing, China
Abstract: A non-equilibrium plasma decomposition reaction kinetics model of gaseous pollutant was developed. The reaction rate constants of various pollutants were obtained by substituting the decomposition experimental data reported from literature into the model equation. The result showed that under different conditions of discharge mode, electrode structure, and operation parameters, the decomposition reaction rate constants were almost unchanged for the same pollutant, which proved that the model had wide applicability and was independent of the discharge mode and reactor structure. The reaction rate constants of pollutants could be classified according to their molecular structure. Then the relationship between reaction rate constant and the dissociation energy of the easiest dissociating chemical bond (EDCB) in pollutant molecule was discussed. It was found that the reaction rate constants of pollutants with lower dissociation energy of EDCB were larger than those of pollutants with a steady structure and higher dissociation energy of EDCB. For example, sulfide, amine, alkene and substituted alkene had much larger reaction rate constants (about 10-2 m3·W-1·h-1) than aromatics, alkane and substituted alkane (10-4-10-3 m3·W-1·h-1). © All Rights Reserved. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Cao, Hongyan; W., Song, Weicong; M., Gong, Maochu; J., Wang, Jianli; S., Yan, Shenghui; Z., Liu, Zhimin; Y.Q., Chen, Yaoqiangb Qiang
Author full names: Cao, Hongyan (23975308400); Song, Weicong (24280503700); Gong, Maochu (7201566748); Wang, Jianli (56365051600); Yan, Shenghui (23977058000); Liu, Zhimin (7406671362); Chen, Yaoqiangb Qiang (8451984400)
Title: MnOx/Al2O3/Ce0.45Zr0.45M0.10Oy (M = Mn, Y, La) catalysts used for ethanol catalytic combustion
Affiliations: Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Cao, Hongyan, College of Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Song, Weicong, College of Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Gong, Maochu, College of Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Wang, Jianli, College of Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Yan, Shenghui, College of Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Liu, Zhimin, College of Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Chen, Yaoqiangb Qiang, College of Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China
Abstract: MnO<inf>x</inf>/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>/Ce<inf>0.45</inf>Zr<inf>0.45</inf>M<inf>0.10</inf>O<inf>y</inf> (M = Mn, Y, La) catalysts were prepared by impregnation method and characterized by BET, TPR and XRD analyses. The catalytic activities toward ethanol combustion were investigated in a microreactor. The results demonstrated that the catalytic activity of MnO<inf>x</inf>/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>/Ce<inf>0.50</inf>Zr<inf>0.50</inf>O<inf>2</inf> monolithic catalyst could be improved by doping Mn, Y and La into Ce<inf>0.50</inf>Zr<inf>0.50</inf>O<inf>2</inf>. When doping Y into Ce<inf>0.50</inf>Zr<inf>0.50</inf>O<inf>2</inf>, the catalyst MnO<inf>x</inf>/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>/Ce<inf>0.45</inf>Zr<inf>0.45</inf>Y<inf>0.10</inf>O<inf>1.95</inf> showed the highest activity. The 100% conversion temperature of ethanol was 230 °C. Furthermore, once the conversion of ethanol started, the complete conversion was quickly achieved. The doping of Mn, Y and La led to better activity for ethanol combustion and lower temperature reduction peaks in TPR profiles. The doping of Mn resulted in enhanced oxygen storage capacity (OSC), larger area of the reduction peaks, and excellent reactivity, and the doping of Y resulted in the lowest reduction temperature and the best activity. © 2009 CAS/DICP. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Zhu, Tao; J., Li, Jian; W., Liang, Wenjun; Y., Jin, Yuquan
Title: Experimental research on toluene decomposition with high frequency DBD
Affiliations: Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, Tao, College of Environmental and Energy Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Li, Jian, College of Environmental and Energy Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Liang, Wenjun, College of Environmental and Energy Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China; Jin, Yuquan, College of Environmental and Energy Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China
Abstract: It is necessary to remove toluene due to its doing harm to people's health in its wide use. Dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) produces non-thermal plasma to remove toluene using high frequency alternating current (AC). Based on the elements of circuit and DBD, the effects of reactor structure, voltage, frequency and power on removal efficiency of toluene were tested. The byproducts and decomposition mechanism of toluene were analyzed. The experimental results show the 99-ceramic reactor of DBD is helpful for toluene removal than the quartz glass reactor. The frequency and power are nonlinearly related with the removal efficiency. If harmonic frequency occurs, the highest power belongs to reactor, and removal efficiency reaches its maximum value. The byproducts include aldehyde, alcohols, amide, and benzene detected by GC-MS. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B., Kartheuser, Benoît
Author full names: Kartheuser, Benoît (6507916117)
Title: Photocatalytic nanomaterials for air purification
Affiliations: Certech ABSL, Seneffe, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Kartheuser, Benoît, Certech ABSL, Seneffe, Belgium
Abstract: Indoor air quality is becoming today a serious concern for the population of Western Countries. People spend generally 80 to 90 % of their time in confined spaces. They are exposed to a very large variety of pollutants (volatile organic compounds: VOC) coming from human activities, heating, chemicals released by furniture, building materials etc. Odours problems encountered in such places are related to the presence of these VOCs sometimes in sub ppmv concentration. Photocatalysis can be a good solution for air remediation. We will be presenting some results on active air purifier testing. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Kudra, Tadeusz; A.S.S., Mujumdar, Arun Sadashiv Sadashiv
Author full names: Kudra, Tadeusz (7003699022); Mujumdar, Arun Sadashiv Sadashiv (57195520301)
Title: Advanced drying technologies, second edition
Affiliations: CANMET Energy Technology Center, Ottawa, Canada; National University of Singapore, Singapore City, Singapore; Université McGill, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kudra, Tadeusz, CANMET Energy Technology Center, Ottawa, Canada; Mujumdar, Arun Sadashiv Sadashiv, Metals and Materials Technology Centre, National University of Singapore, Singapore City, Singapore, Université McGill, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: Presents Drying Breakthroughs for an Array of Materials Despite being one of the oldest, most energy-intensive unit operations, industrial drying is perhaps the least scrutinized technique at the microscopic level. Yet in the wake of today's global energy crisis, drying research and development is on the rise. Following in the footsteps of the widely read first edition, Advanced Drying Technologies, Second Edition is the direct outcome of the recent phenomenal growth in drying literature and new drying hardware. This edition provides an evaluative overview of new and emerging drying technologies, while placing greater emphasis on making the drying process more energy efficient in the green age. Draws on the Authors' 60+ Years of Combined Experience Fueled by the current energy crisis and growing consumer demand for improved quality products, this thoroughly updated resource addresses cutting-edge drying technologies for numerous materials such as high-valued, heat-sensitive pharmaceuticals, nutraceuticals, and some foods. It also introduces innovative techniques, such as heat-pump drying of foods, which allow both industrial practice and research and development projects to save energy, reduce carbon footprints, and thus improve the bottom line. Four New Chapters: • Spray-Freeze-Drying • Fry Drying • Refractance Window Drying • Mechanical Thermal Expression Requiring no prior knowledge of chemical engineering, this single-source reference should assist researchers in turning the laboratory curiosities of today into the revolutionary novel drying technologies of tomorrow. © 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: Ecosystems and the atmosphere: This review describes the state of understanding the processes involved in the exchange of trace gases and aerosols between the earth's surface and the atmosphere. The gases covered include NO, NO<inf>2</inf>, HONO, HNO<inf>3</inf>, NH<inf>3</inf>, SO<inf>2</inf>, DMS, Biogenic VOC, O<inf>3</inf>, CH<inf>4</inf>, N<inf>2</inf>O and particles in the size range 1 nm-10 μm including organic and inorganic chemical species. The main focus of the review is on the exchange between terrestrial ecosystems, both managed and natural and the atmosphere, although some new developments in ocean-atmosphere exchange are included. The material presented is biased towards the last decade, but includes earlier work, where more recent developments are limited or absent. New methodologies and instrumentation have enabled, if not driven technical advances in measurement. These developments have advanced the process understanding and upscaling of fluxes, especially for particles, VOC and NH<inf>3</inf>. Examples of these applications include mass spectrometric methods, such as Aerosol Mass Spectrometry (AMS) adapted for field measurement of atmosphere-surface fluxes using micrometeorological methods for chemically resolved aerosols. Also briefly described are some advances in theory and techniques in micrometeorology. For some of the compounds there have been paradigm shifts in approach and application of both techniques and assessment. These include flux measurements over marine surfaces and urban areas using micrometeorological methods and the up-scaling of flux measurements using aircraft and satellite remote sensing. The application of a flux-based approach in assessment of O<inf>3</inf> effects on vegetation at regional scales is an important policy linked development secured through improved quantification of fluxes. The coupling of monitoring, modelling and intensive flux measurement at a continental scale within the NitroEurope network represents a quantum development in the application of research teams to address the underpinning science of reactive nitrogen in the cycling between ecosystems and the atmosphere in Europe. Some important developments of the science have been applied to assist in addressing policy questions, which have been the main driver of the research agenda, while other developments in understanding have not been applied to their wider field especially in chemistry-transport models through deficiencies in obtaining appropriate data to enable application or inertia within the modelling community. The paper identifies applications, gaps and research questions that have remained intractable at least since 2000 within the specialized sections of the paper, and where possible these have been focussed on research questions for the coming decade. © 2009. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G.R., Parmar, Geeta Rani; N.N., Rao, Nageswara Neti
Author full names: Parmar, Geeta Rani (25931033300); Rao, Nageswara Neti (7401628951)
Title: Emerging control technologies for volatile organic compounds
Source title: Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology
Affiliations: National Environmental Engineering Research Institute India, Nagpur, India; National Environmental Engineering Research Institute India, Nagpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Parmar, Geeta Rani, National Environmental Engineering Research Institute India, Nagpur, India; Rao, Nageswara Neti, National Environmental Engineering Research Institute India, Nagpur, India, National Environmental Engineering Research Institute India, Nagpur, India
Abstract: Environmental problems associated with volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the atmosphere have provided the driving force for sustained fundamental and applied research in the area of environmental remediation. Conventional methods currently used to treat VOCs include incineration, condensation, adsorption, and absorption. Incineration and condensation are cost-effective only for moderate to high VOC concentrations. Adsorption and absorption do not destroy VOCs but simply transfer them to another medium. The humid gas stream can plug the condenser and can fill up the adsorption site of the adsorbent. However, none of these methods are cost-effective for the treatment of gas streams with low to moderate concentration and having large numbers of compounds, as the recovery and reuse of the compounds is not economically feasible. A host of alternative remediation technologies, which offer a number of advantages over conventional technologies, are emerging. These include treatment of VOCs with spark-generated carbon aerosol particles, negative air ions treatment, treatment using mesoporous chromium oxide and silica fiber matrix, electrical discharge treatment, electron beam bombardment, and ultraviolet (UV) photooxidation mediated by heterogeneous photocatalyst particles. This review discusses these emerging technologies against the backdrop of conventional approaches for VOC treatment. Authors: G., Busca, Guido; S., Berardinelli, Silvia; C., Resini, Carlo; L., Arrighi, Laura
Author full names: Busca, Guido (57208583146); Berardinelli, Silvia (24166136000); Resini, Carlo (6701467383); Arrighi, Laura (10142308300)
Title: Technologies for the removal of phenol from fluid streams: A short review of recent developments
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Busca, Guido, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica e di Processo, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; Berardinelli, Silvia, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica e di Processo, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; Resini, Carlo, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica e di Processo, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; Arrighi, Laura, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica e di Processo, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy
Abstract: The available technologies for the abatement of phenol from water and gaseous streams are briefly reviewed, and the recent advancements summarized. Separation technologies such as distillation, liquid-liquid extraction with different solvents, adsorption over activated carbons and polymeric and inorganic adsorbents, membrane pervaporation and membrane-solvent extraction, have been discussed. Destruction technologies such as non-catalytic, supercritical and catalytic wet air oxidation, ozonation, non-catalytic, catalytic and enzymatic peroxide wet oxidation, electrochemical and photocatalytic oxidation, supercritical wet gasification, destruction with electron discharges as well as biochemical treatments have been considered. As for the abatement of phenol from gases, condensation, absorption in liquids, adsorption on solids, membrane separation, thermal, catalytic, photocatalytic and biological oxidation have also been considered. The experimental conditions and the performances of the different techniques have been compared. © 2008. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: A.J., Thompson, Alexander J.; J.M., Etzkorn, Jacob M.; D.M., van Pel, Derek M.; E.T., Krogh, Erik T.; D.R., Drakeford, David R.; C.G., Gill, Christopher G.
Author full names: Thompson, Alexander J. (55727149200); Etzkorn, Jacob M. (26221602900); van Pel, Derek M. (55163809500); Krogh, Erik T. (8259327900); Drakeford, David R. (35226262900); Gill, Christopher G. (57212485188)
Title: Membrane introduction tandem mass spectrometry (MIMS-MS/ MS) as a real-time monitor for biogenic volatile organic compound (BVOC) emissions from plants
Source title: Canadian Journal of Analytical Sciences and Spectroscopy
Affiliations: Vancouver Island University, Nanaimo, Canada; Vancouver Island University, Nanaimo, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, Alexander J., Department of Chemistry, Vancouver Island University, Nanaimo, Canada; Etzkorn, Jacob M., Department of Chemistry, Vancouver Island University, Nanaimo, Canada; van Pel, Derek M., Department of Chemistry, Vancouver Island University, Nanaimo, Canada; Krogh, Erik T., Department of Chemistry, Vancouver Island University, Nanaimo, Canada; Drakeford, David R., Department of Biology, Vancouver Island University, Nanaimo, Canada; Gill, Christopher G., Department of Chemistry, Vancouver Island University, Nanaimo, Canada
Abstract: The ability to monitor trace levels of biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOCs) in real-time is important to the fields of chemical ecology and environmental chemistry. Isoprene is a ubiquitous BVOC that plays an important role in plant physiology and is also involved in a number of environmentally relevant tropospheric chemistries. The use of membrane introduction tandem mass spectrometry (MIMS-MS/MS) is presented as an on-line analytical technique used to directly monitor the emission of biogenic volatile organic compounds in real-time. We present data for the time-resolved emission of isoprene from potato plants (Solanum tuberosum) in response to mechanical wounding and heat stress by continuously monitoring the headspace air of a closed system. We demonstrate as a test case that MIMS- MS/MS is a robust and versatile technique that can be successfully applied as a real-time monitor for trace level (ppbv) biogenic volatile organic compound emissions. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Musialik-Piotrowska, Anna; H., Landmesser, Holger
Author full names: Musialik-Piotrowska, Anna (6603836898); Landmesser, Holger (6701729299)
Title: Noble metal-doped perovskites for the oxidation of organic air pollutants
Affiliations: Politechnika Wrocławska, Wroclaw, Poland; Hochschule für Technik und Wirtschaft Dresden (FH), Dresden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Musialik-Piotrowska, Anna, Institute of Environment Protection Engineering, Politechnika Wrocławska, Wroclaw, Poland; Landmesser, Holger, Hochschule für Technik und Wirtschaft Dresden (FH), Dresden, Germany
Abstract: Ag-Pt- and Pd-doped LaMnO<inf>3</inf>-based perovskite catalysts were prepared and their activity in the oxidation of toluene, n-heptane and ethanol was investigated. The activity of LaMnO<inf>3</inf>-based catalyst was very high in the oxidation of each compound tested. The Ag-doped catalyst was the most active in the oxidation of each compound and it displayed the highest BET specific surface area (SSA) also. The influence of Pt or Pd doping on perovskite activity is negligibly small. Pt-doped catalysts are slightly more active while Pd-doped catalysts are slightly less active than the pure perovskite. Thermogravimetric-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) for the catalyst precursor indicates that above 500 °C a perovskite structure began to form. The XRD analysis reveals the presence of the LaMnO<inf>3.15</inf> perovskite phase and, additionally, the presence of some metal oxide phases (e.g. La<inf>2</inf>O<inf>2</inf>CO<inf>3</inf>, Mn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>) and carbon. BET SSA measured after the oxidation tests was found to decrease for each catalyst. There was no relation between the chemical composition of the catalyst and the loss of SSA. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.J., Glover, David J.
Author full names: Glover, David J. (24375989400)
Title: Plasma technology provides cleaner, greener air
Authors with affiliations: Glover, David J.,
Abstract: The Plasma Clean is offering a new technology developed and patented at the University of Manchester, aiming to be at the forefront of clean, green air revolution. The company is providing a technology-based air purification systems that use non-thermal plasmas. This energy converts harmful airborne contaminants into harmless by-products. The energy efficiency actually increases as the pollutant concentration decreases. Currently, the company is approaching partners for potential germicidal, volatile organic compound (VOC), and odor abatement applications. The non-thermal plasma can be used in destroying pollutants in waste gas streams and VOCs from processing plants from landfill sites, food processing plants, and animal houses. © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.S., Coffey, Patrick S.; C., Phillips, Christopher
Author full names: Coffey, Patrick S. (13408024000); Phillips, Christopher (52964581600)
Title: Best practice odour and VOC emissions control in alumina refineries
Affiliations: Alcoa, Pittsburgh, United States; WA Operations, Australia; Wagerup Refinery, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Coffey, Patrick S., Alcoa, Pittsburgh, United States, WA Operations, Australia; Phillips, Christopher, Alcoa, Pittsburgh, United States, Wagerup Refinery, Australia
Abstract: Use of thermal oxidizer systems on a variety of VOC emission sources at Alcoa's Western Australian refineries, in combination with more traditional forms of exhaust gas particulate and moisture removal, has proven very effective in increasing the capture efficiency for Bayer refinery sources. Catalytic thermal oxidizer (CTO) was first installed to treat the Wagerup Refinery Liquor Burning exhaust gas stream. The use of a catalyst bed in theory allows VOC destruction to occur at lower temperatures than would otherwise be required if an afterburner was employed. Regenerative thermal oxidizers (RTO) were installed in multiple applications in all its refineries. RTOs allows exhaust gases exiting the RTOs to be only 50°C higher than the feed temperature, although the combustion process itself occurs at 850°C. Alternative forms of by-product treatment and control, such as the Biox process for oxalate treatment, are under development as a way to handle these material streams in Bayer processing. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.B., Novaković, Tatjana B.; N.D., Radić, Nenad D.; B.V., Grbić, Boško V.; T.S., Marinova, Ts S.; P.K., Stefanov, P. K.; D.S., Stoychev, D. S.
Author full names: Novaković, Tatjana B. (6602726299); Radić, Nenad D. (7003687038); Grbić, Boško V. (6603237510); Marinova, Ts S. (35495060000); Stefanov, P. K. (14523573000); Stoychev, D. S. (7004342744)
Title: Oxidation of n-hexane over Pt and Cu-Co oxide catalysts supported on a thin-film zirconia/stainless steel carrier
Affiliations: Institute for Chemistry, Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia; Institute of General and Inorganic Chemistry Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria; Institute of Physical Chemistry Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Novaković, Tatjana B., Department of Catalysis and Chemical Engineering, Institute for Chemistry, Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia; Radić, Nenad D., Department of Catalysis and Chemical Engineering, Institute for Chemistry, Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia; Grbić, Boško V., Department of Catalysis and Chemical Engineering, Institute for Chemistry, Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia; Marinova, Ts S., Institute of General and Inorganic Chemistry Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria; Stefanov, P. K., Institute of General and Inorganic Chemistry Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria; Stoychev, D. S., Institute of Physical Chemistry, Institute of Physical Chemistry Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: The complete oxidation of n-hexane in air over a stainless steel foil (SS) coated with a thin film of ZrO<inf>2</inf> (SS/ZrO<inf>2</inf>), SS/ZrO<inf>2</inf>/Pt, SS/ZrO<inf>2</inf>/La<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>/CuCo and SS/ZrO<inf>2</inf>/La<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>/CuCo/Pt catalysts has been investigated. The ZrO<inf>2</inf> films were deposited on the SS substrate by electrochemical and spray pyrolysis (SP) methods. Among electrochemically prepared samples, Pt containing catalysts exhibited the highest activity. The presence of La, Cu and Co oxides along with Pt did not improve the catalytic activity. The SS/ZrO<inf>2</inf>/Pt sample prepared by spray pyrolysis showed a much better light-off characteristic than did the electrochemically obtained catalysts. The spray pyrolysis method permits the preparation of thicker ZrO<inf>2</inf> films as compared to films prepared by an electrodeposition method. Thus, an increase of the surface area available for deposition of Pt atoms was achieved. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Xia, Lanyan; L., Huang, Li; X., Shu, Xiaohong; R., Zhang, Renxi; W., Dong, Wenbo; H., Hou, Huiqi
Title: Removal of ammonia from gas streams with dielectric barrier discharge plasmas
Affiliations: Fudan University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Xia, Lanyan, Institute of Environmental Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Huang, Li, Institute of Environmental Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Shu, Xiaohong, Institute of Environmental Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Zhang, Renxi, Institute of Environmental Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Dong, Wenbo, Institute of Environmental Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, China; Hou, Huiqi, Institute of Environmental Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: We reported on the experimental study of gas-phase removal of ammonia (NH<inf>3</inf>) via dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) at atmospheric pressure, in which we mainly concentrated on three aspects-influence of initial NH<inf>3</inf> concentration, peak voltage, and gas residence time on NH<inf>3</inf> removal efficiency. Effectiveness, e.g. the removal efficiency, specific energy density, absolute removal amount and energy yield, of the self-made DBD reactor had also been studied. Basic analysis on DBD physical parameters and its performance was made in comparison with previous investigation. Moreover, products were detected via ion exchange chromatography (IEC). Experimental results demonstrated the application potential of DBD as an alternative technology for odor-causing gases elimination from gas streams. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. Authors: J., Rivera de la Rosa, Javier; A., Hernández-Ramírez, A.; F., Rojas-González, Fernando; J.J., Ledezma, Juan José
Author full names: Rivera de la Rosa, Javier (57797711100); Hernández-Ramírez, A. (57199644727); Rojas-González, Fernando (7006426268); Ledezma, Juan José (23097963900)
Title: Sol-gel synthesis and characterization of novel La, Mn and Fe doped zirconia: Catalytic combustion activity of trichloroethylene
Source title: Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects
Affiliations: Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León, San Nicolas de los Garza, Mexico; Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana -Unidad Iztapalapa, Iztapalapa, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Rivera de la Rosa, Javier, Facultad de Ciencias Químicas, Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León, San Nicolas de los Garza, Mexico; Hernández-Ramírez, A., Facultad de Ciencias Químicas, Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León, San Nicolas de los Garza, Mexico; Rojas-González, Fernando, Department of Chemistry, Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana -Unidad Iztapalapa, Iztapalapa, Mexico; Ledezma, Juan José, Facultad de Ciencias Químicas, Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León, San Nicolas de los Garza, Mexico
Abstract: Pure zirconia and novel 0.5 wt% La, Mn and Fe doped zirconia powders were synthesized by the sol-gel method. The samples obtained were characterized by thermal analysis (DTA/TGA), infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The textural properties of the catalysts were studied through N<inf>2</inf> sorption isotherms measured at 77 K. In order to study the influence of the doping metals on the ZrO<inf>2</inf> crystalline phase formation, different doping metal loadings were employed. It was found that the ZrO<inf>2</inf> monoclinic phase is favored at 800 °C when using a La-Mn doping combination, while the tetragonal structure was promoted by a La-Fe doping mixture. The morphology of the gel particles was seen to be influenced by the nature of the doping metal; scanning electron microscopy served to observe this phenomenon. Textural analysis by N<inf>2</inf> sorption revealed that were obtained porous materials. The La-Fe zirconia catalyst resisted the high concentration trichloroethylene flow and kept its activity as the temperature was increased. The catalytic activity tests showed that the ZrO<inf>2</inf> tetragonal phase stabilized by La, Fe doping agents significantly improved the catalytic combustion of trichloroethylene. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Ozonation of water and waste water: A practical guide to understanding ozone and its application
Affiliations: ASTeX GmbH, Berlin, Germany; Technische Universität Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Fraunhofer Management GmbH, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gottschalk, Christiane, ASTeX GmbH, Berlin, Germany; Libra, Judy Ann, Technische Universität Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Saupe, Adrian, Fraunhofer Management GmbH, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: The ozonation of compounds in water is a complex process. The mechanisms are very complicated, the parameters are many, but the possibilities of developing cost-effective treatment schemes for drinking water and waste water are large. To take advantage of this potential, it is important to know which parameters contribute to the process, which are important, and how they affect the process. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Nonthermal plasma reactors and plasma chemistry
Source title: International Journal of Environment and Waste Management
Affiliations: Universidad Nacional de Tucuman (UNT), San Miguel de Tucuman, Argentina; Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan; Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan

Abstract: The main goal of this paper is focused in reviewing the last 22 years of the use of nonthermal plasma reactors as alternative technologies for the treatment of residual fluid substances, regarding the destruction of hazardous compounds or the synthesis of other valuable compounds. The electrical discharge processing has emerged as alternative plasma-based technologies. Electrical discharges can be produced in different forms, depending on the geometry of the reactor and the electrical power supply. The nonthermal plasma reactors were classified into: • pulsed or DC corona discharge; • silent discharge or dielectric barrier discharge; surface discharge; • electrified packed-bed. Authors: S., Yuan, Shuhua; M., Shen, Mei; M., Gong, Maochu; J., Wang, Jianli; S., Yan, Shenghui; H., Cao, Hongyan; Y.Q., Chen, Yaoqiangb Qiang
Author full names: Yuan, Shuhua (15752066900); Shen, Mei (56212437800); Gong, Maochu (7201566748); Wang, Jianli (56365051600); Yan, Shenghui (23977058000); Cao, Hongyan (23975308400); Chen, Yaoqiangb Qiang (8451984400)
Title: Catalytic Combustion of Ethyl Acetate over Al2O3- Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 Supported Metal Oxide Catalysts
Source title: Wuli Huaxue Xuebao/ Acta Physico - Chimica Sinica
Affiliations: Sichuan University, Chengdu, China
Authors with affiliations: Yuan, Shuhua, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Shen, Mei, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Gong, Maochu, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Wang, Jianli, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Yan, Shenghui, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Cao, Hongyan, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China; Chen, Yaoqiangb Qiang, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China
Abstract: The catalysts for the combustion of ethyl acetate were prepared using Fe, Co, Cu, Cr, and Mn metal oxide as active components supported on Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-Ce<inf>0.5</inf>Zr<inf>0.5</inf>O<inf>2</inf> mixed oxides and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), oxygen storage capacity measurement, BET surface area, XPS measurement, and activity test. According to the results of characterization, it was found that Cu/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-Ce<inf>0.5</inf>Zr<inf>0.5</inf>O<inf>2</inf> (1:2, mass ratio) and Mn/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-Ce<inf>0.5</inf>Zr<inf>0.5</inf>O<inf>2</inf> (1:2) catalysts presented excellent activity for the catalytic combustion of ethyl acetate, because of the more reducible species and high reducibility of the catalysts. For ethyl acetate oxidation, more than 99% conversion was achieved at 245 °C over catalysts Cu/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-Ce<inf>0.5</inf>Zr<inf>0.5</inf>O<inf>2</inf> (1:2) and Mn/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>-Ce<inf>0.5</inf>Zr<inf>0.5</inf>O<inf>2</inf> (1:2, mass ratio), indicating that the catalysts had great potential for wide use. © 2008 Chinese Chemical Society and College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Peking University. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.H.P., Studer, Michael Hans Peter; P.R., von Rohr, Philipp Rudolf
Author full names: Studer, Michael Hans Peter (57525079000); von Rohr, Philipp Rudolf (55665285400)
Title: Novel membrane bioreactor: Able to cope with fluctuating loads, poorly water soluble VOCs, and biomass accumulation
Affiliations: ETH Zürich, Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Studer, Michael Hans Peter, Transport Processes and Reactions Laboratory, ETH Zürich, Zurich, Switzerland; von Rohr, Philipp Rudolf, Transport Processes and Reactions Laboratory, ETH Zürich, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: Biological waste gas treatment is an attractive method for controlling air emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Microorganisms degrade the VOCs to harmless products such as carbon dioxide (CO<inf>2</inf>), biomass and water. In spite of the advantages, significant unresolved challenges remain for biological waste gas treatment. Fluctuating loads in waste gas streams, especially of VOCs with low water solubility, can often not be satisfactorily removed. Concentration peaks leave the reactor virtually untreated, while periods without VOCs in the waste gas lead to starvation of the bacteria. Furthermore, bioreactors are often subject to clogging due to biomass accumulation. In the current work, a flat sheet membrane bioreactor was developed which was able to buffer fluctuating loads of toluene, our model compound, by absorption in silicone oil prior to degradation and which continuously removed and discharged excess biomass from the reactor. The absorption and the biodegradation were both membrane based. An inverse bacterial biofilm developed on the membrane, which separated the culture medium from the absorbent. The culture medium was constantly passed along the biofilm, introducing shear stresses on the surface and thereby removing excess, inactive biomass. The toluene surface elimination capacity was virtually independent of the gas flow rate for the tested steady-state conditions and reached a maximum of 0.6 g m-2h-1. Experiments with fluctuating inlet mass flow rates of toluene confirmed the excellent buffering capability of the set-up. The reactor was successfully operated for 162 days without clogging. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: H., Huang, Haifeng; Y., Liu, Yaqin; W., Tang, Wei; Y., Chen, Yinfei
Title: Catalytic activity of nanometer La1-xSrxCoO3 (x = 0, 0.2) perovskites towards VOCs combustion
Affiliations: Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Haifeng, College of Biological and Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Liu, Yaqin, College of Biological and Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Tang, Wei, College of Biological and Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China; Chen, Yinfei, College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: Combustive oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), such as propyl alcohol, toluene and cyclohexane, were studied. The combustion was catalyzed by nanoparticles of La<inf>1-x</inf>Sr<inf>x</inf>CoO<inf>3</inf> (x = 0, 0.2) perovskites prepared by a co-precipitation method. The results showed high activities of the perovskite catalysts. Compared to LaCoO<inf>3</inf>, in particular, La<inf>0.8</inf>Sr<inf>0.2</inf>CoO<inf>3</inf> was much higher in catalytic ability. The total oxidation of VOCs followed the increasing order: cyclohexane < toluene < propyl alcohol. The T<inf>99%</inf> of cyclohexane was 40 °C lower than that of toluene, which appeared to be determined by the bond strengths of the weakest C-H and C-C bonds. The 100-h stability experiments showed that La<inf>1-x</inf>Sr<inf>x</inf>CoO<inf>3</inf> (x = 0, 0.2) perovskite was highly stable. © 2007. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Lee, Changmin
Author full names: Lee, Changmin (55700549400)
Title: Low temperature VOCs oxidation technology for Biological Effluent Treatment facility (BET)
Source title: SEAISI Quarterly (South East Asia Iron and Steel Institute)
Affiliations: Technology Development Group, Pohang, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Changmin, Coke Making Dept., Technology Development Group, Pohang, South Korea
Abstract: POSCO Pohang BET(Biological Effluent Treatment facility), in order to prevent VOCs emission and foul odor, cover for the entire dimensions of BET has been installed. This cover is effective to blocking VOCs out. However the problem is the way to treat VOCs after blocking. BET process is continuous process which means consecutive generating of VOCs. For this, we installed catalytic oxidation furnace to burn VOCs. This set is composed of VOCs blower, heat exchanger, burner, catalytic oxidizer and stack. VOCs blower take off-gas from BET to the catalytic oxidation furnace. The next stage is heat exchanging between off-gas and waste gas after oxidation. After this stage, off-gas was pre-heated over 200!. Next, preheated gas charges to the catalytic oxidation furnace after burning. Catalytic oxidation temperature is about 300!. Catalytic oxidation furnace uses HHD (Halohydrocarbon & VOC Destruction Catalysts). This catalyst shape is similar to honey comb. Honey comb base structure is made up of Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> attaching Platinum catalyst which has strong absorption power. From this oxidation process, VOCs was removed about 90% of whole off-gas. We installed 2 sets of catalytic oxidation furnace and 29 number of BET cover. Optimizing new technology to our facility, we need to spend cost for utility and catalyst. However, compare to other technology like regenerative catalytic oxidation and high temperature oxidation, low temperature oxidation is more economical. The reason is pre-heating stage before oxidation. Oxidation needs Coke Oven Gas for heating source. But, preheating stage decreases using amount of COG(Coke Oven Gas). © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Demeestere, Kristof; J.P., Dewulf, Jo P.; H.R., Van Langenhove, Herman R.
Author full names: Demeestere, Kristof (6602756975); Dewulf, Jo P. (7006029915); Van Langenhove, Herman R. (22036947600)
Title: Heterogeneous photocatalysis as an advanced oxidation process for the abatement of chlorinated, monocyclic aromatic and sulfurous volatile organic compounds in air: State of the art
Source title: Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology
Affiliations: Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Demeestere, Kristof, Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; Dewulf, Jo P., Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; Van Langenhove, Herman R., Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium
Abstract: This review focuses on both fundamentals and applicability of heterogeneous photocatalysis as an advanced oxidation technology for degradation of volatile organic compounds (VOC) in air, with peer-reviewed literature data published since 1997 being the backbone of this article. Four key issues are covered. First, the underlying principles of heterogeneous photocatalysis are outlined using the band gap model. Second, a detailed overview is given of chlorinated, monocyclic aromatic and sulfurous VOC recently selected as target compounds in lab-scale photocatalytic degradation experiments. Data on reactor types, photocatalysts, reaction conditions, and reported results are tabulated. The third section deals with reaction products, analytical techniques used for separation and/or identification, proposed reaction pathways, and catalyst deactivation. Finally, effects of process parameters such as gas-phase pollutant and oxygen concentration, relative humidity, temperature, and light intensity on degradation kinetics are reviewed. Authors: D.P., Das, Dipti Prakasini; K.M., Parida, Kulamani M.
Author full names: Das, Dipti Prakasini (35550491600); Parida, Kulamani M. (56914777200)
Title: Fe(III) oxide pillared titanium phosphate (TiP): An effective catalyst for deep oxidation of VOCs
Source title: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
Affiliations: Institute of Minerals and Materials Technology India, Bhubaneswar, India
Authors with affiliations: Das, Dipti Prakasini, Colloids and Materials Chemistry Department, Institute of Minerals and Materials Technology India, Bhubaneswar, India; Parida, Kulamani M., Colloids and Materials Chemistry Department, Institute of Minerals and Materials Technology India, Bhubaneswar, India
Abstract: A series of trinuclear acetato complex of Fe(III) intercalated TiP was successfully prepared by ion exchange process by varying the wt% of Fe(III), activated at various temperatures and characterized by various techniques. The PXRD and FTIR analyses reveal that the pillaring has been taken place in the interlayer of the layered materials. All the catalysts were found to be mesoporous in nature. The number of reducing sites was found to be higher than that of oxidizing sites. With increase in the calcination temperature of 5 wt% Fe(III)/TiP, surface area and surface oxygen increase up to 300 °C, thereafter exhibits a slow decrease up to 500 °C. But the oxidizing and reducing properties go on decreasing with activation temperature. Catalytic decomposition of acetone, methanol, diethyl ether and 2-propanol as probe molecules was studied to find out the suitability of the material for VOCs decomposition reactions. Fe(III) pillared TiP (5 wt%) with high iron content, surface area and surface oxygen shows higher catalytic activity towards the complete decomposition of VOCs. Titanium phosphate pillared with 5 wt% Fe(III), calcined at 300 °C showed complete decomposition of VOCs in the range of 180-350 °C. The catalytic activity of these materials is comparable with other reported catalysts. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.K., Varma, Vipin K.; A.V., Someshwar, Arun V.; K., Vice, Kirsten
Author full names: Varma, Vipin K. (7102388029); Someshwar, Arun V. (6603806009); Vice, Kirsten (6603416950)
Title: Review of available technologies for control of air quality parameters relevant to pulp and paper and wood products facilities in Canada
Affiliations: National Council for Air and Stream Improvement, Inc., Cary, United States; NCASI-Canada, Montreal, Canada; National Council for Air and Stream Improvement, Inc., Cary, United States; Station B, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Varma, Vipin K., NCASI Southern Regional Center, National Council for Air and Stream Improvement, Inc., Cary, United States; Someshwar, Arun V., NCASI Southern Regional Center, National Council for Air and Stream Improvement, Inc., Cary, United States, NCASI, National Council for Air and Stream Improvement, Inc., Cary, United States; Vice, Kirsten, NCASI-Canada, Montreal, Canada, Station B, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: The control options for air emissions of SO <inf>x</inf> (SO <inf>2</inf> and SO <inf>3</inf>/H <inf>2</inf>SO <inf>4</inf>), NO <inf>x</inf>, VOCs, ClO <inf>2</inf>, particulate matter (PM), dioxins and furans, total reduced sulphur (TRS), greenhouse gases (CO <inf>2</inf>, N <inf>2</inf>O) and mercury, especially those relevant to the pulp and paper (P&P) and wood products (WP) industry in Canada, are summarized in this report. First, the predominant emission sources for these compounds are identified within a P&P or WP mill, followed by a discussion of the widely tested control technologies. A fair amount of the experience with technologies is from a lateral transfer from applications to boilers operating mainly in the electric utility industry. For SO <inf>2</inf> emission control for boilers, besides substitution of lower sulphur fuels and capture within the combustion process itself by alkaline constituents of the fuel, end-of-pipe control technologies involve several mature flue gas desulphurization technologies. Control of H <inf>2</inf>SO <inf>4</inf> aerosols from combustion is relatively difficult and limited experience has been gained with candle filters and wet electrostatic precipitators (ESPs). For NO <inf>x</inf> emission control, besides switching to lower nitrogen fuels such as oils, control technologies applicable to fossil fuel-fired boilers are also fairly advanced and include both combustion modifications and end-of-pipe technologies like selective non-catalytic reduction and selective catalytic reduction. NO <inf>x</inf> control for wood-fired and combination wood-fired boilers is difficult to achieve since the wood N content governs the NO <inf>x</inf> emissions, and post-combustion NO <inf>x</inf> control is generally only effective on "base-loaded" boilers. NO <inf>x</inf> emission control for kraft recovery furnaces is mainly obtained by maximizing the principle of staged combustion, while NO <inf>x</inf> emission control techniques for kraft lime kilns are still in their infancy. Regenerative thermal oxidizers and regenerative catalytic oxidizers are the dominant VOC reduction technologies in the WP sectors. VOC reduction in kraft P&P mills is mostly brought about by incinerating NCGs in boilers, kilns and thermal oxidizers. ClO <inf>2</inf> is controlled quite effectively with wet scrubbers with scrubbing media ranging from chilled water to alkaline medium with and without sulphides and sulphites. Particulate matter emissions, including total PM, PM <inf>10</inf>, and PM <inf>2.5</inf>, from P&P and WP facility sources are controlled by a range of control devices including ESPs, fabric filters, venturi scrubbers and multiclones. The control of minute quantities of dioxins and furans that result from combustion of just about any fuel with some chloride content is a continuously evolving art form. Current understanding focuses on three important principles: a) minimize products of incomplete combustion, b) minimize extraneous sources of chloride in the boiler fuel mix, and c) minimize the residence time spent by flue gases in the temperature range of 250 and 400°C where maximum "de novo" formation is believed to occur. TRS emissions, comprised essentially of the four reduced sulphur compounds (RSCs) H <inf>2</inf>S, CH <inf>3</inf>SH, (CH <inf>3</inf>) <inf>2</inf>S and (CH <inf>3</inf>) <inf>2</inf>S <inf>2</inf>, from kraft pulping and recovery sources are mainly controlled by incineration. TRS emission control from recovery furnaces, lime kilns and smelt dissolving tanks is accomplished chiefly by process control. Other TRS control technologies include scrubbing, which only addresses the acidic RSCs. The control of greenhouse gases, principally CO <inf>2</inf>, is mainly concerned with improving the overall energy efficiency of the process. Control of mercury emissions revolves around oxidizing the elemental mercury and removing the oxidized species in wet scrubbers or by injecting activated carbon in the flue gas stream to capture the Hg prior to the PM control device. © 2007 by the National Council for Air and Stream Improvement, Inc. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Removal of volatile organic compounds from activated carbon by thermal desorption and catalytic combustion

Affiliations: University of Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Institute for Chemistry, Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia; University of Belgrade Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia
Authors with affiliations: Rankovic, D. P., Faculty of Physical Chemistry, University of Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Arsenijević, Zorana Lj, Institute for Chemistry, Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia; Radić, Nenad D., Institute for Chemistry, Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia; Grbić, Boško V., Institute for Chemistry, Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia; Grbavčić, Željko B., University of Belgrade Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Belgrade, Serbia
Abstract: The thermal desorption of saturated activated carbon discharged from an industrial adsorber and catalytic oxidation of desorbed products over a Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalyst were investigated. The activated carbon is almost completely regenerated by flushing with air at 200°C for 30 min. Desorbed products are fully oxidized over the Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalyst above 275°C. © 2007 Pleiades Publishing, Ltd. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Guo, Yufang; D., Ye, Daiqi; K., Chen, Kefu; J., He, Jiancong
Title: Toluene removal by a DBD-type plasma combined with metal oxides catalysts supported by nickel foam
Affiliations: South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Guo, Yufang, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Ye, Daiqi, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Chen, Kefu, Department of Resources Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; He, Jiancong, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: The performance on toluene removal in a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) type plasma system under different background gases, including N<inf>2</inf>, Ar, N<inf>2</inf>/Ar, and N<inf>2</inf>/O<inf>2</inf> was studied at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. For comparison, another laboratory-scale plasma-catalysis system was set up and four kinds of metal oxides, i.e., copper oxide, iron oxide, cobalt oxide, and manganese oxide supported on alumina/nickel foam (NF), were used as catalysts. The reaction mechanism and dynamics analysis on toluene removal were suggested. In addition, the characterization of the catalysts was performed by BET, XRD, SEM, FT-IR, and EDS. It has been found that adding argon in the background gas could improve the toluene removal efficiency significantly in the plasma system. Combining plasma with catalyst in situ could improve the toluene removal efficiency, increase the carbon dioxide selectivity and suppress byproducts formation. In addition, manganese oxide/alumina/NF was confirmed as the most effective catalyst for toluene removal. The XRD and SEM results showed that the proportion of metal oxide increased while aluminate decreased after plasma application. The granularity of the grain on the catalyst surface became smaller and the distribution became more uniform after discharge. The results of FT-IR and EDS suggested that some organic compounds deposited on the catalysts after plasma reaction. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: R., Muñoz Torre, Raúl; S., Villaverde, S.; B., Guieysse, Benoît; S.M., Revah, Sergio M.
Author full names: Muñoz Torre, Raúl (57370422200); Villaverde, S. (20836523700); Guieysse, Benoît (6602515156); Revah, Sergio M. (7004330897)
Title: Two-phase partitioning bioreactors for treatment of volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: Universidad de Valladolid, Valladolid, Spain; School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Singapore City, Singapore; Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana Unidad Cuajimalpa, Mexico, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Muñoz Torre, Raúl, Department of Chemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Universidad de Valladolid, Valladolid, Spain; Villaverde, S., Department of Chemical Engineering and Environmental Technology, Universidad de Valladolid, Valladolid, Spain; Guieysse, Benoît, School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Singapore City, Singapore; Revah, Sergio M., Departamento de Ingeniería de Procesos e Hidráulica, Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana Unidad Cuajimalpa, Mexico, Mexico
Abstract: Two-phase partitioning bioreactors (TPPBs) allow the biological removal of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from contaminated gas streams at unprecedented rates and concentrations. TPPBs are constructed by adding a non-aqueous phase (e.g. hexadecane, silicone oil) to an aqueous phase that contains the microorganisms responsible for degrading the VOCs. Presence of a water-immiscible phase improves the transfer of hydrophobic substrates (e.g. hexane, oxygen) or reduces the toxicity of inhibitory substances (e.g. benzene, toluene) to the microorganisms present in the aqueous phase. The non-aqueous phase is selected based on cost, safety, good partitioning properties towards the target pollutants, biocompatibility, and non-biodegradability. TPPBs have hitherto been designed as laboratory-scale well-mixed stirred-tank reactors or as biofilters that contain a non-aqueous phase. Scale-up and industrial use of TPPBs require elucidation and modeling of the mechanisms of substrate transfer and uptake; understanding of the mechanisms of microbial selection; identification or synthesis of new inexpensive and robust non-aqueous phases; and generation of suitable guidelines for process design and control. © 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: J., Jarrige, Julien; P., Vervisch, Pierre
Author full names: Jarrige, Julien (16402122400); Vervisch, Pierre (6603882680)
Title: Decomposition of gaseous sulfide compounds in air by pulsed corona discharge
Affiliations: CORIA - Complexe de recherche Interprofessionnel en Aérothermochimie, Saint-Etienne-du-Rouvray, France
Authors with affiliations: Jarrige, Julien, CORIA - Complexe de recherche Interprofessionnel en Aérothermochimie, Saint-Etienne-du-Rouvray, France; Vervisch, Pierre, CORIA - Complexe de recherche Interprofessionnel en Aérothermochimie, Saint-Etienne-du-Rouvray, France
Abstract: The effectiveness of applying a pulsed corona discharge to the destruction of olfactory pollution in air was investigated. This paper presents a comparative study of the decomposition of three representative sulfide compounds in diluted concentrations: hydrogen sulfide (H <inf>2</inf>S), dimethyl sulfide (DMS), and ethanethiol (C <inf>2</inf>H <inf>5</inf>SH), which could be completely removed when a sufficient but reasonable energy density was deposited in the gas. DMS showed the lowest energy cost (around 30 eV/molecules); C <inf>2</inf>H <inf>5</inf>SH and H <inf>2</inf>S had an EC of respectively 45 eV and 115 eV. The efficiency of the non-thermal plasma process increased with decreasing the initial concentration of sulfide compounds, while the energy yield remained almost unchanged. SO <inf>2</inf> was the only identified byproduct of H <inf>2</inf>S decomposition, but the sulfur balance suggests the formation of undetected SO <inf>3</inf>. The byproducts analyzed during the degradation of DMS and C <inf>2</inf>H <inf>5</inf>SH enabled to propose a reaction mechanism, starting with radical attack and breaking of C-S bonds. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2007. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D.P., Das, Dipti Prakasini; K.M., Parida, Kulamani M.
Author full names: Das, Dipti Prakasini (35550491600); Parida, Kulamani M. (56914777200)
Title: Mn(III) oxide pillared titanium phosphate (TiP) for catalytic deep oxidation of VOCs
Affiliations: Institute of Minerals and Materials Technology India, Bhubaneswar, India
Authors with affiliations: Das, Dipti Prakasini, Colloids and Materials Chemistry Department, Institute of Minerals and Materials Technology India, Bhubaneswar, India; Parida, Kulamani M., Colloids and Materials Chemistry Department, Institute of Minerals and Materials Technology India, Bhubaneswar, India
Abstract: A series of trinuclear acetato complex of Mn(III) intercalated TiP was successfully prepared by ion-exchange process, by varying the wt% of Mn(III) and activated at various temperatures. The calcined and uncalcined samples were characterized by PXRD, FTIR, TG-DTA, BET-surface area, pore size distribution, surface oxygen, surface oxidizing and reducing sites. The PXRD and FTIR analyses support that the pillaring has been taken place in the interlayer of the layered materials. All the catalysts were found to be mesoporous in character. The number of reducing sites was found to be higher than that of oxidizing sites. With increase in the calcination temperature of 15 wt% Mn(III)/TiP, surface area and surface oxygen increase up to 300 °C, thereafter exhibits slow decrease up to 500 °C. But the oxidizing and reducing properties go on decreasing with activation temperature. Catalytic decomposition of acetone, methanol, diethyl ether and 2-propanol was studied to find out the suitability of the material for VOCs decomposition reactions. Mn(III) pillared TiP (15 wt%) with high manganese content, surface area, surface oxygen shows higher catalytic activity towards the complete decomposition of VOCs. Time-on-stream (TOS) experiments justify the stability of the catalysts at least 24 h with minor change in the activity. Titanium phosphate pillared with 15 wt% Mn(III) and calcined at 300 °C showed complete decomposition of VOCs in the range of 180-290 °C. The catalytic activity of these materials is comparable with other reported catalysts. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.Q., Mizuno, Akira Q.
Author full names: Mizuno, Akira Q. (55708287000)
Title: Industrial applications of atmospheric non-thermal plasma in environmental remediation
Affiliations: Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mizuno, Akira Q., Department of Ecological Engineering, Toyohashi University of Technology, Toyohashi, Japan
Abstract: Atmospheric non-thermal plasma (NTP) has been recognized as an important tool for the abatement of pollutants and for promoting various chemical reactions in gas or in liquid. Indoor air cleaners have been mass-produced and proved to be effective for the removal of odour and allergen. NTP has various potential applications in environmental remediation, such as the removal of volatile organic pollutants, simultaneous removal of NO<inf>x</inf> and soot in diesel exhaust and sterilization of air and water. To improve the efficiency of plasma chemical processes, a combination of NTP and catalysts/absorbents is effective. Synergetic effects have been recognized; however, its mechanism remains subject to further investigations. The generation of non-thermal discharge plasma and several industrial applications are presented in this paper. © 2007 IOP Publishing Ltd. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Cantau, Christophe; S., Larribau, S.; T., Pigot, Thierry; M.J., Simon, Maryse J.; M.T., Maurette, Marie Thérèse; S.M., Lacombe, Sylvie M.
Author full names: Cantau, Christophe (9846314400); Larribau, S. (16199550000); Pigot, Thierry (6506088641); Simon, Maryse J. (7404410202); Maurette, Marie Thérèse (24432492600); Lacombe, Sylvie M. (7005404756)
Title: Oxidation of nauseous sulfur compounds by photocatalysis or photosensitization
Affiliations: Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France
Authors with affiliations: Cantau, Christophe, Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Larribau, S., Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Pigot, Thierry, Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Simon, Maryse J., Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Maurette, Marie Thérèse, Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France; Lacombe, Sylvie M., Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France
Abstract: Reduced sulfur compounds such as methanethiol (MSH), dimethylsulfide (DMS) and dimethydisulfide (DMDS) are nauseous by-products produced by a great number of industrial processes. Oxidation of these reduced sulfur compounds in polluted atmospheres and hence the decrease of their harmful and malodorous effects is thus a matter of concern in numerous industrial and water treatment plants. Photocatalytic treatment of gaseous flow polluted by these sulfur compounds has been actively investigated for the last few years. The first part of the paper is devoted to a literature review on the different TiO<inf>2</inf>-based photocatalytic processes designed for the oxidation of these gaseous compounds. The comparison of their efficiency is done according to the process parameters: batch or flow reactors, photocatalytic materials, residence time, gas flow, pollutant nature and concentration, relative humidity, .... Special attention is paid to the poisoning of the photocatalytic material and to its possible recycling. In the second part of the paper, alternative materials based on aromatic photosensitizers (9,10-dicyanoanthracene, 9,10-anthraquinone) deposited or grafted on silica matrices are then presented and their efficiency compared to more conventional TiO<inf>2</inf>-based materials. It is demonstrated that the oxidation products are totally different from those obtained with TiO<inf>2</inf>. With the photosensitizing materials, singlet oxygen addition is shown to be the major pathway, leading to sulfoxide and sulfone starting from DMS and to methyl methanethiosulfonate starting from DMDS. With TiO<inf>2</inf>-based materials, in the absence of water and hence of hydroxyl radicals, products arising of C{single bond}S and S{single bond}S bond cleavage are mainly obtained: disulfide from DMS and CH<inf>3</inf>SSSCH<inf>3</inf> together with CH<inf>3</inf>SCH<inf>2</inf>SSCH<inf>3</inf> from DMDS. These latter products may be accounted for by electron transfer from sulfide or disulfide to photogenerated holes, leading to radical mechanisms. Mineralization to CO<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O is also shown to occur with DMS, but is not favoured under these conditions, due to the absence of water and of a too fast gas hourly space velocity (GHSV). The advantages-drawbacks of the two kinds of materials are presented. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.A., Lillo-Rodenas, Maria Angeles; N., Bouazza, N.; Á., Berenguer-Murcia, Ángel; J.J., Linares-Salinas, J. J.; P., Soto, Pablo; Á.J., Linares-Solano, Ángel J.
Author full names: Lillo-Rodenas, Maria Angeles (7801546469); Bouazza, N. (15768944100); Berenguer-Murcia, Ángel (6508313670); Linares-Salinas, J. J. (15769572900); Soto, Pablo (15770036800); Linares-Solano, Ángel J. (7005333764)
Title: Photocatalytic oxidation of propene at low concentration
Affiliations: Universitat d'Alacant, Alicante, Spain; Grupo Antolín-Irausa, S.A., Burgos, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Lillo-Rodenas, Maria Angeles, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Universitat d'Alacant, Alicante, Spain; Bouazza, N., Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Universitat d'Alacant, Alicante, Spain; Berenguer-Murcia, Ángel, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Universitat d'Alacant, Alicante, Spain; Linares-Salinas, J. J., Grupo Antolín-Irausa, S.A., Burgos, Spain; Soto, Pablo, Grupo Antolín-Irausa, S.A., Burgos, Spain; Linares-Solano, Ángel J., Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Universitat d'Alacant, Alicante, Spain
Abstract: The present paper analyses the preparation and characterisation of different titanium dioxide-based photocatalysts for propene oxidation at low concentration. Special attention has been paid to the agglomeration of the photocatalysts in form of pellets, to the study of the effect of introducing some carbonaceous materials into the catalyst composition and to comparison with commercial photocatalysts. Our results show that P25 exhibits the best activity among all the studied materials. However, activity importantly decreases when agglomerating the photocatalysts in form of pellets, either with or without carbon addition. The type of carbon material used in the photocatalyst strongly affects propene activity. Thus, carbon materials combining high surface area and high electric conductivity enhance the photocatalyst performance and photocatalyst pellets have been prepared exceeding the activity of a carbon-containing commercial photocatalyst. The importance of the UV-source has been highlighted, showing the 257.7 nm peak radiation much better results than the 365 nm UV-light. The studied photocatalysts are very interesting for propene oxidation not only because of their high activity, but also because it remains constant for more than 40 h and total mineralization of the oxidised propene to carbon dioxide and water is achieved. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
