Authors: T., Oppenländer, Thomas
Author full names: Oppenländer, Thomas (56584267200)
Title: Photochemical Purification of Water and Air: Advanced Oxidation Processes (AOPs) - Principles, Reaction Mechanisms, Reactor Concepts
Affiliations: Hochschule Furtwangen, Furtwangen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Oppenländer, Thomas, Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Hochschule Furtwangen, Furtwangen, Germany
Abstract: While the treatment of water and exhaust gas using ultraviolet (UV) light offers both ecological and economic advantages, information on photo-initiated advanced oxidation technologies (AOTs) has been dispersed among various journals and proceedings until now. This authoritative and comprehensive handbook is the first to cover both the photochemical fundamentals and practical applications, including a description of advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) and process engineering of suitable photoreactors. The author presents various real-world examples, including economic aspects, while many references to current scientific literature facilitate access to current research topics relevant for water and air industries. Throughout, over 140 detailed figures visualize photochemical and photophysical phenomena, and help in interpreting important research results. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.S., Upadhyay, Mita S.; M.L., Sattler, Melanie L.
Author full names: Upadhyay, Mita S. (56702332100); Sattler, Melanie L. (7006178884)
Title: Development of reaction rate constants for compounds commonly emitted from wastewater treatment plants and solid waste landfills
Affiliations: The University of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Upadhyay, Mita S., The University of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, United States; Sattler, Melanie L., The University of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, United States
Abstract: Photocatalytic oxidation (PCO) is a relatively new technology which has been found to be effective for smaller emission sources. This study examines the effectiveness of PCO in treating emissions from wastewater treatment plants and landfill facilities. To determine the effectiveness of the process, it is necessary to determine the PCO destruction rates of various volatile organic compounds (VOC) and hazardous air pollutants (HAP) species associated with these sources. The destruction rates and other data obtained from such kinetic experiments aid optimal reactor design. Accordingly, reaction rate constants were determined for photocatalytic destruction of methane, o-xylene, m-xylene, p-xylene, and carbonyl sulfide over a titanium dioxide (TiO<inf>2</inf>) catalyst in a continuous mixed-batch reactor. The PCO destruction rates indicated first order decay for all the components under review. Destruction rates were higher for smaller molecules such as methane and carbonyl sulfide and lower for complex molecules such as xylenes. The destruction rate also depended on humidity in an exponential relationship. The research concludes that PCO is a promising method to treat emissions from wastewater treatment plants and landfills. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B., Goodrich-Welk, Barbara; A., Konzen, Anthony; P., Schratz, Peter
Author full names: Goodrich-Welk, Barbara (36918177900); Konzen, Anthony (36918679700); Schratz, Peter (36919348200)
Title: MTBE remediation and in situ ozone sparging: An old technology given new life treating VOCs
Affiliations: Brown and Caldwell, Walnut Creek, United States; Calcon Systems, San Ramon, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goodrich-Welk, Barbara, Brown and Caldwell, Walnut Creek, United States; Konzen, Anthony, Brown and Caldwell, Walnut Creek, United States; Schratz, Peter, Calcon Systems, San Ramon, United States
Abstract: Ozone oxidation is not a new technology in the water treatment arena, and it has been successfully implemented in the potable water and wastewater industry for decades as a disinfectant and polish to reduce adverse tastes and odor in municipal water supplies. Over the past 10 years, ozone technology has made the cross-over to the environmental remediation industry creating a viable and cost effective option for the in-situ destruction of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in soil and groundwater. Ozone works by oxidizing and breaking the bonds of targeted VOC(s) such as methylene tert-butyl ether (MTBE). The ozone oxidizes the dissolved-phase MTBE, the primary constituent of concern at the study site, and creates an oxygen-rich environment that encourages microbial degradation of MTBE breakdown products such as tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) and tert-butyl formate (TBF). The byproducts of complete oxidation and microbial degradation of MTBE in groundwater include carbon dioxide (CO<inf>2</inf>) and water (H<inf>2</inf>O). The study site is a former aggregate mining facility located in Southern California that operated several diesel and gasoline fuel tanks until the late 1990s for fueling facility vehicles and cement trucks. Upon removal, it was determined that the tanks and associated product piping had leaked significantly resulting in an approximately 50,000 ft2 (aerial extent) source area with adsorbed- and liquid-phase fuel hydrocarbons, and an approximately 100,000 ft2 MTBE plume that included a small fraction of dissolved-phase BTEX near the source area. Because of a fast-track property transaction, the client preferred remedial options that would meet relatively stringent site cleanup goals within a short timeframe. To address the aggressive remediation schedule and cleanup requirements, Brown and Caldwell implemented a 2-phased approach that included: 1) removal of source area fuel impact by excavation with subsequent soil remediation via biopile treatment, and 2) remediation of dissolved-phase MTBE via ozone sparging. The objective of the source area removal was to remediate adsorbed-and liquia-phase hydrocarbons and reduce further impacts to groundwater via leaching. Source area removal resulted in the excavation of nearly 50,000 cubic yards (yd3) of soil. Out of the total 50,000 yd3, 17,000 yd3 was considered impacted and was staged for passive remediation in a series of 17-1,000 yd3 "biopiles" or treatment cells. The objective of the ozone sparging phase is to restore groundwater quality to regulatory-imposed standards within 7 months to expedite property reclamation and transfer. The remediation network includes 16 sparge wells constructed with ozone diffusers to reduce bubble size and maximize surface area contact. The ozone system will deliver timed pulses of ozone to each of the 16 well circuits to provide optimal contact time and destruction efficiency. Based on the extent of dissolved-phase hydrocarbon fuel, Brown and Caldwell anticipates delivery of up to 550 pounds of ozone for oxidation of MTBE and BTEX compounds as well as other organic compounds and other oxygen consumers in the subsurface. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Wu, Hungming; J.H., You, Jiann Hwa
Author full names: Wu, Hungming (56130119400); You, Jiann Hwa (7201683614)
Title: Destruction of methyl ethyl ketone vapor by ozone on activated carbon
Source title: Journal of the Chinese Institute of Chemical Engineers
Affiliations: Chang Gung University, Taoyuan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Hungming, Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Chang Gung University, Taoyuan, Taiwan; You, Jiann Hwa, Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, Chang Gung University, Taoyuan, Taiwan
Abstract: This study attempts to combine the technologies of adsorption of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) on activated carbon and the oxidation of the VOCs by ozone (O<inf>3</inf>). In the adsorption/oxidation process, the effects of ozone on the adsorption characteristics of methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) vapor on activated carbon are investigated. The kinetic parameters of the reaction for MEK vapor and O<inf>3</inf> on activated carbon are also determined. The results show that the destructive efficiencies of MEK by 1000 ppmv O<inf>3</inf> on activated carbon are from 12.4% to 48.5%. From the power law kinetic model, the apparent kinetic constant, k, is obtained with a value of 0.0438 h-1. Moreover, from the analytical results of the Arrhenius equation, the activation energy, E<inf>a</inf>, is found to be 5.12 kcal/mol and the value of rate constant, A, is 189.54 h-1. From the Langmuir-Hishelwood model [Escobar, P., Beroy, Q., Iritia, P.P., Huerta, J.H., 2004. Kinetic Study of the Combustion of Methyl-Ethyl-Ketone over α-Hematite Catalyst. Chem. Eng. J. 102, 107] the values of the kinetics parameters kl<inf>LH</inf> and k<inf>LH</inf> were 0.035 and 0.6183, respectively. Finally, the modified Wheeler equation [Busmundrud, O., 1993. Vapour Breakthrough in Activated Carbon Beds. Carbon 31, 279; Wood, G., Moyer, E.S., 1989. A Review of the Wheeler Equations and Comparison of Its Applications to Organic Vapor Respirator Cartridges Breakthrough Data. Am. Ind. Hyg. Assoc. J. 50, 400; Yoon, Y.H., Nelson, J.J., 1984. Application of Gas Adsorption Kineties I. A Theoretical for Respirator Cartridge Service Life. Am. Ind. Hyg. Assoc. J. 45, 509] in combination with the power law kinetic model or Langmuir-Hishelwood is used to predict the breakthrough curves. The destruction of MEK can be effectively promoted as the bed height of activated carbon and the concentration of ozone increase. When the ozone concentration is increased to 7800 ppmv and the amount of activated carbon is increased to 5 g the destructive efficiency of MEK is still greater than 95% even after a prolonged operational time. From the results of this study, an adsorption process in combination with ozone oxidation shows potential for the control of VOCs and odor. © 2007 Taiwan Institute of Chemical Engineers. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.B., Delebarre, Arnaud B.; Y., Andrès, Yves; M., Pellerano, Mario; P., Pero, Patrizia; D.G.G., Munzer, David Gerardo Garcia
Author full names: Delebarre, Arnaud B. (6701747697); Andrès, Yves (7004236739); Pellerano, Mario (16550621600); Pero, Patrizia (16550685600); Munzer, David Gerardo Garcia (16550098700)
Title: Biofiltration of volatile organic compounds by a fluidized bed of sawdust
Source title: International Journal of Chemical Reactor Engineering
Affiliations: IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France
Authors with affiliations: Delebarre, Arnaud B., IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France; Andrès, Yves, IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France; Pellerano, Mario, IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France; Pero, Patrizia, IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France; Munzer, David Gerardo Garcia, IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France
Abstract: In this study, the use of a natural material, sawdust, in a fluidised biofiltrer has been considered. The performance of the biofiltration of ethanol and toluene was estimated in the presence of the native microorganisms of the material and also after the addition, and a period of acclimatization, of external microorganisms. Modifications of the physical and biological characteristics of the material were studied in order to better understand the process. The influence of biofilter shutdown periods was also considered to evaluate the effect of a period of inactivity on subsequent performances. This study shows that a significant degradation of the pollutants is obtainable provided that the following steps are performed: seeding with activated sludge, introduction of nutrients, and control of the changes in the material characteristics and the bed moisture. During the operation of the fluidized bed biofilter, the moisture of the bed had an important effect on the biofilter performance, but was rather difficult to control because of its dependence on the ambient and inlet air temperatures, which changed during the day and the seasons. During the tests with the batch of sawdust particles used as delivered without any sludge enrichment, a reduction in abatement performances was measured with time. In the case of ethanol alone, for a concentration of 0.02 g.m-3, abatement decreased from 24% to 18% then to 7%. The partial or complete addition of sawdust particles previously activated with sludge significantly enhanced the performance of the biofilter, both for ethanol and toluene pollution. Abatements of ethanol of 85% and 60% were achieved when the sawdust particles were activated by sludge. In contrast, a 5-week shutdown of the reactor produced a decrease in abatement, either by a loss of microorganism efficiency during their "starvation" or by their destruction. Authors: A.T., Hodgson, Alfred T.; D.P., Sullivan, Douglas P.; W.J., Fisk, William J.
Author full names: Hodgson, Alfred T. (7101639272); Sullivan, Douglas P. (7402474402); Fisk, William J. (7007123462)
Title: Evaluation of ultra-violet photocatalytic oxidation for indoor air applications
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hodgson, Alfred T., Indoor Environment Department, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, United States; Sullivan, Douglas P., Indoor Environment Department, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, United States; Fisk, William J., Indoor Environment Department, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Effective air cleaning systems for volatile organic compounds (VOCs), coupled with particle filters, may enable acceptable air quality to be maintained in office buildings while consuming less energy than relying solely on ventilation. For such applications, ultraviolet photocatalytic oxidation (UVPCO) systems are being developed for VOC destruction. An experimental evaluation of a UVPCO system is reported. The evaluation was unique in that it employed complex mixtures of VOCs commonly found in office buildings at realistically low concentrations. VOC conversion efficiencies varied over a broad range, usually exceeded 20%, and were as high as ~80%. Conversion efficiency generally diminished with increased air flow rate. Significant amounts of formaldehyde and acetaldehyde were produced due to incomplete mineralization. Model results indicate that formaldehyde and acetaldehyde production rates may need to be reduced before such UVPCO systems can be deployed safely in occupied buildings. © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: E.H., Lock, Evgeniya H.; A.V., Saveliev, Alexei Vladimirovich; L.A., Kennedy, Lawrence Allan
Author full names: Lock, Evgeniya H. (8320175100); Saveliev, Alexei Vladimirovich (35563725600); Kennedy, Lawrence Allan (57208464190)
Title: Methanol and dimethyl sulfide removal by pulsed corona part I: Experiment
Affiliations: College of Engineering, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lock, Evgeniya H., College of Engineering, Chicago, United States; Saveliev, Alexei Vladimirovich, College of Engineering, Chicago, United States; Kennedy, Lawrence Allan, College of Engineering, Chicago, United States
Abstract: Methanol and dimethyl sulfide are volatile organic compound (VOC) air pollutants that are subject of severe environmental regulations due to their toxicity, environmental persistence and odor. Traditional technologies are often inefficient for their removal, especially in the case of the dilute industrial streams. Non-thermal plasma methods, typically characterized by high removal efficiency, energy yields and good economy, offer possible alternative solutions. The present research employs pulsed corona discharge known for its high selectivity and low energy costs of emission control. This paper provides experimental (Part I) and in a later issue numerical (Part II) data on removal of methanol and dimethyl sulfide from dry and humid air streams. The removal efficiency and the specific energy input are evaluated along with the energy costs required for the removal process. Particular attention is given to the formation of unwanted byproducts such as NO <inf>x</inf> , CO, and SO <inf>2</inf>. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2006. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Duran, Metin; N., Tepe, Nalan; D., Yurtsever, Deniz; V.L., Punzi, Vito L.; C., Bruno, Charles; R.J., Mehta, Raj J.
Author full names: Duran, Metin (9839572700); Tepe, Nalan (6603270549); Yurtsever, Deniz (15082063700); Punzi, Vito L. (6603128313); Bruno, Charles (15080609300); Mehta, Raj J. (24081023000)
Title: Bioaugmenting anaerobic digestion of biosolids with selected strains of Bacillus, Pseudomonas, and Actinomycetes species for increased methanogenesis and odor control
Affiliations: Villanova University College of Engineering, Villanova, United States; Stevens and Mccoy, Inc., Reading, United States; Villanova University College of Engineering, Villanova, United States; Organica Biotech, Norristown, United States
Authors with affiliations: Duran, Metin, Villanova University College of Engineering, Villanova, United States; Tepe, Nalan, Stevens and Mccoy, Inc., Reading, United States; Yurtsever, Deniz, Villanova University College of Engineering, Villanova, United States; Punzi, Vito L., Villanova University College of Engineering, Villanova, United States; Bruno, Charles, Organica Biotech, Norristown, United States; Mehta, Raj J., Organica Biotech, Norristown, United States
Abstract: The objective of this study was to evaluate the effects of bioaugmenting anaerobic biosolids digestion with a commercial product containing selected strains of bacteria from genera Bacillus, Pseudomonas, and Actinomycetes, along with ancillary organic compounds containing various micronutrients. Specifically, the effects of the bioaugment in terms of volatile solids destruction and generation and fate of odor-causing compounds during anaerobic digestion and during storage of the digested biosolids were studied. Two bench-scale anaerobic digesters receiving primary and secondary clarifier biosolids from various full-scale biological wastewater treatment plants were operated. One of the digesters received the bioaugment developed by Organica Biotech, while the other was operated as control. The bioaugmented digester generated 29% more net CH<inf>4</inf> during the 8 weeks of operation. In addition, the average residual propionic acid concentration in the bioaugmented digester was 54% of that in the control. The monitoring of two organic sulfide compounds, methyl mercaptan (CH<inf>3</inf>SH) and dimethyl sulfide (CH <inf>3</inf>SCH<inf>3</inf>), clearly demonstrated the beneficial effects of the bioaugmentation in terms of odor control. The biosolids digested in the bioaugmented digester generated a negligible amount of CH<inf>3</inf>SH during 10 days of post-digestion storage, while CH<inf>3</inf>SH concentration in the control reached nearly 300 ppm<inf>v</inf> during the same period. Similarly, peak CH<inf>3</inf>SCH<inf>3</inf> generated by stored biosolids from the bioaugmented digester was only 37% of that from the control. © 2006 Springer-Verlag. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: N., Doucet, N.; F., Bocquillon, F.; O., Zahraa, Orfan; M., Bouchy, Michel
Author full names: Doucet, N. (57189689040); Bocquillon, F. (6504216441); Zahraa, Orfan (6508297663); Bouchy, Michel (25222614400)
Title: Kinetics of photocatalytic VOCs abatement in a standardized reactor
Affiliations: Université de Lorraine, Nancy, France
Authors with affiliations: Doucet, N., ENSIC, Université de Lorraine, Nancy, France; Bocquillon, F., ENSIC, Université de Lorraine, Nancy, France; Zahraa, Orfan, ENSIC, Université de Lorraine, Nancy, France; Bouchy, Michel, ENSIC, Université de Lorraine, Nancy, France
Abstract: A standardized micro-pilot scale continuous flow apparatus has been built up, using two types of differential photoreactors, and equipped with a refined control of the working conditions in order to study the photocatalytic degradation as a way to abate VOCs in air. Kinetic measurements have been carried out on trichloroethylene (TCE), methanol and benzene as model pollutants. The absence of diffusional limitation and of reaction product effect on the kinetics have both been demonstrated under our working conditions. The influences of concentration, light flux and temperature on the initial degradation rate have been studied. A simple Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic model has been verified for TCE and methanol, whereas benzene degradation was more complex and did not follow this simple mechanism. The determined experimental data aim at being useful in the scaling-up of photocatalytic reactors. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: C.M., Cellier, Caroline M.; V., Ruaux, Valérie; C., Lahousse, Christophe; P., Grange, Paul; E.M., Gaigneaux, E. M.
Author full names: Cellier, Caroline M. (7006543029); Ruaux, Valérie (8076633200); Lahousse, Christophe (6507349033); Grange, Paul (7103339318); Gaigneaux, E. M. (7004221102)
Title: Extent of the participation of lattice oxygen from γ-MnO2 in VOCs total oxidation: Influence of the VOCs nature
Affiliations: Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Cellier, Caroline M., Unité de Catalyse et Chimie des Matériaux Divisés, Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Ruaux, Valérie, Unité de Catalyse et Chimie des Matériaux Divisés, Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Lahousse, Christophe, Unité de Catalyse et Chimie des Matériaux Divisés, Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Grange, Paul, Unité de Catalyse et Chimie des Matériaux Divisés, Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Gaigneaux, E. M., Unité de Catalyse et Chimie des Matériaux Divisés, Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Abstract: Investigation of the total oxidation of n-hexane and trimethylamine as well as extensive characterizations of the catalyst after tests have been coupled to identify the mechanism of oxidation involved over a very active γ-MnO<inf>2</inf> catalyst. This work shows that the extent of the catalyst reduction, which is a consequence of the Mars and van Krevelen redox mechanism, depends on the nature of the organic molecule. Indeed, the nature of the VOC dictates its conversion level through its ability to reduce the catalyst and accelerate the incorporation rate of gaseous oxygen. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Yan, Naiqiang; Z., Qu, Zan; J., Jia, Jingping; X., Wang, Xiaopeng; D., Wu, Dan
Title: Removal characteristics of gaseous sulfur-containing compounds by pulsed corona plasma
Affiliations: Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Yan, Naiqiang, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Qu, Zan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Jia, Jingping, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Wang, Xiaopeng, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Wu, Dan, School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Pulsed corona plasma was employed to treat the gases containing hydrogen sulfide, methyl mercaptan (MM), and dimethyl sulfide (DMS), respectively. For the plasma oxidation only, the removal efficiencies of hydrogen sulfide, MM, and DMS were approximated to be 90%, 69%, and 52% when the discharge power was 5.6 W. But all the removal efficiencies were over 98% when an activated carbon fiber (ACF) filter was used downstream from the plasma reactor. In addition, the decomposition reaction mechanism was discussed and a competitive reaction kinetics model was proposed to describe the plasma decomposition reaction kinetics. The ACF filter appeared to be co-beneficial in the improvement of removal efficiency, reduction of energy consumption, and the abatement of ozone or other byproducts. The energy consumption was about 3 W'h/m3 for hydrogen sulfide to obtain about 90% of the removal efficiency by plasma oxidation only, but it can be reduced below 1.2 W-h/m3 in the present of the ACF filter. © 2006 American Chemical Society. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Guo, Yufang; D., Ye, Daiqi; K., Chen, Kefu
Title: Toluene removal characteristics by a superimposed wire-plate dielectric barrier discharge plasma reactor
Affiliations: South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Guo, Yufang, Department of Resources Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Ye, Daiqi, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Chen, Kefu, Department of Resources Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: A superimposed wire-plate dielectric barrier discharge reactor was used to remove toluene in this study. The effects of oxygen content, gas flow rate, gas initial concentration and with/without catalyst on toluene decomposition were investigated. It was found that an optimal toluene removal was achieved when the oxygen content was about 5%. Under this condition, the highest toluene removal efficiency of 80.8% was achieved when the gas concentration was 80 mg/m3. The toluene removal efficiency decreased with the increase of the gas flow rate and the initial concentration of toluene. In addition, the ozone concentration decreased with the increase of the initial concentration of toluene. It suggested that combining DBD (dielectric barrier discharge) with Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>/foam nickel catalyst in-situ could improve the toluene removal efficiency and suppress ozone formation. Products analysis showed that the main products were CO and CO<inf>2</inf> when oxygen was more than 5%. © 2006 Science Press. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.A., Merino, Nora Andrea; B.P., Barbero, Bibiana P.; P.E., Ruíz, Patricio E.; L.E., Cadús, Luis E.
Author full names: Merino, Nora Andrea (8251839800); Barbero, Bibiana P. (6603006154); Ruíz, Patricio E. (7201624339); Cadús, Luis E. (7004615497)
Title: Synthesis, characterisation, catalytic activity and structural stability of LaCo1-yFeyO3±λ perovskite catalysts for combustion of ethanol and propane
Affiliations: Instituto de Investigaciones en Tecnologia Quimica, San Luis, Argentina; Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Merino, Nora Andrea, Instituto de Investigaciones en Tecnologia Quimica, San Luis, Argentina; Barbero, Bibiana P., Instituto de Investigaciones en Tecnologia Quimica, San Luis, Argentina; Ruíz, Patricio E., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Cadús, Luis E., Instituto de Investigaciones en Tecnologia Quimica, San Luis, Argentina
Abstract: LaCo<inf>1-y</inf>Fe<inf>y</inf>O<inf>3</inf> perovskite-type oxides with y = 0.1, 0.3, and 0.5 were prepared by the citrate method and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), BET surface area measurement (SSA), diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), and Mössbauer spectroscopy. With this preparation method, a good inclusion of the substituting cation in the B-site is reached, maintaining the rhombohedral crystalline structure, modifying the volume of the unit cell, and weakening the B{single bond}O bond. This likely affects the capacity and the mechanism of oxygen supply or the redox behavior. At high iron content, Fe4+ could exist. Surface enrichment in lanthanum was observed on XPS. The singularity observed in the improvement of the catalytic activity for y = 0.1, in both propane and ethanol combustion, could be explained by the electronic complexity introduced by iron in the perovskite conductor characteristics. © 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J., Yang, Jiantao; Y., Shi, Yao; W., Li, Wei; X., Wang, Xin; D., Wang, Dahui
Title: Combination of non-thermal plasma and activated carbon fibers for decomposition of hydrogen sulfide
Affiliations: Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Yang, Jiantao, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Shi, Yao, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Li, Wei, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Xin, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Dahui, Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: The combination of non-thermal plasma and activated carbon fibers for decomposition of H<inf>2</inf>S was studied. When the peak voltage of the corona reactor was 30 kv, the initial concentration of H<inf>2</inf>S was 100 mg/cu m, the concentration of H<inf>2</inf>S from corona reactor decreased to 5 mg/cu m, i.e., the removal efficiency of H<inf>2</inf>S was 95%. In the activated carbon fibers reactor, the H<inf>2</inf>S, which was not decomposed, would react with the ozone which generated by corona reactor. Therefore, the concentration of H<inf>2</inf>S was undetected before the activated carbon fibers were broken through. When H<inf>2</inf>S was decomposed in the corona reactor, SO<inf>2</inf>, NO<inf>x</inf> and ozone generated. In the activated carbon fibers reactor, the SO<inf>2</inf> and NO<inf>x</inf> could react with ozone or be absorbed in the surface of activated carbon fibers. The ozone generated in the corona reactor reacted with H<inf>2</inf>S, SO<inf>2</inf>, NO<inf>x</inf> and reacted as the functions and in the surface of activated carbon fibers; the concentration of ozone from the activated carbon fibers reactor could be decreased very low. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 231st ACS National Meeting (Atlanta, GA 3/26-30/2006). © 2006 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Cantau, Christophe; T., Pigot, Thierry; R., Brown, Ross; P., Mocho, Pierre; M.T., Maurette, Marie Thérèse; F., Benoit-Marque, F.; S.M., Lacombe, Sylvie M.
Author full names: Cantau, Christophe (9846314400); Pigot, Thierry (6506088641); Brown, Ross (24438905800); Mocho, Pierre (12772476600); Maurette, Marie Thérèse (24432492600); Benoit-Marque, F. (13407657300); Lacombe, Sylvie M. (7005404756)
Title: Photooxidation of dimethylsulfide in the gas phase: A comparison between TiO2-silica and photosensitizer-silica based materials
Affiliations: Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France
Authors with affiliations: Cantau, Christophe, Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Pigot, Thierry, Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Brown, Ross, Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Mocho, Pierre, Laboratoire de Thermique, Energétique et Procédés, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France; Maurette, Marie Thérèse, Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France; Benoit-Marque, F., Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France; Lacombe, Sylvie M., Laboratoire de Chimie Théorique et Physico-Chimie Moléculaire, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour, Pau, France
Abstract: The photooxidation of dimethylsulfide (DMS) in the gas phase was studied with two different materials, under identical conditions. The first material (TiO<inf>2</inf>-QZ) is based on titanium dioxide (TiO<inf>2</inf>) deposited on quartz bars by the sol-gel method. The second one (DCA-SG) is based on the well known photosensitizer, 9,10-dicyanoanthracene (DCA) encapsulated in a sol-gel silica network. In spite of non-optimized conditions, both materials allow the oxidation of DMS in air under irradiation. However, the oxidation products are strikingly different: dimethyldisulfide is the main product detected in the gas phase with TiO<inf>2</inf>-QZ due to a too short residence time to achieve complete mineralization. With DCA-SG no gaseous product is detected in the treated gaseous flow for more than 100 h, due to the exclusive formation of polar dimethylsulfoxide and dimethylsulfone which are totally adsorbed on the highly polar silica gel. The efficiency of this latter reaction depends on the DMS concentration, gas flow and light intensity, but is not affected by the presence of small amounts of water. Singlet oxygen appears to be formed efficiently under these conditions. The saturation of DCA-SG by the oxidation products was demonstrated by several complementary methods, and some possible solutions to regenerate the material are proposed. The complementarities of both TiO<inf>2</inf>-QZ and DCA-SG could be used to achieve the oxidation of different classes of pollutants. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Cassez, Andy; A., Ponchel, Anne; H., Bricout, Hervé; S., Fourmentin, Sophie; D., Landy, David; E., Monflier, E.
Author full names: Cassez, Andy (13405377300); Ponchel, Anne (6602706436); Bricout, Hervé (6701749886); Fourmentin, Sophie (6505850347); Landy, David (6603890766); Monflier, E. (7003541672)
Title: Eco-efficient catalytic hydrodechlorination of carbon tetrachloride in aqueous cyclodextrin solutions
Affiliations: Université d'Artois, Arras, France; Unité de Chimie Environnementale et Interactions sur le Vivant, Dunkerque, France
Authors with affiliations: Cassez, Andy, Laboratoire de Physico-Chimie des Interfaces et Applications, Université d'Artois, Arras, France; Ponchel, Anne, Laboratoire de Physico-Chimie des Interfaces et Applications, Université d'Artois, Arras, France; Bricout, Hervé, Laboratoire de Physico-Chimie des Interfaces et Applications, Université d'Artois, Arras, France; Fourmentin, Sophie, Unité de Chimie Environnementale et Interactions sur le Vivant, Dunkerque, France; Landy, David, Laboratoire de Physico-Chimie des Interfaces et Applications, Université d'Artois, Arras, France; Monflier, E., Laboratoire de Physico-Chimie des Interfaces et Applications, Université d'Artois, Arras, France
Abstract: An eco-efficient process of catalytic hydrodechlorination of carbon tetrachloride into methane and chloride salts has been developed in aqueous basic medium at room temperature. The organic pollutants are trapped in water by cyclodextrins (CDs) via the formation of inclusion complexes and dechlorinated by a supported heterogeneous palladium catalyst. Catalytic investigations demonstrate that CDs act as efficient CCl<inf>4</inf> solubilizcrs and, much more interesting, as protective molecules against side reactions. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Chang, Changtang; K., Lin, Kaelong
Author full names: Chang, Changtang (7407038710); Lin, Kaelong (7403967063)
Title: Assessment of the strategies for reducing VOCs emission from polyurea-formaldehyde resin synthetic fiber leather industry in Taiwan
Affiliations: National Ilan University, Yilan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, Changtang, Department of Environmental Engineering, National Ilan University, Yilan, Taiwan; Lin, Kaelong, Department of Environmental Engineering, National Ilan University, Yilan, Taiwan
Abstract: This study provides a novel attempt to assess the effectiveness of control strategies for reducing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emission from polyurea-formaldehyde resin synthetic fiber leather (PU) industry. Dimethyl formamide (DMF), major content of solvents, accounts for roughly 2500 tonnes/year to avoid excessive viscosity of polyurea-formaldehyde and to increase facility in working. The other solvent contents, methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) and toluene, are used as carrier of DMF. Emission of these VOCs from solvent causes serious odor problems. It is important to know the VOCs pollution sources and emission characteristics before treating the VOCs in PU industry. In this study, 80 stacks in five factories were tested to evaluate emission characteristics at each VOCs source. After examining the VOCs concentrations in the flue gases and contents in the PU, the DMF emission rate before treatment and from fugitive source is 2300 and 80 tonnes/year, respectively. To reduce VOCs emission rate, it is important to assess reducing solvent content in painting and increasing control efficiency of treatment equipment. In this study, the zeolite rotator is recommended to be used as effective control equipment. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Guo, Yufang; D., Ye, Daiqi; K., Chen, Kefu; J., He, Jiancong; W., Chen, Weili
Title: Toluene decomposition using a wire-plate dielectric barrier discharge reactor with manganese oxide catalyst in situ
Source title: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
Affiliations: South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Guo, Yufang, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, Department of Resources Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Ye, Daiqi, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Chen, Kefu, Department of Resources Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; He, Jiancong, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Chen, Weili, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: Laboratory-scale experiments were performed to evaluate the efficiency of toluene decomposition by using a wire-plate dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) reactor with manganese oxide/alumina/nickel foam catalyst in the discharge area at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. The effects of oxygen content and gas flow rate were investigated. Under the optimal oxygen content and gas flow rate conditions, the combination effect of DBD and catalyst was observed, and the catalyst before/after discharge was structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). It has been found that combining DBD with catalyst in situ could improve the toluene removal efficiency, increase carbon dioxide selectivity and suppress byproducts formation. Whether the catalyst existed or not, the major products were carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide when oxygen was enough. The characterization of the catalyst suggested that DBD enhanced the dispersion of the active species, increased the stability as well as the activity of the catalyst, and strengthened the oxidation capability of the catalyst, therefore the removal of toluene was promoted. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: E., Finocchio, Elisabetta; G., Busca, Guido; M., Notaro, Maurizio
Author full names: Finocchio, Elisabetta (7004523769); Busca, Guido (57208583146); Notaro, Maurizio (6602089735)
Title: A review of catalytic processes for the destruction of PCDD and PCDF from waste gases
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; CESI S.p.A., Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Finocchio, Elisabetta, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica e di Processo, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; Busca, Guido, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica e di Processo, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; Notaro, Maurizio, BU Processi per la Generazione, CESI S.p.A., Milan, Italy
Abstract: The current literature concerning the catalytic destruction of dioxins and of related model compounds is reviewed. Several different catalyst formulations have been tested, but V-rich vanadia-tungsta-titania catalysts seem to be mostly applied and allow reducing the dioxins concentration well below the limits of 0.1 ng TEQ/Nm3, as required by the EU directives. Other catalysts (in particular the noble metal-based ones) seem to be less efficient, due to deactivation effects and/or a considerable amount of polychlorinated by-products formation during oxidation activity. The coupled de-NO<inf>x</inf> and dioxin destruction systems compete with activated carbon adsorption for efficiency in PCDD/F removal from gases. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.B., Hocking, Martin B.
Author full names: Hocking, Martin B. (7006182220)
Title: Handbook of Chemical Technology and Pollution Control, Third Edition
Affiliations: University of Victoria, Victoria, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Hocking, Martin B., University of Victoria, Victoria, Canada
Abstract: The Handbook of Chemical Technology and Pollution Control, Third Edition provides a detailed review of the chemistry and operating conditions of many of the present large-scale chemical processes important to our economy and high standards of living. The processes that could lead to emissions affecting our air, soil, and water are considered, together with ways in which it may be possible to reduce or eliminate these pollutants. Focusing on cleaner production concepts without neglecting 'end of pipe' measures. With an increase in the awareness of corporate and social responsibility among business and industry leaders, the pressure to reduce harmful emissions and the desire to increase efficiencies and energy utilization, this book provides an essential resource. Suitable for researchers, practitioners and postgraduate students in the fields of chemical and biochemical engineering and environmental science, as well as government monitoring and regulatory agencies and industry leaders who want to stay one step ahead, this book will be a valuable addition to any library. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Zhong, Hua; R., Zeng, R.
Title: Structure of LaSrMO4 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) and their catalytic properties in the total oxidation of hexane
Source title: Journal of the Serbian Chemical Society
Affiliations: Jinggangshan University, Jinan, China; Jinggangshan University, Jinan, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhong, Hua, Provincial Key Laboratory of Coordination Chemistry, Jinggangshan University, Jinan, China, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jinggangshan University, Jinan, China; Zeng, R., Provincial Key Laboratory of Coordination Chemistry, Jinggangshan University, Jinan, China, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jinggangshan University, Jinan, China
Abstract: Perovskite-type LaSrMO<inf>4</inf> (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) mixed oxides were prepared by the decomposition of amorphous citric and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid complexes and investigated by the XRD, FTIR, BET, TPR, TPD and XPS-methods. Their catalytic behavior in the total oxidation of hexane was examined. The following activity order was found LaSrCoO <inf>4</inf> > LaSrNiO<inf>4</inf> > LaSrCuO<inf>4</inf> > LaSrFeO <inf>4</inf> > LaSrMnO<inf>4</inf>. This is explained in terms of oxygen vacancies and mobile lattice oxygen, particle size and BET surface area. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Catalytic Property; Hexane Oxidation; Perovskite-type Lasrmo4

Authors: A., Kachina, Anna; S.V., Preis, Sergei V.; J., Kallas, Juha
Author full names: Kachina, Anna (8340940400); Preis, Sergei V. (7003331897); Kallas, Juha (7003545491)
Title: Catalytic TiO2 oxidation of ethanethiol for environmentally begnin air pollution control of sulphur compounds
Affiliations: LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Kachina, Anna, Department of Chemical Engineering, LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland; Preis, Sergei V., Department of Chemical Engineering, LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland; Kallas, Juha, Department of Chemical Engineering, LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland
Abstract: Volatile organic compounds containing reduced sulphur such as thiols and thioethers are released mostly from biological activities and a number of manufacturing processes, such as papermaking and petroleum refining. Environmentally benign and cost-effective air pollution control technology for reduced sulphur compounds is still a topic of research, e.g., in pulp and paper industry. Due to its advantages, photocatalytic oxidation over titanium dioxide presents a potential alternative for the air treatment strategies. The temperature influence on the reaction pathway and kinetics of gas-phase photocatalytic oxidation and thermal catalytic decomposition of ethanethiol over Degussa P25 TiO<inf>2</inf> was established by a continuous flow method in a simple tubular reactor at temperatures from 373 to 453 K. Kinetic parameters for ethanethiol were: adsorption enthalpy -45 kJ mol-1 and activation energy 42 kJ mol-1. Sulphur dioxide, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, acetic acid and water were identified as by-products. © Springer-Verlag 2006. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Chang, Changtang; C.S., Chiou, Chyowsan Shan
Author full names: Chang, Changtang (7407038710); Chiou, Chyowsan Shan (7202682192)
Title: Assessment of control strategies for reducing volatile organic compound emissions from the polyvinyl chloride wallpaper production industry in taiwan
Source title: Journal of the Air and Waste Management Association
Affiliations: National Ilan University, Yilan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, Changtang, Department of Environmental Engineering, National Ilan University, Yilan, Taiwan; Chiou, Chyowsan Shan, Department of Environmental Engineering, National Ilan University, Yilan, Taiwan
Abstract: This study attempts to assess the effectiveness of control strategies for reducing volatile organic compound (VOC) emission from the polyvinyl chloride (PVC) wallpaper production industry. In Taiwan, methyl ethyl ketone, TOL, and cyclohexanone have comprised the major content of solvents, accounting for ∼113,000 t/yr to avoid excessive viscosity of plasticizer dioctyl phthalate (DOP) and to increase facility in working. Emissions of these VOCs from solvents have caused serious odor and worse air quality problems. In this study, 80 stacks in five factories were tested to evaluate emission characteristics at each VOC source. After examining the VOC concentrations in the flue gases and contents, the VOC emission rate before treatment and from fugitive sources was 93,000 and 800 t/yr, respectively. In this study, the semiwet electrostatic precipitator is recommended for use as cost-effective control equipment. © 2006 Air & Waste Management Association. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P., Chin, Paul; L.P., Yang, Lao P.; D.F., Ollis, David F.
Title: Formaldehyde removal from air via a rotating adsorbent combined with a photocatalyst reactor: Kinetic modeling
Affiliations: NC State College of Engineering, Raleigh, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chin, Paul, NC State College of Engineering, Raleigh, United States; Yang, Lao P., NC State College of Engineering, Raleigh, United States; Ollis, David F., NC State College of Engineering, Raleigh, United States
Abstract: A novel rotating honeycomb adsorbent coupled with a photocatalytic reactor demonstrated by Shiraishi et al. is modeled here. In operation, the air pollutant formaldehyde was adsorbed from a simulated room (10 m3) onto a slowly rotating honeycomb, which then passed slowly through a small chamber (0.09 m3) in which locally recirculated heated air desorbed the formaldehyde and carried it through a photocatalytic reactor, which oxidized the desorbed material. The regenerated rotor-adsorbent then rotated back into the airtight chamber. This system was modeled at steady states and transient states to determine adsorption, desorption, and photocatalyst pseudo-first-order rate constants at the appropriate temperatures (ambient temperature for adsorption, 120-180 °C for desorption and photocatalysis). Intensity-corrected values for the photocatalytic rate constant kcat (cm 2/(mW s)) deduced from fitting our model to the data of Shiraishi et al. were in good agreement with those calculated from five literature reports for formaldehyde photocatalytic destruction. © 2005 Elsevier Inc. Authors: P.A., Le Cloirec, Pierre A.; Y., Andrès, Yves; C., Gérente, Claire; P., Pré, Pascaline
Author full names: Le Cloirec, Pierre A. (7005451027); Andrès, Yves (7004236739); Gérente, Claire (6603314321); Pré, Pascaline (6602436933)
Title: Biological treatment of waste gases containing volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France
Authors with affiliations: Le Cloirec, Pierre A., IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France; Andrès, Yves, IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France; Gérente, Claire, IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France; Pré, Pascaline, IMT Atlantique, Nantes, France
Abstract: In recent years, a strong technological base has been developed for air quality zcontrol. The driving force has been public awareness of the need for human health and environmental protection. Consequently, environmental legislation and regulations have been initiated by governments to control air quality. Removing air pollutants, and especially volatile organic compounds (VOC s),from industrial polluted gaseous emissions is achieved by different ways:- Transfer and or concentration of compounds in a liquid phase (condensation, absorption) or onto a solid (adsorption).- Destruction of molecules by thermal oxidation, catalytic treatments, flaring,or degradation of compounds by microorganisms. Among these technologies useful for air treatment, processes involving the biodegradation of pollutants present in the gaseous phase are widely used. They may be applied to both water and air purification (Godish 1997; Liu and Liptak 1997; Heinsohn and Kabel 1999). Thus, these biological systems canre move a large number of molecules, especially volatile organic compounds and odorous molecules. They are generally utilized for the treatment of industrial gaseous emissions. The applications are possible for a concentration of pollutant above 1gm<inf>3</inf> to diluted air (some mg or ?gm<inf>3</inf>). The installation designs cater for an airflow of between 1,000 to 100,000m<inf>3</inf> h<inf>1</inf>, or even more for some systems (Le Cloirec 1998). The principles, processes and modeling of biological systems for air pollution control have been described previously in this book. The objective of this chapter is to present practical approaches to air treatment, especially removal of volatileorganic compounds, by biological methods. Specific points and process examples are developed:- examples and data on the biodegradation of VOC s;- applications of biological processes: general operating conditions and case studies: bio filters, bio trickling filters and bio scrubbers;- treatment of by-products generated by VOC bio treatments. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2005. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Mohseni, Madjid
Author full names: Mohseni, Madjid (7005809210)
Title: Biological treatment of waste gases containing inorganic compounds
Affiliations: The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Mohseni, Madjid, Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
Abstract: The detrimental impact of many air pollutants to human health, vegetation, human property, or the global environment is evident from various studies conducted over many years. Inorganic air pollutants are among those that require special attention because of their significant environmental impacts as well as their lack of response to many physical air pollution control techniques(e.g., filters, vapor capture, and condensation). Many of these inorganic air pollutants (such as hydrogen cyanide and hydrogen sulfide) can be associated with severe and acute health impacts following industrial accidents. However, most of the interest in air pollution and health is directed at long-term and low concentration exposure to harmful air contaminants. With the compelling evidence on the long-term impacts of inorganic air pollutants, many researchers have focused on developing and optimizing novel and cost-effective air pollution control strategies that can meet the increasingly stringent regulations on the emissions of these chemicals (e.g., Barnes et al. 1995; Chung et al. 2000;Philip and Deshusses 2003). © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2005. © 2014 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Li, Congna; K.S., Bowman, Kimberly S.; W.M., Moe, William M.
Author full names: Li, Congna (8272937300); Bowman, Kimberly S. (7103098793); Moe, William M. (7003743715)
Title: Effects of elevated relative humidity on passively operated activated carbon load equalization systems for biofilters treating gas-phase toluene
Affiliations: Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Li, Congna, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, United States; Bowman, Kimberly S., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, United States; Moe, William M., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, United States
Abstract: Biofiltration is an attractive treatment option for removal and destruction of VOC found in many air emissions. Results from a series of experiments conducted to evaluate the effect of relative humidity on the degree of load equalization achieved by columns packed with Calgon BPL 4 × 6 mesh activated carbon under intermittent loading conditions where toluene contaminated air was supplied 8 hr/day and uncontaminated air 16 hr/day were described to simulate an industrial process with discontinuous contaminant generation. Experimental testing was conducted for a variety of loading conditions with granular activated carbon column empty bed contact times (EBCT) ranging from 1.5 to 10 sec, influent toluene concentrations as high as 1000 ppm vol, and relative humidity level of 80%. Appreciable load equalization could be accomplished at low EBCT (on the order of a few seconds) even when high relative humidity was present. Implementation of this load equalization approach may facilitate use of smaller, less expensive biofilters, and it had the potential to minimize much of the uncertainty that accompanies biofilter design and operation. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 98th AWMA Annual Conference and Exhibition (Minneapolis, MN 6/21-24/2005). © 2006 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., Cotter, David; D., Sykes, Derek
Author full names: Cotter, David (13407947700); Sykes, Derek (57225384706)
Title: Biofilter pilot study for control of VOC emissions at a chemical batch processing plant
Affiliations: Capaccio Env. Eng., Marlboro, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cotter, David, Capaccio Env. Eng., Marlboro, United States; Sykes, Derek, Capaccio Env. Eng., Marlboro, United States
Abstract: While biofiltration has proven to be an effective tool in controlling odor emissions, it has had limited application in the control of VOC emissions from industrial processes where BACT must be applied. A study on the effectiveness of biofiltration as a control for VOC emissions from a chemical batch processing plant was carried out. The study was conducted over a 12-wk period and designed to evaluate the destruction removal efficiency (DRE) of a biofilter system for methanol, acetone, and toluene with the intent of demonstrating if a biofilter could meet BACT for VOC control. Individual 95% DRE for the overall pilot unit could be consistently achieved for inlet test VOC concentrations above the following levels: methanol 100 ppm vol, acetone 50 ppm vol, and toluene 5 ppm vol. At levels below these, the DRE dropped precipitously with the decreasing inlet concentrations. The pilot unit performed better under daytime and warmer conditions than during nighttime and colder conditions. The daytime/warmer temperature data points for both toluene and acetone suggested that the pilot system was significantly oversized with respect to the overall loading form these two materials. Since the configuration of the biofilters affected the VOC loadings in the bed this, in turn, produced a different overall consumption rate and DRE. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 98th AWMA Annual Conference and Exhibition (Minneapolis, MN 6/21-24/2005). © 2006 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G., Wittmann, Gyula; K., Demeestere, Kristof; A., Dombi, András; J.P., Dewulf, Jo P.; H.R., Van Langenhove, Herman R.
Author full names: Wittmann, Gyula (7007014588); Demeestere, Kristof (6602756975); Dombi, András (57210201829); Dewulf, Jo P. (7006029915); Van Langenhove, Herman R. (22036947600)
Title: Preparation, structural characterization and photocatalytic activity of mesoporous Ti-silicates
Affiliations: University of Szeged Faculty of Science and Informatics, Szeged, Hungary; Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Wittmann, Gyula, Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, University of Szeged Faculty of Science and Informatics, Szeged, Hungary; Demeestere, Kristof, Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; Dombi, András, Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, University of Szeged Faculty of Science and Informatics, Szeged, Hungary; Dewulf, Jo P., Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; Van Langenhove, Herman R., Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium
Abstract: This paper focuses on structural and photocatalytic properties of ordered mesoporous Ti-silicates, prepared by both impregnation (IMP) and coprecipitation (CP) methods. Catalyst characterization was carried out by inductively coupled plasma analysis, nitrogen adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX). Photocatalytic activity was evaluated for gaseous trichloroethylene (TCE) decomposition in a batch reactor under near-UV irradiation. Both the Ti incorporation method (IMP or CP) and TiO<inf>2</inf> content (4.7-35.0 wt.%) had large effects on structural characteristics and photocatalytic activity of Ti-silicates, whereas no important effects were observed with respect to calcination temperature (200-600°C). At all conditions, TiO<inf>2</inf> was present as pure anatase crystallites with particle diameters in IMP catalysts of 4.4-7.0 nm, being clearly smaller than those in CP ones (12.0-19.6 nm). The ordered structure of the silica was at least partially preserved up to a TiO<inf>2</inf> content of 25 wt.% (CP) and 33 wt.% (IMP). With increasing TiO<inf>2</inf> content, specific surface area (SSA 376-805 m2 g-1) of both CP and IMP catalysts decreased. Similar trends were observed for pore volumes (0.6-1.2 mL g-1) and pore diameters (4.5-7.5 nm) in IMP catalysts. Initial photocatalytic TCE degradation rate constants (0.014-0.202 min-1) obtained with CP catalysts increased systematically with TiO<inf>2</inf> contents up to 35 wt.%, while in IMP ones, they levelled off at TiO<inf>2</inf> contents above 17 wt.%. TCE degradation rates obtained with CP catalysts were up to a factor of six higher than those measured applying the IMP method. This may be explained by a different TiO<inf>2</inf> localization in the silica structure. During IMP preparation, TiO<inf>2</inf> is mostly incorporated within the silica mesopores, whereas during CP synthesis, it is mainly localized on the external silica surface. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K., Demeestere, Kristof; J.P., Dewulf, Jo P.; B.P., De Witte, Bavo P.; H.R., Van Langenhove, Herman R.
Author full names: Demeestere, Kristof (6602756975); Dewulf, Jo P. (7006029915); De Witte, Bavo P. (8504316600); Van Langenhove, Herman R. (22036947600)
Title: Titanium dioxide mediated heterogeneous photocatalytic degradation of gaseous dimethyl sulfide: Parameter study and reaction pathways
Affiliations: Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Demeestere, Kristof, Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; Dewulf, Jo P., Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; De Witte, Bavo P., Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; Van Langenhove, Herman R., Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium
Abstract: This paper deals with the photocatalytic degradation of gaseous dimethyl sulfide (DMS) in a wide range of inlet concentrations (3 ppmv < [DMS] <inf>in</inf> < 545 ppmv), gas residence times (5 s < τ < 55 s) and relative humidities (3% < RH < 75%), using TiO<inf>2</inf> Degussa P25 as a photocatalyst in a flat-plate photoreactor. DMS removal efficiencies increased with lower [DMS]<inf>in</inf> and higher τ, while the optimum RH was 22%. Although DMS removal efficiencies higher than 90% (peaks over 97%) could be obtained for at least 180 min at τ = 55 s, RH < 53% and [DMS]<inf>in</inf> < 10 ppmv, prolonged irradiation and/or increased [DMS]<inf>in</inf> resulted into catalyst deactivation due to accumulation of reaction products on the TiO<inf>2</inf> surface. During photocatalytic DMS degradation at [DMS]<inf>in</inf> ≥ 100 ppmv, dimethyl disulfide, carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide were detected as gas-phase reaction products, while solid-liquid extraction revealed dimethyl sulfoxide, dimethyl sulfon, methane sulfonic acid and sulfate as reaction products adsorbed on the exposed catalyst. Consequently, detailed photocatalytic DMS degradation pathways were proposed, starting with TiO<inf>2</inf>(h+) or •OH mediated DMS oxidation and followed by CS bond cleavage, S-oxidation and C-oxidation. Carbon and sulfur mass balances were closed for 90-105% and 98-110%, respectively. [DMS]<inf>in</inf> did not have an important effect on product distribution, but interesting trends in DMS degradation products were observed as a function of RH. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Jiang, Chungqi; A.A.H., Mohamed, Abdel Aleam Hefney; R.H., Stark, Robert H.; J.H., Yuan, James H.; K.H., Schoenbach, Karl H.
Author full names: Jiang, Chungqi (9638836900); Mohamed, Abdel Aleam Hefney (8076352900); Stark, Robert H. (7202161321); Yuan, James H. (37020315400); Schoenbach, Karl H. (35499111900)
Title: Removal of volatile organic compounds in atmospheric pressure air by means of direct current glow discharges
Affiliations: Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States; Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jiang, Chungqi, Center for Bioelectrics, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States; Mohamed, Abdel Aleam Hefney, Center for Bioelectrics, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States; Stark, Robert H., Center for Bioelectrics, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States; Yuan, James H., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States; Schoenbach, Karl H., Center for Bioelectrics, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States
Abstract: A nonthermal plasma with an electron density on the order of 1012 cm-3 and a gas temperature of 2000 K was generated in atmospheric pressure air, using a microhollow cathode discharge as plasma cathode. The plasma was sustained in a ∼1 mm3 micro reactor, by a voltage of 470 V between the plasma cathode and a planar anode, and at currents ranging from 12 to 22 mA. This direct current glow discharge has been used to study the remediation of methane and benzene, two of the most stable volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The removal fraction for 300-ppm methane in atmospheric pressure air, flowing through the 0.5-mm thick plasma layer, with a residence time of the gas in the plasma of less than 0.5 ms, was measured at 80% with an energy density of 4 kJ/L. For benzene, the remediation rate is as high as 90%, comparable to results obtained with low pressure glow discharges. The energy efficiency for benzene remediation is 0.9 g/kWh, higher than that obtained for benzene remediation in low pressure glow discharges in noble gases. However, the VOC fraction remaining was found to be limited to values of approximately 0.1 and 0.05 for methane and benzene, respectively. In addition to experimental studies, the VOC dissociation mechanism in a VOC/dry air mixture plasma was modeled using a zero-dimensional plasma chemistry code. The modeling results have shown that atomic oxygen impact reactions are the dominant dissociation reactions for VOC destruction in this kind of glow discharge. Diffusion of atomic oxygen to the dielectric wails of the reactor is assumed to cause the observed limitation in the VOC destruction rate and efficiency. © 2005 IEEE. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Products: RTO replaces catalytic oxidizers
Abstract: To eliminate the potential problems with odor and equipment breakdowns, Times Printing Co Inc replaced three older catalytic oxidizers with a new regenerative thermal oxidizer (RTO) from The CMM Group. The 20,000 scf/m RTO was designed to provide a greater VOC destruction efficiency than the previous catalytic units, while also generating savings in natural gas consumption. © 2005 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V.R., Choudhary, Vasant R.; G.M., Deshmukh, Girish M.; S.G., Pataskar, Suryakant G.
Author full names: Choudhary, Vasant R. (7102950631); Deshmukh, Girish M. (6701364659); Pataskar, Suryakant G. (6603619930)
Title: Low temperature complete combustion of dilute toluene and methyl ethyl ketone over Mn-doped ZrO2 (cubic) catalysts
Source title: Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology
Affiliations: National Chemical Laboratory India, Pune, India; Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Technological University, Lonere, India
Authors with affiliations: Choudhary, Vasant R., Division of Chemical Engineering, National Chemical Laboratory India, Pune, India; Deshmukh, Girish M., Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Technological University, Lonere, India; Pataskar, Suryakant G., Division of Chemical Engineering, National Chemical Laboratory India, Pune, India
Abstract: Combustion of dilute toluene and methyl ethyl ketone over Mn-doped ZrO<inf>2</inf> catalysts prepared using different precipitating agents, such as tetra-alkyl ammonium hydroxides and NH<inf>4</inf>OH, having Mn/Zr ratios from 0.05 to 0.67, and calcined at different temperatures has been thoroughly investigated. The Mn-doped ZrO<inf>2</inf> catalyst shows high toluene or methyl ethyl ketone combustion activity, particularly when its ZrO<inf>2</inf> is in cubic form, when its Mn/Zr ratio is close to 0.2, and when it is prepared using tetra-methyl ammonium hydroxide as a precipitating agent and calcined at 773 K. © 2005 Society of Chemical Industry. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.C., Delhoménie, Marie Caroline; M.W., Heitz, Michèle W.
Author full names: Delhoménie, Marie Caroline (6603273650); Heitz, Michèle W. (7006738900)
Title: Biofiltration of air: A review
Affiliations: Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Delhoménie, Marie Caroline, Department of Chemical Engineering, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Heitz, Michèle W., Department of Chemical Engineering, Université de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada
Abstract: In this paper we present a review of the existing air pollution control technologies (APCT), when used essentially for the elimination of volatile organic compounds (VOC). The biotechnologies referred to, bioscrubbers, biotrickling filters and biofilters, are also described. A more detailed review of biofiltration is proposed, presenting the most recent and latest developments achieved in the field of bioprocessing. In particular, the influence of the filter bed, the polluted air flowrates, the pollutants, the pressure drop, bed moisture content, temperature, nutrients, pH and the microorganisms are reviewed. Models of biofiltration are also presented. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: K., Kim, Ki-joon; J., Kim, Jo-chun; J., Kim, Jinkyu; Y., Sunwoo, Young
Title: Development of hybrid technology using E-beam and catalyst for aromatic VOCs control
Affiliations: Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea; EB Tech Co., Ltd., Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Ki-joon, Dept. of Environmental Engineering, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Jo-chun, Dept. of Environmental Engineering, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Jinkyu, EB Tech Co., Ltd., Daejeon, South Korea; Sunwoo, Young, Dept. of Environmental Engineering, Konkuk University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: A hybrid technology has been developed to control aromatic volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emission by annexing the catalyst technique with already existing electron beam (EB) technology. There is an increase in the removal efficiency and CO<inf>2</inf> conversion rate as well as a decrease in by-product formation yield. When compared to EB-ceramic hybrid under the same existing EB-catalyst conditions, EB-catalyst hybrid has shown a 10% increase in efficiency in toluene treatment at approximately 10 kGy. In the comparison study on the independent effect of EB-catalyst and catalyst itself, the removal efficiency with EB-catalyst revealed a 10% improvement in toluene treatment and an increase of 20% in styrene treatment. In addition, CO<inf>2</inf> conversion rate also improved because there was a 55% increase in the generation of CO <inf>2</inf> as well as a significant decrease in the by-products formation yield. Therefore, it is concluded that this technology will have a great effect on treating VOCs and odors. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Shijie, Liao; Y., Weiyong, Ying; F., Dingye, Fang; H., Kameyama, Hideo

Title: Kinetics of catalytic combustion in air over Pt/Al2O 3/Al catalyst
Affiliations: Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Shanghai, China; East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, China; Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shijie, Liao, Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Shanghai, China; Weiyong, Ying, ; Dingye, Fang, Department of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, China; Kameyama, Hideo, Department of Chemical Engineering, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Japan
Abstract: Catalytic combustion of toluene, propylene and CO over Pt/Al <inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> /Al catalyst was investigated. Strong inhibition effects are observed when the mixture of toluene, propylene and CO is oxidized. A reaction mechanism of catalytic combustion over Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O/Al is proposed. The results from kinetic models are in good agreement with the experimental data. © Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Kim, Hyun-Ha; A., Ogata, Atsushi; S., Futamura, Shigeru
Author full names: Kim, Hyun-Ha (35737438500); Ogata, Atsushi (56448190500); Futamura, Shigeru (7006558904)
Title: Atmospheric plasma-driven catalysis for the low temperature decomposition of dilute aromatic compounds
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Hyun-Ha, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Ogata, Atsushi, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Futamura, Shigeru, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The decomposition of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) - six aromatic compounds of benzene derivatives and formic acid - was investigated using a plasma-driven catalysis (PDC) system at atmospheric pressure. In the PDC reactor, the decomposition efficiency of VOCs was mostly determined by the specific input energy (SIE) and insensitivity to the gas hourly space velocity from 11000 to 55 000h-1. Formic acid (HCOOH) was formed as a common intermediate from the decomposition of the tested aromatic compounds. Formic acid was also found to be an important intermediate for CO<inf>2</inf> formation. Except for styrene, all the tested VOCs indicated zero-order kinetics, which confirm the dominant role of the catalytic reaction in the decomposition of VOCs using the PDC reactor. A simple kinetic model represents well the observed zero-order kinetics with respect to the SIE. Unlike conventional plasma reactors, no correlation between the ionization potential and the decomposition was found with the PDC reactor. Continuous operation tests indicated stable performance without deterioration of catalytic activity over 150h. © 2005 IOP Publishing Ltd. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Kim, Hyun-Ha; S., Oh, Seung-min; A., Ogata, Atsushi; S., Futamura, Shigeru
Author full names: Kim, Hyun-Ha (35737438500); Oh, Seung-min (57198898387); Ogata, Atsushi (56448190500); Futamura, Shigeru (7006558904)
Title: Decomposition of gas-phase benzene using plasma-driven catalyst (PDC) reactor packed with Ag/TiO2 catalyst
Affiliations: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Hyun-Ha, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Oh, Seung-min, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Ogata, Atsushi, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Futamura, Shigeru, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes the decomposition of gas-phase benzene using a plasma-driven catalyst (PDC) reactor packed with 1.0 wt.% Ag/TiO<inf>2</inf> catalysts. The decomposition of benzene preferentially produced CO<inf>2</inf> and CO, and formic acid as minor one. Carbon balance based on these products was satisfactory at around 100%. For the concentration lower than 110 ppm, the PDC reactor successfully decomposed benzene with specific input energy of around 130 J/l, where the formation of nitrogen oxides was small. The plasma-induced catalytic activity appeared only during plasma application and disappeared as the plasma was turned off. Thermal catalysis showed that temperature was not an important parameter in the decomposition of benzene using the PDC reactor. Comparison of the effects of dilution gases (Ar, N<inf>2</inf>) on the benzene decomposition revealed that the contribution of UV light from the plasma to the activation of Ag/TiO<inf>2</inf> catalyst was negligible. The contribution of catalytic reaction became dominant as increasing specific input energy. The removed amount of benzene showed zero-order to the initial concentration of benzene and determined mostly by specific input energy to the PDC reactor. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Kim, Hyoung-sik; T., Kim, Tae-won; H., Koh, Hyoung-lim; S., Lee, Seo-ho; B., Min, Byoungryul
Author full names: Kim, Hyoung-sik (56981386400); Kim, Tae-won (55696540600); Koh, Hyoung-lim (7202300907); Lee, Seo-ho (55870233700); Min, Byoungryul (7202932078)
Title: Complete benzene oxidation over Pt-Pd bimental catalyst supported on γ-alumina: Influence of Pt-Pd ratio on the catalytic activity
Affiliations: Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Hanseo University, Seosan, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Hyoung-sik, Department of Chemical Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Tae-won, Department of Chemical Engineering, Hanseo University, Seosan, South Korea; Koh, Hyoung-lim, ; Lee, Seo-ho, Department of Chemical Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea; Min, Byoungryul, Department of Chemical Engineering, Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Pt-Pd bimetal catalysts were prepared in order to develop and investigate catalysts with excellent activity and stability for benzene destruction. In the reaction results, the addition of Pt to Pd/γ -Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalyst brought about the increase of catalytic activity. Moreover, it was effective in preventing the deactivation of the catalysts in benzene combustion. The addition of some amount of Pt made Pd particles available for better benzene combustion. On the contrary, the addition of Pt beyond a certain amount decreases activity because of the Pd active sites overlapped with the Pt active sites. The activity of the catalysts is related to oxidation state of metal, Pd/Al ratio and particle size on γ -Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>. These effects of Pt addition to Pd catalysts were studied by XPS, XRD, and TEM analyses. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: The legislative requirements concerning removal of gas emissions containing halogenated organic compounds from environment led to intensification of research towards catalytic incineration of these pollutants. An analysis of the research in the field conducted in order to study the behavior of transitional metal oxides is carried out including the main factors that influence the oxidation reaction of organic compounds such as: temperature, the amount of catalytic active component, the type of catalytic system, the presence of water vapors. The catalytic system as V<inf>2</inf>O<inf>5</inf>/TiO<inf>2</inf> as well as the bimetallic catalytic systems of V<inf>2</inf>O<inf>5</inf>-WO<inf>3</inf>/TiO<inf>2</inf> type, specific for gas de-nox through catalytic reduction (SCR-DeNO<inf>x</inf>) exhibit efficiencies in the process of catalytic conversion of chlorinated aromatic compounds VOC-Cl. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
