Authors: E., Kullavanijaya, Emwajee; N.W., Cant, Noel W.; D.L., Trimm, David L.
Author full names: Kullavanijaya, Emwajee (57193785336); Cant, Noel W. (7006485397); Trimm, David L. (7006689199)
Title: The treatment of binary VOC mixtures by adsorption and oxidation using activated carbon and a palladium catalyst
Source title: Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology
Affiliations: UNSW Sydney, Sydney, Australia; Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Kullavanijaya, Emwajee, School of Chemical Engineering and Industrial Chemistry, UNSW Sydney, Sydney, Australia; Cant, Noel W., School of Chemical Engineering and Industrial Chemistry, UNSW Sydney, Sydney, Australia, Department of Chemistry, Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia; Trimm, David L., School of Chemical Engineering and Industrial Chemistry, UNSW Sydney, Sydney, Australia
Abstract: The adsorption of binary thiophene-containing mixtures on activated carbon and their subsequent desorption and oxidation over a Pd/CeO<inf>2</inf>/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalyst has been studied as a model for the treatment of dilute VOC streams by intermittent accumulation and combustion. When adsorbed together, cyclohexene and thiophene have similar breakthrough times with little tendency for one to displace the other. However the adsorption of thiophene continues beyond that of diethylamine in mixtures while thiophene is itself displaced by methylmethacrylate. Oxidation of the binary mixtures is controlled by that of thiophene which requires temperatures somewhat above 300°C for complete removal. Combustion of the other VOCs proceeds in parallel with thiophene although they react at much lower temperatures when alone. Both components of the mixtures can be removed by a system in which the VOCs are accumulated on carbon and then undergo temperature programmed desorption in air onto Pd/CeO<inf>2</inf>/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> held at 350°C. However it is not possible to operate with the adsorbent and catalyst together since desorption then occurs before the catalyst reaches working temperature. © 2002 Society of Chemical Industry. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.L., Daniels, Stacy L.
Author full names: Daniels, Stacy L. (59829766100)
Title: "On the ionization of air for removal of noxious effluvia" (air ionization of indoor environments for control of volatile and particulate contaminants with nonthermal plasmas generated by dielectric-barrier discharge)
Affiliations: Quality Air of Midland, Inc., Midland Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Daniels, Stacy L., Quality Air of Midland, Inc., Midland Park, United States
Abstract: Recent developments in the application of controllable air ionization processes that apply dielectric-barrier discharge devices to generate nonthermal plasmas have led to applications for chemical and biological decontamination in indoor air environments. These include significant reductions in airborne microbials, neutralization of odors, and reductions of specific volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Removal of very fine particulates (PM<inf>x</inf>) is also is enhanced by air ionization. The process of air ionization involves the electronically induced formation of small air ions, including reactive oxygen species, such as superoxide O<inf>2.</inf>-, the diatomic oxygen radical anion, which react rapidly with airborne VOC and PM<inf>x</inf>. The physics and chemistry of air ionization, and its utility for contributing to significant improvements in indoor air quality are discussed. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: A series of γ-alumina- and silica-supported oxides as Mn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, CO<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> and Sm-Mn, Sm-Co bimetallic combinations was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of the supports with aqueous solutions containing the nitrates of the metals and citric acid. The results obtained with these catalysts in the acetone complete oxidation reaction have shown a predominant effect of the support and the transition metal nature. The silica-supported oxides exhibited a bulk-like behaviour with relatively little difference between the Mn and Co catalysts. In contrast, when supported on alumina the performance of the Mn catalysts was remarkably better than that of the Co-based ones. In this case, whereas the Sm-Mn catalysts maintained a rather good performance relative to that of Mn/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, the temperatures required for acetone combustion over the Sm-Co catalysts were significantly lower than the ones over Co/Al<inf>2</inf>O. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Burgos, Nerea; M., Paulis, María; M.M., Antxustegi, M. M.; M., Montes, Mario
Author full names: Burgos, Nerea (59800375000); Paulis, María (57189506111); Antxustegi, M. M. (7801528866); Montes, Mario (7102925861)
Title: Deep oxidation of VOC mixtures with platinum supported on Al2O3/Al monoliths
Affiliations: Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Burgos, Nerea, Department of Applied Chemistry, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Paulis, María, Department of Applied Chemistry, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Antxustegi, M. M., Department of Applied Chemistry, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Montes, Mario, Department of Applied Chemistry, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain
Abstract: Pt impregnated metallic monoliths prepared from aluminium foils were tested to study their catalytic activity in complete oxidation of volatile organic compound (VOC) mixtures. The VOCs oxidised were 2-propanol, toluene, methyl ethyl ketone (MEK), acetone and their mixtures. Complete oxidation was obtained in all cases except for the case of 2-propanol, where acetone was found as an oxidation intermediate. Even if the adsorption of the VOC on the Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> is governed by its polarity, the reactivity is mainly affected by the competition of the oxygen atoms chemisorbed on the Pt particles. © 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: R., Spinicci, Roberto; A., Tofanari, Anna; M., Faticanti, Marco; I., Pettiti, Ida; P., Porta, Piero
Author full names: Spinicci, Roberto (7003658409); Tofanari, Anna (6603330095); Faticanti, Marco (6602190239); Pettiti, Ida (56627508700); Porta, Piero (7005731490)
Title: Hexane total oxidation on LaMO3 (M = Mn, Co, Fe) perovskite-type oxides
Source title: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Sapienza Università di Roma, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Spinicci, Roberto, Dipartimento di Energetica, Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Tofanari, Anna, Dipartimento di Energetica, Università degli Studi di Firenze, Florence, Italy; Faticanti, Marco, Dipartimento di Chimica, Sapienza Università di Roma, Rome, Italy; Pettiti, Ida, Dipartimento di Chimica, Sapienza Università di Roma, Rome, Italy; Porta, Piero, Dipartimento di Chimica, Sapienza Università di Roma, Rome, Italy
Abstract: LaMO<inf>3</inf> (M = Mn, Fe, Co) perovskites were prepared by calcining the citrate precursors at 800°C for 5 h. PdO 3%/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, a largely used combustion catalyst, was also studied for comparison. The catalytic behavior was examined in the hexane total oxidation. The following activity scale was found: LaFeO<inf>3</inf> > LaCoO<inf>3</inf> > LaMnO<inf>3</inf>. >3% PdO/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, the three perovskites activating the C-H bond cleavage of hexane better than PdO/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>. At temperature around 250-300°C mobile surface oxygen species are involved in the oxidation process, whereas at T > 300°C oxygen mobile species are no more present and so, particularly for LaCoO<inf>3</inf> and PdO/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, the activation mechanism becomes more energetic. The activity values were compared with those obtained from the total oxidation of methane. © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. © 2007 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G., Sinquin, Gilles; C., Petit, Corinne; J.P., Hindermann, Jean Paul; A.A., Kiennemann, Alain A.
Author full names: Sinquin, Gilles (6602590947); Petit, Corinne (7202973260); Hindermann, Jean Paul (57210406538); Kiennemann, Alain A. (7004564499)
Title: Study of the formation of LaMO3 (M = Co, Mn) perovskites by propionates precursors: Application to the catalytic destruction of chlorinated VOCs
Affiliations: Institut de Chimie et Procédés pour l'Energie, l'Environnement et la Santé (ICPEES), Strasbourg, France
Authors with affiliations: Sinquin, Gilles, Polymères et Matériaux, Institut de Chimie et Procédés pour l'Energie, l'Environnement et la Santé (ICPEES), Strasbourg, France; Petit, Corinne, Polymères et Matériaux, Institut de Chimie et Procédés pour l'Energie, l'Environnement et la Santé (ICPEES), Strasbourg, France; Hindermann, Jean Paul, Polymères et Matériaux, Institut de Chimie et Procédés pour l'Energie, l'Environnement et la Santé (ICPEES), Strasbourg, France; Kiennemann, Alain A., Polymères et Matériaux, Institut de Chimie et Procédés pour l'Energie, l'Environnement et la Santé (ICPEES), Strasbourg, France
Abstract: LaMO<inf>3</inf> (M = Co, Mn) have been obtained by a sol-gel-like method with propionic acid as solvent. The influence of the nature of the metallic source (metal, nitrate or chloride) on the gel formation has been studied by fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and thermogravimetric analysis ATD-ATG. After calcination, the obtained perovskites have been characterised by X-ray diffraction (XRD), FTIR, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) in order to investigate the influence of the preparation parameters on the final product. These mixed oxides have been used as catalyst for the destruction of chlorinated compounds. For each compound, the perovskite structure of LaCoO<inf>3</inf> decomposes in the same manner as LaOCl and Co<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf>. Under the same test conditions, the perovskite with Mn is not altered. The stability of the structure has been explained by the formation of an oxygen overstoichiometric phase (LaMnO<inf>3+δ</inf>) which is thermodynamically more resistant to chlorination than the stoichiometric LaMnO<inf>3</inf>. The catalytic behaviour of these oxides shows that two ways (hydrolysis and oxidation) are involved in the destruction of chlorinated hydrocarbons. The first one requires acidic sites and is less sensitive to the modification of the catalyst surface induced by chlorine than the second one requiring metallic oxidation sites. © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. © 2007 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G.C., Centi, Gabriele C.

Title: Supported palladium catalysts in environmental catalytic technologies for gaseous emissions
Source title: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Messina, Messina, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Centi, Gabriele C., Department of Industrial Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Università degli Studi di Messina, Messina, Italy
Abstract: Palladium is the active component in several catalytic formulations for environmental technologies, due to its superior performances in the conversion of some hydrocarbons (for example, methane) and halocarbons, and the thermal stability and low volatility of Pd species. The properties and reactivity of Pd-based catalysts in the conversion of methane catalytic combustion for gas turbine applications, reduction of greenhouse gas (methane, N<inf>2</inf>O) emissions, hydrodehalogenation and oxidative destruction of halocarbons and their applications in the elimination of other pollutants from gaseous emissions are reviewed, with emphasis on the structure-activity relationships, reaction mechanism and sensitivity to poisoning. © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.F., Garetto, Teresita F.; C.R., Apesteguía, C. R.
Author full names: Garetto, Teresita F. (6601983496); Apesteguía, C. R. (7003683327)
Title: Structure sensitivity and in situ activation of benzene combustion on Pt/Al2O3 catalysts
Affiliations: Instituto de Investigaciones en Catálisis y Petroquímica, Santa Fe, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Garetto, Teresita F., Instituto de Investigaciones en Catálisis y Petroquímica, Santa Fe, Argentina; Apesteguía, C. R., Instituto de Investigaciones en Catálisis y Petroquímica, Santa Fe, Argentina
Abstract: The structure sensitivity and in situ activation of benzene combustion on Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalysts of different platinum and chlorine loadings were studied. The catalyst activities were evaluated through both conversion versus temperature (light-off curves) and conversion versus time catalytic tests. The light-off curves shifted to lower temperature with increasing Pt particle size, thereby suggesting that benzene combustion is a structure sensitive reaction. Kinetically-controlled catalytic tests confirmed that benzene oxidation turnover rates are preferentially promoted by larger Pt crystallites. Kinetic studies showed that the reaction orders and the apparent activation energy are not changed by changing the metallic dispersion. Results are explained by considering that benzene oxidation proceeds via a Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism which involves the rapid and strong adsorption of benzene on metallic platinum and assumes that the rate constant of oxygen adsorption is very low compared to the rate constant of the surface reaction. The number of Pt-O bonds of lower binding energy, i.e. the site density of more reactive surface oxygen, increases on larger Pt particles. Low-conversion catalytic tests performed at constant temperature showed that on well,dispersed Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalysts the benzene conversion increases with time, irrespective of the chlorine content on the sample. TEM examination and hydrogen chemisorption measurements suggested that the activity increase parallels a concomitant increase in the platinum particle size. In contrast, sintered samples (platinum dispersions lower than 10%) did not exhibit initial activation periods. It is proposed that the initial in situ activation of well-dispersed Pt catalysts is caused by the sintering of the metallic phase. Hot-spots on the metallic particles together with the presence of gaseous water cause the formation of larger Pt crystallites, even at mild reaction conditions. As a result, the benzene conversion increases with time until the formation of larger steady state Pt particles is completed. © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Deep oxidation kinetics of trieline over LaFeO3 perovskite catalyst
Affiliations: Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy
Authors with affiliations: de Paoli, A., Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy; Barresi, Antonello A., Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy
Abstract: The catalytic activity of LaFeO<inf>3</inf> perovskite for the gas-phase destruction of chlorinated compounds was investigated; 1,1,2-trichloroethylene in dry and moistened air was selected as the test compound. The catalyst showed good activity and satisfactory stability for prolonged time on stream (>200 h). Experimental data evidenced inhibition effects; a rate equation was proposed. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Jiang, Chungqi; R.H., Stark, Robert H.; K.H., Schoenbach, Karl H.
Author full names: Jiang, Chungqi (9638836900); Stark, Robert H. (7202161321); Schoenbach, Karl H. (35499111900)
Title: Benzene destruction in direct current and pulse-superimposed atmospheric pressure air glow discharges
Affiliations: Batten College of Engineering & Technology, Norfolk, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jiang, Chungqi, Batten College of Engineering & Technology, Norfolk, United States; Stark, Robert H., Batten College of Engineering & Technology, Norfolk, United States; Schoenbach, Karl H., Batten College of Engineering & Technology, Norfolk, United States
Abstract: Benzene, a carcinogenic volatile organic compound, is commonly used as a solvent. We have explored the use of a high pressure glow discharge in a near atmospheric and atmospheric pressure benzene/air mixture for benzene remediation. By using a micro-hollow cathode discharge (MHCD) as an electron source to lower or eliminate the cathode fall voltage, a glow discharge could be operated either in a dc mode [1] or in a pulse-superimposed mode [2] at atmospheric pressure air. A higher than 90% destruction rate has been obtained by flowing a benzene/dry air mixture through the dc glow discharge. For a pressure of 720 torr, superimposed electric pulses caused an increase in destruction of benzene, however, for 760 torr, the remediation effect was reversed. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P., Dégé, Philippe; L., Pinard, Ludovic; P., Magnoux, Patrick; M.R., Guisnet, Michael R.
Author full names: Dégé, Philippe (6506751913); Pinard, Ludovic (6701822090); Magnoux, Patrick (7007007287); Guisnet, Michael R. (23483646800)
Title: Catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Oxidation of o-xylene over Pd and Pt/HFAU catalysts
Source title: Comptes Rendus de l'Academie des Sciences - Series IIc: Chemistry
Affiliations: LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France
Authors with affiliations: Dégé, Philippe, LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France; Pinard, Ludovic, LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France; Magnoux, Patrick, LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France; Guisnet, Michael R., LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France
Abstract: The transformation of o-xylene in low concentration (1700ppmv) into air was investigated over Pd and Pt/HFAU catalysts (framework Si/Al ratio equal to 17 and 100). Whatever the catalyst, o-xylene oxidation into CO<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O is accompanied by the retention within the zeolite pores of heavy compounds ('coke'). The relative significance of these reactions depends on the operating conditions (temperature, time-on-stream) and on the catalyst characteristics (Pd or Pt, Si/Al ratio). Over Pt and Pd/HFAU(17), time-on-stream has a positive effect on the xylene oxidation apparently related to the reducibility of Pd and Pt species during the reaction. The higher activity of Pt/HFAU catalysts can be attributed to its greater number of active species (especially Pt0). Those active species can be more rapidly formed than Pd0 by auto reduction during the calcination of Pt precursor. Whatever the metal, the higher the Si/Al ratio of the support, the faster the xylene oxidation and the lower the coke formation. This can be related to the higher proportion of reduced species (Pd0 and Pt0) formed on the more dealuminated catalyst but also to the hydrophobicity of the support. Indeed, the hydrophobicity of the zeolite play a positive role in the oxidation activity in presence of steam; the higher the Si/Al ratio of the zeolite, the faster the o-xylene oxidation. Thus a catalyst with a low platinum content supported on a hydrophobic zeolite (0.10Pt/HFAU(100)) allows to oxidising totally o-xylene at 210°C in presence of steam. © 2001 Académie des sciences / Éditions scientifiques et médicales Elsevier SAS. © 2005 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: B., Zygmunt, Bogdan; A., Jastrzȩbska, Anna; J., Namiesnik, Jacek
Author full names: Zygmunt, Bogdan (56210213200); Jastrzȩbska, Anna (6508343229); Namiesnik, Jacek (7007063399)
Title: Solid phase microextraction - A convenient tool for the determination of organic pollutants in environmental matrices
Affiliations: Gdańsk University of Technology, Gdansk, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Zygmunt, Bogdan, ; Jastrzȩbska, Anna, ; Namiesnik, Jacek, Department of Analytical Chemistry, Gdańsk University of Technology, Gdansk, Poland
Abstract: This article reviews the application of solid phase microextraction (SPME) for determination of organic pollutants in gaseous, liquid, and solid environmental samples. Practical aspects of direct and headspace SPME sampling and combination of SPME with other techniques of sample preparation are discussed. The application range can be widened by derivatizing analytes. SPME can combined with other related techniques of sample preparation. © 2001 by CRC Press LLC. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Myslinski, Thomas; S., Basu, Somnath; S.F., Rhode, Steven F.; G.T., Hunt, Gary T.; K.A., Shilinsky, Kenneth A.
Author full names: Myslinski, Thomas (7801654974); Basu, Somnath (7403656657); Rhode, Steven F. (57221254383); Hunt, Gary T. (7202673811); Shilinsky, Kenneth A. (6507826932)
Title: Fate of air toxics and VOCs in the odor control scrubbers at the Deer Island Treatment Plant
Affiliations: Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, Boston, United States; Parsons Engineering Science Inc, Pasadena, United States; TRC Environmental Corporation, Lowell, United States; Stone & Webster Engineering Corp, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Myslinski, Thomas, Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, Boston, United States, Parsons Engineering Science Inc, Pasadena, United States; Basu, Somnath, Stone & Webster Engineering Corp, Boston, United States; Rhode, Steven F., Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, Boston, United States, Parsons Engineering Science Inc, Pasadena, United States; Hunt, Gary T., TRC Environmental Corporation, Lowell, United States; Shilinsky, Kenneth A., Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, Boston, United States, Parsons Engineering Science Inc, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: Process off-gases at the Deer Island wastewater treatment plant in Boston are collected and treated and its stack emissions regulated for selected gases including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), which are monitored as nonmethane hydrocarbons (NMHC). The air treatment processes of countercurrent wet oxidation scrubbing and granulated activated carbon adsorption are available for emissions control at Deer Island. In addition, since the wastewater treatment process of biochemical oxidation is fully enclosed at the site, microbial destruction of VOCs is an intrinsic treatment process for organic gases. Surveyed results of wastewater research literature indicate that the use of scrubbers for the removal of VOCs is controversial, as the fate of volatile hydrocarbon molecules across odor control scrubbers is complex and not fully understood. Continuous emission monitoring tests across the Deer Island scrubbers have consistently shown a VOC removal efficiency in excess of 50%. The fate of the scrubber inlet VOCs at Deer Island was researched as part of a plant-wide, on-going VOC study. Removal efficiencies across the pure oxygen bioreactors were also investigated. Preliminary results of this study indicate chemical reactions involving VOCs in odor control scrubbers partially oxidize and chlorinate derivatives possibly destroying a fraction of the compounds by complete oxidation. In addition, VOC reduction across the enclosed aerobic bioreactors was found to be significant. This article represents the opinions and (legal) conclusions of the authors and not necessarily those of the MWRA. © 2005 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: T.F., Garetto, Teresita F.; C.R., Apesteguía, C. R.
Author full names: Garetto, Teresita F. (6601983496); Apesteguía, C. R. (7003683327)
Title: Oxidative catalytic removal of hydrocarbons over Pt/Al2O3 catalysts
Affiliations: Instituto de Investigaciones en Catálisis y Petroquímica, Santa Fe, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Garetto, Teresita F., Instituto de Investigaciones en Catálisis y Petroquímica, Santa Fe, Argentina; Apesteguía, C. R., Instituto de Investigaciones en Catálisis y Petroquímica, Santa Fe, Argentina
Abstract: The reaction kinetics, structure sensitivity, and in situ activation of cyclopentane and methane combustions were studied on Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalysts of different platinum and chlorine loadings. The catalyst activities were evaluated through both conversion vs. temperature (light-off curves) and conversion vs. time catalytic tests. Cyclopentane oxidation turnover rates (TOF) increased dramatically with increasing Pt crystallite size while TOF values for methane oxidation increased only three times by diminishing the Pt dispersion from 65 to 15%. The reaction orders in oxygen were one (cyclopentane) and zero (CH<inf>4</inf>). For both reactions, the orders and activation energies did not change by changing the Pt dispersion. Results are interpreted in basis of two different reaction mechanisms over the metallic Pt active sites. Cyclopentane oxidation proceeds via a surface redox mechanism, being the dissociative adsorption of oxygen the rate-determining step. The observed turnover rate increase with increasing Pt particle size reflects an increase in the density of reactive Pt-O species resulting from higher Pt oxidation rates. The methane oxidation mechanism is interpreted in terms of Mars-van Kravelen reduction-oxidation pathways which include the abstraction of the first hydrogen on the adsorbed methane molecule as the rate-determining step. Low-conversion catalytic tests performed at constant temperature showed that on well-dispersed Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalysts the cyclopentane conversion increases with time on stream, while the methane activity decreases. Activating induction periods during the oxidation of cyclopentane are related to the sintering of the metallic phase in reaction conditions. Hot-spots on the metallic particles together with the presence of gaseous water cause the formation of larger, more reactive, Pt crystallites, even at mild reaction conditions. The activation phenomenon ab initio of the reaction is not verified for methane oxidation on Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalysts. The different structure sensitivity of the slowest steps in the reaction-oxidation mechanisms explains the existence of induction periods on well-dispersed Pt catalysts only for cyclopentane oxidation. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Thermal oxidizers meet MACT requirements for VOC control
Abstract: Adwest Technologies, Inc's retox regenerative thermal oxidizers (RTO) have destruction efficiencies of ≤ 99% for VOC and odors, while recovering 95% of primary heat. These units can accommodate throughputs of 1000-70,000 cu ft/min, and can operate without fuel at volatile loadings of 3%. The system has programmable logic controls and remote diagnostics for rapid startup. It is shop-assembled, skid-mounted, and uses a natural gas burner. These units have been chosen as a MACT for VOC and odor compliance. Specialized designs are available for halogenated chemical-vapor processes and acid-gas scrubbers. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Gervasini, Antonella; V., Ragaini, Vittorio
Author full names: Gervasini, Antonella (7006668683); Ragaini, Vittorio (6701829637)
Title: Catalytic technology assisted with ionization/ozonization phase for the abatement of volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Milano, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Gervasini, Antonella, Dipto. Chim. Fis. ed Elettrochimica, Università degli Studi di Milano, Milan, Italy; Ragaini, Vittorio, Dipto. Chim. Fis. ed Elettrochimica, Università degli Studi di Milano, Milan, Italy
Abstract: The catalytic combustion process of air-mixtures containing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) associated with an ionization/ozonization reactor (IOCC technique, ionization-ozonization-catalytic-combustion) has been utilized for the abatement of two very toxic industrial VOCs: acrylonitrile (ACN) and vinyl chloride (VCM). The pre-catalytic effects (electric discharge plus the action of ozone), the conventional and IOCC combustion tests were studied. Two different catalysts were used: oxide catalyst, copper-chromite (Cu-Cr), and Pt metal catalyst (0.5 wt.% Pt/γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>). The abatement of ACN was markedly influenced by the pre-catalytic effects. Starting from 3 kV, an increasing abatement of ACN was observed with the voltage applied to the ionization reactor at any initial ACN concentration (500-1500 ppm). The ACN catalytic combustion, performed by the IOCC technique, led to 91 and 98% yield of CO<inf>2</inf> on Cu-Cr and Pt catalysts, respectively, at 260°C. Complete absence of hazardous intermediates, such as hydrogen cyanide, was observed. The Cu-Cr catalyst, at 300°C, was able to abate 57 and 23% of VCM at 10 000 and 20 000 h-1, respectively. IOCC combustion led to improved conversion. At 200°C and 3300 h-1, 98% and only 49% of VCM abatement operating according to IOCC and classical combustion was obtained, respectively. The IOCC combustion runs, performed at different initial VCM concentrations (585 and 1170 ppm), indicated a superior abatement when low VCM concentration was fed, at a given catalyst temperature and contact time. This indicated a marked influence of the pre-catalytic effects on the abatement. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P., Dégé, Philippe; L., Pinard, Ludovic; P., Magnoux, Patrick; M.R., Guisnet, Michael R.

Title: Catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds. II. Influence of the physicochemical characteristics of Pd/HFAU catalysts on the oxidation of o-xylene
Affiliations: LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France
Authors with affiliations: Dégé, Philippe, LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France; Pinard, Ludovic, LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France; Magnoux, Patrick, LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France; Guisnet, Michael R., LACCO Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Poitiers, France
Abstract: The transformation of o-xylene in low concentration (1700 ppmv) in air was investigated over a series of Pd/HFAU catalysts differing in their Pd content (from 0 to 0.8 wt.%) and their framework Si/Al ratio (4, 17 and 100). With all catalysts, o-xylene oxidation into CO<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O is accompanied by the retention within the zeolite pores of heavy products of xylene transformation ('coke'). The relative significance of these reactions depends on the operating conditions (temperature, time-on-stream) and on the catalyst characteristics. The higher the reaction temperature, the faster the oxidation of xylene and the lower the coke formation. The time-on-stream has a positive effect on oxidation apparently related to the reducibility of Pd species and a negative one on coking due to the self deactivation of this reaction. For a given zeolite support, the rate of o-xylene oxidation increases with palladium content. On the other hand, the higher the Si/Al ratio of the zeolite, the lower the number of acid sites n<inf>A</inf>, the slower the coke formation and the faster the o-xylene oxidation, this latter effect being related to a negative effect of acidity on Pd reducibility.; The transformation of o-xylene in low concentration (1700 ppmv) in air was investigated over a series of Pd/HFAU catalysts differing in their Pd content (from 0 to 0.8 wt.%) and their framework Si/Al ratio (4, 17 and 100). With all catalysts, o-xylene oxidation into CO<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O is accompanied by the retention within the zeolite pores of heavy products of xylene transformation ('coke'). The relative significance of these reactions depends on the operating conditions (temperature, time-on-stream) and on the catalyst characteristics. The higher the reaction temperature, the faster the oxidation of xylene and the lower the coke formation. The time-on-stream has a positive effect on oxidation apparently related to the reducibility of Pd species and a negative one on coking due to the self deactivation of this reaction. For a given zeolite support, the rate of o-xylene oxidation increases with palladium content. On the other hand, the higher the Si/Al ratio of the zeolite, the lower the number of acid sites n(A), the slower the coke formation and the faster the o-xylene oxidation, this latter effect being related to a negative effect of acidity on Pd reducibility. Authors: A., Musialik-Piotrowska, Anna; K., Syczewska, Krystyna
Author full names: Musialik-Piotrowska, Anna (6603836898); Syczewska, Krystyna (6602215270)
Title: Combustion of volatile organic compounds in two-component mixtures over monolithic perovskite catalysts
Affiliations: Politechnika Wrocławska, Wroclaw, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Musialik-Piotrowska, Anna, Ul. W., Politechnika Wrocławska, Wroclaw, Poland; Syczewska, Krystyna, Ul. W., Politechnika Wrocławska, Wroclaw, Poland
Abstract: Activity of monolithic perovskite catalysts in oxidation of selected hydrocarbons and oxy-derivatives, oxidized individually and in two-component mixtures, as well as the reaction selectivity were investigated. One bulk perovskite (LaMn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>) catalyst and two catalysts based on LaMn<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> with addition of silver (25 at.%) coated on cordierite support were prepared for the study. The efficiency of oxy-derivatives oxidation was higher than that of hydrocarbon oxidation, but some by-products (first of all aldehydes) were detected in the flue gases. Addition of silver to the active phase improved catalyst activity and selectivity to CO<inf>2</inf> and water. The 'mixture effect' on cataly activity and selectivity depended on composition of the reaction mixture and the catalyst used. The presence of oxy-derivative in the reaction mixture inhibited oxidation of hydrocarbons. Toluene inhibited the process of oxy-derivatives conversion and increased the concentration of incomplete oxidation products. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F., Benoît-Marquié, Florence; U., Wilkenhöner, Uwe; V., Simon, Valérie; A.M., Braun, André M.; E., Oliveros, Esther; M.T., Maurette, Marie Thérèse
Author full names: Benoît-Marquié, Florence (6506072981); Wilkenhöner, Uwe (57496421400); Simon, Valérie (7103308338); Braun, André M. (7201571208); Oliveros, Esther (7003712517); Maurette, Marie Thérèse (24432492600)
Title: VOC photodegradation at the gas-solid interface of a TiO2 photocatalyst: Part I: 1-butanol and 1-butylamine
Source title: Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology A: Chemistry
Affiliations: Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France; Toulouse INP-ENSIACET, Toulouse, France; Karlsruher Institut für Technologie, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Benoît-Marquié, Florence, Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France; Wilkenhöner, Uwe, Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France; Simon, Valérie, Toulouse INP-ENSIACET, Toulouse, France; Braun, André M., Lehrstuhl für Umweltmesstechnik, Karlsruher Institut für Technologie, Karlsruhe, Germany; Oliveros, Esther, Lehrstuhl für Umweltmesstechnik, Karlsruher Institut für Technologie, Karlsruhe, Germany; Maurette, Marie Thérèse, Laboratoire des Interactions Moléculaires et Réactivité Chimique et Photochimique (IMRCP), Toulouse, France
Abstract: The gas-solid heterogeneous photocatalytic oxidation of 1-butanol and 1-butylamine in air was investigated using supported TiO<inf>2</inf> as a catalyst. The supported catalyst was prepared using a sol-gel method and irradiated employing two different light sources, a medium pressure mercury lamp or a xenon-chloride excimer lamp. The experimental set-up was especially designed for generating a gas stream containing stable and defined concentrations of the model pollutants. The gas stream at the reactor exit was analyzed on line by gas chromatography and the structures of the intermediates were established by gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry. Six major intermediates (butanal, butanoic acid, 1-propanol, propanal, ethanol and ethanal) were identified in the case of the photocatalytic degradation of 1-butanol. 1-Butylamine was less efficiently adsorbed on the catalyst and its degradation was slower. Three intermediates could be identified in this case (N-butylidene-1-butylamine, N-ethylidene-1-butylamine and N-butylformamide). Based on these results, a degradation mechanism is proposed for both compounds. Mineralization could be achieved under various conditions of concentrations and flow rates and was confirmed by infrared spectroscopy. © 2000 Elsevier Science S.A. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 1-butanol; 1-butylamine; Excimer Lamp; Gas Phase; Photocatalytic Degradation; Tio2

Authors: J.R., González-Velasco, Juan Ramón; A., Aranzábal, Asier; R., López-Fonseca, Rubén; R., Ferret, Raquel; J.A., González-Marcos, José Antonio
Author full names: González-Velasco, Juan Ramón (7006777854); Aranzábal, Asier (6701708929); López-Fonseca, Rubén (56253589200); Ferret, Raquel (6505978900); González-Marcos, José Antonio (56230792400)
Title: Enhancement of the catalytic oxidation of hydrogen-lean chlorinated VOCs in the presence of hydrogen-supplying compounds
Affiliations: Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain
Authors with affiliations: González-Velasco, Juan Ramón, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Aranzábal, Asier, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; López-Fonseca, Rubén, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; Ferret, Raquel, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain; González-Marcos, José Antonio, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Leioa, Spain
Abstract: The complete catalytic oxidation of trichloroethylene (TCE) over alumina-supported noble metal catalysts (Pt and Pd) and in the presence of hydrogen-rich compounds, i.e. water, hexane and toluene was evaluated. Experiments were performed at conditions of lean TCE concentration (around 1000 ppm) in air, between 250 and 550°C in a conventional fixed-bed reactor. Hexane and toluene were added to the feedstream in a concentration of around 1000 ppm and water concentration varied from 1000 to 15000 ppm. TCE oxidation occurred faster in the presence of hexane and toluene over both catalysts. Over palladium catalysts, water did not alter catalytic activity, whereas over platinum catalysts water enhanced TCE oxidation at low temperatures (<400°C) but inhibited it at higher temperatures (>400°C). Selectivity to HCl was much improved by feeding water as a hydrogen-supplying reactant; 7500 ppm of water enhanced HCl outputs from 39.4 to 78.0% with Pd, and from 37.5 to 58.9% with Pt. Selectivities to C<inf>2</inf>Cl<inf>4</inf>, formed by chlorination of the feed, and Cl<inf>2</inf> were greatly reduced. On the other hand water promoted complete oxidation of TCE to CO<inf>2</inf>, and thus reduced selectivity to CO. In the presence of hexane and toluene, formation of HCl was also enhanced. Hexane showed higher inhibition ability than toluene over both catalysts for the C<inf>2</inf>Cl<inf>4</inf> and Cl<inf>2</inf> formation. Unlike in the presence of water, selectivity to CO increased, as a consequence of partial oxidation of both hydrocarbons.; The complete catalytic oxidation of trichloroethylene (TCE) over alumina-supported noble metal catalysts (Pt and Pd) and in the presence of hydrogen-rich compounds, i.e. water, hexane and toluene was evaluated. Experiments were performed at conditions of lean TCE concentration (around 1000 ppm) in air, between 250 and 550 °C in a conventional fixed-bed reactor. Hexane and toluene were added to the feedstream in a concentration of around 1000 ppm and water concentration varied from 1000 to 15 000 ppm. TCE oxidation occurred faster in the presence of hexane and toluene over both catalysts. Over palladium catalysts, water did not alter catalytic activity, whereas over platinum catalysts water enhanced TCE oxidation at low temperatures (<400 °C) but inhibited it at higher temperatures (>400 °C). Selectivity to HCl was much improved by feeding water as a hydrogen-supplying reactant; 7500 ppm of water enhanced HCl outputs from 39.4 to 78.0% with Pd, and from 37.5 to 58.9% with Pt. Selectivities to C<inf>2</inf>Cl<inf>4</inf>, formed by chlorination of the feed, and Cl<inf>2</inf> were greatly reduced. On the other hand water promoted complete oxidation of TCE to CO<inf>2</inf>, and thus reduced selectivity to CO. In the presence of hexane and toluene, formation of HCl was also enhanced. Hexane showed higher inhibition ability than toluene over both catalysts for the C<inf>2</inf>Cl<inf>4</inf> and Cl<inf>2</inf> formation. Unlike in the presence of water, selectivity to CO increased, as a consequence of partial oxidation of both hydrocarbons. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: F.I., Khan, Faisal I.; A., Kr Ghoshal, Aloke
Author full names: Khan, Faisal I. (7402008246); Kr Ghoshal, Aloke (55663799600)
Title: Removal of Volatile Organic Compounds from polluted air
Source title: Journal of Loss Prevention in the Process Industries
Affiliations: Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Pilani, India
Authors with affiliations: Khan, Faisal I., Department of Chemical Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Pilani, India; Kr Ghoshal, Aloke, Department of Chemical Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Pilani, India
Abstract: Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) are among the most common air pollutants emitted from chemical, petrochemical, and allied industries. VOCs are one of the main sources of photochemical reaction in the atmosphere leading to various environmental hazards; on the other hand, these VOCs have good commercial value. Growing environmental awareness has put up stringent regulations to control the VOCs emissions. In such circumstances, it becomes mandatory for each VOCs emitting industry or facility to opt for proper VOCs control measures. There are many techniques available to control VOCs emission (destruction based and recovery based) with many advantages and limitations. Therefore, deciding on a particular technique becomes a difficult task. This article illustrates various available options for VOCs control. It further details the merits, demerits and applicability of each option. The authors hope that this article will help in critically analysing the requirements and accordingly decide on the appropriate strategy to control VOCs. © 2000 Elsevier Science Ltd. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: New products: Thermal oxidizer is a low-cost way to destroy pollutants
Abstract: Haden Drysys Environmental's SCO single-canister regenerative oxidizer removes VOC, odors, and other pollutants from exhaust gas streams at 99% destruction efficiency. Available in catalytic and thermal versions, the device contains several segments packed with ceramic saddles or structured packing. The oxidizer needs no supplementary fuel during operation. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: M.A., Malik, Muhammad Arif; S.A., Malik, Salman Akbar
Author full names: Malik, Muhammad Arif (7401485325); Malik, Salman Akbar (7402973266)
Title: Pulsed corona discharges and their applications in toxic VOCs abatement
Affiliations: Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad, Pakistan; Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Malik, Muhammad Arif, Applied Chemistry Division, Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad, Pakistan, Department of Biological Sciences, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan; Malik, Salman Akbar, Applied Chemistry Division, Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad, Pakistan
Abstract: Plasma processes are among the emerging technologies for volatile organic compounds (VOCs) abatement[1]. Both thermal plasmas and non-equilibrium plasmas (cold plasmas) are being developed for VOCs cleanup[2,3]. Particularly, pulsed corona discharges offer several advantages over conventional VOCs abatement techniques[4-7]. To optimize the existing technology and to develop it further, there is need to understand the mechanisms involved in plasma chemical reactions. Furthermore, it is strongly desirable to be able to predict the behavior of new VOCs in non-equilibrium plasma environment from the data known for a few representative compounds. Pulsed corona discharge technique is introduced here with citation of relevant literature. Fundamental principles, useful for predicting the VOCs' decomposition behavior, have been worked out from the published literature. Latest developments in the area, targeted to minimize the energy losses, improve the VOCs destruction efficiency and reduce the generation of unwanted organic and inorganic by-products, are presented. © 2006 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

This article illustrates various available options for VOCs control and discusses the merits, demerits and applications of each option. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G., Sinquin, Gilles; J.P., Hindermann, Jean Paul; C., Petit, Corinne; A.A., Kiennemann, Alain A.
Author full names: Sinquin, Gilles (6602590947); Hindermann, Jean Paul (57210406538); Petit, Corinne (7202973260); Kiennemann, Alain A. (7004564499)
Title: Perovskites as polyvalent catalysts for total destruction of C1, C2 and aromatic chlorinated volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: CNRS Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Sinquin, Gilles, CNRS Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Paris, France; Hindermann, Jean Paul, CNRS Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Paris, France; Petit, Corinne, CNRS Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Paris, France; Kiennemann, Alain A., CNRS Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Paris, France
Abstract: Perovskites ABO<inf>3</inf> (A: La, B = Co, Mn) have shown to be effective and polyvalent in catalytic total oxidation of chlorinated volatile organic compounds such as chlorinated methanes, and chlorinated saturated and unsaturated C<inf>2</inf> hydrocarbons and chlorobenzene. Perovskites prepared by a sol-gel like method are characterised before and after catalytic test. The difference in behavior of the manganese and cobalt containing catalysts is discussed and attributed to an oxygen overstoichiometry in the manganese catalyst. Differences have also been observed in reaction mechanisms depending on the reacting chlorinated molecule. © 1999 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Catalytic Total Oxidation; Chlorinated Voc; Perovskites; Reaction Mechanism

Authors: A., O'Malley, A.; B.K., Hodnett, B. Kieran
Author full names: O'Malley, A. (7005941106); Hodnett, B. Kieran (7006651326)
Title: The influence of volatile organic compound structure on conditions required for total oxidation
Affiliations: University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: O'Malley, A., Department of Chemical and Environmental Sciences, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland; Hodnett, B. Kieran, Department of Chemical and Environmental Sciences, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland
Abstract: The reactivity of a range of volatile organic compounds with differing functional groups has been assessed over platinum catalysts supported on β-zeolite, mordenite, silica or alumina. Alcohols, ketones, carboxylic acids, aromatics and alkanes were included in the range. In general, the reactivity pattern observed was alcohols > aromatics > ketones > carboxylic acids > alkanes, although some overlap was observed in that the more reactive alkanes were more readily oxidized than the less reactive carboxylic acids. The same order of reactivity was observed for all the catalysts studied here. A kinetic isotope effect was observed when deuterated acetone was compared to normal acetone, consistent with C-H bond cleavage being the slow step in the catalytic oxidation of this substrate. A correlation was found between the reactivity of the individual substrates and the strength of the weakest C-H bond in the structure. A single weak C-H bond in the substrate led to a high reactivity. It is postulated that catalytic oxidation on platinum catalysts proceeds via initial rupture of the weakest C-H bond in the substrate followed by further reaction steps which involves free radical chemistry. © 1999 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bond Energies; Catalytic Combustion; Heptane; Hydrocarbon; Platinum; Zeolite

Title: Scrubbing and biological treatment combine to tackle VOCs, odors
Abstract: CMS Group Inc's Bioscrub process, which employs a rotating biological contactor technology in a single vessel for gas contact, absorption and contaminant destruction, and requires few or no chemicals, is suited for treating VOC, odor producing gases and other contaminated gases. The enclosed vessel contains a series of closely spaced disks mounted on a horizontal shaft, where the gas stream to be treated flow through as it enters one end of the unit. Nutrient-containing water keeps the surface of the rotating disks wet, absorbing contaminants in the gas stream. A film of active, naturally occurring microorganisms on the disk surface removes absorbed contaminants, converting them to CO<inf>2</inf> and H<inf>2</inf>O. Water conveys any excess biomass through the vessel for removal in a clarifier. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Title: VOC/HAP regenerative thermal oxidizer
Abstract: Crawford Equipment and Engineering Co's RTO, designed for controlling various VOC, allows process changes without impact. The compact, skid-mounted RTO unit with a destruction efficiency as high as 99% features a simple, reliable two-chamber design. The RTO unit is easy to operate and maintain, provides efficient fume and odor destruction, and is expandable from 3000 to 500,000 scfm. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: S.H., Kirn, Sung Hee; Y.C., Kirn, Young Chul; N., Park, Namcook
Author full names: Kirn, Sung Hee (15059038600); Kirn, Young Chul (15058912100); Park, Namcook (7202111756)
Title: Development of Metal Oxide Catalysts for the Removal of VOCs
Source title: Studies in Surface Science and Catalysis
Affiliations: Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kirn, Sung Hee, Department of Chemical Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; Kirn, Young Chul, Department of Chemical Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea; Park, Namcook, Department of Chemical Engineering, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, South Korea
Abstract: Metal oxide catalysts were tested for the removal of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in an atmospheric fixed bed flow reactor. Silver containing mixed oxide was highly active when it was calcined at lower temperature (400C) due to the surface exposed metallic Ag°. However, when the catalyst was calcined at higher temperature (800 "C), it became less active since Ag° was changed into Ag ion to form AgzMnOi. The complete oxidation of various VOCs by this catalyst took place at 2701, which is 80-180^ lower than the literature values. Therefore, mixed metal oxide seems to be substituted for noble metal catalysts for the economic removal of VOCs. Copyright ©1999 by Kodansha Ltd. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J.C., Hage, Jacobus C.; S., Hartmans, Sybe
Author full names: Hage, Jacobus C. (7102834718); Hartmans, Sybe (7004049287)
Title: Monooxygenase-mediated 1,2-dichloroethane degradation by Pseudomonas sp. strain DCA1
Affiliations: Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands; Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Hage, Jacobus C., Dept. Food Technol. Nutritional Sci., Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands, Dept. Food Technol. Nutritional Sci., Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands; Hartmans, Sybe, Dept. Food Technol. Nutritional Sci., Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands
Abstract: A bacterial strain, designated Pseudomonas sp. strain DCA1, was isolated from a 1,2-dichloroethane (DCA)degrading biofilm. Strain DCA1 utilizes DCA as the sole carbon and energy source and does not require additional organic nutrients, such as vitamins, for optimal growth. The affinity of strain DCA1 for DCA is very high, with a K(m) value below the detection limit of 0.5 μM. Instead of a hydrolytic dehalogenation, as in other DCA utilizers, the first step in DCA degradation in strain DCA1 is an oxidation reaction. Oxygen and NAD(P)H are required for this initial step. Propene was converted to 1,2- epoxypropane by DCA-grown cells and competitively inhibited DCA degradation. We concluded that a monooxygenase is responsible for the first step in DCA degradation in strain DCA1. Oxidation of DCA probably results in the formation of the unstable intermediate 1,2-dichloroethanol, which spontaneously releases chloride, yielding chloroacetaldehyde. The DCA degradation pathway in strain DCA1 proceeds from chloroacetaldehyde via chloroacetic acid and presumably glycolic acid, which is similar to degradation routes observed in other DCA-utilizing bacteria. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Gaseous emissions from wastewater facilities
Affiliations: Operations Mgmt. International, Inc., United States; Dames and Moore, Greenville, United States
Authors with affiliations: D'Amato, Richard M., Operations Mgmt. International, Inc., United States, ; DeHollander, Glenn Robert, Dames and Moore, Greenville, United States
Abstract: Several issues relating to gaseous emissions from wastewater facilities are discussed. These include: regulatory compliance; methods of sampling volative organic compounds (VOC); system modeling to determine the fate of hydrophobic and VOCs in activated sludge; hazardous air pollutants emissions from wastewater treatment plants (WWTP); process and operation tools; odor control; VOC emissions from biosolids; physicochemical treatment; and the use of biofilters and biotrickling filters in WWTP. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Ogata, Atsushi; N., Shintani, Noboru; K., Mizuno, Kouichi; S., Kushiyama, Satoshi; T., Yamamoto, Toshiaki
Author full names: Ogata, Atsushi (56448190500); Shintani, Noboru (7003437686); Mizuno, Kouichi (35460039100); Kushiyama, Satoshi (7006685841); Yamamoto, Toshiaki (55950052800)
Title: Decomposition of benzene using a nonthermal plasma reactor packed with ferroelectric pellets
Affiliations: National Institute for Resources and Environment, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ogata, Atsushi, National Institute for Resources and Environment, Tsukuba, Japan; Shintani, Noboru, National Institute for Resources and Environment, Tsukuba, Japan; Mizuno, Kouichi, National Institute for Resources and Environment, Tsukuba, Japan; Kushiyama, Satoshi, National Institute for Resources and Environment, Tsukuba, Japan; Yamamoto, Toshiaki, National Institute for Resources and Environment, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The decomposition of benzene in air was carried out using a nonthermal plasma discharge reactor packed with ferroelectric materials. It was found that ferroelectric materials of 1-2 mm in diameter with a relative dielectric constant of ε<inf>r</inf> ≥ 1100 decomposed benzene with greatest energy efficiency. Benzene at low concentrations (below 50 ppm) was completely decomposed to CO and CO<inf>2</inf> with no formation of other hydrocarbons. The ratio of CO to CO<inf>2</inf> produced from benzene was minimized under an atmosphere containing more than 5% O<inf>2</inf>. © 2007 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Kohno, Hitoshi; A.A., Berezin, Alexander A.; J., Chang, Jenshih
Author full names: Kohno, Hitoshi (57205962277); Berezin, Alexander A. (7102064387); Chang, Jenshih (57083236600)
Title: Destruction of volatile organic compounds used in a semiconductor industry by a capillary tube discharge reactor
Affiliations: Asahikogyosha Co Ltd, Chiba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kohno, Hitoshi, Research and Development Center, Asahikogyosha Co Ltd, Chiba, Japan; Berezin, Alexander A., Research and Development Center, Asahikogyosha Co Ltd, Chiba, Japan; Chang, Jenshih, Research and Development Center, Asahikogyosha Co Ltd, Chiba, Japan
Abstract: Nonthermal plasma technologies offer an innovative approach to the problem of decomposing various volatile organic compounds (VOC's). We focused on dc capillary tube discharge plasma reactors to study the decomposition/destruction efficiency for toluene, EGM, trichloroethane, and trichlroethylene at 50-2300-ppm levels in dry air. The effects of gas flow rate, VOC concentration, and reactor operating conditions on decomposition and analysis of reactant conversion for each VOC were investigated. The results show that VOC destruction efficiency as high as 90% can be achieved, even under a short residence time (3.8 ms) with a destruction energy efficiency of up to 95 g (VOC)/kWh. Laboratory-scale plasma technology was successfully demonstrated for its potential application for VOC control in the semiconductor clean-room environment. © 1998 IEEE. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Biofiltration of BTEX contaminated air streams using compost-activated carbon filter media
Affiliations: Cleveland State University, Cleveland, United States; Southern Methodist University, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abumaizar, Riyad J., Cleveland State University, Cleveland, United States; Kocher, Walter M., Cleveland State University, Cleveland, United States; Smith, Edward H., Southern Methodist University, Dallas, United States
Abstract: Three laboratory-scale biofilter columns were operated for 82 days to investigate the removal of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and o-xylene (BTEX) from a waste gas stream. The columns contain a mixture of yard waste and sludge compost as the base biofilter material. Different amounts of granular activated carbon (GAC) are mixed with the compost in two of the three columns to evaluate the extent to which biofilter performance can be enhanced. The columns displayed preferential utilization of benzene followed by toluene, ethylbenzene, and o-xylene, respectively. Removal efficiencies of ≤ 90% were achieved for inlet concentrations of ≤ 200 ppm of each of the BTEX compounds and a gas loading rate of 17.6 m3/m2 h in all columns over the period of study. During sudden increases in the gas flow rate or the BTEX influent concentration, biofilters containing GAC exhibited significantly higher removal efficiencies and more stable operation than the biofilter containing only compost. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Baldi, Marco; E., Finocchio, Elisabetta; F., Milella, Fabio; G., Busca, Guido
Author full names: Baldi, Marco (7006404719); Finocchio, Elisabetta (7004523769); Milella, Fabio (57050532600); Busca, Guido (57208583146)
Title: Catalytic combustion of C3 hydrocarbons and oxygenates over Mn3O4
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Pavia, Pavia, Italy; Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Baldi, Marco, Dipto. Ingegneria Idraul. Ambientale, Università degli Studi di Pavia, Pavia, Italy; Finocchio, Elisabetta, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; Milella, Fabio, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy; Busca, Guido, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Università degli Studi di Genova, Genoa, Italy
Abstract: The catalytic oxidation of the C3 organic compounds: propane, propene, 1-propanol, 2-propanol, prop-2-en-1-ol (allyl alcohol), propanal, propanone (acetone) and propenal (acrolein) has been investigated over Mn<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> in the presence of excess oxygen. Total combustion to CO<inf>2</inf> occurs at temperatures > 623 K (673 K for propane). However, the production of pollutant products (such as propene from propane, CO from propene, acetaldehyde from propanols, propanal and propanone, carboxylic acids) persists even at very high volatile organic compounds (VOC) conversions. On the basis of the reaction products, a tentative reaction pathway for propane and propene combustion is proposed.; The catalytic oxidation of the C3 organic compounds: propane, propene, 1-propanol, 2-propanol, prop-2-en-1-ol (allyl alcohol), propanal, propanone (acetone) and propenal (acrolein) has been investigated over Mn<inf>3</inf>O<inf>4</inf> in the presence of excess oxygen. Total combustion to CO<inf>2</inf> occurs at temperatures>623 K (673 K for propane). However, the production of pollutant products (such as propene from propane, CO from propene, acetaldehyde from propanols, propanal and propanone, carboxylic acids) persists even at very high volatile organic compounds (VOC) conversions. On the basis of the reaction products, a tentative reaction pathway for propane and propene combustion is proposed. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Lietti, L.
Title: Plants of catalytic combustion of volatile organic compounds; Impianti di combustione catalitica di sostanze organiche volatili
Affiliations: Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Lietti, L., Dipto. Chim. Industriale I., Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy
Abstract: The present review illustrates the basic principles of the catalytic combustion of volatile organic compounds (VOC). After a brief introduction on the typical plants configurations, the advantages and disadvantages of the catalytic combustion technology are addressed, in particular with respect to the conventional thermal incineration techniques. © 2005 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: P., Papaefthimiou, Panagiotis; T., Ioannides, Theophilos; X.E., Verykios, Xenophon E.
Author full names: Papaefthimiou, Panagiotis (57192912399); Ioannides, Theophilos (6603886886); Verykios, Xenophon E. (35551305100)
Title: Performance of doped Pt/TiO2 (W6+) catalysts for combustion of volatile organic compounds (VOCS)
Affiliations: University of Patras, Rio, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Papaefthimiou, Panagiotis, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Rio, Greece; Ioannides, Theophilos, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Rio, Greece; Verykios, Xenophon E., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Rio, Greece
Abstract: The oxidation of benzene and ethylacetate, present in trace amounts in air, over Pt supported on γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, SiO<inf>2</inf>, TiO<inf>2</inf> and TiO<inf>2</inf> (W6+) carriers has been studied. It was found that doping of the TiO<inf>2</inf> support with W6+ cations has a positive effect on the activity of Pt catalysts for benzene and ethylacetate oxidation. A maximum in activity enhancement has been observed at a W6+ content of 0.45 at% in the TiO<inf>2</inf> support. The Pt/TiO<inf>2</inf> (0.45 at% W6+) catalyst is over two orders of magnitude more active than the Pt/γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalyst in the case of ethylacetate oxidation and an order of magnitude more active in the case of benzene oxidation. Doping of TiO<inf>2</inf> with W6+ cations enhances its activity for ethylacetate degradation towards smaller organic intermediates, such as ethanol, acetic acid and ethylene, and it also affects product distribution. The enhanced activity of the Pt/TiO<inf>2</inf> (W6+) catalysts is attributed to complementary bifunctional steps occuring on sites offered by Pt metal and by the support. During oxidation of benzene-ethylacetate-water mixtures, benzene oxidation is strongly suppressed in the presence of ethylacetate, while water acts as an inhibitor for both volatile organic compounds (VOC) oxidations.; The oxidation of benzene and ethylacetate, present in trace amounts in air, over Pt supported on γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>, SiO<inf>2</inf>, TiO<inf>2</inf> and TiO<inf>2</inf> (W6+) carriers has been studied. It was found that doping of the TiO<inf>2</inf> support with W6+ cations has a positive effect on the activity of Pt catalysts for benzene and ethylacetate oxidation. A maximum in activity enhancement has been observed at a W6+ content of 0.45 at% in the TiO<inf>2</inf> support. The Pt/TiO<inf>2</inf> (0.45 at% W6+) catalyst is over two orders of magnitude more active than the Pt/γ-Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalyst in the case of ethylacetate oxidation and an order of magnitude more active in the case of benzene oxidation. Doping of TiO<inf>2</inf> with W6+ cations enhances its activity for ethylacetate degradation towards smaller organic intermediates, such as ethanol, acetic acid and ethylene, and it also affects product distribution. The enhanced activity of the Pt/TiO<inf>2</inf> (W6+) catalysts is attributed to complementary bifunctional steps occurring on sites offered by Pt metal and by the support. During oxidation of benzene-ethylacetate-water mixtures, benzene oxidation is strongly suppressed in the presence of ethylacetate, while water acts as an inhibitor for both volatile organic compounds (VOC) oxidations. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: E., Smet, Erik; H.R., Van Langenhove, Herman R.
Author full names: Smet, Erik (6603932783); Van Langenhove, Herman R. (22036947600)
Title: Abatement of volatile organic sulfur compounds in odorous emissions from the bio-industry
Affiliations: Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Smet, Erik, Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium; Van Langenhove, Herman R., Department of Organic Chemistry, Universiteit Gent, Ghent, Belgium
Abstract: Compounds of interest in this work are methanethiol (MESH), dimethyl sulfide (Me<inf>2</inf>S), dimethyl polysulfides (Me<inf>2</inf>S(x)) and carbon disulfide (CS<inf>2</inf>) since these volatiles have been identified as predominant odorants in the emission of a wide range of activities in the bio-industry (e.g. aerobic waste water treatment plants, composting plants, rendering plants). In these processes, the occurrence of volatile organic sulfur compounds is mainly related to the presence of anaerobic microsites with consecutive fermentation of sulfur containing organic material and/or to the breakdown of the latter due to thermal heating. Due to the chemical complexity of these low- concentrated waste gas streams and the high flow rates to be handled, mainly biotechnological techniques and scrubbers can be used to control the odour emission. When using biofilters or trickling filters, inoculation with specific microorganisms and pH-control strategies should be implemented to optimise the removal of volatile organic sulfur compounds. In scrubbers, chemical oxidation of the volatile organic sulfur compounds can be obtained by dosing hypochlorite, ozone or hydrogen peroxide to the scrubbing liquid. However, optimal operational conditions for each of these abatement techniques requires a further research in order to guarantee a long-term and efficient overall odour abatement.; Compounds of interest in this work are methanethiol (MeSH), dimethyl sulfide (Me<inf>2</inf>S), dimethyl polysulfides (Me<inf>2</inf>S<inf>x</inf>) and carbon disulfide (CS<inf>2</inf>) since these volatiles have been identified as predominant odorants in the emission of a wide range of activities in the bio-industry (e.g. aerobic waste water treatment plants, composting plants, rendering plants). In these processes, the occurrence of volatile organic sulfur compounds is mainly related to the presence of anaerobic microsites with consecutive fermentation of sulfur containing organic material and/or to the breakdown of the latter due to thermal heating. Due to the chemical complexity of these low-concentrated waste gas streams and the high flow rates to be handled, mainly biotechnological techniques and scrubbers can be used to control the odour emission. When using biofilters or trickling filters, inoculation with specific microorganisms and pH-control strategies should be implemented to optimize the removal of volatile organic sulfur compounds. In scrubbers, chemical oxidation of the volatile organic sulfur compounds can be obtained by dosing hypochlorite, ozone or hydrogen peroxide to the scrubbing liquid. However, optimal operational conditions for each of these abatement techniques requires a further research in order to guarantee a long-term and efficient overall odour abatement. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.J., O'Reilly, Alan J.
Author full names: O'Reilly, Alan J. (7003695510)
Title: A series reaction approach to VOC incineration
Affiliations: Teesside University, Middlesbrough, United Kingdom; Teesside University, Middlesbrough, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: O'Reilly, Alan J., Department of Chemical Engineering, Teesside University, Middlesbrough, United Kingdom, Department of Chemical Engineering, Teesside University, Middlesbrough, United Kingdom
Abstract: Thermal incineration of VOCs has been evaluated by means of a two step series reaction approach, VOC → CO → CO<inf>2</inf>, so that the rates of VOC and CO oxidation may both be considered. Temperature and concentration profiles have been obtained for oxidation of several VOCs as functions of space time π. Appropriate conditions for 99.99% removal of VOC and 99.5% oxidation of intermediate CO appear to be 930 to 980 K inlet temperature, 0.05 to 0.06 kmol auxiliary fuel per kmol dry waste air and 90 to 130% excess air for auxiliary fuel, without heat recovery. These conditions yield approximately 0.4 seconds space time and an L/d<inf>i</inf> ratio for the oxidation section of the incinerator of approximately 2 to 3. Heat loss from the incinerator should be less than 2% of the total heat from auxiliary fuel and VOC combustion and incinerator design should therefore be optimized with respect to fuel and insulation costs. The approach outlined in this work can easily be adapted to estimate auxiliary fuel savings via heat recovery. © Institution of Chemical Engineers. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Basu, Somnath; Z., Gu, Zhongchun; K.A., Shilinsky, Kenneth A.
Author full names: Basu, Somnath (7403656657); Gu, Zhongchun (7401760313); Shilinsky, Kenneth A. (6507826932)
Title: Application of packed scrubbers for air emissions control in municipal wastewater treatment plants
Affiliations: MWRA, Charlestown, United States; College of Engineering, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Basu, Somnath, MWRA, Charlestown, United States; Gu, Zhongchun, College of Engineering, Boston, United States; Shilinsky, Kenneth A., MWRA, Charlestown, United States
Abstract: The process air emissions from municipal wastewater treatment plants primarily consist of hydrogen sulfide gas, along with other organo-sulfur compounds, and some trace quantities of volatile organic compounds (VOC). Various Federal and/or State Regulations require monitoring, and control of these emissions down to some specified levels. At the Deer Island Wastewater Treatment Plant of the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority (MWRA), air containing hydrogen sulfide is collected and treated in several emission control systems. These systems consist of wet scrubbers which facilitate destruction of hydrogen sulfide gas and the related odor by continuously contacting the collected air counter-currently with a strong oxidizing solution of sodium hypochlorite. This paper reviews the performance of a typical scrubber in light of the theory of absorption followed by chemical reaction. Based on an analysis of a set of test data, it has been concluded that when the concentration of hydrogen sulfide at a scrubber inlet exceeds 25 ppm, the scrubber becomes mass transfer limited. This can lead to the incomplete oxidation of hydrogen sulfide gas. Unreacted H<inf>2</inf>S eventually can exit the scrubber while partially oxidized H<inf>2</inf>S, in the form of elemental sulfur, can deposit on, and eventually foul, the packing media. Measures taken to overcome such a situation have also been reported. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C.C., Head, Craig C.; C.S., Wright, Charlene S.; E.F., Hetzel, Edward F.
Author full names: Head, Craig C. (7006091572); Wright, Charlene S. (7403507546); Hetzel, Edward F. (7801398328)
Title: Investigation of regenerative thermal oxidation for control of pulp mill VOC emissions and sludge dryer odor
Affiliations: Procter and Gamble, Cincinnati, United States
Authors with affiliations: Head, Craig C., Procter and Gamble, Cincinnati, United States; Wright, Charlene S., Procter and Gamble, Cincinnati, United States; Hetzel, Edward F., Procter and Gamble, Cincinnati, United States
Abstract: Two challenges facing Procter & Gamble's ammonia based, sulfite mill at Mehoopany, Pennsylvania are control of odor and preparation for the proposed MACT emissions standards. The site's location in a river valley, combined with meteorological factors, have resulted in community odor issues. The predominant sources of odor have been traced to pulp mill and sludge dryer exhausts. Several technologies were investigated for odor control including biological treatment, wet oxidative scrubbing, and thermal oxidation. Regenerative Thermal Oxidation (RTO) was selected due to its high VOC destruction efficiency and ability to process high moisture and high temperature feeds. Four issues faced the project team: 1) Would the RTO be capable of eliminating sludge dryer odor? 2) Would the RTO demonstrate satisfactory VOC destruction? 3) How would the RTO's ceramic media react to salts and particulate entrained in the feed streams? 4) What materials of construction would be required? To answer these questions a 3 month pilot study was planned using a 2 chamber, 17,000 liter per minute RTO. The study concluded that RTO is an effective technology for the control of sludge dryer odor and VOC emissions. Sudden and irreversible media build up due to salts and particulate will not be an issue with the technology. Stainless steel was found to be a suitable material of construction. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: P., Papaefthimiou, Panagiotis; T., Ioannides, Theophilos; X.E., Verykios, Xenophon E.
Author full names: Papaefthimiou, Panagiotis (57192912399); Ioannides, Theophilos (6603886886); Verykios, Xenophon E. (35551305100)
Title: Combustion of non-halogenated volatile organic compounds over group VIII metal catalysts
Affiliations: University of Patras, Rio, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Papaefthimiou, Panagiotis, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Rio, Greece; Ioannides, Theophilos, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Rio, Greece; Verykios, Xenophon E., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, Rio, Greece
Abstract: Catalytic combustion of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), present in low concentrations (10-1000 ppm) in industrial effluent streams, is a promising air abatement technology. The oxidation of benzene, butanol and ethyl acetate over group VII metal catalysts supported on alumina carriers has been investigated. Pt, Pd and Co were found to be the most active among group VIII metals, while ethyl acetate was found to be the most-difficult-to-oxidize compound. Benzene and ethyl acetate oxidations over Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>were found to be structure sensitive reactions with the turnover frequency (TOF) increasing with increasing mean metal particle size. The presence of chloride on the catalyst surface, originating from chloride-containing metal precursor compounds was found to exert an inhibiting effect on the activity of Pt. Apparent activation energies of the reactions over Pt and Pd catalysts were found to be in the 70-120 kJ/mol range while the reaction order with respect to the VOC was positive in all cases. During oxidation of benzene-butanol mixtures, benzene oxidation was completely suppressed as long as butanol was present in the reaction mixture.; Catalytic combustion of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), present in low concentrations (10-1000 ppm) in industrial effluent streams, is a promising air abatement technology. The oxidation of benzene, butanol and ethyl acetate over group VII metal catalysts supported on alumina carriers has been investigated. Pt, Pd and Co were found to be the most active among group VIII metals, while ethyl acetate was found to be the most-difficult-to-oxidize compound. Benzene and ethyl acetate oxidations over Pt/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf>were found to be structure sensitive reactions with the turnover frequency (TOF) increasing with increasing mean metal particle size. The presence of chloride on the catalyst surface, originating from chloride-containing metal precursor compounds was found to exert an inhibiting effect on the activity of Pt. Apparent activation energies of the reactions over Pt and Pd catalysts were found to be in the 70-120 kJ/mol range while the reaction order with respect to the VOC was positive in all cases. During oxidation of benzene-butanol mixtures, benzene oxidation was completely suppressed as long as butanol was present in the reaction mixture. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
