Authors: A.H., Wani, Altaf H.; R.M.R., Branion, Richard M.R.; A.K.P., Lau, Anthony Ka Pong
Author full names: Wani, Altaf H. (7005337481); Branion, Richard M.R. (7003592460); Lau, Anthony Ka Pong (7202626105)
Title: Biofiltration: A promising and cost-effective control technology for odors, VOCs and air toxics
Source title: Journal of Environmental Science and Health - Part A Toxic/Hazardous Substances and Environmental Engineering
Affiliations: The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wani, Altaf H., Dept. of Chem. and Bio-Rsrc. Eng., The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada; Branion, Richard M.R., Dept. of Chem. and Bio-Rsrc. Eng., The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada; Lau, Anthony Ka Pong, Dept. of Chem. and Bio-Rsrc. Eng., The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
Abstract: Biofiltration, a relatively recent air pollution control technology, has been identified as a promising method of odor, VOC and air toxic removal form waste-gas streams because of low capital and operating costs, low energy requirements and an absence of residual products requiring further treatment or disposal. Biofiltration units are microbial systems incorporating microorganisms grown on a porous solid media like compost, peat, soil or mixture of these materials. The filter media and the microbial culture are surrounded by a thin film of water called biofilm. Waste-gases containing biodegradable VOCs and inorganic air toxics are vented through this biologically active material, where soluble contaminants partition into the liquid film and are biodegraded by the resident microorganisms in the biofilm. The technology has been successfully applied to a wide range of industrial and public sector sources for the abatement of odors, VOCs and air toxics, with an elimination efficiency of more than 90%. Owing to its economic advantage over the conventional air pollution control methods coupled with environmental benefits like low energy requirements and the avoidance of cross-media transfer of pollutants, biofiltration is becoming more popular and practical in meeting the statutory emission regulations. The study presents an overview of the historical development and present status of biofiltration; summarizes its basic requirements, engineering fundamentals, operating principles, applicability, cost-effectiveness and potential failures. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B.M., Penetrante, Bernie M.; J.N., Bardsley, J. Norman; M.C., Hsiao, Mark C.
Author full names: Penetrante, Bernie M. (6603878742); Bardsley, J. Norman (22965792200); Hsiao, Mark C. (7101897636)
Title: Kinetic analysis of non-thermal plasmas used for pollution control
Source title: Japanese Journal of Applied Physics, Part 2: Letters
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Penetrante, Bernie M., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, United States; Bardsley, J. Norman, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, United States; Hsiao, Mark C., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, United States
Abstract: Non-thermal plasma techniques are being developed for the treatment of many gas-phase pollutants. In these methods electrical energy from electron beams or electrical discharges is directed selectively into the production of electrons, ions and radicals, or into molecular excitations that will result in the efficient destruction of the unwanted species. The processes by which this can be achieved are described. Kinetic analysis of the deposition of energy into contaminated air is illustrated by studies of the decomposition of nitrogen oxides, methylene chloride, carbon tetrachloride and methanol. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: K.W., Kelly, Kevin W.; J., Butcher, J.
Title: Catalytic processes for environmental use
Affiliations: Akzo Nobel N.V., Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kelly, Kevin W., Akzo Nobel N.V., Amsterdam, Netherlands; Butcher, J., Akzo Nobel N.V., Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: In the paper the catalysis utilization to increase the efficiency of industrial effluents treatment is reviewed and some of the products and processes involved are described. The processes include catalytically enhanced odour and low level volatile organic compounds (VOC) destruction using a heterogeneous nickel catalyst in a fixed bed reactor. The process is recognized as a unique and practical solution to a high profile environmental problem. A fixed bed catalytic process to remove organic contaminants (pesticides, nonbiodegradable species, etc.) from liquid streams is developed on the base of the same chemical reaction proceeding over the catalyst. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: W.J., Swanson, Warren J.; R.C., Loehr, Raymond C.
Author full names: Swanson, Warren J. (8418500800); Loehr, Raymond C. (7005377720)
Title: Biofiltration: Fundamentals, design and operations principles, and applications
Affiliations: Malcolm Pirnie, Inc. White Plains, White Plains, United States; The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Swanson, Warren J., Malcolm Pirnie, Inc. White Plains, White Plains, United States, Envir. Water Resour. Engrg. Prog., The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Loehr, Raymond C., Envir. Water Resour. Engrg. Prog., The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States,
Abstract: Biofiltration is a biological air pollution control technology for volatile organic compounds (VOCs). This paper summarizes the fundamentals, design and operation, and application of the process. Biofiltration has been demonstrated to be an effective technology for VOCs from many industries. Large and fullscale systems are in use in Europe and the United States. With proper design and operation, VOC removal efficiencies of 95-99% have been achieved. Important parameters for design and performance are empty-bed contact time, gas surface loading, mass loading, elimination capacity, and removal efficiency. Key design and operation factors include chemical and media properties, moisture, pH, temperature, nutrient availability, gas pretreatment, and variations in loading. ©ASCE. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P., Lundberg, Per; P.D., Howe, Paul D.; S., Dobson, Stuart; M.J., Crookes, Michael J.
Author full names: Lundberg, Per (57197533070); Howe, Paul D. (8742497700); Dobson, Stuart (23483363300); Crookes, Michael J. (23066229800)
Title: Environmental Health criteria 190
Affiliations: Arbetslivsinstitutet, Stockholm, Sweden; UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology, Wallingford, United Kingdom; Building Research Establishment, Watford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lundberg, Per, Arbetslivsinstitutet, Stockholm, Sweden; Howe, Paul D., UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology, Wallingford, United Kingdom; Dobson, Stuart, UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology, Wallingford, United Kingdom; Crookes, Michael J., Building Research Establishment, Watford, United Kingdom
Abstract: Xylene is an aromatic hydrocarbon which exists in three isomeric forms: ortho, meta and para. Technical grade xylene contains a mixture of the three isomers and also some ethylbenzene. The estimated world production in 1984 was 15.4 million tonnes. Xylene is a colourless liquid at room temperature with an aromatic odour. The vapour pressure lies between 0.66 and 0.86 kPa for the three isomers. Approximately 92% of mixed xylenes is blended into petrol. It is also used in a variety of solvent applications, particularly in the paint and printing ink industries. The majority of xylene released into the environment enters the atmosphere directly. In the atmosphere the xylene isomers are readily degraded, primarily by photooxidation. Volatilization to the atmosphere from water is rapid for all three isomers. In soil and water, the meta and para isomers are readily biodegraded under a wide range of aerobic and anaerobic conditions, but the ortho isomer is more persistent. The limited evidence available suggests that bioaccumulation of the xylene isomers by fish and invertebrates is low. Elimination of xylene from aquatic organisms is fairly rapid once exposure has ceased. Typically, mean background levels of all three xylene isomers in ambient air are around 1 μg/m3, but in suburban areas they are around 3 μg/m3. Higher levels have been measured in urban and industrialized areas, mean concentrations ranging up to 500 μg/m3. However, concentrations are generally below 100 μg/m3. Estimated daily exposure of the general population through inhalations is 70 μg in rural areas and less than 2000 μg in urban areas. The concentration in drinking-water ranges from not detectable to 12 μg/litre. The data on the level in food are too limited to estimate daily oral exposure. Mean background concentrations of xylenes in surface water are generally below 0.1 μg/litre. However, much higher values have been measured in industrial areas and areas associated with the oil industry (up to 30 μg/litre in polluted waters and up to 2000 μg/litre near to discharge pipes). Similar background levels have been reported for groundwater although high levels have been reported due to localized pollution from underground storage tanks and pipes. After inhalation exposure the retention in the lungs is about 60% of the inhaled dose. Xylene is efficiently metabolized. More than 90% is biotransformed to methylhippuric acid, which is excreted in mice. Xylene does not accumulate significantly in the human body. Acute exposure to high concentrations of xylene can result in CNS effects and irritation in humans. However, there have been no long-term controlled human studies or epidemiological studies. The chronic toxicity appears to be relatively low in laboratory animals. There is suggestive evidence, however, that chronic CNS effects may occur in animals at moderate concentrations of xylene. Xylene appears not to be a mutagen or a carcinogen. The critical end-point is developmental toxicity, which has been demonstrated at an exposure level of 870 mg/m3 (200 ppm) in rats. Based on this end-point, the recommended guidance value for xylene in air is 0.87 mg/m3 (0.2 ppm). The xylene isomers are of moderate to low toxicity for aquatic organisms. For invertebrates the lowest LC<inf>50</inf> value, based on measured concentrations, is for o-xylene at 1 mg/litre (Daphnia magna). The lowest LC<inf>50</inf> values recorded for fish are 7.6 mg/litre for o-xylene (rainbow trout; based on measured concentrations), and 7.9 and 1.7 mg/litre for m- and p-xylenes respectively (both for striped bass; based on nominal concentrations). Limited information is available regarding chronic exposure of aquatic organisms to xylenes; however, rapid volatilization makes chronic exposure in water unlikely. The acute toxicity or xylene to birds is low. © 2021 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.M., Firmin, Scott M.; S., Lipke, Sheldon; A., Baturay, Allen
Author full names: Firmin, Scott M. (58657609400); Lipke, Sheldon (57210629590); Baturay, Allen (55952877700)
Title: Reduction of carbon monoxide emissions with regenerative thermal oxidizers
Authors with affiliations: Firmin, Scott M., ; Lipke, Sheldon, ; Baturay, Allen,
Abstract: Regenerative thermal oxidizers (RTOs) have been extensively used for the control of volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions from various sources. However, very little information is available on the ability of RTOs to control carbon monoxide (CO) emissions. This paper presents the results of extensive tests conducted on two RTOs to determine their VOC and CO control efficiencies. The inlet gas stream to the RTOs includes VOC and CO concentrations as high as 2,000 ppm and 3,600 ppm, respectfully. The testing demonstrated that both RTOs were capable of controlling greater than 98% of both inlet VOCs and CO. While the destruction efficiencies within the combustion chambers exceeded 99.9%, direct leakage past valves accounted for the lower control efficiencies. The tests indicated that the overall VOC and CO control efficiencies of the RTOs may be limited by valve leakage. The design and permitting of a RTO should include conservative control estimates which account for possible valve leakage. © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: G., Drouin, Guy; J.J.O., Gravel, Jean J.O.; V., Papadopoullos, Valya
Author full names: Drouin, Guy (57200878264); Gravel, Jean J.O. (7006248700); Papadopoullos, Valya (6507394680)
Title: VOC & COC emission control by regenerative thermal oxidation
Authors with affiliations: Drouin, Guy, ; Gravel, Jean J.O., ; Papadopoullos, Valya,
Abstract: The impregnation of felt paper with liquid asphalt releases large volumes of odorous fumes containing toxic VOC (volatile organic compounds) and COC (condensable organic compounds) now coming under demanding emission standards. In 1990, Biothermica developed a unique technology for treating organic emissions that pollute and generate odors. This regenerative incineration system, called BIOTOX, is a thermal oxidation process that offers a destruction efficiency in excess of environmental requirements and uses more than 90% of the heat generated by the combustion of volatile and condensable organic compounds and natural gas. A number of improvements were required to adapt the conventional regenerative incineration process to the treatment of fumes containing condensable heavy organics such as those generated from asphalt coating processes. COC accumulation, which can cause overheating and even fire, has been eliminated by patented features such as a hot purge system combined with a cyclonic separator. In addition, the equipment is protected from overheating by means of temperature detectors, which automatically trigger a cooling cycle, which also caters to equipment or power failures. The first BIOTOX unit was installed in March 1993 at BPCO asphalt paper saturation plant in Montreal (Canada). Designed to treat a flow of 15 000 scfm of asphalt fumes with a organic compounds concentration of 1200 mg/m3, the system has completely eliminated the odors, and the reduction of total organic compounds was consistently over 94%. A second unit, with a capacity of 20 000 scfm, was installed at the same asphalt paper plant in January 1995. A higher organic compound concentration in the fumes at the inlet required the implementation of a bake-out procedure in order to eliminate any risks of tar accumulation. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Authors: F.C., Sapienza, Frank C.
Author full names: Sapienza, Frank C. (6602878225)
Title: Combined odor and VOC control at the Tampa, Florida sludge drying facility using regenerative thermal oxidizers
Authors with affiliations: Sapienza, Frank C.,
Abstract: The Tampa, Florida Sludge Drying Facility was the first municipal sludge dryer facility to utilize regenerative thermal oxidizers (RTOs) for the control of odors and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). This paper reviews the design development and operating history of the Tampa facility. The following topics are discussed: initial odor panel testing performed at a similar sludge drying facility, design considerations necessary to accommodate the RTOs, VOC performance testing of the RTO's, and critical operations and maintenance considerations. At the Tampa facility, sewage sludge is dried in rotary dryers in which hot 1000-degree-F gases come in direct contact with the sludge, resulting in highly odorous offgases. Odor testing at a similar sludge drying facility confirmed that wet scrubbing systems would not adequately control the organic odors from a direct contact sludge dryer. At the Tampa facility, RTOs were used to treat the dryer offgas. Controlling the particulate loading of the dryer offgas was critical to the successful operation of the RTOs. The RTOs demonstrated 96%-97% destruction of VOCs and effectively controlled odors as evidenced by the absence of odor complaints. © 2004 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam. All rights reserved.

Title: Comparison of precious metals and base metal oxides for catalytic deep oxidation of volatile organic compounds from coating plants: Test results on an industrial pilot scale incinerator

Abstract: For the coating application case, base metal oxides catalysts (Cu/Cr, Cu/W or Cu/Mn) are not more resistant to poisoning than PGM catalysts, the best results being obtained for a Pt/Pd (1:5) catalyst formulation. Furthermore, the cleaning of aged PGM catalyst is easy and efficient whereas their degree of compactiveness is very high. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.B., Chang, Moo Been; T., Tseng, Tiandeng
Author full names: Chang, Moo Been (7404504201); Tseng, Tiandeng (7102607974)
Title: Gas-phase removal of H2S and NH3 with dielectric barrier discharges
Affiliations: National Central University, Taoyuan, Taiwan; Environmental Protection Administration, Taiwan, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, Moo Been, Graduate Institute of Environmental Engineering, National Central University, Taoyuan, Taiwan; Tseng, Tiandeng, Environmental Protection Administration, Taiwan, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: Hydrogen sulfide and ammonia are two inorganic compounds that may cause severe odor problems. In this study, the effectiveness of applying dielectric barrier discharges (DBDs) to destroy and remove these two odor-causing compounds from gas streams via the generation of gas-phase radicals and high-energy electrons is experimentally evaluated with a bench-scale apparatus. Experimental results indicate that the removal efficiencies of both H<inf>2</inf>S and NH<inf>3</inf> with DBD plasmas depend on the gas composition, gas residence time, and applied voltage. Electronegative gases, such as O2 and H<inf>2</inf>O<inf>(g</inf>), tend to increase the electron attachment and therefore decrease removal efficiencies. Simultaneous removal of H<inf>2</inf>S and NH<inf>3</inf> from gas streams is accomplished with DBD technology. Results of this study indicate DBD is an effective technology for controlling inorganic odor-causing compounds. © 2020 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P.O., Larsson, Per Olof; A.A., Andersson, Arne A.; R.L., Wallenberg, Reine L.; B., Svensson, Bo
Author full names: Larsson, Per Olof (16194709300); Andersson, Arne A. (57223382444); Wallenberg, Reine L. (7006124844); Svensson, Bo (36877280100)
Title: Combustion of CO and toluene; characterisation of copper oxide supported on titania and activity comparisons with supported cobalt, iron, and manganese oxide
Affiliations: Lunds Universitet, Lund, Sweden; Lunds Universitet, Lund, Sweden; Kemicentrum, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Larsson, Per Olof, Department of Chemical Engineering II (Chemical Technology), Lunds Universitet, Lund, Sweden; Andersson, Arne A., Department of Chemical Engineering II (Chemical Technology), Lunds Universitet, Lund, Sweden, Department of Chemical Engineering, Kemicentrum, Lund, Sweden; Wallenberg, Reine L., Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Lunds Universitet, Lund, Sweden; Svensson, Bo, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Lunds Universitet, Lund, Sweden
Abstract: Titania-supported copper oxide catalysts have been prepared with loadings in the range from 1/3 to 5 theoretical layers and have been tested for the combustion of CO and toluene. Characterisation with XRD, electron microscopy, EDX, TPR, Raman, and XPS gives details about the structure of copper oxide on titania. The results show that dispersed CuO<inf>x</inf> is formed up to a loading of about one theoretical layer. TPR indicates the formation of two types of dispersed species, which possibly are isolated and polymeric, respectively. XPS data show that the dispersed copper is Cu2+. The dispersed species have high catalytic activity for combustion. At higher copper oxide loading, bulk CuO is formed, contributing little to the activity. Comparison of three titania supports with differing surface area and pore size distribution shows that the most favorable is a support with a surface area of about 38 m2/g and mesopores in the range 100-800 A. The longevity of the catalysts was tested in the waste gas from a formaldehyde plant. Deactivation was observed after being on stream for 57 days, and the deactivation is due to sintering of both the support and the copper oxide. Copper oxide on titania is shown to be more active than cobalt, manganese, and iron oxide on the same support. © 1996 Academic Press, Inc. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Van De Beld, L.; M.C., van der Ven, M. C.; K.R., Westerterp, Klass Roel
Author full names: Van De Beld, L. (6603470248); van der Ven, M. C. (57188649529); Westerterp, Klass Roel (59057596700)
Title: A kinetic study of the complete oxidation of ethene, propane and their mixtures on a Pd/Al2O3 catalyst
Source title: Chemical Engineering and Processing - Process Intensification
Affiliations: Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van De Beld, L., Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; van der Ven, M. C., Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Westerterp, Klass Roel, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands
Abstract: The complete oxidation of ethene and propane as individual hydrocarbons and of their mixtures on a Pd/Al<inf>2</inf>O<inf>3</inf> catalyst has been studied using an internal recycle reactor. The pressure was varied from 1.6-5 bar and the temperature from 180-220 °C for ethene oxidation and from 280-330 °C for propane oxidation. The maximum hydrocarbon concentration was ca. 3000 ppm or 0.3vol.%. The effect of the reaction products and the co-educt on the kinetics was investigated and it is shown that whereas water significantly retards the oxidation, the influence of CO<inf>2</inf> is negligible. Propane oxidation is inhibited by ethene. Such inhibition can only partly be explained by the additional water formed due to the combustion of ethene. The conversions in these experiments studied ranged between 70% and 90% for ethene and between 15% and 30% for propane, respectively. Four different rate expressions have been tested bearing in mind that the influence of water must be taken into account in any adequate description of the experimental data. The best-fitting rate expression described the experimental data to within an average error of 17% for ethene and 13% for propane, respectively. A comparison of the results with data from dynamic experiments showed a reasonable agreement. © 1995 Elsevier Science S.A. All rights reserved. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: E., Noordally, Ehsan; J.R., Richmond, J. R.; K.J., Drumm, K. J.
Title: Catalytic oxidation processes for odour and VOC control
Affiliations: UOP LLC., UK, Brimsdown, United Kingdom; Honeywell UOP, Des Plaines, United States
Authors with affiliations: Noordally, Ehsan, Chemical and Environmental Catalyst Group, UOP LLC., UK, Brimsdown, United Kingdom; Richmond, J. R., Chemical and Environmental Catalyst Group, UOP LLC., UK, Brimsdown, United Kingdom; Drumm, K. J., Chemical and Environmental Catalyst Group, Honeywell UOP, Des Plaines, United States
Abstract: Catalytic recuperative systems for the oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOC S using precious metal catalysts operate at typically 200 to 350°C and have a heat recovery of 60 to 70. Compared to thermal oxidation units, these units are much smaller in size and weight and can be modularized for easy installation. These benefits, together with low oxides of nitrogen (NO,) emissions and less expensive metallurgy, make catalytic recuperative systems an attractive solution to VOC emission control. These systems are the most cost- effective for flows under 850 Nm 3/min over a wide renge of VOC concentrations. For larger flow, both catalytic recuperative and thermal regenerative sustems can compete on equal economic terma. Catalyst-life enhancement is achieved by the selection and use of appropriate pretreaters. Typical catalyst performance dara are for VOC and odour destruction in painting applications, an actual coffee roasting operation, and typical compost plant © 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.A., Barresi, Antonello A.; G., Baldi, Giancarlo
Author full names: Barresi, Antonello A. (57190793843); Baldi, Giancarlo (57022278900)
Title: Deep Catalytic Oxidation of Aromatic Hydrocarbon Mixtures: Reciprocal Inhibition Effects and Kinetics
Affiliations: Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Barresi, Antonello A., Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy; Baldi, Giancarlo, Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy
Abstract: The deep catalytic oxidation kinetics of different aromatic hydrocarbons, in lean mixtures, over a Pt catalyst has been investigated. The reactivity increases in the order benzene > toluene > ethylbenzene > o-xylene > styrene. An apparent zeroth-order kinetics with respect to hydrocarbon concentration has been observed; the dependence on the oxygen partial pressure is more complex. Experiments with mixtures containing up to four hydrocarbons have been carried out. Remarkable effects on reaction rate and selectivity have been evidenced; the strongest inhibiting effect is shown by styrene and increases in a reverse order with respect to that of reactivity. A significant increase in the ignition temperature may occur in real burners. A kinetic model assuming strong irreversible adsorption of the aromatics and nonequilibrium adsorption of the oxygen over different sites has been proposed. © 1994, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L., Van De Beld, L.; M.P.G., Bijl, M. P.G.; A., Reinders, A.; B., van der Werf, B.; K.R., Westerterp, Klass Roel
Author full names: Van De Beld, L. (6603470248); Bijl, M. P.G. (7003783367); Reinders, A. (55254317700); van der Werf, B. (6602991899); Westerterp, Klass Roel (59057596700)
Title: The catalytic oxidation of organic contaminants in a packed bed reactor
Affiliations: Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van De Beld, L., Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Bijl, M. P.G., Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Reinders, A., Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; van der Werf, B., Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Westerterp, Klass Roel, Department of Chemical Engineering, Universiteit Twente, Enschede, Netherlands
Abstract: The catalytic oxidation of several hydrocarbons was studied over noble metal and metal oxide catalysts. A fast empirical method was developed to determine the minimum operating temperature required to guarantee complete conversion of the hydrocarbon. The influence of the operating parameters such as the inlet concentration and residence time, as well as the chemical character of the component to be oxidized, have been investigated. The results can be described satisfactorily by a simple isothermal, plug flow reactor model and first-order reaction kinetics. In the case of simultaneous oxidation of different components a significant mixture effect was not observed. The presence of water in the feed did significantly inhibit the oxidation of alkanes. Of the applied catalysts, Pt was the most effective for the combustion of the alkenes, whereas Pd showed a higher activity for the oxidation of alkanes. © 1995 Elsevier Science Ltd All rights reserved. © 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: W., Ying, Weichi; R.R., Bonk, Robert R.; S.C., Hannam, Shennen C.; Q., Li, Qidong
Author full names: Ying, Weichi (7102083499); Bonk, Robert R. (7004085744); Hannam, Shennen C. (6603873881); Li, Qidong (57191018858)
Title: Final disposal of VOCs from industrial wastewaters
Affiliations: Occidental Chemical Corporation, Grand Island, United States; Fudan University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Ying, Weichi, Occidental Chemical Corporation, Grand Island, United States; Bonk, Robert R., Occidental Chemical Corporation, Grand Island, United States; Hannam, Shennen C., Occidental Chemical Corporation, Grand Island, United States; Li, Qidong, Fudan University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Vapor phase carbon adsorption followed by spent carbon regeneration and catalytic oxidation where evaluated as methods for disposal of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) released from industrial wastewaters during treatment operations such as aeration, air‐stripping and aerobic biodegradation. Adsorptive capacities and breakthrough characteristics for eight VOCs found in many hazardous landfill leachates and contaminated groundwater were compared for selection of the best adsorbent and optimum treatment conditions. Coconut shell‐based activated carbons exhibited higher VOC loading capacities than coal‐based carbons, fiber carbon, molecular sieve and zeolite. Steam and hot nitrogen were both effective for regeneration of the spent carbon. A small quantity of adsorbates left in the regenerated carbon did not result in immediate VOC breakthrough in the next cycle adsorption treatment. Catalytic oxidation was found to be an attractive alternative for VOC disposal. Using a new commercial catalyst developed for destruction of halogenated organic compounds, even stable VOCs such as trichloroethylene and tetrachloroethylene were completely destroyed at <350°C when oxidation was conducted at a space velocity of 17000/hr. Authors: L.M., Freitas Dos Santos, Luisa M.; A.G., Livingston, Andrew G.
Author full names: Freitas Dos Santos, Luisa M. (7004269268); Livingston, Andrew G. (7102581618)
Title: A novel bioreactor system for the destruction of volatile organic compounds
Affiliations: Imperial College London, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Freitas Dos Santos, Luisa M., Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemical Technology, Imperial College London, London, United Kingdom; Livingston, Andrew G., Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemical Technology, Imperial College London, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The biological treatment of waste-waters containing 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE) in conventional bioreactors results in air-stripping of DCE. In the present work, a novel bioreactor system intended to overcome this problem has been developed for the treatment of a synthetically concocted DCE-containing waste-water (1000 mg DCE l-1). The operation of a conventional air-lift bioreactor at a waste-water flow rate of 0.24 l h-1 led to 33% of the DCE supplied to the reactor being lost to the exit gas stream. The use of the novel enclosed system, operated with a recycling O<inf>2</inf> sparge instead of air, resulted in negligible air-stripping at the same waste-water flow rate. A control system was implemented to add O<inf>2</inf> as required to maintain the pressure of the recycle gas stream, and a scrubber removed the CO<inf>2</inf> produced. Over 99% of DCE supplied was biodegraded during operation of this system, and virtually all carbon entering the system was evolved as CO<inf>2</inf>. © 1993 Springer-Verlag. © 2007 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C.M., Kaufman, Clifford M.; M.R., Overcash, Michael R.
Author full names: Kaufman, Clifford M. (7006733770); Overcash, Michael R. (7007152380)
Title: Green biomass materials in polyurethane foams
Authors with affiliations: Kaufman, Clifford M., ; Overcash, Michael R.,
Abstract: Flexible polyurethane foams were prepared using naturally derived materials as alternatives to conventional auxiliary blowing agents. This research was based on the concept held by some that natural chemicals are better as a part of industrial ecology. The authors have attempted to define the foam manufacturing suitability of natural chemicals, but have not defined or defended the policy implications of such choices. Natural chemicals are often less suitable than those refined from petroleum and may then need some environmental credit related to greater discharge to be viable substitutes. Modest decreases in density (relative to foams without any auxiliary blowing agent) were obtained with the addition of solid CO<inf>2</inf>but other physical properties were not measured. It is unclear whether the reduction in density is a result of the phase change of CO, from solid to liquid within the polyurethane cell matrix or simply a bubbling effect of C02 in solution causing voids within the final product. Although it was anticipated that the high boiling point of limonene, from citrus peeis, would negate effectiveness as an auxiliary blowing agent, there were analogous decreases in foam density. The observed effect might be rationalized by the significant vapor pressure of limonene at temperatures lower than the boiling point. The limonene may be sweptf rom the foam system coincident with the loss of in situ generated CO<inf>2</inf>isoprene, naturally emitted from deciduous vegetation as well as from the combustion of carbonaceous fuels, provides a useful, if not complete, range of foam densities and may then be a partial substitute for halogenated auxiliary blowing agents. Switching from methyiene chloride to isoprene as the auxiliary blowing agent of choice would immediately decrease organic emissions from polyurethane foam plants by 20 percent (molecular weight effect). Regulation as a VOC and the residual acrid odor may be potential drawbacks to commercial utilization of isoprene. © Taylor and Francis Group, LLC. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y.S., Matros, Yu Sh; A.S., Noskov, Aleksandr S.
Author full names: Matros, Yu Sh (7004026802); Noskov, Aleksandr S. (7005685096)
Title: Procedures for making gaseous industrial waste safe
Authors with affiliations: Matros, Yu Sh, ; Noskov, Aleksandr S.,
Abstract: The application of various methods (adsorption, absorption, thermal afterburning, catalytic purification, and others) for the removal of sulphur and nitrogen oxides, toxic organic compounds, hydrogen sulphide, and carbon monoxide from industrial waste gases is described. Much attention is devoted to the catalytic procedure for making the gases safe using an energy collecting non-stationary method (reversible process). The advantages and limitations of various gas purification methods are considered. © 1990 The Chemical Society. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.T., Shen, Thomas T.
Author full names: Shen, Thomas T. (7202006537)
Title: Assessment and Control of VOC Emissions from Waste Disposal Facilities
Affiliations: New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, Albany, United States; Radian Corporation, Austin, United States; WEST Consultants, Folsom, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shen, Thomas T., New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, Albany, United States, Department of Process Engineering, Radian Corporation, Austin, United States, WEST Consultants, Folsom, United States
Abstract: Concerns with emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOC) from waste disposal facilities are increasing because of the emission quantity and toxicity and/or carcinogenicity, especially at the Superfund sites. Many state regulatory provisions require air quality assessment to be performed by applicants prior to the issuing of an air emission permit for a new or modified waste disposal facility. This article reviews the current published papers and significant government documents related to VOC emissions and their control at waste disposal sites. The review topics include dimensions of the VOC problem, characterization of VOC emission sources, effects of atmospheric processes, air pathway analyses, and technical feasibility of various VOC control options. Discusssions include a waste minimization strategy to reduce VOC quantity and concentration in wastewater at sources. © 1990, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved. © 2016 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J.J., Spivey, James Jerry
Author full names: Spivey, James Jerry (7005741953)
Title: Complete Catalytic Oxidation of Volatile Organics
Affiliations: RTI International, Research Triangle Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Spivey, James Jerry, RTI International, Research Triangle Park, United States
Abstract: Heterogeneous catalytic oxidation of organic compounds is an important and intensely studied area. However, most reported research deals with the partial oxidation of petrochemical feedstocks to make products of economic value (e.g., ethylene oxide from ethylene), automotive exhaust catalysts, or CO oxidation. Complete (or “deep”) catalytic oxidation of low molecular weight volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in air has received relatively little attention. This review of heterogeneous catalytic oxidation focuses on its application to control of VOCs at operating conditions typical of field applications. The parameters for this review are low to moderate temperatures (25-400 °C), atmospheric pressure, high space velocity (103–105h-1), and low organic reactant concentration (roughly 102-103ppm) in air. © 1987, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved. © 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
